editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p:
THE Pre≈øent State Of His Maje≈øties I≈øles and Territories IN AMERICA, VIZ.
Iamaica, Barbadoes,
S. Chri≈øtophers, Mevis,
Antego, S. Vincent,
Dominica, New-Ier≈øey,
Pen≈øilvania, Mon≈øerat,
Anguilla, Bermudas,
Carolina, Virginia,
New-England, Tobago.
New-Found-Land.
Mary-Land, New-York.
With New Maps of every Place.
Together with A≈øtronomical TABLES, Which will ≈øerve as a con≈øtant Diary or Calendar, for the u≈øe of the Engli≈øh Inhabitants in tho≈øe I≈ølands; from the Year 1686, to 1700.
Al≈øo a Table by which, at any time of the Day or Night here in England, you may know what Hour it is in any of tho≈øe parts. And how to make Sun-Dials fitting for all tho≈øe places.
Licens'd, July 20. 1686. Roger L'E≈øtrange.
LONDON: Printed by H. Clark, for Dorman Newman, at the Kings-Arms in the Poultrey, 1687.

div.head: TO HIS SACRED MAJESTY JAMES II. King of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, &c.
div.p: THIS Treati≈øe, or De≈øcription, of Your Maje≈øties Dominions and Territories in America, humbly pre≈øents it≈øelf unto Your Royal Patronage, by the hands of

closer.signed: Your Maje≈øties mo≈øt humble and obedient Subject and Servant, Richard Blome.

div.head: THE PREFACE TO THE READER.
div.p:
THE en≈øuing Di≈øcour≈øe contains an Account of the Pre≈øent State of His Maje≈øties Dominions, on the Coa≈øt of America; wherein thou wilt find a con≈øiderable Di≈øcovery of the growing Greatne≈øs of tho≈øe di≈øtant Colonies, which, by the mo≈øt clement and wi≈øe Admini≈øtration of the Monarchs of Great Britan, have already arrived to a Figure ≈øo Con≈øiderable, as may attract the Emulation of the Neighbouring Potentates; the Golden Peru hardly affording ≈øo great a Trea≈øure to the Catholick Crown, as the≈øe mo≈øt Flouri≈øhing Plantations produce to the Crown of England. The va≈øt Returns which the Merchants of London, and other Parts of His Maje≈øties Dominions, make from tho≈øe Parts, are a ≈øufficient Encouragement for any one that would ≈øtudy the Improvement of his Fortunes, to look into the advantages of that Exten≈øive Traffick
which tho≈øe Regions produce. And ≈øince our Neighbours have not been wanting (in the mo≈øt Remote Courts) to repre≈øent their Foreign Plantations as va≈øt and mighty Acce≈ø≈øions to their Government, and to make their State look the more Con≈øiderable in the Eyes of di≈øtant Monarchs: Why may not an E≈ø≈øay towards the Delineation of the Engli≈øh Territories in Foreign Parts (at lea≈øt in ≈øome mea≈øure) contribute to rai≈øe in them an E≈øteem and Dread of the Mighty Power of the Briti≈øh Crown. Little more need be ≈øaid to recommend the u≈øefulne≈øs of the en≈øuing Di≈øcour≈øe, but that the natural re≈øult of Di≈øcoveries, is the Promotion of Improvement, and the Con≈øiderate know how to make their Advantages thereof.

There was intended to be added to this Volume, a Summary of the ≈øeveral Laws in Force in each Plantation, but that being a work which will ≈øwell to a larger Bulk than this, is re≈øerved for a particular Treati≈øe by it ≈øelf.

I have one thing more to adverti≈øe thee, That the Printer hath neglected to fix the Running-Title on the top of every Page; therefore thou may'≈øt find that part of the Di≈øcour≈øe which relates to them in the following Table.

list.item: Directions for the Improvement of the I≈øland of Tobago Page 253
Propo≈øals lately made by Captain John Poyntz, for Him≈øelf and Company, to all ≈øuch People as are minded to Tran≈øport or Concern them≈øelves in the I≈øland of Tobago Page 259

A≈øtronomical Tables, ≈øhewing the Ri≈øing and Setting of the Sun, with the Length of the Days and Nights in all the Principal Engli≈øh Plantations in the We≈øt-Indies
Al≈øo Tables of the New and Full Moons in every Month, from the Year 1686, to 1700, in the Meridian of London,
and from thence referred to the Meridians of the Principal Plantations above≈øaid. The which Tables will ≈øerve as a con≈øtant Diary or Calendar, for the ∆≤≈øe of the Engli≈øh Inhabitants in tho≈øe I≈ølands.
Al≈øo a Table by which, at any time of the Day or Night here in England, you may know what Hour it is in any of tho≈øe I≈ølands.
And how to make Sun-Dials fitting for all tho≈øe Remote Parts.

figure.head: The North We≈øt Part of AMERICA

div.head: THE Pre≈øent State OF HIS MAJESTY's I≈øles and Territories IN AMERICA.
Of JAMAICA,
div.p:
THE I≈øland of JAMAICA is ≈øituate between the Tropicks ≈øeventeen or eighteen degrees North-Latitude, Its Scituation. upon the Sea u≈øually known by the Name of Mare del Nort, being about an hundred and forty Leagues North of the Main Continent of America; fifteen
Leagues South from the great I≈øland of Cuba, and twenty Leagues Westward from Hi≈øpaniola, from Porto Bello, Northwards an hundred and ≈øixty; and from Carthagena an hundred and forty Leagues.

'Tis ≈øomewhat of an Oval Form, and hath a continued Ridge of lofty Mountains running from East to West, which extend them≈øelves from one end of it to the other, and being full of fre≈øh Springs, furni≈øheth the I≈øland with great plenty of plea≈øant and u≈øeful Rivers, to the great refre≈øhment of the Inhabitants, and accommodation of Trade.

It is exceeding fruitful, being for the mo≈øt part a rich fat ≈øoyl,Its Fertility. the Earth blacki≈øh, and mixt with clay, except in the South-west parts, where it is generally of a more red and loo≈øe Earth; but every where wonderful fertil, and incomparably apt to an≈øwer the Cultivator's expectation, and recompence his pains and expence in planting; for it enjoys a perpetual Sp ‚Ä¢ ing, and its Plants and Trees are never di≈ørob'd of their Summer Livery, but every Month is to them like April or May to us.

It is in length about 170 Miles, and about 70 in breadth,Its Form aad Extent. containing between four or five Millions of Acres, nine hundred thou≈øand whereof were planted in the Year 1675. There are intermixt with the Woods and Mountains, many Savanaes or Plains, which are ≈øuppo≈øed to have formerly been Fields of Indian Maiz or Wheat; but the Spaniards when they made them≈øelves Ma≈øters of the I≈øle, and had de≈øtroyed all the Natives, to the number of about ≈øixty thou≈øand Per≈øons, converted them to Pa≈øture for the feeding of
Hor≈øes, Cows, Hogs, and other Cattel which they brought with them for Breed; which they did ≈øo fa≈øt, that there are now great Heards of Hor≈øes and other Cattel running wild in the Woods. The≈øe Savanaes are accounted the mo≈øt barren parts of the I≈øland, in regard they have lain ≈øo long without Tillage; which notwith≈øtanding doth produce ≈øuch va≈øt quantities of Gra≈øs, that the Planters are oftentimes con≈øtrained to burn it up.

The Air is there very ≈øerene and clear,Its Temperature. and more temperate than in any other I≈ølands in tho≈øe parts; and in reference to Heat, is as mild as in any place that lieth between the Tropicks, in regard it is continually fann'd and cool'd by fre≈øh Breezes, which continually blow Ea≈øtwardly; be≈øide which, 'tis refre≈øhed with frequent Showers of Rain, and great Dews which fall in the night, and conduce very much to the quickning the growth of what is planted; ≈øo that it may truly be called temperate and healthful; and its continual Verdure commends it as one of the mo≈øt delightful Places in the World to live in, e≈øpecially the South part of the I≈øle; the East and West parts being ≈øomewhat more ≈øubject to Rains and Winds, and in regard the Mountainous and Woody renders the Air le≈øs whol≈øom and agreeable than it is in the North; but e≈øpecially the Southern, which gave the occa≈øion to the Engli≈øh to build Port-Royal there; it being thought convenient that the chief Port and Capital City be upon the be≈øt Spot they could find out in the I≈øland. However no part of this I≈øland is in the lea≈øt ≈øubject to tho≈øe violent and injurious Storms called Hurricans, wherewith the Caribbies and ≈øome other places in tho≈øe parts are ≈øometimes pe≈øtered; which with a ≈øudden fury
drive their Ships from Harbour, ca≈øt them on ≈øhore, blow down their Hou≈øes, tear up their Canes, and hurry all into confu≈øion. And had not this I≈øland afforded Relief to many of the wracked Inhabitants when they had been thus di≈øtre≈ø≈øed, they mu≈øt in all probability have peri≈øhed. Nor doth any part of this I≈øland unavoidably nece≈ø≈øitate any of its new Inhabitants to any particular Di≈øtemper, as Virginia and other places do; but if tho≈øe who go thither, will upon their Arrival, but forbear exce≈øs of eating and drinking, u≈øe moderate exerci≈øe, and make choice of ≈øuch places for their ≈øettlement, as lie not too low in Vallies, where there comes but little Air; or too near Rivers, where they may peradventure be incommoded with too much moi≈øture, or at the Foot of Mountains or Mora≈ø≈øes, where probably you may have more Rain than you'l de≈øire; nor by the Sea ≈øide, or upon Bays, where be≈øides the inconvenience of its Sandine≈øs, it will occa≈øion your want of good Water, you will be mightily afflicted with the violent Reflections of the Sun's Beams, which are much fiercer here than in other parts of the I≈øle.

It hath been ob≈øerved by ≈øome who have lived in the I≈øland, that the Mountains which run along through the mid≈øt of the I≈øle from one extream point to the other, are much cooler than the other parts; in≈øomuch that ≈øometimes in the Morning early there are ≈ømall white Fro≈øts.

There is no apparent Winter, only they have ≈øomewhat more Rain and Thunder in the Winter-Months than at other times; nor doth the length of the Days and Nights vary much, but they continue almo≈øt all the year round of an equal length, (viz.) about fifteen hours day: And that which ≈øeems much ≈øtranger, is, the Seas having ≈øeldom been ob≈øerved to ebb or flow above a foot or thereabouts; nor hath any Pilot ever yet been able to give a certain account of the Currents of tho≈øe Seas, in regard they are ≈øo various and uncertain; nor could any ever give a rea≈øon why the Hurricans and Earthquakes ≈øhould never reach Jamaica, although they have ≈øo grievou≈øly afflicted the adjacent I≈ølands.

The Rivers of this I≈øland are none of them fair or navigable up into the Country,Its Road and Harbors. in regard the I≈øland is very mountainous, and their original is for the mo≈øt part in tho≈øe Hills that run through its Center; which running Ea≈øt and We≈øt, the Rivers that ri≈øe in them di≈øembogue them≈øelves North and South, and falling out of tho≈øe high Mountains, are very fierce and rapid in their motion; being likewi≈øe in regard of the great Rains, ≈øubject to great and ≈øudden Inundations; at which times they fall with ≈øuch fury, that great Stone-Rocks and large pieces of Timber are born down,
and carried along by the violence of the Torrent, which makes their u≈øual pa≈ø≈øage ≈øo foul and trouble≈øom, that they are thereby rendred altogether unpa≈ø≈øable by Boats and other ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels. Be≈øides which, there are divers of them which at ≈øome times have not one drop of Water in them, but are wholly dried up, which renders them likewi≈øe u≈øele≈øs for Navigation; as particularly that of Minoa, that runs through Clarendon, which ≈øometimes hath not a drop of Water, and yet at other Sea≈øons hath as much as the River of Thames at high-water: But although the Rivers are thus u≈øele≈øs, yet towards the Sea the I≈øland abounds with great plenty of very good Bays, Roads and Harbours; the principal whereof are,

1. Port-Royal, Port-Royal. which at it fir≈øt ≈øetling by the Engli≈øh, ≈øoon after they took the I≈øland from the Spaniards, received the Name of Cagway, but when the Town began to encrea≈øe, and draw towards its perfection, it obtained in Sir Charles Littleton's time the Name of Port-Royal, in regard of the excellency of its Harbour. It is ≈øituated on the extream end of that long point of Land that makes the Harbour, running about twelve Miles from the Main We≈øterly, having the Sea on its South, and the Harbour on the North; which Harbour is ≈øo exceeding ≈øafe and commodious for Shipping, that they are ≈øecure in all Weathers, and can unlade them≈øelves afloat at the Merchants-Key; being likewi≈øe during their Riding there, ≈øecured from any Attempts that might be made on them by an Enemy, by one of the ≈øtronge≈øt and mo≈øt con≈øiderable Ca≈øtles that His Maje≈øty hath in all Amemerica, which is well garri≈øonn'd with Souldiers, and hath above ≈øixty Pieces of Cannon mounted in
it. Be≈øides which, it is Land-lock'd by a Point of Land that runs Twelve Miles South-East from the Main of the I≈øland, and hath the great River which runs by Los-Angelos and St. Jago (where Ships that trade to Jamaica, commonly water, and provide them≈øelves with what Wood they want for their Voyage back) falling into it. The Harbour is about three Leagues broad in mo≈øt places, and is ≈øo deep, that a Ship of a Thou≈øand Tun may lay her ≈øides to the Shoar of the Point, and load and unload at plea≈øure; nor doth there want good Anchorage in any part of it. This Harbour being ≈øo exceeding ≈øafe and commodious, is the rea≈øon why it is frequented both by Merchants Ships and Men of War more than any other Port in that I≈øland.

The Point of Land whereon the Town is built, is exceeding narrow, and nothing but a loo≈øe Sand, ≈øo that it affords neither Gra≈øs, Stone, fre≈øh Water, Trees, nor any thing el≈øe which could encourage the building a Town upon it, be≈øides the goodne≈øs of the Harbour. It was at fir≈øt began by building a few Ware-hou≈øes, but is now grown exceeding large and populous; for it contains above fifteen hundred Hou≈øes, and extends it≈øelf about twelve or thirteen Miles in length, being inhabited by Merchants, Store-hou≈øe-keepers, Handicraft≈ømen, Vintners, Victuallers, and the like: And being ≈øo very populous, and ≈øo much frequented by Strangers, as well as the Planters in the Negotiation of their Affairs, it being, as it were, the Scale of Trade in that I≈øland, the Hou≈øes are as dear rented as in well Traded Streets in London, and Provi≈øions are dearer than in any other place in that I≈øland.

In the time of the Earl of Carli≈øle's Government, there was a ≈øtately Church built, partly by Liberal Sub≈øcriptions of divers well di≈øpo≈øed Gentlemen inhabiting the I≈øle, and partly by an A≈ø≈øe≈øsment laid upon the Inhabitants of the Port. There is likewi≈øe a Hou≈øe belonging to the King, though it is not very ≈øpacious. This Town of Port-Royal lieth about twelve Miles from the Metropolitan Town of this I≈øland, called St. Jago de la Vega, or the Spani≈øh Town.

Old Harbour, Old Harbour. about ≈øeven miles We≈øtward from St. Jago, is generally accounted next to Port-Royal, the be≈øt Harbour on the South-≈øide; notwith≈øtanding which, it is not ≈øo much frequented as it was when the Spaniards enjoy'd the I≈øle; ≈øo that there are not above thirty Hou≈øes there, which are chiefly for the U≈øes of tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels and Mariners that come thither, and for Store-hou≈øes for Planters Goods.

Port Morant, Port Morant. in the Ea≈øtern Point, is a very fair, capacious, and ≈øecure Harbour, where Ships do with great conveniency Wood, Water, and Ride fafe from the Winds, in which Place, and the Parts adjacent, a large and potent Colony of Engli≈øh People have ≈øeated them≈øelves.

Negril in the extream We≈øterly Point,Point Negril. is a good Habour very convenient and ≈øufficiently ≈øecure to the Windwards. In this Harbour Men of War do often ply when they look for the return of the Spani≈øh Ships, and not far from thence, a little to the North-We≈øt, was ≈øeated the old Town of Melila, founded by Columbus as he had ≈øuffered Shipwrack there; which was the fir≈øt place the
Spaniards ≈øetled at, but they afterwards de≈øerted it again.

Port Antonio Port Antonio. is accounted the next be≈øt Port, being indeed a very ≈øafe Land-lock'd Harbour; only the coming in is ≈øomewhat difficult, in regard the Channel is a little narrowed by a ≈ømall I≈øland that lies off the Mouth of the Port. The Earl of Carli≈øle took up this Place, and the adjacent Countrey to plant upon. The≈øe Harbours are all of them ≈øecured either by Ca≈øtles, ≈øtrong Forts, or Brea≈øt-works ca≈øt up, and Guns planted on them for the Defence of the Port.

But there are divers other good Bays and Harbours along the Coa≈øt of this I≈øland,Other Harbours. which are not altogether ≈øo much frequented; as, Michael's Hole, Mucary Bay, Allegator Point, Point Pedro, Pallate Bay, Lewana Bay, Blewfield's Bay, Cabarita's Bay: The≈øe are on the South-≈øide, and are all very good and commodious Harbours for Ships. On the North-≈øide, there is Porto Maria, Ora Cabe≈ø≈øa, Cold Harbour, Rio Nova, Montega Bay, Orange Bay, and divers more both on this and the South-≈øide; at all which there are ≈øome Hou≈øes.

There is likewi≈øe at a Place called Withy-Wood, on the South-≈øide, about forty or fifty Hou≈øes built for the conveniency and accommodation of Ve≈ø≈øels, many Ships frequenting that Road, in regard there is very good Land, many con≈øiderable Settlements, and a plea≈øant Countrey all about it.
This I≈øland doth not very much abound with Towns;Their Towns. there being but three in the whole I≈øland, that are of any con≈øiderable note; the Chief whereof is,

St. Jago St. Jago.
de la Vega, ≈øituated ≈øix miles within the Land North-We≈øt, upon a large Plain, by the ≈øide of a River called Pro de Cabre, from a certain Metal which the Spaniards found, and called by that Name, in the Mountains of Liguania, where this River hath its original Spring. This Place was when the Spaniards were Ma≈øters of the I≈øle, a large City, containing about two thou≈øand Hou≈øes, two Churches, four Chappels, and an Abbey for Divine Wor≈øhip, which were upon the taking the I≈øland by the Engli≈øh, all de≈øtroyed, except about fifteen hundred Hou≈øes, and its Churches and Chappels reduced to a ≈ømaller number; nor did tho≈øe which remained, altogether e≈øcape, but were ≈øufficiently hara≈ø≈øed and ≈øpoiled. But ≈øince the Engli≈øh have begun to ≈øettle there, and in the Countrey about it, it begins to be again a place of con≈øiderable account, and grows apace towards its former ≈øplendor and beauty. 'Tis the Metropolis of the I≈øland, where the Governor him≈øelf re≈øides, and where all the chief Courts of Judicature are kept; which occa≈øions its being well inhabited, and a place of very great re≈øort; ≈øo that mo≈øt of its Ruinous Hou≈øes are now repaired, and it is in a fair way of extending it≈øelf to a far greater largene≈øs than when it was enjoyed by the Spaniards; for the Town is very well ≈øituated, the Hou≈øes fair and convenient, and the Inhabitants live in as much plea≈øure as their hearts can wi≈øh, having their Havana, to which the better ≈øort repair every Evening to take the Air, and recreate them≈øelves, as the Gentry at London do in Hide-Park.
The ≈øecond Town of Note is Port-Royal; which hath been already de≈øcribed; and the third is known by the Name of

Pa≈ø≈øage, Pa≈ø≈øage. ≈øituated on the Mouth of the River, ≈øix miles di≈øtant from St. Jago by Land, and about two Leagues from Port-Royal by Sea. But before I pa≈øs from this Di≈øcour≈øe, of the Product of Jamaica, I ≈øhall give you an account of the manner of managing a Cacao Walk, in regard it is the Chief Commodity of the I≈øland, with a particular calculation of the change in Planting, and the profits that ari≈øe from it, as it was lately e≈øtimated by a very judicious and under≈øtanding per≈øon, and one who hath given great incouragement to divers of the Planters there.

When a per≈øon, who intends to ≈øettle at Jamaica, arrives,Of a Cocao Walk. after he hath taken a view of the Country, his fir≈øt work mu≈øt be to take up Six hundred Acres of Land, which mu≈øt be cho≈øen in a good place, that ≈øo the Land may be proper to produce the Nut; which Grant, for the Patent and Surveying, will co≈øt Ten Pounds. Having taken up his Land, he mu≈øt provide him≈øelf of three Negro Men, and as many Women; which, at Twenty Pounds per head, will come to an Hundred and twenty Pounds; with four White Servants, which, with their Pa≈ø≈øage and Diet for a Year, will co≈øt him about Eighty Pounds; with Twenty Axes, and the like number of Bills and Hoes, which will co≈øt him about Five Pounds; and with an Over≈øeer, to look after his Servants and keep them to their work, who≈øe Wages and Diet, at Forty Shillings a Month, will co≈øt him Twenty
four Pounds: All which, with Eighteen Pounds, which the Provi≈øions for his Six Negro Servants, will, at Four Pence per day, each of them co≈øt him for the fir≈øt ≈øix Months, till his own Plantation is capable of maintaining them, is Two hundred fifty ≈øeven Pounds, Five Shillings.

When this is done, his next bu≈øine≈øs is to ≈øet his Servants to work, who≈øe fir≈øt imployment mu≈øt be to cut down the Wood, and clear a convenient place, whereon to build fitting Hou≈øes for their Lodging; which, if they begin with March, they will have effected by the middle of that Month: After which, he mu≈øt ≈øet them to felling the Timber, grubbing up the Roots, and clearing a piece of Ground, of four Acres, whereon to plant Potatoes; all which planting, and all, with the help of his Servants, will be ea≈øily effected by the middle of April. And then his be≈øt way is to ≈øet them to prepare more Ground, which he may plant with Plantane-Trees, and other things, (which he thinks he ≈øhall fir≈øt want, for the enabling his Plantation to ≈øub≈øi≈øt of its ≈øelf) till the beginning of February, which compleats the Year. In which time they may, with ea≈øe, prepare and plant about one or two and twenty Acres, and the Plantation will be able to live of its ≈øelf, for they will now be full of Potatoes and Corn, and within two Months of the new Year with Plantanes, which, together with his ≈øtock of Hoggs and Fowls will ≈øufficiently furni≈øh him with Provi≈øions for his Servants.

To improve this Ground, and plant the Cacao-Walk, he mu≈øt, about the beginning of the next March, provide him≈øelf with five Negro men more, and as many Women, which will come to Two hundred pounds more: And that Month he mu≈øt
imploy all the hands he has in planting Cacao-Trees between all the Rows of Plantanes, which, by this time are grown to be ≈øix foot high, and, by the beginning of June, he will have, be≈øides much other work done, the whole twenty one Acres, which were planted the year before with Cacao-Trees, which, in le≈øs than four years, will begin to bear Cods, and, in five years, produce compleat Crops, each Acre affording yearly to the Planter a Thou≈øand Weight of Cacao-Nuts, which is there worth about four Pounds per cent. ≈øo that the twenty one Acres, which are already planted and come to perfection, are worth Eight hundred and forty Pounds per Annum. And the whole Expence, together with Forty two Pounds fifteen Shillings more, allowed for gathering and hou≈øing them, amounts but to Five hundred Pounds, ≈øo that the profit will be very con≈øiderable.

All the Work, already mentioned, will be performed in fifteen Months, and the remaining time, till the Cacaoes come to perfection, which will be ≈øomewhat better than four year, he may imploy in increa≈øing the Walk, building convenient Hou≈øes, and making of Gardens for plea≈øure: Or, if the ≈ømalne≈øs of his Stock will not permit him to forbear his Money till the Cacaoes come to bear compleatly, he may fall to planting Ginger, Indico, or ≈øome ≈øuch kind of Commodity for pre≈øent profit.
And according to this Calculation the planting of a ≈ømaller or a larger Walk may be effected.

There is in this I≈øland a greater plenty of CattelTheir Cattel. than in mo≈øt of the Engli≈øh Plantations in America. Hor≈øes ≈øo much abound there, that one of the better

Jamaica very much abounds both in its Rivers,Their Fi≈øh. Bays, Roads, and Creeks, with great variety of excellent Fi≈øh, the great abundance whereof very much contributes to the feeding of the Inhabitants, and others who frequent the I≈øland. 'Tis true, indeed, they have none of tho≈øe ≈øorts common to us, but ≈øuch va≈øt variety of tho≈øe appropriated to the Indies, that it would be too tedious to repeat their Names, were they known or remembred.

The principal ≈øort of tho≈øe Fi≈øh, is the Tortoi≈øe, which are taken in ≈øuch plenty about twenty or thirty Leagues to the Leeward of Port Nigril, near the I≈øles of Camavos, that great ≈øtore of Ships from divers of the Caribby I≈ølands re≈øort thither
to victual and load therewith, its Fle≈øh being reputed the whol≈øome≈øt and be≈øt Provi≈øion in all the West-Indies.

There are in Jamaica great ≈øtore of tame Hens, Turkies, ≈øome
‚Ä¢ ee≈øe and Ducks, but of Wild FowlTheir Fowl. ≈øuch plenty, that it is almo≈øt incredible, viz. Ducks, Teal, Wigeon, Gee≈øe, Turkies, Pigeons, Guinea Hens, Plover, Flemingo's, Snipes, Parots, Paracheto's, with abundance more, who≈øe Names are not yet known.

There are in Jamaica very few obnoxious Bea≈øts, and ≈øcarce any venomous things, either Animal or Vegetable.Animals and Vegetables. The mo≈øt con≈øiderable of all the obnoxious Creatures which infe≈øt this I≈øle, is the Alligator, a very voracious Creature, which in many of their Rivers and Land-Ponds, lives by preying upon ≈øuch Bea≈øts and Fowls as come thither to drink, which they catch and kill with the more ea≈øe and facility, by lying ≈øtretch'd forth upon the brinks of the Rivers, like a piece of dry Wood, which in that po≈øture they very much re≈øemble, ≈øo that the innocent creatures approach the fatal place without the lea≈øt dread of ≈øo cruel an entertainment as they meet withal from that remor≈øle≈øs adver≈øary. They are ten, fifteen, and ≈øome twenty foot long, having four Feet, or rather Fins, wherewith they both walk and ≈øwim; they move forward with great ≈øwiftne≈øs and ≈øtrength, but are not able to turn without much tediou≈øne≈øs and trouble; their Back and Sides are ≈øo covered with Scales, that they are impenetrable and ≈øcarcely to be killed, unle≈øs the weapon pierce their Eye or Belly, notwith≈øtanding which they are rarely known to ≈øet upon a Man.
They breed like a Fowl, by Eggs no bigger than tho≈øe of a Turk ‚Ä¢ y, which, having laid in the Sand, not far from the Water, ≈øhe leaves the Sun-beams to hatch, without ever looking after them more: And the young ones, ≈øo ≈øoon as ever they have broke the ≈øhell, naturally creep into the water, and ≈øhift for them≈øelves, by preying upon ≈øuch things as they are able to ma≈øter.

But tho' the Alligator be ≈øo hurtful a creature whil≈øt living, yet at his death he makes a retaliation, and in ≈øome mea≈øure repairs the dammages of his life; for, be≈øides their Fat, which is a ≈øovereign Balm for internal Aches and Pains in the Joynts and Bones, they have in them Musk-Cods, ≈øtronger ≈øented than tho≈øe of the East-Indies; by which ≈øtrong ≈øent they are di≈øcovered and avoided, and, it is ≈øuppo≈øed, that the Cattel, by an in≈øtinct of nature, are likewi≈øe ≈øen≈øible of it, and do by that means often ≈øhun them.

There is likewi≈øe the Manchon ‚Ä¢ le, a kind of Crab, common to all the Caribby I≈ølands; And Snakes and Guiana's, but they have no poi≈øonous quality ob≈øerved in them. There are al≈øo in ≈øome parts of the I≈øle Muskettoes, and Merry-wings, but they are ≈øeldom found in any of the Engli≈øh Plantations.

It is confirmed by a long experience,Their Di≈øea≈øes. that there is no ≈øuch antipathy betwixt our Britanick Temper and the Climate of Jamaic ‚Ä¢ , as to nece≈ø≈øitate them to any Di≈øtemper upon their arrival there, or occa≈øion Di≈øea≈øes to prove mortal or contagious more than in other parts. The Drop≈øie, Calentures, Feavers and Agues, are the Maladies mo≈øt incident to the Inhabitants, which are generally procured by Surfeits, Slothfulne≈øs, or exce≈ø≈øive
drinking; and although they are found to be more acute there, than with us, yet they ≈øeldom prove mortal: And the only rea≈øon that can be given for the great Mortality in the Army upon their fir≈øt Arrival there, is, their want of Provi≈øions, and their di≈øcontent, together with their unwillingne≈øs to labour and exerci≈øe them≈øelves.

The GardensTheir Gardens. adjoyning to the Planters Hou≈øes, are be≈øides great variety of curious and delightful Flowers, and whole≈øom Medicinal Herbs proper to the I≈øland, ≈øufficiently ≈øtored with all manner of Summer-Garden-Herbs and Roots common to us in England; as, Pea≈øe, Beans, Cabbage, Carrots, Turnips, Radi≈øhes, Onions, Lettuce, Pur≈øley, Colli-flowers, Cucumbers, Melons, Par≈øley, and other Pot-herbs.

The LawsTheir Laws. of Jamaica are as near as the different Circum≈øtances of the Places will admit a≈ø≈øimilated to tho≈øe of England; and they have their ≈øeveral Courts, Magi≈øtrates and Officers, for executing their Laws, hearing and determinating all Cau≈øes and Controver≈øies between party and party.

Having now given a ≈øhort and brief De≈øcription of this I≈øland of Jamaica, and of what≈øoever is worth ob≈øervation in it, I ≈øhall next acquaint you with the State of it in the Spaniards time, and ≈øhut up my Di≈øcour≈øe about it, with ≈øome Con≈øiderations relating to our Engli≈øh Affairs in America, together with ≈øome Rea≈øons to ju≈øtifie the fir≈øt De≈øign in taking it, and why His Maje≈øty ≈øhould keep and ≈øupport it.

Columbus, Its fir≈øt Di≈øcovery. having in the Year 1492. di≈øcover'd the Lucca's I≈ølands, Hi≈øpaniola and Cuba, ≈øoon after
returned for Spain, to give that King an account of his Di≈øcoveries, and provide him≈øelf with Conveniencies for a ≈øecond Voyage; which he undertook ≈øo ≈øoon as all things were ready: And in this Voyage endeavouring to ≈øail round Cuba, the better to ≈øatisfie him≈øelf whether it were an I≈øland, or a part of the Continent, he di≈øcovered the I≈øland of Jamaica; where he made ≈øome ≈øhort ≈øtay, and gave it the Name of St. Jago.

In his third Voyage, he was ≈øhipwrack'd on this Coa≈øt,Columbus ≈øhipwrack'd and and driven to that extremity, that he was compelled to run his Ships on ground in a Port on the North-≈øide of this I≈øle, to which he gave the Name of Sancta Gloria; where, having la≈øhed them together, he lodged him≈øelf and his men on the Decks, not daring to Land, in regard the Inhabitants were numerous; and there had like to have ended his Life and his Di≈øcoveries together; the ungrateful Spaniard, e≈øpecially the malicious Governor of St. Domingo, who hated him extreamly for his fortunate Succe≈øs, refu≈øed to ≈øend him any Relief, with a De≈øign that he ≈øhould peri≈øh in that ≈øad and di≈øcon≈øolate condition; but having after two Months lying in that deplorable condition, obtained the good opinion of the Natives, he Landed, and finding the Ground fertile, and the Natives more Civil and Ingenious than what he had met withal in any of the other I≈ølands, he re≈øolved to fall to Planting: In order whereunto, the Town called Metilla, was pre≈øently begun by the Spaniards; but before it was far advanced, they de≈øerted it again, and ≈øetled ten Leagues further We≈øt; where they met with a better Bay, whereunto they gave the Name of St. Annes; which it ≈øtill retains.

Near this Place they built a hand≈øom large Town, called Sevil, which hath been already de≈øcribed: But finding in time that the South-≈øide was more fruitful and plea≈øant, about the Year 1590. the Spaniards for≈øook this likewi≈øe, and removed thither; where they built St. Jago; St. Jago built. which they enjoyed without any trouble or mole≈øtation, till it was about 1638. ≈øurprized and taken by one Jack≈øon Taken by Jack≈øon. with a Fleet of Engli≈øh Privateers; but having no De≈øign but Pillage, when he had plundered the Town, he ≈øurrendred it up again to the Spaniards for a thou≈øand Beavers.

More fatal to the Spaniard was the next Attempt made on this I≈øland; for Cromwel Cromwel's Pre- having turned out the Rump, u≈øurp'd the Title of Protector, and made peace with the Hollander, found him≈øelf at lei≈øure to try his Fortune in the Indies, and endeavour by a ≈øtrange kind of a ≈øudden and unexpected Enterprize again≈øt the Spaniards (with whom he was about this time highly offended, for giving entertainment to his injured Sovereign) to make his Name as terrible in tho≈øe remoter parts of the Earth, as his Trea≈øon and U≈øurpation had rendered it in Europe. In order whereunto, having with great hurry and ≈øilence got ready a great Fleet, he ≈øent it under Penn, who was General at Sea, and Venables, who had the Command of the Land-Forces.

Having after their leaving the Engli≈øh Coa≈øt, toucht at Barbados, they ≈øailed from thence directly towards Hi≈øpaniola, without making any Declaration of War again≈øt the Spani≈øh King, and
had certainly ≈øurprized and taken Domingo, and con≈øequently the whole I≈øland, had not his being ruled by ≈øome ≈øtrange Councils of his own, or (as ≈øome report) by his Wife, ruined the whole De≈øign, and fru≈øtrated the U≈øurper of his Golden Expectations: For ≈øo terrified were the Spaniards at the ≈øudden approach of this mighty Fleet, and the Fame of Cromwel's con≈øtant Succe≈øs in all he undertook, that in great amazement and fear they for≈øook the Town, and left it as a prey to tho≈øe new invaders, had they been ≈øpeedy enough in taking po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion: But ≈øeeing Venables land his Souldiers at ≈øo great a di≈øtance as 12 leagues to the we≈øtward of it, they re-a≈ø≈øumed their courage, and betook them≈øelves again to the defence of it.

The Engli≈øh finding no oppo≈øition at their Landing, thought them≈øelves Lords of the Indies, and began in their own thoughts to ≈øhare the Golden Mines among them≈øelves; which they had peradventure effected, had not Venables's covetous humour, and an in≈øatiable de≈øire to appropriate all to him≈øelf, by forbidding the Souldiers by Proclamation made at the Head of the Army to meddle with any of that rich Booty, or pre≈øume to kill any Cattle without leave, together with their tedious and di≈øcon≈øolate March through thick Woods, and deep ≈øcalding Sands, ready to die with Thir≈øt, ≈øo damped their Spirits, and lo≈øt their wonted Courage, that they became an ea≈øie prey to the wary Spaniard, who taking them at that advantage, and ≈øetting upon them at unawares,The Engli≈øh di≈øappointed & beaten. de≈øtroyed them without re≈øi≈øtance, even till they were weary of killing, and Major Gen. Haines and between ≈øix or ≈øeven hundred more left both their Lives and their
expected Booty behind them to pay for Venables's Folly, be≈øides near as many more which were killed in ≈øtragling Parties; the whole Execution being performed with the lo≈øs of ≈øixty per≈øons on the Spaniards ≈øide.

Having thus fru≈øtrated their Expectations by their unadvi≈øed Landing, and lo≈øt all hope of winning that Town, they re≈øolve however not to lo≈øe the whole Voyage without gaining ≈øomething from the Spaniard, and therefore next directed their Cour≈øe to Jamaica, wherein was at that time but one only Town (viz.) St. Jago, within which Place dwelt all the Spaniards that were in the I≈øle, who kept their Slaves at ≈øeveral little Plantations in the Country, from whence they were continually ≈øupplied with ≈øtore of Fruits and Provi≈øions, which they luxuriou≈øly ≈øpent in their Hou≈øes, that being a lazy People, who are naturally ≈øo proud, that they think it below them to take pains; de≈øigning nothing more but only to live in ea≈øe and plenty, their whole number, Slaves and all, not exceeding three Thou≈øand.

Upon the Landing of the Engli≈øh Army,They take Jamaica. the Inhabitants of St Jago for≈øook the Town, and betook them≈øelves to the Mountains; but after divers Skirmi≈øhes and Surpri≈øals on both ≈øides, ≈øeeing but little hopes of regaining the I≈øland, ≈øeveral of the mo≈øt con≈øiderable among them got into Cuba, but were ≈øoon after commanded back again by the Vice-roy of Alexico, with promi≈øes of a ≈øpeedy ≈øupply to be ≈øent after them. The Vice-roy's Promi≈øe was long before it was performed; and when the Succour came, it was but five hundred men, who refu≈øed to joyn with them, in regard they were ≈øo few in number,
and by this time grown very ≈øickly, but fortified them≈øelves at a place called St. Chereras, expecting to receive more Recruits; but the Engli≈øh finding them out before they came, marched immediatly again≈øt them, and defeated them, and ≈øo they did about thirty Companies of Spani≈øh Souldiers that arrived ≈øoon after; which bad Succe≈øs made the Spaniards de≈øpair of ever regaining the I≈øland. Whereupon the Engli≈øh began now to form them≈øelves into a Body or Colony; ≈øome ≈øetling them≈øelves in Plantations, and others venturing to Sea as Privateers, the better to ≈øecure them≈øelves again≈øt the Spaniards, and force them to con≈øent to a Peace, by their frequent annoying them, and ≈øeizing ≈øuch of their Ships as they met withal; in which they proved ≈øo very ≈øucce≈øsful, that Jamaica began to be much talked of, and had in great e≈øteem in England, and fre≈øh Supplies of Men, Ammunition, and other Nece≈ø≈øaries were ≈øent them thence; and ≈øo by little and little it came to its pre≈øent Potency, wherein His Maje≈øty will without doubt take care to pre≈øerve and ≈øupport it, upon the following Con≈øiderations:
1. Its being ≈øo large and capacious, that it is capable of entertaining a far greater number of People than any other I≈øland enjoyed by the Engli≈øh in that part of the World.

2. Its being ≈øo ≈øeated in the heart of the Spani≈øh Territories in America, that their Ships, as they come thither, and pa≈øs from Port to Port, make this I≈øle, or may be ea≈øily met with by tho≈øe Ships that ply upon the Coa≈øt; for all the Plate-Fleet, in their return from Carthagena, ≈øteer directly from St. Domingo, and pa≈øs by one of the ends of this I≈øle, to recover Havana, which is the common Rendezvouz of the Spani≈øh Armado,
before they ≈øail home through the Gulph of Florida. Nor indeed is there any other way; for the Voyage would be too unrea≈øonable long ≈øhould they turn it to the Windward of Hi≈øpaniola; by which means, be≈øides the great difficulty of its performance, they would lo≈øe the benefit of uniting the Fleets from Mexicos Nombre de Dios, and other places, at their common Rendezvouz at Havana, wherein their greate≈øt Security lies; for from thence they ≈øail all home in company together.

3. In regard Jamaica exceeds all the re≈øt of our Plantations in America for the goodne≈øs of tho≈øe Commodities proper to their ≈øeveral Colonies; and is be≈øides its being ≈øo profitable in furni≈øhing us with excellent Commodities, it likewi≈øe takes off abundance of our Manufactures, both of the product of this Kingdom, and ≈øuch as are brought us from Parts beyond the Seas.

4. Becau≈øe it appears to be a place con≈øiderable enough to de≈øerve His Maje≈øties Care for its pre≈øervation, not only by its ≈øub≈øi≈øting of its ≈øelf when fir≈øt taken; but likewi≈øe by its increa≈øing its Potency and Grandeur, ≈øo that it will in all probability become in a little time very profitable both to the King and Kingdom, and bring into His Maje≈øties Trea≈øury ≈øeveral hundred thou≈øand Pounds per Annum.
5. This I≈øland being (when ≈øetled) of its ≈øelf able to carry on a War again≈øt the Spaniards, when the Affairs of England ≈øhall require it.

6. The con≈øiderable progre≈øs already made in the Settlement of this I≈øle; nor can its di≈øtance be any real di≈øadvantage, ≈øince the greater number of Ships are thereby employed, and con≈øequently the more Saylors, Ship-wrights, and other Trade≈ømen, who≈øe Livelihood depends upon trade
at Sea. Be≈øides, if it lay nearer, we could expect no ≈øuch Commodities as we receive from thence, in regard they are appropriated to that Clime. And it mu≈øt certainly be a great advantage to His Maje≈øty to have ≈øuch Merchandize within His own Dominions, as are both valued and needed by His Subjects and Neighbours, as the Cacao is, though it be at a di≈øtance.

7. The Coa≈øt of Virginia, and ≈øome of the Caribby-I≈ølands are ≈øubject to ≈øuch Gu≈øts of Wind, that Ships are often driven to put to Sea, and fly for ≈øhelter to ≈øome or other of the Spani≈øh Leeward Ports, where they were wont to be made Prizes of; but Jamaica, ≈øince it hath fallen into our hands, hath proved a convenient Harbour for ≈øuch Ships or Ve≈ø≈øels as are at any time thus di≈øtre≈ø≈øed; which is an Argument ≈øufficient to per≈øwade His Maje≈øty to undertake its Support and Defence.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION OF THE I≈øland of BARBADOS.
div.p: It was fir≈øt di≈øcovered in the Reign of King James the Fir≈øt,Its first Di≈øcovery. by Sir William Curteen, who returning homewards from Fernambuck in Brazil, was driven by a ≈øtorm upon this Coa≈øt, and anchoring before the I≈øle, he went with ≈øome of his Company a≈øhore, to inform him≈øelf of the Nature of the Place; which he found ≈øo exceedingly overgrown with Woods, that they could find no plain or champaign ground ≈øit to inhabit, nor any ether Bea≈øts but Swine, which the Portugals, having formerly put on ≈øhore here, to furni≈øh them with Provi≈øions in ca≈øe they ≈øhould be ca≈øt on that ≈øhoar by foul weather, had by this time multiplied abundantly, the Fruits and Roots that grew there ≈øerving them for food; ≈øo that the Natives of the adjacent I≈ølands (for there were none in this) were u≈øed to come thither frequently to kill them.

Having made this Di≈øcovery, and informed him≈øelf as well as he could of the Nature and Condition of the I≈øland, he gave notice thereof
to his Friends in England; from whence divers Ships were with all convenient ≈øpeed di≈øpatched thither; who, upon their Arrival, applied them≈øelves to the rendering the I≈øland ≈øit for Habitation. In order to which, they cut down the Woods, and planted Potatoes and Maiz; which, together with the Swine which they found there, did but ju≈øt keep Life and Soul together; for having as yet nothing to trade withal, Ships from England vi≈øited them but ≈ølowly; ≈øo that they were oft-times driven to great extremities: But having about the year 1627. increas'd the number of its Inhabitants, and Tobacco, Indico, Cotton-wool, Fu≈øtick-wood, and the like, begun to grow there, and afford great increa≈øe, the I≈øland began to gain more repute in England, and invited divers Ships, in hope of gain, to trade with them, exchanging divers ≈øorts of working-tools made of Iron and Steel, together with Cloth, Shirts, Drawers, Ho≈øe, Shoes, Hats, Servants, and other things which they needed, for Tobacco and other things which the I≈øland produced. After which, they grew and increa≈øed wonderfully both in number and wealth; e≈øpecially when their Sugar-Canes were grown, and they had learned the Art of making Sugar.

This I≈øle is very hot, e≈øpecially for eight Months,Its Temperature. and would be more in≈øupportable, were it not for the cool Briezes of Wind, which ri≈øe with the Sun, and blow fre≈øher as the Sun mounteth higher. And the≈øe Briezes blow alway from the North-Ea≈øt, except it be in the time of the Turnado, and then for an hour or two it chops into the South; but after returns to the ≈øame Point again. And it is ob≈øerved, that although the People do ≈øo much ≈øweat, yet they
find not that faintne≈øs as with us in England in the Months of July and August; neither are they ≈øo thir≈øty, unle≈øs over-heated by exce≈øs of Labour, or drinking of ≈øtrong Liquors, which the People here are too much addicted unto, to their great hurt; which, if moderately taken, would be as a great pre≈øervative to comfort and refre≈øh their inward parts, which are left cold and faint through their ≈øweating. Be≈øides, our Bodies being accu≈øtomed to colder Climates, our Spirits are not ≈øo vigorous without them in a moderate manner.

This I≈øle is not over-plentifully watered with Rivers or fre≈øh Springs,Its Waters. there being but one that can appropriate to it≈øelf that Name, or rather a Lake which runs not far into the Land; yet notwith≈øtanding, the Inhabitants are not de≈øtitute thereof; for the Country lying low and level, there are ≈øeveral Pools or Ponds; and be≈øides they are ≈øupplied with Rain-water by having Wells and Ci≈øterns in their Hou≈øes.
Here is al≈øo a River which the Inhabitants call Tuigh-River, from the top of who≈øe water is gathered an Oyl which ≈øerveth them to burn in their Lamps.

This I≈øle is exceeding fertil,Its Fertility. bearing Crops all the year long, and its Trees being always cloathed in their Summer-Livery, and the Fields and Woods in their verdure, renders it very delightful to the Inhabitants. But the two principal ≈øea≈øons of the year for planting, are in May and November, but the Sugar-Canes are planted all the year round, the making of which is not only very chargeable, but al≈øo as dangerous, and ≈øubject to ca≈øualties, either in the Boyling-hou≈øe, with the Coppers and Furnaces,
in the Filling-Room, in the Still-Hou≈øe, or in the Curing-Hou≈øe.

The Commodities this I≈øland produceth,Its Commodities. are Sugars (which though not ≈øo white as tho≈øe of Brazile, yet better when refined, being of a fairer grain) Indico, Cotton-wool, Ginger, Logwood, Fu≈øtick, and Lignum vitae; and the≈øe Commodities, e≈øpecially Sugar, Indico, Cotton and Ginger, here are in ≈øuch great abundance, that about two hundred Sail of Ships and Ve≈ø≈øels, both great and ≈ømall, have yearly their loading; which, after imported in the ≈øeveral Ports of England and Ireland, is again in great quantities exported to foreign parts, to our great enrichment; and the rather, for that they are not permitted to trade with any other Nation but the Engli≈øh, and ≈øuch of His Maje≈øties Subjects in New-England, Virginia and Bermudas; and in exchange of tho≈øe Commodities, they take ≈øuch as are nece≈ø≈øary for the u≈øe of man, as well for the Back and Belly, as for their Hou≈øes and Plantations; with many of which they are ≈øupplied from New-England, Virginia, and the Bermudas, together with Servants and Slaves, with ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Commodities and Provi≈øions, as, Hor≈øes, Camels, A≈ø≈øinegroes, Cattel, al≈øo ≈øalted Fle≈øh, and Fi≈øh of ≈øeveral ≈øorts; Butter and Chee≈øe; but by rea≈øon of the great heat of the weather, it will ≈øoon ≈øtink, and become unfit to eat; ≈øo that in≈øtead of Butter, they make great u≈øe of Oyl for their Sauces.
The Dayes and Nights are almo≈øt throughout the year of an equal length, the Sun ri≈øing and ≈øetting at ≈øix, except about October, and then there is ≈øome ≈ømall difference.

The Ayr,The Ayr. though hot, is very moi≈øt, which cau≈øeth all Iron-Tools, as Knives, Swords, Locks, Keys, &c. to ru≈øt; ≈øo that without con≈øtant u≈øage, they will ≈øoon become eaten up with Ru≈øt. And this great heat and moi≈øture doth cau≈øe the Plants and Trees to grow ≈øo large and high.

Here are abundance of Fruits of all ≈øorts; as, Dates, The Fruits. Oranges two ≈øorts, the one ≈øweet, and the other ≈øharp, Pomgranates, Citrons, Limes, Limons, Macows, Grapes, Juniper-Apples, Papayers, Momins, Mombains, Acajous, Icacos, Cherries, Rai≈øins, Indian-Figs, Cocoes, Plantins, Bononoes, Guavars, Prickle-Apples, Prickle-Pears, Cu≈øtard-Apples, Melons, both Land and Water, and Pine-Apples, the rare≈øt Fruit in the Indies.

Here are great ≈øtore of Fi≈øh in the Sea; as, Snappers, Crabs, Their Fi≈øh. Lob≈øters, Terbums, Macquerels, Mullets, Cavalloes, Parrot-Fi≈øh, Cony-Fi≈øh, and Green Turtles; which of all others, are the mo≈øt delicious; with ≈øeveral other ≈øorts appropriated to this and the re≈øt of the Caribby-I≈øles; but the Rivulets or Ponds have few or no Fi≈øh in them.

Here are no Bea≈øts or Cattel but what are tame,Their Cattel. and brought them; as, Camels, Hor≈øes, A≈ø≈øinegroes, Oxen, Bulls, Cows, Sheep, Goats and Hogs? which are here in great plenty in every Plantation, it being their common Food; who≈øe Fle≈øh is e≈øteemed very good and delicious; but as for Beef and Mutton, it is very dear, as having but a ≈ømall ≈øtock; but might be ≈øoon increa≈øed, would they ≈øpare ground enough for Pa≈øturage for them from their other occa≈øions.

Here groweth divers ≈øorts of Engli≈øh Herbs and Roots;Their Herbs. as, Ro≈øemary, Lavender, Lavender-Cotton, Marjoram, Winter-Savoury, Time, Par≈øley, Tan≈øcy, Sage, Pur≈ølan, &c. And for Roots, Cabbages, Coleworts, Colliflowers, Turnips, Potatoes, Onions, Garlick, Radi≈øhes, Lettice, Taragon, Marigolds, &c.
Here are ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Fowls, as,Their Fowls Turkeys, Hens, Mu≈øcovy-Ducks, Pigeons, Turtle-Doves, &c. And for ≈ømall Birds, great variety; as, Thru≈øhes, Black-Birds, Sparrows, &c.

Here are ≈øeveral AnimalsAnimals. and In≈øects; as, Snakes a yard and half long, Scorpions as big as Rats, but no way hurtful to Man or Bea≈øt; Lizards, which are exceeding harmle≈øs, much frequenting the Hou≈øes, and loving the company of Men; Musketoes, Cockroches, and Merriwings, which are very trouble≈øom in the Night in ≈øtinging; al≈øo there are Land-Crabs, which are found good to eat.

Here are great variety of Trees,Trees. fit for ≈øeveral U≈øes; as, the Locust, Ma≈øtick, Red-wood, the Iron-wood-tree and Cedar, which are fit for Building. Al≈øo the, Ca≈ø≈øia-Fi≈øtula, Coloquintida, Tamarind, Ca≈ø≈øary, of which is made their Bread; the Poy≈øon-Tree, and the Phy≈øick-Nut, the≈øe have a Phy≈øical, and ≈øome a Poy≈øonous Vertue in them. Al≈øo here are the≈øe trees following, the Caliba≈øh, the ≈øhell of who≈øe fruit ≈øerveth to carry liquid things in, being of the nature of Gourds; the Mangra≈øs-tree, which is of an exceeding greatne≈øs, the Roucou, of who≈øe Bark is made Ropes; as al≈øo Flax, which being ≈øpun, is employed to ≈øeveral u≈øes, the Lignum Vitae, the
Palmeto, which is very large, and beautiful to behold; with ≈øeveral others.

In this I≈øland are divers Caves, ≈øome of which are very deep, and large enough to hold five hundred men; and the≈øe Caves are often the Sanctuary of ≈øuch Negro-Slaves that run away; in which they lie a good while before they are found out; ≈øeldom ≈øtirring in the day-time, although they are ≈øuch unwhol≈øome places, by rea≈øon of the great damps that are found in them: And it is ≈øuppo≈øed that the≈øe Caves were the Habitation of the Natives.

They have a Drink call'd Mobby, Their Drink. made of Potatoes ≈øoaked in water; another named Prino, made of Ca≈ø≈øavy-Root and Water, which, though it is not ≈øo plea≈øant, yet is reckoned much better, made by the Indians for their own drinking, which in it ≈øelf is a ≈øtrong Poy≈øon, and this they cau≈øe their old Women, who≈øe Breath and Teeth have been tainted with divers Poxes, to chew and ≈øpit out in the water, for the better breaking and macerating the Root, and in a few hours this Juice will purge it≈øelf of its poy≈øonous qualities; for their poy≈øonous Breath, and the poy≈øon of the Ca≈ø≈øary, being oppo≈øites, work with ≈øuch vehemency, that they ≈øpend their poy≈øonous qualities in the conflict; they likewi≈øe drink Crippo, Kill-Devil, Punch, Plum-Drink, Plantane-Drink, a ≈øtrong Drink made of the skimming of Sugar, Beveridge, made of Spring-water, Sugar, and the Juice of Oranges, and Wine of Pines, which is only made of the Juice of the Fruit, which is the be≈øt of all.

Their MeatTheir Meats. is generally Hogs-Fle≈øh, ≈øalted Fle≈øh or Fi≈øh, and when any of the Cattel die by any di≈øtemper, or by accident,
it is given to the Negroes, who feed like Princes on it; but they are commonly contented from weeks end to weeks end, with Potatoes, Loblolly made of Maize mixt with water; Ca≈ø≈øader-Bread, common in all the Indies, Bonariff, and ≈øuch like Food that the Plantation affords; as, Pompions as ≈øweet as Melons, Plantanes, Sugar-Canes, &c. They have al≈øo Turkeys, Pullets, Mu≈øcovy Ducks, Their Fowls. Turtle-Doves, Pigeons and Rabbits, with excellent Fi≈øh of divers kinds,Their Fi≈øh. not known to us, as the Green Turtle, who come in with the Tide, lie upon the Sand till the next return, and are ea≈øily taken in Lucaick I≈ølands, though not in this; but ≈øent hither; for it is but turning them on their backs with ≈øtaves, and there they lie till they are fetched away: A large Turtle (as we have mentioned) will have in her Body half a Bu≈øhel of Eggs, which ≈øhe lays in the Sands, where they hatch by the Sun, When you are to kill one of the Fi≈øhes, you lay him on his Back on a Table, and when he ≈øees you come with a knife in you hand to kill him, he ≈øends forth the mo≈øt grievous ≈øighs that ever were heard, and ≈øheds Tears in abundance; after he is opened, and his Heart taken out, if you lay it in a Di≈øh, it will ≈øtir and pant ten hours after the Fi≈øh is dead, there is none more delicious in ta≈øte, nor more nouri≈øhing than he.

But as for the Ma≈øter-planters, Merchants Factors, and Strangers, their Fare is far otherwi≈øe, having their curious made Di≈øhes; as, Cu≈øtards, Chee≈øe-Cakes, Tan≈øics, al≈øo, Sturgeon, Anchovies, Caveare, Botardo, Neats Tongues; be≈øides Poultrey, Fi≈øh, Fowl, Mutton, Beef, Kid, Pork, Beans, Pea≈øe, ≈øeveral Roots, and other good Di≈øhes. And be≈øides
the ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Liquors already named, Wines, Strong Waters, Brandy, and Engli≈øh Beer; ≈øo that they find no want, and do not con≈øider the condition of tho≈øe poor wretches, their Servants and Slaves, who are con≈øtrained to ≈øo hard a Labour.

This I≈øland may be divided into Ma≈øters, Servants and Slaves;The Divi≈øion of the I≈øland. the Ma≈øters live in all affluence of Plea≈øure and Delight. The Apparel they allow their Servants yearly, for the Men, are, ≈øix pair of Drawers, twelve pair of Shoes, three Monmouth-Caps, ≈øix Shirts; and for the Women, four Smocks, three Petticoats, four Coifs, and twelve pair of Shoes, be≈øides a Rug-Gown to each, to keep them warm in the night, and to put on them when they come ≈øweating from their labour. To the Negro-Men they allow but three pair of Canvas Drawers, and to the Women, but three Petticoats.
But for them≈øelves (e≈øpecially the better ≈øort) they are exceeding profu≈øe and co≈øtly.

The Lodging of the≈øe poor Wretches is wor≈øt of all; for having laboured all the day in ≈øo hot a Country, without any nouri≈øhing Diet, at night they mu≈øt be content to lie hard, on nothing but a Board, without any Coverlet, in their Huts or rather Hog-≈øties; but Chri≈øtian Servants are ≈øomething better treated, being allowed Hamocks.

Every Sunday (which is the only day of Re≈øt, and ≈øhould be ≈øet apart for the Service of God) they employ either in the getting of the Bark of Trees, and making Ropes with it, which they truck away for Shirts, Drawers, and the like; or el≈øe ≈øpend the Day in Recreation, as Dancing and Wre≈øtling, which they much delight in, though
they are no great Proficients in either; for in their Dancing they u≈øe Antick Actions, their hands having more of motion than their feet, and their head than either; nor do the men and women dance together, but apart; the Mu≈øick to which they dance being a ≈øort of Kettle-Drums, one bigger than another, which makes a ≈øtrange and various noi≈øe, but whether harmonious I leave to the Judgment of the Reader.

The Servants, after five years, become Freemen of the I≈øland, and then employ their time as may be mo≈øt to their Advantage; but the Negro-Slaves and their Children being in bondage for ever, are pre≈øerved with greater care, and u≈øed with ≈øuch ≈øeverity, as occa≈øioned a great con≈øpiracy again≈øt their Ma≈øters ≈øome years ≈øince; which was ≈øo clo≈øely carried, as no di≈øcovery was made till the day before it was to be acted, and then one of them, either failing of his Courage, or out of Love to his Ma≈øter, di≈øcovered and prevented it; for which, many of them were put to death, as a Terror to the re≈øt; who being ≈øo numerous, might prove dangerous, but that they are kept in ≈øuch ≈øtrict aw, and not ≈øuffered to touch or handle a Weapon; ≈øo that nothing is more terrible to them than Gun-≈øhot; and be≈øides, being of different Countries, do not under≈øtand one anothers Language; for in ≈øome of tho≈øe places in Africa, where petty Kingdoms are, who go to War again≈øt one another, the Pri≈øoners that are taken on each ≈øide, they ≈øell unto and other European Nations that come to traffick with them; yea, they ≈øell their Subjects, and ≈øome poor men their Servants, and ≈øometimes their Wives, for ≈øuch Traffick as our Merchants bring them; when they are brought hither, the Planters buy them
out of the Ship, where they find them ≈øtark naked, and therefore cannot be deceived in any outward infirmity, chu≈øing them as men do Hor≈øes in a Fair, and according as they are hand≈øom, lu≈øty, well ≈øhapen, and young; the youthfulle≈øt and mo≈øt beautiful yield the greate≈øt price; the general rate for the better ≈øort of Negro-Men is thirty pound ≈øterling, and five and twenty for a Woman, is u≈øual; if they buy any that have no Wives, they will come to their Ma≈øters and complain they cannot live without, and he provides them one by the next Ships. Religion they have none, yet ≈øeem to acknowledge a God, by looking up to Heaven for Revenge when they are wronged: One Negro-Woman being brought abed of two Children, her Husband provided a Cord to hang her, as fal≈øe to him, but the Over≈øeer prevented it, by telling him, it was common with the Engli≈øh Women, and they liked them the better; yet if he were re≈øolved to hang her, he ≈øhould be hang'd him≈øelf by her, the fear of which hindered him.
The Chief TownsChief Towns. of this I≈øle are St. Michael's, formerly call'd the Bridg-Town, or Indian Bridg, Little Bri≈øtol, St. Jame's and Charles-Town, with other Pari≈øhes of le≈øs Note.

1. St. Michael'sSt. Michaels. is ≈øcituate at the bottom of Carli≈øle-Bay in the Leeward, or Southern part of the I≈øle, which Bay is very capacious, deep and ≈øecure for Ships, being large enough to entertain 500 Ve≈ø≈øels at one time. The Town is long, containing ≈øeveral Streets, and graced with abundance of well built Hou≈øes. It is very populous, being the re≈øidence of the Governour, or his Deputy, the place of Judicature, and the Scale of Trade, where mo≈øt of the Merchants
and Factors in the I≈øle have their Store-Hou≈øes for the negotiation of their Affairs; and from the≈øe Store-hou≈øes or Shops, the Inhabitants are ≈øupplied with ≈øuch Commodities as they have occa≈øion for, in exchange of theirs, which are the product of the I≈øle. The Town is ill ≈øeated, the Ground being lower than the Banks of the Sea; by which means the Spring-Tides do ≈ølow over, and there remaining, do make a kind of a moori≈øh Bogg, which doth occa≈øion it to be more unhealthful than the other parts of the I≈øle. This Town for its Defence, and ≈øecurity of the Ships, hath two ≈øtrong Forts oppo≈øite to each other, with a Platform in the mid≈øt, which al≈øo commands the Road; all which are well fortified with great Guns, &c. The principal of the≈øe Forts is called Charles Fort, being ≈øeated in Nedham's Point.

2. Little Bri≈øtol, Little Bri≈øtol. formerly Sprights Bay, ≈øituate about four Leagues Leeward from St. Michaels, hath a commodious Road for Ships, and is a place well frequented and traded unto, and is ≈øtrongly defended by two powerful Forts.

3. St. James, St. James. formerly called the Hall, ≈øeated not far from Bri≈øtol, hath the accommodation of a good Road for Ships, and is a place of a con≈øiderable Trade, for its defence, be≈øides a large Platform, hath fortified Brea≈øt-works, and in this Town is kept for the Precinct, the Monthly Courts.

Charles-Town, Charles-Town. ≈øeated wind-ward of St. Michaels, about two leagues, and an Oy≈øter-Bay; it is ≈øecured by two ≈øtrong Forts, the one to the windward, and the other to the Leeward of the
Town and Road, with a Platform in the mid≈øt.
This Town hath the accommodation of weekly Markets, and here is kept the Monthly Courts for the Precinct.
The other Places of Name along the Sea-coa≈øt of this I≈øle, beginning Ea≈øterly, and ≈øo encompa≈ø≈øing the I≈øle, are as followeth,
Fowl-bay, Augu≈øtin's-bay, Maxwell's-bay, where there is a ≈ømall I≈øle, Black Rock, The Hole, Spikes-bay, Bali≈øes-bay, Long-bay, Clark's-bay, and Con≈øtance-bay.

This I≈øland is very ≈øtrong, as well by Nature as Art, being ≈øheltered with Rocks and Shoals, and where Nature hath not thus defended it, it is fortified by Trenches and Ramperts, with Palli≈øado's, Curtains, and Counter≈øcarps; be≈øides, round about the I≈øle, regarding the Sea, is ≈øtanding-wood: here are al≈øo for its further defence, three Forts, one for a Magazine for the Ammunition and Powder to lie in, and the other two places for Retreats, as occa≈øion ≈øerves. They have al≈øo, for their further ≈øecurity, a ≈øtanding Militia, con≈øi≈øting of two Regiments of Hor≈øe, and five of Foot, which are ≈øtout and well-di≈øciplined Men, and always to be ready on beat of Drum.

Tho≈øe who are de≈øirous to know more of the Nature of the Sugar-Canes, the manner of their planting, growth, cutting, grinding, boiling, together with the manner of their conveying the Skimmings into their Cy≈øtern, where to di≈øtil it for Spirits, how long it continueth in the Curing-hou≈øe before it become Mu≈øcovado-Sugar, together with the manner of its refining and making into Whites, may con≈øult Mr. Richard Ligons de≈øcription of this I≈øle, where they will find ≈øufficient ≈øatisfaction.
The pre≈øent Governour of the I≈øland of Barbado's is Sir Richard Dutton.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION Of the ISLAND of St. CHRISTOPHERS.
div.p: ST. CHRISTOPHERS, ≈øo named from Chri≈øtopher Columbus, the fir≈øt di≈øcover thereof, who finding it very plea≈øant, gave it his own Name, which the ≈øhape of the Mountains likewi≈øe inclined him to, for on its upper part it hath as it were upon one of its ≈øhoulders another le≈ø≈øer Mountain, as St. Chri≈øtopher is painted like a Giant, carrying our Saviour upon his back, like as it were a little Child. It is ≈øituated in the latitude of 17 degrees,Situation. and 25 minutes on this ≈øide the Line; in circuit about 75 Miles: the Land lies high in the mid≈øt, by rea≈øon of ≈øome very high Mountains, from which ≈øprings ≈øeveral Rivers, which oftentimes, by rea≈øon of the Rains falling from the Mountains, are overflown, to the detriment of the Inhabitants.
The SoylThe Soyl. being light and ≈øandy, is apt to produce all ≈øorts of the Country-Fruits, Provi≈øion and Commodities, as Sugar, Tobacco, Cotton, Ginger, &c.

This I≈øle by rea≈øon of its ≈øeveral great and ≈øteep Mountains, between which are dreadful Rocks and Springs of hot and ≈øulphurous Water, with
horrid Precipices and thick Woods, yea ≈øome Springs of Sulphur, which cau≈øes one of them to be called the Sulphurous Mountain.
There is on the Sea-≈øide a Salt-Pit, called Gulde≈øac; and not far from the Salt-Pit there is a ≈ømall I≈øthmus of Land, which reacheth within a Mile and a half of the I≈øland of Nevis and Mevis.

The I≈øland is placed exceeding delightful, and of a mo≈øt delectable pro≈øpect to the eye of the beholder, for it is divided into ≈øeveral ≈øtages, from the uppermo≈øt whereof a man may take an exceeding plea≈øant pro≈øpect of all the Plantations and Gardens, which gently de≈øcend to the Sea-≈øide, and in regard of the general a≈øcent of the I≈øle, the lower ≈øtage or ≈øtory doth not debar the eye of the plea≈øant pro≈øpect of that which lieth at a remoter di≈øtance; and that which makes the pro≈øpect the more delectable in the ≈øeveral Plantatious (which are bounded with Rows of Trees always in their verdure) are the fair Hou≈øes covered with glazed Slate.

The whole I≈øland is divided into four Quarters or Cantons; two whereof are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Engli≈øh, and two by the French, but ≈øo ≈øeparated, that People cannot go from one Quarter to another without pa≈ø≈øing over the Lands of one of the two Nations. The Engli≈øh have more little Rivers in their Divi≈øion, the French more of the plain Countrey fit for Tillage. The Engil≈øh exceed the French in number, but the French have four Forts; of which, one hath regular Works like a Citadel; that of mo≈øt note commands the Haven, and is called Ba≈ø≈øe-Terre; and the Engli≈øh only two, one commanding the great Haven, and the other a De≈øcent not far from Pointe de Sable;
and to prevent Differences between the two Nations, each of them have a Guard upon the Frontiers of their Divi≈øion, which is renewed every day.

The Engli≈øh have erected five fair Churches, well furni≈øhed with Pulpits, and Seats of excellent Joyners Work of precious Wood, the Mini≈øters being ≈øent thither by the Lord Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury; one of the Churches is at Sandy-Point, one at Palm-Tree, another near the Great Rood, and two at the Inlet of Cayoune, with many fair Structures.

The French and Engli≈øh Colonies had their beginning at the ≈øame time; for in the Year 1625. Mon≈øieur De≈ønambuck, a French, and Sir Thomas Warner an Engli≈øh Gentleman, joyntly took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Sir Chri≈øtophers on the ≈øame day, in the Names of the Kings of Great Britain and France, their Ma≈øters, that ≈øo they might have a place of ≈øafe Retreat, and a good Haven for the Ships of both Nations bound for America, as being well furni≈øhed with Provi≈øions, and therefore often vi≈øited by the Spaniards, who ≈øometimes left the Sick there to be looked to by the Caribeans, with whom they had made a Peace upon tho≈øe Terms.

The≈øe two Gentlemen, having thus taken po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the I≈øland, for the better e≈øtabli≈øhment of the≈øe Colonies, returned to their re≈øpective Countries, leaving ≈øome men in it to ≈øecure it; but ≈øu≈øpecting ≈øome private Intelligence between the Indians and Spaniards, for de≈øtroying all, both Engli≈øh and French, in their ab≈øence, (to prevent which) they in one night rid their Hands of the mo≈øt factious of that Nation, and ≈øoon after forced all the re≈øt, who were got together in ≈øeveral Bodies, and ≈øtood upon their Guard, to retire to
≈øome other I≈ølands, and leave that to their Di≈øpo≈øal. After this, they returned home, where their Conque≈øt and Proceeding being approved of by the Kings their Ma≈øters, they returned with Recruits of Men, in the quality of Governors and Lieutenants under the Kings of Great Britain and France; and having divided the I≈øland according to their fir≈øt Agreement; and the Engli≈øh having plentiful Provi≈øions from London, pro≈øpered much more than the French, who wanted nece≈ø≈øary a≈ø≈øi≈øtance.

The French, be≈øides their ≈øeveral Habitations di≈øper≈øed up and down in their Quarters, have at Ba≈ø≈øe-Terre (near the Haven where Ships lie at Anchor) a Town of a good bigne≈øs, who≈øe Hou≈øes are well built, of Brick, Free-≈øtone and Timber, where the Merchants have their Store-hou≈øes, and is well inhabited by Trade≈ømen, and are well ≈øerved with ≈øuch Commodities both for the Back and Belly, together with Uten≈øils for their Hou≈øes and Plantations, as they have occa≈øion for, in exchange of ≈øuch Commodities which are the Product of the I≈øland.

Here is a fair and large Church, as al≈øo a publick Hall, for the Admini≈øtration of Ju≈øtice. Here is al≈øo a very fair Ho≈øpital, built by the General, for ≈øuch People as cannot get Cure at their Hou≈øes; where they are well maintained, and attended by Phy≈øitians for the recovery of their healths. Here is al≈øo a ≈øtately Ca≈øtle, being the Re≈øidence of the Governour, being mo≈øt plea≈øantly ≈øeated at the foot of a high Mountain, not far from the Sea, having ≈øpacious Courts, delightful Walks and Gardens, which cau≈øeth a curious Pro≈øpect.

In 16 ‚Ä¢ 9. a powerful Fleet from Spain under Don Frederick de Toledo, had received Order from that
King, that before he fell down the Havana, he ≈øhould touch at St. Chri≈øtophers, and force from thence all the Engli≈øh and French, who had ≈øome time before planted them≈øelves there. This Navy con≈øi≈øted of twenty four great Ships of Burden, and fifteen Frigots, who fir≈øt ≈øeized ≈øome Engli≈øh Ships that were lying at Anchor near the I≈øle of Mevis, and from thence came and ca≈øt Anchor in the Road of St. Chri≈øtophers, in the French Divi≈øion, and the Forts of both Colonies being not in a condition to ≈øtand out a Siege, being unfurni≈øhed with Ammunition and Provi≈øions, not being able to with≈øtand ≈øo great an Army if all the Forces of the Nations had been in conjunction, which made it a very great di≈øcouragement to them; yet re≈øolving the Enemy ≈øhould not boa≈øt they had compa≈ø≈øed their de≈øigns without Blows, they made a very vigorous oppo≈øition; but being overcome by number, the French for≈øook the I≈øland; De≈ønambuck embarking all his Men in certain Ships which happened to be in the Haven. Upon this Intelligence, the Quarters of the Engli≈øh were put into very great di≈øorder, and in continual expectation that the Spaniards would fall upon them; ≈øome endeavouring to e≈øcape by Sea, or hide them≈øelves in the Mountains; but others, being more couragious, ≈øent Deputies to Don Frederick, to propo≈øe an accommodation; but all the An≈øwer they received, was an expre≈øs Command immediately to depart the I≈øland, or to be treated with that rigour which the Law of Arms allowed toward ≈øuch as wrongfully po≈ø≈øe≈øs that which belongs not to them; and to ≈øpeed their departure, he order'd tho≈øe Engli≈øh Ships ≈øhould be re≈øtored to them that were taken at Mevis, wherein in≈øtantly they ≈øhould imbark for England; and becau≈øe it was
impo≈ø≈øible tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels ≈øhould contain ≈øo great a number, he permitted the re≈øt to continue in the I≈øle till they had opportunity of Tran≈øportation.

Upon which, Don Frederick weighed Anchor; but a≈ø≈øoon as the Fleet was departed, tho≈øe of the Engli≈øh that were left, began to rally, and took a re≈øolution to carry on the Settlement of their Colony; during which Tran≈øaction at St. Chri≈øtophers, the French, who went to Sea, having ≈øuffered many Inconveniences, were forced to put in at the I≈ølands of St. Martin and Mont≈øerrat, but looking on them as De≈øarts in compari≈øon of the Places they had left, and being de≈øirous to be informed of the condition of the Spaniards there, ≈øent one of their Ships to St. Chri≈øtophers; who returning, gave them an Account that the Enemy was gone, and the Engli≈øh couragiou≈øly employed in re-building, planting and repairing De≈øolations. This unexpected good News revived their decayed hopes, and per≈øuaded them to a ≈øpeedy return; the Engli≈øh Colony with con≈øtant ≈øupplies from London, for that time grew very powerful, peopling not only this Place, but ≈øending new Plantations from hence to Barbuda, Mont≈øerrat, Antego, and Barbadoes which are grown very numerous and famous for the Trade of the rich Commodities they are furni≈øhed with, as well as this curious I≈øland, who≈øe chiefe≈øt Trade is Sugar, Their Commodities. Tobacco, Cotton, Ginger, with ≈øeveral other ≈øorts of Fruits and Provi≈øions

There is in this I≈øle a very pretty Animal,Animals. called a Recquet, who≈øe Skin is of the colour of a withered Leaf, marked with little yellow or blewi≈øh points, they go on four
feet, their fore-feet being highe≈øt, their Eyes lively and ≈øparkling, they con≈øtantly hold up their heads, and are ≈øo very active, that they leap up and down perpetually, like Birds when they make no u≈øe of their Wings, their Tails are ≈øo turned up towards their back, that they make a Circle and a half; they love to look upon men, and are con≈øtantly ≈øtaring on them; when they are pur≈øued, they open their mouths, and put out their tongues like little Hounds.

There is a large Bird in the Caribbies called the Engle of Orinoca, Their Fowls. much like an Eagle in ≈øhape, all his Feathers are of light Gray, marked with black Spots, ≈øave that the end of his Wings and Tail are yellow, he hath a piercing ≈øight, and feeds on other Birds, yet to ≈øhew his Genero≈øity, never ≈øets upon the weaker ≈øort, but tho≈øe that are armed with crooked Beaks and ≈øharp Talons like him≈øelf; nay, it is ob≈øervable, he never ≈øeizes his Prey on the Ground or a Tree, but ≈øtays till it has taken its ≈ølight, that he may engage it in the open Air with equal advantage, upon whom he furiou≈øly fa≈øtens his Talons, and having ma≈øtered them, tears them in pieces and devours them. There is al≈øo a large Bird in this I≈øle called a Craw-Fowl, about the bigne≈øs of a great Duck, the Feathers A≈øh colour, and hideous to the Eye; it hath a long ≈øl ‚Ä¢ t back, a great head, ≈ømall eyes, deep ≈øet in his head, and a ≈øhort neck, under which hangs a Bag or Craw ≈øo big that it will contain two Gallons of Water; they are commonly found on Trees by the Sea-≈øide, where, a≈ø≈øoon as they perceive a Fi≈øh at advantage, they ≈øeize it, and ≈øwallow it whole; they are ≈øo attentive on their Fi≈øhing, fixing their Eye con≈øtantly on the Sea, that
they are ea≈øily ≈øhot, and become a prey to others: They have ≈øuch an an admirable Sight, that they will di≈øcover a Fi≈øh in the Sea at a very great di≈øtance, and under Water above a fathom, yet they will not ≈øeize until they come almo≈øt even with it; their Fle≈øh is not to be eaten: Here are likewi≈øe found a kind of Phea≈øants which are called Pintadoes, becau≈øe they are as it were painted with colours, and have about them ≈ømall points, like ≈øo many Eyes on a dark Ground.

To conclude with the≈øe Fowls, we ≈øhall give an account of the Colibry or Humming-Bird, which is admirable for its Beauty, Bulk, ≈øweet Sent, and manner of Life; for being the lea≈øt of all Birds, he gloriou≈øly confirms the Saying of Pliny That Nature is ever greatest in its least productions: Some of the≈øe Birds are no bigger bodied than the greater ≈øorts of Flies, yet of ≈øuch beautiful Feathers, that the Neck, Wings and Back repre≈øent the Rainbow; there are others that have ≈øuch a bright red under their Neck, that at a di≈øtance one would imagine it to be a Carbuncle, the Belly, and under the Wings as yellow as Gold, the Thighs green like an Emerald, the Feet and Beak as black as poli≈øh'd Ebony, the two little Eyes like two Diamonds ≈øet in an Oval, of the colour of burni≈øh'd Steel, the Head is gra≈øs-green, which gives it ≈øuch a lu≈øtre that it looks as if gilt; the Male hath a little Tuft on the Head, in which may be ≈øeen all the Colours which enamel this little Body, the Miracle of this feathered Commonwealth is one of the rare≈øt productions of Nature; he moves that little Crown of Feathers at plea≈øure, and is more beautiful than the Female; as his Bulk and Plumage is miraculous, ≈øo is the activity of his flight, making a noi≈øe with his wings as if a little whirlwind
were rai≈øed in the Air of a ≈øudden, which ≈øurprizes them that hear him before they ≈øee him; he lives only on the dew which he ≈øucks from the flowers of Trees with his Tongue, which is longer than his Beak, hollow as a Reed, and about the bigne≈øs of a ≈ømall Needle; 'tis plea≈øant to look on him in that po≈øture; for ≈øpreading abroad his little Cre≈øt, one would think he had on his head a Crown of Rubies and all ≈øorts of precious ≈øtones, animated, and flying in the Air: The Female commonly lays but two Eggs, which are oval, about the bigne≈øs of a Pea or ≈ømall Pearl; and though he lo≈øe much of his Beauty when dead, yet there is ≈øo much left, that ≈øome Ladies have worn them for Pendants, and imagined they became them better than any other; its Smell is ≈øo odoriferous, that it is like the fine≈øt Musk and Amber.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION OF THE I≈øland of MEVIS.
div.p: THE I≈øland of Nevis or Mevis lieth not far from St. Chri≈øtophers, Its Situation. as I have before noted, and in the Latitude of 17 degrees and 19 minutes north of the Line.

It is but ≈ømall, being not above 18 Miles in Circuit;Its Circuit. and in the mid≈øt of the I≈øle there is but one only Mountain, which is of a great heighth, but of an ea≈øie acce≈øs, and cloathed with Trees up to the very top; about which Mountains are the Plantations, which reach to the Sea-≈øhoar. Here are divers Springs of fre≈øh-water, whereof ≈øome are ≈øtrong enough to make their way into the Sea; and one Spring is of a hot and mineral Water; not far from who≈øe Spring-head are Baths made, found very beneficial for ≈øeveral Di≈øea≈øes.
