The Engli≈øh planted them≈øelves in this I≈øle in 1628.Inhabitants. and are ≈øtill po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors thereof, being now about three or four thou≈øand Inhabitants, who live well and drive a very hand≈øom Trade for ≈øuch things as they have occa≈øion for, by exchanging ≈øuch CommoditiesCommodities. as the I≈øle produceth, as, Sugar, Cotton, Ginger, Tobacco, &c. which they exchange for other Conveniencies.

Of all the Caribby-I≈ølands, none is ≈øo well governed as this;Their Government. Ju≈øtice being admini≈øtred with that impartiality, and all Debauchery and Immorality ≈øeverely puni≈øhed, by a Council of the mo≈øt eminent and ancient Inhabitants.

For the Service of God, there are three ChurchesTheir Churches. erected; and for its further ≈øecurity, and ≈øafety, it hath a Fort, whereon are mounted ≈øeveral great Guns, that command at a great di≈øtance, for the ≈øecurity of the Ships in the Road or Harbour; which likewi≈øe ≈øecure their Store-hou≈øes, into which all the Commodities imported
for the u≈øe of the Inhabitants, are di≈øpo≈øed, and ≈øo di≈øtributed to them that have occa≈øion for them.
It is indifferent fruitful, and it hath great ≈øtore of Deer,Its Fertility. with with ≈øeveral other ≈øorts of Game for hunting.

This I≈øle, as the re≈øt of the Charibbies, is troubled with Mu≈øchetoes, Chigoes, Murigoins, and there are Lizards five foot in length, and a foot about, their Skins of divers colours, according to the different Soil they are bred in; ≈øeveral of them have ≈øuch glittering Scales and Skins, that at a di≈øtance off, look like Cloth of Gold and Silver; they have four feet, each with five Claws, and very ≈øharp Nails; they run exceeding fa≈øt, and climb trees dexterou≈øly; and whether they love men, or are ≈øtupid, they ≈øtand ≈øtill looking on the Hunt≈ømen, ≈øuffering them to put a Ginn with a running knot about their necks, which is fa≈øtened to the end of a Pole, whereby they get them off the trees where they re≈øt them≈øelves; they have wide Jaws, with exceeding ≈øharp Teeth, their Tongues thick, and what≈øoever they catch with their Teeth they hold very fa≈øt, which are not at all venomous; the Females lay Eggs about the bigne≈øs of Woodcocks, the ≈øhell being ≈øoft, which they lay deep in the Sands of the Sea-≈øhoar to be hatched by the Sun; they are ≈øometimes eaten, though not very well liked by many.

The Annolis is another Creature very common in all the Plantations, about the bigne≈øs of a Lizard, but the Head longer, the Skin yellowi≈øh; and they are green on their backs, gray and blew ≈øtreaks drawn from the very top of the Head to the end of the Tail; they live in holes under
ground, whence, in the night, they make a very loud and important noi≈øe; in the day they are continually wandring about Cottages for ≈øub≈øi≈øtance.

A Land-Pike is another ≈øtrange Reptile, ≈øo called from its likene≈øs to that Fi≈øh; but in≈øtead of Fins, it hath four Feet, which are ≈øo weak, that they only crawl on the ground, and wind their Bodies like Pikes newly taken out of the water; ≈øome of the longe≈øt are about fifteen inches, and proportionably big; their Skin being covered with ≈ømall ≈øcales, which ≈øhine extreamly, and are of a ≈øilver gray colour; they make a very hideous noi≈øe in the night from under the Rocks, and from the bottoms of hollow places where they are lodged; it is more ≈øharp and grating to the Ear than Frogs or Toads, and they change their Notes according to the variety of the place where they lurk; they are ≈øeldom ≈øeen but a little before night, and when met in the day, their ≈øtrange motion on a ≈øudden, is apt to affright the Spectator.

There are in this I≈øle ≈øeveral In≈øects,In≈øects. as the flying Tyger is very ob≈øervable, who≈øe body is chequered with ≈øpots of ≈øeveral colours, as the Tyger's is, about the bigne≈øs of a horned Beetle, the head ≈øharp, with two great eyes, as ≈øparkling and green as an Emerald, his mouth being armed with two extreamly hard and ≈øharp hooks, by which he holds fa≈øt his prey while he gets the ≈øub≈øtance, the whole body being covered with a hard and ≈øwarthy cru≈øtine≈øs, ≈øerves him for Armour; Under his Wings, which are al≈øo of ≈øolid matter, are four le≈øs wings, as ≈øoft as ≈øilk; it hath ≈øix Legs, each whereof hath three joynts, and they are bri≈øtled with certain little prickles; He is continually catching Flies in the
day, with other ≈ømall Animals, and ≈øits ≈øinging on the trees in the night. The Horn-fly is another, which hath two Snouts like an Elephant, one turning upward, and the other down, about three Inches long, the Head is blew like a Gra≈øhopper, the Eyes green; the upper ≈øide of the Wings of a bright Violet, damaskt with Carnation, heightned by a ≈ømall natural thred of Silver, the Colours drawn with ≈øuch curio≈øity, that the mo≈øt curious painting cannot reach it; in≈øomuch as ≈øome at fir≈øt ≈øight have thought it to be Artificial, becau≈øe of its lively Carnation colour and ≈øtring of Silver; but having taken it into their hand, they have thought Nature to be in a gay kind of humour, and had a mind to divert her≈øelf when ≈øhe be≈øtowed ≈øuch ≈øumptuous Robes on this ≈ømall Queen of In≈øects.

There is likewi≈øe in this I≈øland an In≈øect ≈øomewhat like a Snail, called a Soldier, but have no ≈øhells proper to them≈øelves; therefore, to ≈øecure their weak bodies again≈øt the Air, and the a≈ø≈øaults of other Creatures, they get ≈øhelter in ≈øuch ≈øhells as they find mo≈øt convenient, which, for the mo≈øt part, is that of Perriwinkles, but as they grow bigger they ≈øhift their ≈øhells, and go into bigger; their Foot, or In≈øtrument, is like a Crab's-claw, wherewith they clo≈øe the entrance of their ≈øhells, for the ≈øecurity of their bodies: if they be ≈øet neer the fire, they for≈øake their Quarters, but if it be pre≈øented to them, to get it again, they go in backward; when they de≈øign to change quarters, which they are very ≈øubject to do, there happens a furious Ingagement, managed with their cla≈øping In≈øtrument, 'till the ≈øtronge≈øt gets po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, which he enjoys very peaceably during his plea≈øure.

There is likewi≈øe found in the≈øe parts a mon≈øtrous Spider, which when ≈øhe ≈øpreads her legs, is ≈øo large, that ≈øhe takes up above the breadth of a man's hand, who≈øe body con≈øi≈øts of two parts, one round, and the other flat, le≈ø≈øer at one end, like a Pigeons Egg, with a hole in the back, which is as it were their Navel; it is armed with two ≈øharp Tu≈øhes, which are very ≈øolid, black, and ≈øhining; ≈øo that there are ≈øome that make u≈øe of them for Tooth-pickers, being fir≈øt ≈øet in Gold, which are counted to have a power of pre≈øerving from corruption and pain, rubbing the places therewith; when they come to be old, they are clothed with a ≈øwarthy Down, which is as ≈øoft as Velvet: they have about ten Feet, each having four joynts, and at the ends armed with a black, hard Horn. They ≈øhift their old Skins every Year, and al≈øo their Tu≈øhes; they feed on Flies, and ≈øuch Vermin; and in ≈øome places it hath been ob≈øerved, that their Webs are of ≈øuch a ≈øtrength, that ≈ømall Birds can hardly get them≈øelves from it.

There is al≈øo a very lovely Animal,Animals. called the Fly-catcher, it hath four Legs, and is of a very ≈ømall ≈øize, ≈øome of them ≈øeeming to be covered with fine gold or ≈øilver Brocado, and ≈øeveral with a mixture of Green, Gold, with other very delightful Colours; they are ≈øo very familiar, that they will come boldly into Rooms, doing no mi≈øchief, but on the contrary, clear them of Flies, and ≈øuch kind of Vermin, which they perform with ≈øuch activity of flight, that the cunning of Hunt≈ømen is not to be compared to it, for he generally lies down where he expects the Fly to come, keeping his eye always fixed thereon, putting his
head into as many different po≈øtures, as the Fly removes places, and ≈øtanding upon his fore-feet, gapes after it, his little mouth being half open, as if he had ≈øwallowed it in hope; and if one come near him, and make never ≈øo great a noi≈øe, it will not di≈øturb him, and at la≈øt, having an opportunity, he goes direct on his prey, very rarely mi≈ø≈øing of it. They are ≈øo extraordinary tame, that they will come at Dinner time upon the very Table, and endeavour to catch Flies upon their Hands or Clothes, being extraordinary neat and clean things: the Eggs they lay are as big as Pea≈øe, which they leave to be hatched by the Sun, covering of it fir≈øt with Sand: they are no ≈øooner killed, but all their beauty vani≈øheth, and they become pale. It may be counted a ≈øort of Camelion, partaking of the colour of tho≈øe things on which it makes its ordinary re≈øidence, for being about Palm-Trees, it is green, and about Orange-Trees, yellow, and the like.

The Palm-Worm is remarkable from its infinite number of Feet, which are like Bri≈øtles under his Body, which, if pur≈øued, help him to creep with incredible ≈øwiftne≈øs. It's half a foot long, the upper part covered with ≈øwarthy Scales, which are hard, and joynted one within another, like the Tiles of a Hou≈øe; but the mo≈øt danger in this Creature is, that he hath a kind of Claw, both in Head and Tail, wherewith he pierces ≈øo home, and poy≈øons the wound he makes therewith, that for the ≈øpace of 24 hours the party feels great pain.

There was ≈øeveral years ≈øince brought from thence a Bird about the bigne≈øs and ≈øhape of a Swallow, only two large Feathers on the Tail, a little ≈øhorter, and the Beak turned down,
like a Parrot, and its Feet like Ducks; its only black under the Belly, ≈øomething white, like our Swallows; in ≈øhort, it is ≈øo very like them, that it may be called the Swallow of America.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION OF THE I≈øland of ANTEGO.
div.p: Its Situation.THE I≈øland of Antego is ≈øeated in the Latitude of 16 Degrees, and 11 Minutes.

Extent.It is in length about 6 or 7 Leagues, and much of the ≈øame breadth in ≈øeveral places; The Acce≈øs to it is very dangerous for Shipping, by rea≈øon of the Rocks which incompa≈øs it: It was conceived heretofore, that it was not to be inhabited, upon pre≈øumption that there was no fre≈øh Water in it; but the Engli≈øh, who have planted them≈øelves in it, have met with ≈øome few Springs of fre≈øh Water; be≈øides which, the Inhabitants, which are about 8 or 900 per≈øons, have made ≈øeveral Ponds and Ci≈øterns for the pre≈øerving of Rain-water.
The CommoditiesIts Commodities. of this I≈øle are Sugar, Indico, Ginger, and Tobacco, &c.

This I≈øle doth abound with Fi≈øh of all ≈øorts,Their Fi≈øh. among≈øt which the Shark-fi≈øh de≈øerves remark; it is a kind of Sea-Wolf, or Sea-Dog, the mo≈øt devouring of all Fi≈øhes, and the mo≈øt greedy of Mans-fle≈øh, and therefore exceeding dangerous to tho≈øe that ≈øwim; he lives altogether by prey, and generally follows Ships, to feed on the filth ca≈øt out of them into the Sea. The≈øe Mon≈øters ≈øeem yellow in the water; ≈øome of them are of a va≈øt length and bigne≈øs, in≈øomuch that they are able to cut a man in two at one bite; their Skin ≈øo rough, that they polli≈øh Wood with it, in≈øtead of Files; their Heads are flat, and the opening of their Mouths is under their Snout, ≈øo that they are forced to turn their Bellies almo≈øt upward when they ≈øeize their prey; their Teeth are very ≈øharp and broad, jagged like a Saw, ≈øome having three or four ranks in each Jaw-bone, they lye within their Gums, but ≈øufficiently appear when there is occa≈øion. The≈øe cruel Sea-Dogs are attended by two or three ≈ømall Fi≈øhes, and ≈øometimes more, which go before them with ≈øuch ≈øwiftne≈øs and exactne≈øs, that they go either forward or ≈øtay as he doth: The Meat of him is not good, but the Brains are found to be good and profitable again≈øt the Stone and Gravel.

There is likewi≈øe found another ravenous Sea-Mon≈øter, called the Becune, a dreadful enemy to Man-kind, in ≈øhape like a Pike, being about ≈øeven or eight foot long; he lives by prey, and furiou≈øly fa≈øtens, like a Blood-hound, on the Men he perceives in the water. He carries away what≈øoever he once fa≈øtens on, and his Teeth are ≈øo venomous, that the lea≈øt touch of them becomes mortal, if ≈øome ≈øovereign Antidote be not immediately
applied, to divert and abate the Poy≈øon.

There are another ≈øort of Becunes, by ≈øome called Sea Wood-Cocks, their Beaks being ≈øomewhat like a Wood-Cock's Bill, only the upper part much longer than the lower, and moves both Jaws with like facility, ≈øome of them being four foot long, and twelve inches broad near the Head, which is ≈øomewhat like a Swines, with two large Eyes extreamly ≈øhining; he hath two Fins on the ≈øides, and under the Belly a large Plume, ri≈øing higher, like a Cock's Comb, reaching from Head to Tail: Be≈øides a long ≈øolid Beak, it hath two ≈øorts of Horns, hard and black, and about a foot and a half in length, which hang down under his Throat, and are particular to this kind of Fi≈øh, and the≈øe he can ea≈øily hide in a hollow place under his Belly, which ≈øerves them for a ≈øheath; it hath no Scales, but a rough, black Skin on the Back, and the Meat is eatable.

Another Fi≈øh, found about the≈øe I≈ølands, is called the Sea ∆≤rchin, or Hedge-Hog, and rightly de≈øerves that Name; it is round as a Ball, and full of exceeding ≈øharp Prickles, which makes it to be feared, and by ≈øeveral it is called the Armed Fi≈øh; they are ≈øent as Pre≈øents to tho≈øe that are curious, to hang in their Clo≈øets.
There is great plenty of mo≈øt ≈øorts of Wild Fowl, and not wanting in Veni≈øon and Tame Cattel. The Commodities this I≈øland affords are Sugar, Indico, Ginger, and Tobacco, &c.

The Sea-Parrots are very admirable, having extraordinary ≈øparkling and beautiful Eyes, the Ball whereof being as clear as Cri≈øtal, inclo≈øed within a circle as green as an Emerald, of which colour are the Scales on their Backs; they have no Teeth, but Jaws above and below of a ≈øolid bone, very
≈øtrong, of the ≈øame colour with their Scales, and divided into little compartiments, very beautiful to the Eye; they live on Shell-fi≈øh, and they cru≈øh, as between two Mil≈øtones, with their hard Jaws, Oy≈øters, Mu≈øcles, and other Shell-fi≈øh, to get out the Meat. They are an excellent ≈øort of Fi≈øh to eat, and ≈øo great, that ≈øome of them have weighed upward of twenty pound.

The Dorado, by ≈øome called the Sea-Bream, by others the Amber-fi≈øh, is al≈øo common in the≈øe parts; ≈øo called, becau≈øe in the water the Head ≈øeems to be of a green guilt, and the re≈øt of the Body as yellow as Gold. It takes great plea≈øure and delight in following of Ships, but being ≈øo ≈øwift, is very hard to take, being extraordinary well furni≈øhed for ≈øwimming, having the fore-part of the Head ≈øharp; the Back bri≈øtles with prickles reaching to the Tail, which is forked; two Fins on each ≈øide the Head, and as many under the Belly, and the whole Body rather broad than big; all which give him a ≈øtrange command of the water: he is as good Meat as a Trout or Salmon; they are caught only with a piece of white Linnen tyed to the Hook.

This I≈øland al≈øo abounds with divers ≈øorts of Fowls and Birds;Fowls and Birds. tho≈øe of more than an ordinary kind are the Canades, which ≈øome count the mo≈øt beautiful Bird in the World, being under the Belly and Wings of a waving Aurora colour; the Back and one half of the Wings of a very bright Sky-colour; the Tail and greater Feathers of Wings are mixt with a ≈øparkling Carnation, diver≈øified with a Sky; upon the Back it is gra≈øs-green with ≈øhining black, which very much addeth to the Gold and Azure of the other Plumage; but the mo≈øt beautiful part is the Head covered with a kind of
Murrey-down, chequered with green, yellow, and a pale blew, which reaches waving down to his Back, the Eye-lids being white, and the Apple of the Eye of a mo≈øt excellent yellow, and red like a Ruby ≈øet in Gold; it hath upon the Head a Tuft, or Cap of Feathers, of a Vermilion red, ≈øparkling like a lighted Coal, which is incompa≈ø≈øed by other ≈ømaller Feathers of a Pearl colour. It is about the bigne≈øs of a Phea≈øant, and exceeding kind and familiar with its friends, but as ≈øevere to its enemies.

The Flamot is an exceeding large and beautiful Bird, about the bigne≈øs of a wild Goo≈øe; his Beak is like a Spoon, his Legs and Neck very long, ≈øo that his Body is three foot from the ground, their Feathers being white when they are young, after Murrey, and when they come to be old, of a bright Carnation, being rarely ≈øeen but in great companies; and their hearing and ≈ømelling is ≈øo perfect, that they ≈ømell the Hunt≈ømen and Fire-arms at a large di≈øtance, and therefore, for fear of ≈øurprize, they make their aboad in the mid≈øt of the Fens, one of them being always Continel while they are ≈øearching about the waters for a livelihood; as ≈øoon as he hears the lea≈øt noi≈øe, or ≈øees a man, he takes his flight, and makes a great cry, for a ≈øignal to the re≈øt to follow him: when the Hunt≈ømen take them, they get the wind of them, that they may not ≈ømell the Powder, and covering them≈øelves with an Ox-hide, creep on their hands and feet 'till they get ≈øuch an opportunity that they are ≈øure of killing them.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION OF THE I≈øland of St. VINCENT.
div.p:
THE I≈øland of St. Vincent lies in the latitude of 16 degrees North from the Line, and is about 24 Miles in length, and 18 in breadth,Situation. wherein are ≈øeveral high Mountains, having between them exceeding fruitful Plains, yielding good ≈øtore of Sugar Canes, which grow naturally without planting: It is well water'd with Rivers, and hath ≈øeveral convenient Harbours and Bays for Shipping. The Engli≈øh have here ≈øome ≈øettlement, but are not very powerful, it being more populous of Caribeans, than of any po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by them, who have here many fair Villages, where they dwell exceeding plea≈øant, without the lea≈øt di≈øturbance; and though they are jealous of tho≈øe Strangers that live near them, and keep Guard when they come upon their Roads, yet they do not deny Ca≈ø≈øavy Bread, Water, Fruits, and other Provi≈øions growing in their Country, to them that want them, taking in exchange Wedges, Hooks, and other Implements of Iron, which they much e≈øteem. Their ≈øimplicity is very remarkable in ≈øeveral things, as in admiring our Fire-Arms, but
e≈øpecially Fire-Locks, to which they ≈øee no fire put, as to Muskets, and therefore believe Maboya, or the Devil, ≈øets them on fire; they believe when the Moon is Eclip≈øed, the Devil eats her; they daunce all night, making a noi≈øe with Gourds, wherein are many pebble ≈øtones; when they ≈ømell any evil ≈øcent, they cry, Maboya, or the Devil, is here, let us be gone from him.

Some time ≈øince, mo≈øt of the Caribeans were per≈øwaded, that Gun-powder was the Seed of ≈øome Hearb, in≈øomuch that ≈øome of them ≈øowed it in their Gardens. They never make u≈øe of Salt, accounting it very prejudicial to health, and when they ≈øee Chri≈øtians u≈øe it, cry, Compere, thou ha≈øtneth thy own death; but in≈øtead thereof, they ≈øea≈øon all things with American Pepper: Neither do they eat Swines-fle≈øh, for this ≈øimple rea≈øon, lea≈øt they ≈øhould have ≈ømall Eyes like that Bea≈øt, which they judge the greate≈øt deformity; nor Tortoi≈øe or Turtle, le≈øt they ≈øhould participate of its lazine≈øs and ≈øtupidity. They have no notion of a Deity, ≈øo that neither Prayers, Ceremonies, Sacrifices, or any Exerci≈øe or A≈ø≈øembly what≈øoever, is to be found among≈øt them; but ≈øay, the Earth is their indulgent Mother, who furni≈øhes them with all things nece≈ø≈øary to Life. If any di≈øcour≈øe to them about God, and the My≈øteries of our Religion, they hearken attentively, but in the end, an≈øwer as it were in je≈øt, Friend, thou art very eloquent and ≈øubtile, I wi≈øh I could talk as well as thee. Nay, they ≈øometimes ≈øay, That if they ≈øhould be per≈øwaded by ≈øuch Di≈øcour≈øes, their Neighbours would laugh at them. A certain Caribean being at work on a Sunday, Moun≈øieur Montel ≈øaid to him, Friend, He that made Heaven and Earth will be angry with thee for working
on this Day, for he hath appointed this Day for his Service: And I, replied the Savage very bluntly, am already very angry with him; for thou ≈øay'st he is Master of the World and the Sea≈øons, He it is therefore that hath forborn to ≈øend Rain in due time, and by rea≈øon of the great Drougth, hath cau≈øed my Manioc and my Potatoes to rot in the ground; now ≈øince he hath treated me ≈øo ill, I will work on every Sunday on purpo≈øe to vex him: A pregnant Example of the Brutality of this wretched People.

They have a natural ≈øentiment of ≈øome Divinity or Superior Power, that hath its Re≈øidence in Heaven, which they ≈øay is content to enjoy quietly the delights of his own felicity, without being offended at the ill actions of Men; and is endued with ≈øo great goodne≈øs, as not to take any Revenge, even of his Enemies, from whence they render Heaven neither Honour nor Adoration, interpreting its liberality and long-≈øufferance, an effect either of its weakne≈øs or indifference towards Mankind, believing that there are a number of Good and Evil Spirits, the Good being their Gods, and every one imagines he has one particularly de≈øign'd for his Conduct, yet will not acknowledge them Creators of the World: And when the Chri≈øtians tell them, we adore that God who made Heaven and Earth, and cau≈øeth the Earth to bring forth Fruits and Herbs for our nouri≈øhment; they an≈øwer, It is true, thy God hath made the Heaven and Earth, of France, (or ≈øome other Country which they name) and cau≈øes the Wheat to grow there; but our God has made our Country, and cau≈øes our Manioc to grow. This Manioc is a Root of a ≈ømall Tree or Shrub, whereof the Caribeans make Bread. When they are recovered of ≈øome Di≈øea≈øe, they ≈øet a little Table at the end of
their Hutts, and upon it their Offerings, but without the lea≈øt Adoration or Prayers; yet they invocate their Fal≈øe Gods, when they de≈øire his pre≈øence; but this is done by their Prie≈øts, and that upon four occa≈øions. 1. To Demand Revenge. 2. To be Healed of Di≈øea≈øes. 3. To know the Event of their Wars. 4. To invocate them to carry away their Great Devil, or Maboya, for they never pray to him: His Invocation is by Singing ≈øome words, and burning Tobacco, the ≈øcent whereof is ≈øo plea≈øant, that it makes this little Devil appear. And when their ≈øeveral Prie≈øts call upon their ≈øeveral Gods together, as they ≈øpeak, the≈øe Gods, or rather Devils, rail, quarrel, and ≈øeem to fight with each other. The≈øe Daemons ≈øhelter them≈øelves ≈øometimes in the Bones of dead Men, taken out of the Graves, and wrapt in Cotton, and thereby give Oracles, ≈øaying, it is the Soul of the decea≈øed Per≈øon; they make u≈øe of them to bewitch their Enemies, the Sorcerers wrapping up the≈øe Bones with ≈øomething that belongs to the Enemy.

The≈øe Devils do al≈øo ≈øometimes enter into the Bodies of Women, and ≈øpeak by them, clearly an≈øwering all que≈øtions demanded: After the Boy or Prie≈øt is retir'd, the Devil ≈øtirs the Ve≈ø≈øels, and makes a noi≈øe with his Jaws, as if he were eating and drinking the Pre≈øents prepared for him, but the next day they find he hath not medled with any thing. The≈øe poor Wretches complain that ≈øometimes Maboya beats them ≈øeverely, which though ≈øome impute to melancholy Dreams, yet other Per≈øons of Quality and exqui≈øite Knowledge, who have lived long in St. Vincent's I≈øland, do affirm, that the Devils do effectually beat them, and they often ≈øhew on their Bodies the vi≈øible marks of the
blows they have received: Sometimes they make horrid complaint of his Cruelty, ≈øaying, That of late he is mightily incen≈øed again≈øt the Caribeans, accounting the Europeans happy that their Maboya doth not beat them. Tho≈øe who have been very conver≈øant with them, and have likewi ‚Ä¢ e been at their A≈ø≈øemblies, ≈øay, That notwith≈øtanding their Ignorance and Irreligion, they fear, more than Death, the Evil Spirit whom they call Maboya, for he doth many times appear to them in mo≈øt dreadful and hideous Shapes, and what is more remarkable, is, that this unmerciful and bloody Executioner, who is an in≈øatiable Murtherer from the beginning of the World, mo≈øt cruelly torments and wounds tho≈øe mi≈øerable People, when they are not ≈øo forward as he would have them to engage in War; ≈øo that when they are reproach'd with Blood-thir≈øtine≈øs, their an≈øwer is, They are forced thereto by Maboya again≈øt their Wills.

It is this mo≈øt cruel and bloody Spirit that cau≈øes them to act ≈øuch barbarous Cruelty upon tho≈øe they take in War, in relating which, I had need dip my Pen in Blood, being to draw ≈øuch a Picture which mu≈øt needs rai≈øe horror in the Beholder. In which there appears nothing but Inhumanity, Barbari≈øm and Rage, to ≈øee Rational Creatures devouring tho≈øe of the ≈øame kind with them, and filling them≈øelves with their fle≈øh and blood, a thing which Pagans heretofore thought ≈øo full of Execration, that they imagined the Sun withdrew him≈øelf, becau≈øe he would not give light to ≈øuch bloody Banquets. When the≈øe Cannibals, or Eastern Men, (here their proper Names) have brought home a Pri≈øoner of War of the Arovagnes, he belongs of right to him who either ≈øeized him in Fight, or took him running away; being brought to
this I≈øland, he keeps him ≈øafe in his Hou≈øe, and after he has made him fa≈øt four or five days, produces him upon ≈øome Solemn Day of Debauch, to ≈øerve for a Publick Sacrifice, to the mortal hatred of his Country-men toward that Nation. If any of their Enemies die on the place of Battel, they eat them there; they de≈øign only for Slavery the young Maids and Women taken in War; they have ta≈øted of all the Nations that frequent them, and upon experience affirm, that the French are the mo≈øt tender, and the Spaniards the harde≈øt of dige≈øtion; but now they feed on no Chri≈øtians at all.

They ab≈øtain from ≈øeveral Cruelties formerly u≈øed before they killed their Enemies, for now they think it enough to di≈øpatch them at a blow or two with a Club, and afterwards cut them into pieces, and having boyl'd them, they devour them: They heretofore put them to ≈øeveral torments before they gave them the mortal blow, which deplorable Relation they them≈øelves have given to tho≈øe who have been curious, from their own mouths. Tho≈øe who have been ≈øo unfortunate in the time of War, to fall as Pri≈øoners into their Hands, are not ignorant of the cruel torments they de≈øign again≈øt them, and therefore to arm them≈øelves with con≈øtancy, and to expre≈øs how generous a People the Arovagues are, march very chearfully to the place of Execution, being neither bound nor dragged thereto, but pre≈øent them≈øelves with a mild and ≈øteady countenance before the whole A≈ø≈øembly, which they know de≈øire nothing ≈øo much as their Death, and expecting their abu≈øes and bitter di≈øcour≈øes, prevent them in the≈øe tetms I know well enough upon what account you have brought me to this Place, I doubt not
but you are de≈øirous to fill your≈øelves with my blood, and that you are impatient to exerci≈øe your teeth upon my body; but you have not ≈øo much rea≈øon to triumph, to ≈øee me in this condition, nor I much to be troubled, my Country-men having put your Predece≈ø≈øors to greater mi≈øeries than you are now able to invent again≈øt me, and I have done my part with them in mangling, ma≈ø≈øacring and devouring your People, your Friends, and your Fathers; be≈øides this, I have Relations who will not fail to revenge my quarrel with advantage upon you, and upon your Children, for the mo≈øt inhumane tortures you intend again≈øt me; what torment ≈øoe-ever the mo≈øt ingenious cruelty can dictate to you, for the taking away of my life is nothing in compari≈øon of tho≈øe which my generous Nation prepares for you in exchange; therefore delay not the utmo≈øt of your cruelty any longer, and a≈ø≈øure your≈øelves, I both ≈ølight and laugh at it. Somewhat of this nature is that brave and bloody Bravado which we read of, a Bra≈øilean Pri≈øoner, ready to be devoured by his Enemies, Come on boldly (≈øaid he to them) and fea≈øt your≈øelves upon me, for at the ≈øame time you ≈øeed on your Fathers and Grand-fathers, who ≈øerved for nouri≈øhment for my Body; the≈øe Mu≈øcles, this Fle≈øh, and the≈øe Veins, are yours; blind Fools as you are, you do not ob≈øerve that the ≈øub≈øtance of the Members of your Ance≈øtors are yet to be ≈øeen in them, ta≈øt them well, and you will find the ta≈øt of your own fle≈øh.

The Great Soul of our Arovagues was not only in his Lips, but likewi≈øe ≈øhewed it al≈øo in the effects which follow his Bravado; for after the Company had a while endured his arrogant defiance without
out touching him, one among≈øt them came and burnt his Sides with a flaming Brand, another cut great gobbets of fle≈øh out of him, and had cut bigger if the bones would have admitted it, and then they ca≈øt Pepper into his wounds; others diverted them≈øelves in ≈øhooting Arrows at the poor Patient, and every one took plea≈øure in tormenting of him; but he ≈øuffer'd with the ≈øame unconcerned countenance, and expre≈ø≈øed not the lea≈øt ≈øen≈øe of pain. After they had thus ≈øported a long time with the poor wretch, and growing weary of in≈øulting and out-braving by his con≈øtancy, which ≈øeemed ≈øtill the ≈øame, one of them came, and with one blow di≈øpatch'd him with his Club. This is the U≈øage wherewith the Caribeans heretofore treated their Pri≈øoners of War, but now they think it enough to put them to a ≈øpeedy death. As ≈øoon as this unfortunate per≈øon is thus laid dead upon the place, the young Men take the Body, and having wa≈øhed it, cut it in pieces, and then boyl ≈øome part, and broyl ≈øome upon wooden Frames, made for that purpo≈øe, like a Gridiron. When this dete≈øtable Di≈øh is ready, and ≈øea≈øoned according to their Palats, they divide it into ≈øo many parts as there are Per≈øons pre≈øent, and joyfully devour it, thinking the World cannot afford equal therewith, ≈øo that the Women lick the very ≈øticks whereon the Fat dropped, not ≈øo much from the deliciou≈øne≈øs they find in that kind of ≈øu≈øtenance, as from the exce≈ø≈øive plea≈øure they receive in being revenged in that manner on their chiefe≈øt Enemies; and to heighten this rage and hatred again≈øt the A ‚Ä¢ ovagues, they ≈øave the Fat that comes from it, and pre≈øerve it very carefully to put ≈øome few drops thereof into their Sauces at their ≈øolemn Entertainments, ≈øo to perpetuate, as
much as lies in their power, the motive of Revenge.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION OF THE I≈øland of DOMINICA.
div.p:
THE I≈øland of Dominica is ≈øituated in the Latitude of 15 Degrees,Its Situation. 30 Minutes, and about 12 Leagues in length, and 8 in breadth. On the We≈øt-≈øide is a very convenient Harbour for Ships. It is very mountainous in the mid≈øt, which incompa≈ø≈øes an inacce≈ø≈øable bottom, where, from the tops of certain Rocks, may be ≈øeen an infinite number of Dragons, Vipers, and other mo≈øt venomous and dreadful creatures, whom none dares come near, yet there are many Fertile Villages, producing ≈øeveral Commodities, but chiefly Tobacco, which is planted by the Engli≈øh; but the Natives, which are Canibals, and very barbarous, doth much hinder the coming of the Engli≈øh to ≈øettle there; for the Canribeans are very populous in it, and have a long time entertained tho≈øe who come to vi≈øit them with a ≈øtory of a va≈øt mon≈øtrous Serpent that frequented that bottom; affirming, that there was on its Head a very ≈øparkling Stone, like a Carbuncle of ine≈øtimable price, which it commonly
covered with a thin moving skin, like a Mans eyelid, but when he drank or ≈øported him≈øelf in that deep bottom, it was fully and plainly di≈øcovered, the Rocks and all about the place receiving a wonderful lu≈øtre from the fire, i≈ø≈øuing out of that precious Crown.

They are generally very friendly with the French, and upon the approach of any of their Ships, ≈øeveral Canoes, with three or four Indians in each of them, immediately meet them and conduct them to the Havens, where they may ≈øafely Anchor. And having pre≈øented the Captain and others Officers with the choice≈øt of tho≈øe Country-Fruits, they commonly bring them, they offer the re≈øt in exchange, for Fi≈øhing-hooks, and other ≈øuch kind of trifles, which they account precious. But to the Engli≈øh they have a great aver≈øion, conceived, as is reported, upon this occa≈øion: Some evil-minded Engli≈øh-men, under the Flags of other Nations, having, by pretended kindne≈øs and little gifts, gotten divers of them on board their Ships, and made them merry with Aqua Vitae and Brandy, which they love extreamly, they ≈øuddenly hoi≈øted up ≈øail, and carried away tho≈øe poor, innocent People, who expected no ≈øuch Treachery, from ≈øuch pretended Friends. And although the Engli≈øh have indeavoured to ≈øatisfie them, yet ≈øo implacable is their temper, that they can't be per≈øwaded to forget or forgive the injury; but, next to the Arovagues, a People on the Continent, they hate the Engli≈øh as their wor≈øt Enemies: and to ≈øuch an height of envy hath this Action exa≈øperated them, that they hate the very Language, and can't indure to hear it ≈øpoken, and if a French man, or any other at peace with them, happen, through forgetfulne≈øs, to make u≈øe of an Engli≈øh Expre≈ø≈øion,
in di≈øcour≈øing with them, he runs the hazard of contracting his envy for ever upon him≈øelf. Nor do they fail, when they find opportunity, to make incur≈øions into Mont≈øerrat, Antego, and other of our Engli≈øh Settlements, plundering and burning down their Hou≈øes, and carrying away ≈øuch Men, Women and Children as they can get into their hands by ≈øurpri≈øe, but do not eat them as they do the Arovagues.

They can't indure to be called Cannibals: they do eat the fle≈øh of their enemies, which they ≈øay is to gratifie their revenge, and not out of any delicacy they find in the meat. They are for the mo≈øt part of a good tractable di≈øpo≈øition, and ≈øuch enemies to ≈øeverity, that tho≈øe of them that fall into the hands of the Europeans, or any other Nation, if their Ma≈øters treat them with rigour, they die out of pure grief. They de≈øpi≈øe Riches, and often reproach the Europeans for their avarice and exce≈ø≈øive de≈øire of Wealth, not only for them≈øelves, but tho≈øe that come after them too, ≈øince the Earth will find a ≈øufficiency for all men, who will take pains to manure it; telling them, that they never perplex and torture them≈øelves with cares for tho≈øe things whereby their Lives are pre≈øerved; and yet, for any thing they can ≈øee to the contrary, they are fatter in fle≈øh and much happier in the whole cour≈øe of their Lives, than tho≈øe that do always eat and drink of the be≈øt. And, to ≈øay the truth, they are a People that live without ambition, vexation, or di≈øquieting them≈øelves with a fruitle≈øs thoughtfulne≈øs about future Events; having no de≈øire of acquiring Wealth and Honour, ≈ølighting Gold and Silver as things not worth the valuing, prote≈øting they can't but wonder we
≈øhould e≈øteem, ≈øo much as we do, ≈øeeing we are ≈øo well furni≈øhed with things much more valuable and beautifuller, as they e≈øteem Gla≈øs, Cri≈øtal, and the like to be. When they ≈øee any of the Chri≈øtians are perplex'd, they cry, Compeer, which ≈øignifies Friend or Go≈ø≈øip, How mi≈øerable dost thou make thy Life, by expo≈øing thy ≈øelf to ≈øuch long and dangerous Voyages, oppre≈ø≈øing thy ≈øelf with cares and the inordinate de≈øire of getting Wealth, which puts thee to all this trouble, and is the occa≈øion of the various inconveniencies thou every day meetest withal, from which we are wholly free. And that which yet ≈øeems to me much ≈øtranger, is, your being no le≈øs di≈øquieted about the Goods you have already gotten, than you are about tho≈øe you de≈øire to obtain. Thou art always in fear lest ≈øomebody ≈øhould rob thee by Land or by Sea, or that thy Goods ≈øhould ≈øuffer Shipwreck, or thou ≈øhouldest ≈øuffer dammage by their coming too late for the Market. And by this means thou growest old before thy time, thy Hair turns grey, thy Body waxes lean thy Forehead wrinkled, a thou≈øand inconveniencies attend thy Per≈øon, and as many afflictions ≈øurround thy Heart, and hurries thee with the greater ≈øpeed to thy Grave. What a ≈øtrange thing 'tis, that thou canst not content thy ≈øelf with what thy own Countrey produces, and contemn Riches, as thou ≈øeest us do. Or tell me, Doth that Wealth which you Chri≈øtians pur≈øue with ≈øo much eagerne≈øs, tend to your advancement in holine≈øs? doth it prevent your dying, or can you carry any of it into that Eternity you ≈øometimes talk of.

Sometimes they will upbraid the Europeans with manife≈øt inju≈øtice, in invading their Country; Having driven us from Mevis, Mont≈øerrat, Antego, &c. none of all which did by any pretence of right belong to you, and threatning ≈øtill to take away what is left;
What ≈øhall become of the poor Caribeans! Whither ≈øhall we fly next for Habitations? would you have us go and dwell in the Sea with the Fi≈øhes? Which kind of Di≈øcour≈øes ≈øhew them not to be ≈øo Savage as tho≈øe of St. Vincents.

They are great enemies to thieving, and live without di≈øtru≈øt of each other, frequently leaving their Hou≈øes and Plantations without any to look to them; but if they chance to lo≈øe any thing, though but a little Knife, they will weep and grieve a Week after; and if any Chri≈øtians live near, they pre≈øently ≈øu≈øpect them, and ≈øay, Some Chri≈øtian hath been here. And in their Complaints to any of the French Governours, this is commonly the fir≈øt: Thy Mariners (for ≈øo they call all ≈øtrangers) have taken away a Knife (or ≈øome ≈øuch ≈ømall trifle) out of my Cottage.

They are a People linked in one common intre≈øt, and love each other extreamly, ≈øo that very rarely any difference ari≈øeth among≈øt them; but if they are by chance offended, though it be by one of their own People, they ≈øeldom ever forget it, but ≈øtudy all imaginable ways of revenge, and when their Sorcerers tell them ≈øuch an one hath done them the Mi≈øchief that happens to them, they watch all opportunities to kill him, crying out, He hath bewitched me, I will be revenged on him.

They bear great re≈øpect to ancient people, the younger ≈øort complying in all things with their ≈øentiments and wills. Their Youths have no conver≈øation either with their Maids or married Women, and are generally le≈øs amorous than tho≈øe of the Female Sex, though both are very cha≈øt, a Vertue worthy admiration in a barbarous People that go naked. But, by the pernicious
Examples the Chri≈øtians have ≈øet them, they are now grown ≈øomewhat more loo≈øe. They are great lovers of Neatne≈øs, which is not very u≈øual among Savages, for if a man ≈øhould but ea≈øe him≈øelf in their Garden where their Potatoes grow, they will for≈øake them.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION OF NEW-JERSEY.
div.p: NEW-JERSEY is part of the Province of New-Albion aforementioned, and is ≈øubdivided into East and West-Jer≈øey. East-Jer≈øey lies between 39 and 41 Degrees of North-Latitude,Its Situation. being about 12 Degrees more to the South than the City of London; it is bounded on the South-Ea≈øt by the main Sea; Ea≈øt, by that va≈øt Navigable Stream, called Hud≈øon's River; We≈øt, by a Line of Divi≈øion, which ≈øeparates it from West-Jer≈øey; and North, upon the main Land, and extends it≈øelf in length on the Sea-Coa≈øts, and along Hud≈øon's River One hundred Engli≈øh Miles and upward.

The ProprietorsProprietors. of this Province, who in 1682. were William Penn, Robert West, Thomas Rudyard, Samuel Groom, Thomas Hart, Richard Mew, Thomas Wilcox,
Ambro≈øe Rigg, John Heywood, Hugh Hart≈øhorn, Clement Plum≈øtead, and Thomas Cooper, have publi≈øhed the following Account, for the information and incouragement of all Per≈øons, who are inclined to ≈øettle them≈øelves, Families, and Servants, in that Country, which may give ≈øufficient ≈øatisfaction of the Situation, Conveniencies, and Product thereof.

The conveniency of Situation, temperature of Air, and fertility of Soyl is ≈øuch, that there is no le≈øs then ≈øeven con≈øiderable Towns, viz. Shrewsbury, Chief Towns. Middle-Town, Burgin, Newark, Elizabeth-Town, Woodbridge, and Pi≈øcataway: which are all inhabited by a ≈øober and indu≈øtrious People, who have nece≈ø≈øary Provi≈øions for them≈øelves and Families, and for the comfortable Entertainment of Strangers and Travellers. And this Colony is experimentally found generally to agree well with Engli≈øh Con≈øtitutions.

For Navigation it hath the≈øe advantages,Its Advantanges for Navigation. not only to be ≈øituate along the Navigable part of Hud≈øon's River, but lies al≈øo fifty Miles on the main Sea. And near the mid≈øt of this Province is that noted Bay for Ships, within Sand-Hook, very well known not to be inferiour to any in America, where Ships not only harbour in greate≈øt ≈øtorms, but ride ≈øafe with all winds, and ≈øail in and out thence, as well in Winter as Summer.

For Fi≈øhery, the Sea-banks there are very well ≈øtored with variety of Fi≈øh, not only ≈øuch as are profitable for Trans≈øportation, but fit for Food there; As Whales, Its Fi≈øh. Cod-fi≈øh, Cole, and Hake-fi≈øh, large Mackarel,
and many other ≈øorts of flat and ≈ømall Fi≈øh. The Bay al≈øo, and Hud≈øon's River, are plentifully ≈øtored with Sturgeon, Great Ba≈ø≈øe, and other Scale-fi≈øh; Eels and Shell-fi≈øh, as Oy≈øters, &c. in great plenty and ea≈øie to take.

This Counrry is plentifully ≈øupplied with lovely Springs,Waters. Rivulets, In-land Rivers, and Creeks which fall into the Sea, and Hud≈øon's River, in which is much plenty and variety of fre≈øh-Fi≈øh and Water-Fowl.

There is al≈øo great plenty of Oak-Timber, Trees. fit for Shipping, and Ma≈øts for Ships, and other variety of Wood, like the adjacent Colonies; as, Che≈ønut, Walnut, Poplar, Cedar, A≈øh, Fir, &c. fit for building, within the Countrey.

The Land or Soyl (as in other places) varies in goodne≈øs and richne≈øs,Its Fertility. but generally fertil, and with much ≈ømaller labour than in England, produceth plentiful Crops of all ≈øorts of Engli≈øh Grain, be≈øides Indian Corn, which Engli≈øh Planters find not only to be of va≈øt encrea≈øe, but very whol≈øome, and good in u≈øe. It al≈øo produceth good Flax and Hemp, which they now ≈øpin and manufacture into Linnen Cloth. There's ≈øufficient Meadow and Mari≈øh to their Up-lands; and the very Barrens there (as they are called) are not like ≈øome in England, but produce Gra≈øs fit for grazing Cattel in Summer ≈øea≈øon.

The Countrey is well ≈øtored with Wild Deer, Fruits & Fowls. Conies, and wild Fowl of ≈øeveral ≈øorts; as, Turkeys, Pigeons, Partridges, Plover, Quails, wild Swans, Gee≈øe, Ducks, &c. in great plenty. It produceth
variety of good delicious Fruits; as, Grapes, Plums, Mulberries, Apricocks, Peaches, Pears, Apples, Quinces, Water-Melons, &c. which are here in England planted in Orchards and Gardens. The≈øe, as al≈øo many other Fruits which come to perfection in England, are the more natural product of this Country.

There are already great ≈øtore of Hor≈øes, Cows, Hogs, Cattel. and ≈øome Sheep, which may be bought at rea≈øonable prices, with Engli≈øh Money, or Engli≈øh Commodities, or Man's Labour, where Moneys and Goods are wanting. What ≈øort of Mine or Minerals are in the Bowels of the Earth, aftertime mu≈øt produce, the Inhabitants not having yet employed them≈øelves in ≈øearch thereof. But there is already a Melting-Furnace and Forge ≈øet up in this Colony, where is made good Iron, which is of great benefit to the Country. It is exceedingly well furni≈øhed with ≈øafe and convenient HarboursHarbours. for Shipping; which is of great advantage to that Countrey, and affords already for Exportation great plenty of Hor≈øes; and al≈øo Beef, Pork, Pipe-≈øtaves, Boards, Bread, Flower, Wheat, Barley, Rie, Indian Corn, Butter and Chee≈øe, which they export for Barbadoes, Jamaica, Mevis, and other adjacent I≈ølands; as al≈øo to Portugal, Spain, the Canaries, &c. Their Whale-Oyl and Whale-Fins, Bever, Monkey, Racoon and Martin-Skins (which this Countrey produceth) they tran≈øport for England.

The Situation and Soyl of this Country may invite any who are inclined to tran≈øport them≈øelves into tho≈øe parts of America: For 1. It being con≈øiderably peopled, and ≈øituate on the Sea-coa≈øt,
with convenient Harbours, and ≈øo near adjacent to the Province of New York and Long I≈øland, being al≈øo well peopled Colonies, may be proper for Merchants, Trade≈ømen and Navigators. 2. It is likewi≈øe proper for ≈øuch who are inclined to Fi≈øhery; the whole Coa≈øt and very Harbours-mouths being fit for it; which has been no ≈ømall Ri≈øe to New-England People, and may be here carried on al≈øo with great advantage. 3. For its Soyl, it is proper for all indu≈øtrious Husbandmen, and ≈øuch who by hard Labour, here on Rack-Rents are ≈øcarce able to maintain them≈øelves, much le≈øs to rai≈øe an E≈øtate for their Children, may, with God's Ble≈ø≈øing on their Labours, there live comfortably, and provide well for their Families. 4. For Carpenters, Brick-layers, Ma≈øons, Smiths, Mill-wrights, Wheel-wrights, Bakers, Tanners, Taylors, Weavers, Shoomakers, Hatters, and all or mo≈øt Handicrafts, where their Labour is much more valued than in the≈øe parts, and Provi≈øions much cheaper. 5. And chiefly for ≈øuch of the above-mentioned, or any other who upon ≈øolid Grounds and weighty Con≈øiderations, are inclined in their minds to go into tho≈øe parts, without which, their going there cannot be comfortable, or an≈øwer their expectation.

The Indian Natives are but few,The Inhabitants. comparative to the neighbouring Colonies; and tho≈øe that are there, are ≈øo far from being formidable or injurious to the Planters and Inhabitants, that they are really ≈øerviceable and advantageous to the Engli≈øh; not only in hunting and taking the Deer, and other wild Creatures, and catching of Fi≈øh and Fowl fit for Food in their Sea≈øons, but in the killing and de≈øtroying of Bears, Wolves,
Foxes, and other Vermin and Poltry, who≈øe Skins and Furs they bring the Engli≈øh, and ≈øell at a le≈øs price than the value of Time an Engli≈øhman mu≈øt ≈øpend to take them. As for the Con≈øtitutions of the Country, they were made in the time of John Lord Barclay and Sir George Carteret, the late Proprietors thereof; in which ≈øuch provi≈øion was made for Liberty in Matters of Religion, and Property in their E≈øtates, that under the Forms thereof that Colony has been con≈øiderably peopled, and that much, from the adjacent Countries, where they have not only for many years enjoyed their E≈øtates according to the Conce≈ø≈øions, but al≈øo to an interrupted exerci≈øe of their particular Per≈øwa≈øions in Matters of Religion; and we the pre≈øent Proprietors, ≈øo ≈øoon as any per≈øons here in England, or el≈øewhere, are willing to be engaged with us, ≈øhall be ready and de≈øirous to make ≈øuch farther Additions and Supplements to the ≈øaid Con≈øtitutions, as ≈øhall be thought fit for the encouragement of all Planters and Adventurers, and for the ≈øaid Colony with a ≈øober and indu≈øtrious People.
Having with all po≈ø≈øible brevity given an account of the Country, we ≈øhall ≈øay ≈øomething as to the di≈øpo≈øition of Lands there.

1. Our purpo≈øe is, with all convenient expedition, to erect and build our principal Town; which by rea≈øon of Scituation, mu≈øt in all probability be the mo≈øt con≈øiderable for Merchandize, Trade, and Fi≈øhery, in tho≈øe parts: It is de≈øigned to be placed upon a Neck or Point of rich Land, call'd Ambo-Point, lying on Raritor-River, and pointing to Sandy-Hook Bay, and near adjacent to the place where Ships in that great Harbour commonly ride at Anchor; a Scheme whereof
is already drawn, and tho≈øe who ≈øhall de≈øire to be ≈øatisfied therewith, may treat for a ≈øhare thereof.
2. As for encouragement of Servants, &c. we allow the ≈øame Priviledges as were provided in the Conce≈ø≈øions at fir≈øt.

3. Such who are de≈øirous to purcha≈øe any Lands in this Province, free from all charge, and to pay down their Purcha≈øe Moneys here, for any quantities of Acres; or that de≈øire to take up Lands there, upon any ≈ømall quit Rents to be re≈øerved, ≈øhall have Grants to them and their Heirs, on moderate and rea≈øonable terms.

4. Tho≈øe who are de≈øirous to Tran≈øport them≈øelves into tho≈øe parts before they Purcha≈øe, if any thing there pre≈øent to their ≈øatisfaction, we doubt not but the Terms of Purcha≈øe will be ≈øo moderate, equal and encouraging, that may engage them to ≈øettle in that Colony.

Our purpo≈øe being with all po≈ø≈øible Expedition to di≈øpatch Per≈øons thither, with whom they may Treat, and who ≈øhall have our full power in the Premi≈ø≈øes. As for Pa≈ø≈øages to this Province, Ships are going hence the whole year about, as well in Winter as Summer: Sand ‚Ä¢ y-hook-Bay being never Frozen, the u≈øual Price is 5 l. per Head,Pa≈ø≈øengers Prizes. as well Ma≈øter as Servant, who are above ten years of Age; and under ten years (and not Children at the Brea≈øt) pay 50 s. Sucking Children pay nothing. Carriage of GoodsFor Carriage of Goods. is u≈øu≈øally 40 s. per Tun, and ≈øometime le≈øs, as we can agree. The cheape≈øt and chiefe≈øt time of the year for Pa≈ø≈øage, is, from Mid≈øummer, till the later end of September, when many Virginia and Maryland
Ships are going out of England into tho≈øe Parts; and ≈øuch who take then their Voyage, arrive u≈øually in good time to Plant Corn-≈øufficient for next Summer.

The Goods to be carried there, are fir≈øt for Peoples own u≈øe, all ≈øorts of Apparel and Hou≈øhold≈øtuff, and al≈øo Uten≈øils for Husbandry and Building; and ≈øecondly, Linnen and Wollen Cloaths, and Stuffs ≈øitting for Apparel, &c. which are fit for Merchandize and Truck there in the Country, and that to good advantage for the Importer. La≈øtly, Although this Country (by rea≈øon of its being already con≈øiderably inhabited) may afford many Conveniences for Strangers, of which Unpoepled Countries are de≈øtitute, as Lodging, Victualling, &c. yet all Per≈øons inclined unto tho≈øe Parts, mu≈øt know, that in their Settlements there, they will find they mu≈øt have their Winter as well as Summer, they mu≈øt Labour before they Reap, and till their Plantations be cleared (in Summer time) they mu≈øt expect (as in all tho≈øe Countries) the Musketo Flies, Gnats, and ≈øuch like, may in hot and fair Weather give them ≈øome di≈øturbance, where people provide not again≈øt them, which as the Land is cleared, are le≈øs trouble≈øom.

The South and We≈øt Part of New-Jer≈øey lying on the Sea and Dela-ware River, is called We≈øt-Jer≈øey, We≈øt-Jer≈øey. of which Mr. Edward Billing is now Proprietor; it hath all the Conveniencies and Excellencies of the other Part afore-mention'd, and may be made one of the be≈øt Colonies in America, for the Situation, Air and Soil, the Ports, Creeks, good Harbours and Havens, being not Inferiour to any in that Part of the World, having no le≈øs than thirty Navigable Creeks, ranking them≈øelves
at a convenient di≈øtance upon the Sea, and that ≈øtately River of Dela-ware, the Shores thereof are generally very deep and bold.

The Engli≈øh that are ≈øettled here,Buying of Lands. buy the Lands of the Natives, and give them real ≈øati≈øfaction for the ≈øame, whereby they are a≈ø≈øured of their love and friend≈øhip for ever, and the poor Creatures are never the wor≈øe, but much better, as them≈øelves confe≈øs; being now ≈øupplied, by way of Trade, with all they want or ≈øtand in need of, Hunting and Fi≈øhing as they did before, except in inclo≈øed or planted Ground, bring home to the Engli≈øh ≈øeven or eight fat Bucks in a day.

There is a Town called Burlington, which will quickly be a place of great Trade; their Orchards are ≈øo laden with Fruit, that the very Branches have been torn away with the weight thereof; it is delightful to the eye, and mo≈øt delicious to the ta≈øte; Peaches in ≈øuch plenty, that they bring them home in Carts; they are very delicate Fruit, and hang almo≈øt like our Onions tied upon Ropes: They receive forty Bu≈øhels of good Engli≈øh Wheat, for one Bu≈øhel ≈øown. Cherries they have in abundance, and Fowl and Fi≈øh great plenty, with ≈øeveral that are unknown in England. There are likewi≈øe, Bears, Wolves, Foxes, Rattle-Snakes, and ≈øeveral other Creatures, as I imagin, (≈øaith my Author) becau≈øe the Indians bring ≈øuch Skins to ≈øell; but I have travelled ≈øeveral hundred of Miles to and fro, yet never, to my knowledge, ≈øaw one of them, except two Rattle-Snakes, and killed them both; ≈øo that the fear of them is more than the hurt: neither are we troubled with the Musk ‚Ä¢ to-fly in this place, our Land lying generally high and healthy, and they being commonly in
boggy ground. With common and rea≈øonable care there may in a few years be Hor≈øes, Beef, Pork, Flour, Bisket and Pea≈øe to ≈øpare; yea, this Country will produce Honey, Wax, Silk, Hemp, Flax, Hops, Woad, Rape≈øeed, Madder, Pota-≈øhes, Anni≈øeed, and Salt, Hides, raw or tann'd; and there is a very large va≈øt Creature, called a Moo≈øe, of who≈øe Skins are made excellent Buff; be≈øides the natural product of Pitch, Tar, Rozin, Turpentine, &c. As for Furs, they are Beaver, black Fox, and Otter, with divers other ≈øorts. The Tobacco is excellent upon the River Delaware. There may be very good fi≈øhing for Cod and Cu≈øh, as ≈øeveral have found by experience, who have caught great plenty of well-grown Fi≈øh. Upon the whole matter, this Province affords all that is either for the Nece≈ø≈øity, Conveniency, Profit or Plea≈øure of Humane Life; and it may therefore be rea≈øonably expected, that this Country, with the re≈øt of America, may in a few Ages be throughly peopled with Chri≈øtianity. And this ≈øhall ≈øuffice for New Jer≈øey.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION OF PENSYLVANIA.
div.p: IT is the Jus Gentium, or Law of Nations, that whatever wa≈øte or uncultivated Country is the di≈øcovery of any Prince, it is the Right of that Prince who was at the charge of that di≈øcovery: Now this Province is a Member of that part of America which the King of England's Ance≈øtors have been at the charge of di≈øcovering, and which they and he have taken care to pre≈øerve and improve; and his late Maje≈øty, of happy Memory, upon the Petition of William Penn, E≈øq (wherein he ≈øet forth his Father's Service, his own Sufferings, and his Lo≈ø≈øes, in relation to his Father's E≈øtate; and la≈øtly, his long and co≈øtly attendance without ≈øucce≈øs) was plea≈øed, in right and con≈øideration thereof, to make a grant to the ≈øaid William Pen, of all that Tract of Land in America, which is expre≈ø≈øed in the following Declaration to the Inhabitants and Planters of the Province of Pen≈øylvania.

body.p:
WHereas His Maje≈øty, in Con≈øideration of the Great Merit and Faithful Services of Sir William Penn, decea≈øed, and for divers other good Cau≈øes Him thereunto moving, hath been graciou≈øly plea≈øed, by Letters Patents, bearing Date the Fourth Day of March, la≈øt pa≈øt, To give and grant unto William Penn, E≈øq Son and Heir of the ≈øaid Sir William Penn, all that Tract of Land, called by the Name of Pen≈øylvania, as the ≈øame is bounded on the Ea≈øt by Delaware River, from Twelve Miles di≈øtance Northward of New-Ca≈øtle Town, unto the three and fortieth Degree of Northern Latitude, if the ≈øaid River doth extend ≈øo far Northward, then by the ≈øaid River ≈øo far as it doth extend: And from the Head of the ≈øaid River, the Ea≈øtern bounds to be determined by a Meridian-Line, to be drawn from the head of the ≈øaid River, unto the ≈øaid three and fortieth Degree, the ≈øaid Province to extend We≈øtward, five Degrees in Longitude, to be computed from the ≈øaid Ea≈øtern bounds; and to be bounded on the North by the beginning of the three and fortieth Degree of Northern Latitude; and on the South, by a Circle drawn at Twelve Miles di≈øtance from New-Ca≈øtle Northwards; and We≈øtwards, unto the beginning of the fortieth Degree of Northern Latitude, and then by a ≈øtrait Line We≈øtward to the Limit of Longitude above-mentioned,
together with all Powers, Preheminences, Iurisdictions nece≈ø≈øary for the Government of the ≈øaid Province, as by the ≈øaid Letters Patents, reference being thereunto had, doth more at large appear.

His Maje≈øty doth therefore hereby publi≈øh and declare His Royal Will and Plea≈øure, That all Per≈øons ≈øettled or inhabited within the Limits of the ≈øaid Province, do yield all due Obedience to the ≈øaid William Penn, his Heirs, and A≈ø≈øigns, as Ab≈øolute Proprietors and Governors thereof; As al≈øo to the Deputy or Deputies, Agents or Lieutenants, lawfully Commi≈ø≈øioned by him or them, according to the Powers and Authorities granted by the ≈øaid Letters Patents; Wherewith His Maje≈øty Expects and Requires a ready Compliance from all Per≈øons whom it may concern, as they tender His Maje≈øties Di≈øplea≈øure.

closer.dateline: Given at our Court at White-hall, the Second Day of April, 1681. in the Three and thirtieth Year of Our Reign.

div.p: The De≈øcription of the Province cannot better be given by any than by William Penn him≈øelf, who ≈øent the following Account from off the place, in a Letter dated from Philadelphia, Aug. 16. 1683.

div.head: For this Province, the general Condition of it take as followeth:
div.p: THE Country it≈øelf in its Soil, Air, Water, Sea≈øons, and Product, both Natural and Artificial, is not to be de≈øpi≈øed.

The Land contains divers ≈øorts of Earth; as Sand, yellow and black,Its Soil. poor and rich: Al≈øo Gravel, both loomy and du≈øty; and in ≈øome places a fa≈øt, fat Earth, like to our be≈øt Vales in England, e≈øpecially by Inland-Brooks and Rivers; God, in his wi≈ødom, hath ordered it ≈øo, that the Advantages of the Country are divided, the Back-Lands being generally three to one richer than tho≈øe that lye by Navigable Waters; we have much of another Soil, and that is a black, Ha≈øle-Mould, upon a ≈øtony or rocky bottom.
The AirIts Air. is ≈øweet and cleer, the Heavens ≈øerene, like the South-Parts of France, rarely over-ca≈øt, and as the Woods come by numbers of people to be more cleared, that it≈øelf will refine.

The WatersIts Waters. are generally good, for the Rivers and Brooks have mo≈øtly gravel and ≈øtony bottoms, and in number hardly credible. We have al≈øo Mineral Waters, that operate in the ≈øame manner with Barnet
and North-hall, not two Miles from Philadelphia.

For the Sea≈øons of the Year, having,Its Climate. by God's goodne≈øs, now lived over the colde≈øt and hotte≈øt, that the olde≈øt liver in the Province can remember, I can ≈øay ≈øomething to an Engli≈øh under≈øtanding. Fir≈øt, Of the Fall, for then I came in: I found it from the 24th of October, to the beginning of December, as we have it u≈øually in September, or rather like an Engli≈øh mild Spring. From December, to the beginning of the Month called March, we had ≈øharp, fro≈øty weather; not foul, thick, black weather, as our North-Ea≈øt Winds bring with them in England, but a Sky as clear as in Summer, and the Air dry, cold, piercing, and hungry; yet I remember not, that I wore more Clothes than in England. The rea≈øon of this cold is given from the great Lakes that are fed by the Fountains of Canada. The Winter before was as mild, ≈øcarce any Ice at all; while this for a few days froze up our great River Delaware. From that Month, to the Month called June, we enjoyed a ≈øweet Spring, no Gu≈øts, but gentle Showers and a fine Sky. Yet this I ob≈øerve, that the Winds here, as there, are mo≈øt incon≈øtant Spring and Fall, upon that turn of Nature, than in Summer or Winter. From thence, to this pre≈øent Month, which ended the Summer, (commonly ≈øpeaking) we have had extraordinary heats, yet mitigated ≈øometimes by cold Breezes. The Wind that rules the Summer-≈øea≈øon, is the South-We≈øt; but Spring, Fall, and Winter, 'tis rare to want the whole≈øom North-We≈øtern ≈øeven days together; and whatever Mi≈øts, Fogs, or Vapours, foul the Heavens by Ea≈øterly or Southerly Winds, in two hours time are blown away; the
one is always followed by the other. A Remedy that ≈øeems to be a peculiar Providence in it to the Inhabitants; the multitude of Trees yet ≈øtanding, being liable to retain Mi≈øts and Vapours, and yet not one quarter ≈øo thick as I expected.

The natural product of the Country of Vegetables, Vegetables. is Trees, Fruits, Plants, Flowers; the Trees of mo≈øt Note, are, the Black Walnut, Cedar, Cyprus, Che≈ønut, Poplar, Gum-wood, Hickery, Sa≈ø≈øafras, A≈øh, Beech, and Oak of divers ≈øorts, as Red, White and Black; Spani≈øh Che≈ønut and Swamp, the mo≈øt durable of all; of all which there is plenty for u≈øe of Man.

The FruitsFruits. that I find in the Woods, are, the white and black Mulberry, Che≈ønuts, Walnut, Plums, Strawberries, Cranberries, Hurtleberries, and Grapes of divers ≈øorts, the great red Grape, (now Ripe) called by ignorance, the Fox-Grape (becau≈øe of the reli≈øh it hath with unskilful palates) is in it ≈øelf an extraordinary Grape, and by art doubtle≈øs may be cultivated to an excellent Wine, if not ≈øo ≈øweet, yet little inferiour to the Frontiniack, as it is not much unlike in ta≈øte, ruddine≈øs ≈øet a≈øide, which in ≈øuch things, as well as Mankind, differs the ca≈øe much. There is a white kind of Muskadel, and a little black Grape, like the clu≈øter of Grapes in England, not yet ≈øo ripe as the other, but they tell me when ripe, ≈øweeter, and that they only want skilful Vinerons to make good u≈øe of them; I intend to venture on it with my French-Man this Sea≈øon, who ≈øhews ≈øome knowledge in tho≈øe things.

Here are al≈øo Peaches, very good, and in great quantities, not an Indian Plantation without them;
but whether naturally here at fir≈øt, I know not, however one may have them by Bu≈øhels for little; they make a plea≈øant Drink, and I think not inferiour to any Peach you have in England, except the true Newington. 'Tis di≈øputable with me, whether it be be≈øt to fall to Fining the Fruits of the Country, e≈øpecially the Grapes, by the care and skill of Art, or ≈øend for Forreign Stems and Sets already good and approved; it ≈øeems mo≈øt rea≈øonable to believe, that not only a thing groweth be≈øt, where it naturally grows; but will hardly be equall'd by another's Species of the ≈øame kind, that doth not naturally grow there. But to re≈øolve this doubt, I intend (if God give me life) to try both, and hope the Con≈øequences will be as good Wine as any European Countries of the ≈øame Latitude do yield.

The artificial ProductIts Product. of the Country, is Wheat, Barley, Oats, Rye, Pea≈øe, Beans, Squa≈øhes, Pumkins, Water-Melons, Musk-Melons, and all Herbs and Roots that our Gardens in England u≈øually bring forth.

Of Living Creatures,Living Creatures. as Fi≈øh, Fowl, and the Bea≈øt of the Woods, here are divers ≈øorts, ≈øome for Food and Profit, and ≈øome for Profit only; for food as well as profit, the Elk, as big as a ≈ømall Ox, Deer bigger than ours, Beaver, Racoon, Rabbits, Squirrils, and ≈øome eat young Bear, and commend it. Of Fowls of the Land, there is the Turkey, (forty or fifty pound weight) which is very great; Phea≈øants, Heath-Birds, Pidgeons, and Patridges in abundance: Of the Water, the Swan, Goo≈øe, white and gray, Ducks, Teal, al≈øo the Snipe and Curloe, and
that in great numbers; but the Duck and Teal excel, nor ≈øo good have I ever eat in other Countries. Of Fi≈øh, there is the Sturgeon, Herring, Rock, Shad, Cat≈øhead, Eel, Smelt, Pearch, Roch; and in Inland Rivers, Trout, ≈øome ≈øay Salmon, above the Falls. Of Shell-fi≈øh, we have Oy≈øters, Crabs, Cockles, Concks, Mu≈øeta's; ≈øome Oy≈øters ≈øix Inches long,; and one ≈øort of Cockles, as big as the ≈øtewing Oy≈øter; they make a rich Broth. The Creatures for profit only, by Skin or Furr, and that are natural to tho≈øe Parts, are the Wild-Cat, Panther, Otter, Wolf, Fox, Fi≈øher, Minx, Musk-Rat: And of the Water, the Whale for Oyl, of which we have good ≈øtore; and two companies of Whalers, who≈øe Boats are built, will ≈øoon begin their work, which hath the appearance of a con≈øiderable improvement to nothing of our rea≈øonable hopes, of good Cod in the Bay. We have no want of Hor≈øes, and ≈øome are very good, & ≈øhapely enough; two Ships have been fraighted to Barbadoes with Hor≈øes and Pipe-≈øtaves, ≈øince my coming in; here is al≈øo plenty of Cow-Cattel, and ≈øome Sheep; the People Plow mo≈øtly with Oxen.

There are divers Plants,Plants. that not only the Indians tell us, but we have had occa≈øion to prove, by Swellings, Burns, Cuts, &c. that they are of great virtue, ≈øuddenly curing the Patient; and for ≈ømell, I have ob≈øerved ≈øeveral, e≈øpecially one, the wild Mirtle; the other I know not what to call, but are mo≈øt fragrant; the Woods are adorned with lovely Flowers, for colour, greatne≈øs, figure and variety; I have ≈øeen the Gardens of London be≈øt ≈øtored with that ≈øort of beauty, but think they may be improved by our Woods; I have ≈øent a few to a Per≈øon of Quality this year for a Tryal. Thus
much of the Country; next of the Natives or Origines.

The Natives I ≈øhall con≈øider in their Per≈øons, Language, Manners, Religion and Government, with my ≈øen≈øe of their Original. For their Per≈øons, Their Per≈øons. they are generally tall, ≈øtreight, well built, and of ≈øingular proportion; they tread ≈øtrong and clever, and mo≈øtly walk with a lofty Chin; of Complexion black, but by de≈øign, as the Gyp≈øies in England; they grea≈øe them≈øelves with Bear's Fat clarifi'd, and u≈øing no defence again≈øt Sun or Weather, there Skins mu≈øt needs be ≈øwarthy; their Eye is little and black, not unlike a ≈øtreightlook'd Jew; the thick Lip and flat No≈øe, ≈øo frequent to the Ea≈øt-Indians and Blacks, are not common to them; for I have ≈øeen as comely European-like Faces among them, of both, as on your ≈øide the Sea; and truly an Italian Complexion hath not much more of the White, and the No≈øes of ≈øeveral of them have as much of the Roman.

Their Language Their Language. is lofty, yet narrow, but like the Hebrew; in Signification full, like Short-hand in Writing; one word ≈øerveth in the place of three, and the re≈øt are ≈øupplied by the under≈øtanding of the Hearer; imperfect in their Ten≈øes, wanting in their Moods, Participles, Adverbs, Conjunctions, Interjections: I have made it my bu≈øine≈øs to under≈øtand it, that I might not want an Interpreter on any occa≈øion; and I mu≈øt ≈øay, I know not a Language, ≈øpoken in Europe, that hath words of more ≈øweetne≈øs or greatne≈øs, in Accent and Empha≈øis, than theirs; for In≈øtance, Octorockon Rancocas, Oricton, Schakamazon, Poque≈øin, all which are Names of Places, and have grandeur in them of
words of ≈øweetne≈øs: Anna is Mother, I≈ø≈øimus a Brother, Netap a Friend, ∆≤≈øque oret very good, Poru Bread, Met≈øe cat, Matta no, Hatta to have, Payo to come, Sepa≈ø≈øen, Pa≈ø≈øejou, the Names of Places; Tamane, Secane, Menan≈øe, Secatereus, are the Names of Per≈øons; if one ask them of any thing they have not, they will an≈øwer, Matta ne hotta, which to Tran≈ølate, is, not I have, in≈øtead of, I have not.

Of their Cu≈øtoms and Manners Cu≈øtoms and Manners. there is much to be ≈øaid. I will begin with Children: So ≈øoon as they are born, they wa≈øh them in Water; and while very young, and in cold Weather to chu≈øe, they plunge them in the Rivers to harden and embolden them: Having wrapt them in a Clout, they lay them on a ≈øtrait thin Board, a little more than the length & breadth of the Child, and ≈øwaddle it fa≈øt upon the Board, to make it ≈øtreight; wherefore all Indians have flat Heads; and thus they carry them at their Backs. The Children will go very young, at nine Months commonly; they wear only a ≈ømall Clout round their Wai≈øt till they are big; if Boys, they go a Fi≈øhing till ripe for the Woods, which is about fifteen; then they Hunt, and having given ≈øome proofs of their Manhood, by a good return of Skins, they may Marry, el≈øe it is ≈øhame to think of a Wife. The Girls ≈øtay with their Mothers, and help to Hoe the Ground, Plant Corn, and carry Burthens; and they do well to u≈øe them to that Young, which they mu≈øt do when they are Old; for the Wives are the true Servants of their Husbands; otherwi≈øe the Men are very affectionate to them. When the young Women are fit for Marriage, they wear ≈øomething upon their Heads for an Adverti≈øement,
but ≈øo as their Faces are hardly to be ≈øeen, but when they plea≈øe: The Age they Marry at, if Women, is about thirteen and fourteen; if Men, ≈øeventeen and eighteen; they are rarely elder: their Hou≈øes are Mats, or Barks of Trees, ≈øet on Poles, in the fa≈øhion of an Engli≈øh Barn, but out of the power of the Winds, for they are hardly higher than a man; they lie on Reeds or Gra≈øs. In travel they lodge in the Woods about a great fire, with the Mantle-Duffils they wear by day, wrapt about them, and a few Boughs ≈øtuck round them. Their Diet is Maiz or Indian-Corn, divers ways prepapared; ≈øometimes roa≈øted in the A≈øhes, ≈øometimes beaten and boiled with Water, which they call Homine; they al≈øo make Cakes, not unplea≈øant to eat; they have likewi≈øe ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Beans and Pea≈øe, that are good nouri≈øhment; and the Woods and Rivers are their Larder.

If an European comes to ≈øee them,Their Enterment. or calls for Lodging at their Hou≈øe or Wigwam, they give him the be≈øt place and fir≈øt cut. If they come to vi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t us, they ≈øalute us with an It ah, which is as much as to ≈øay, Good be to you, and ≈øet them down, which is mo≈øtly on the ground, clo≈øe to their Heels, their Legs upright; may be they ≈øpeak not a word more, but ob≈øerve all pa≈ø≈øages: If you give them any thing to eat or drink, well, for they will not ask; and be it little, or much, if it be with kindne≈øs, they are well-plea≈øed, el≈øe they go away ≈øullen, but ≈øay nothing. They are great concealers of their own re≈øentments; brought to it, I believe, by the revenge that hath been practi≈øed among them; in either of the≈øe they are not exceeded by the Italians. A Tragical In≈øtance fell out ≈øince I came into the
Country; A King's Daughter, thinking her≈øelf ≈ølighted by her Husband, in ≈øuffering another Women to lie down between them, ro≈øe up, went out, pluckt a Root out of the ground, and eat it, upon which ≈øhe immediately died; and for which, la≈øt Week, he made an Offering to her Kindred, for Atonement, Liberty, and Marriage, as two others did to the Kindred of their Wives, that died a natural death: for till Widowers have done ≈øo, they mu≈øt not Marry again. Some of the young Women are ≈øaid to take undue liberty before Marriage for a Portion; but when Married, cha≈øte: when with Child, they know their Husbands no more, till delivered; and, during their Month, they touch no Meat they eat, but with a ≈øtick, le≈øt they ≈øhould defile it; nor do their Husbands frequent them, till that time be expired.

But in LiberalityTheir Liberality they excel, nothing is too good for their Friend; give them a fine Gun, Coat, or other thing, it may pa≈øs twenty hands, before it ≈øticks; light of heart, ≈øtrong affections, but ≈øoon ≈øpent; the mo≈øt merry Creatures that live, Fea≈øt and Dance perpetually; they never have much, nor want much: Wealth circulateth like the Blood, all parts partake; and though none ≈øhall want what another hath, yet exact ob≈øervers of Property. Some Kings have ≈øold, others pre≈øented me with ≈øeveral Parcels of Land; the Pay or Pre≈øent I made them, were not hoarded by the particular owners, but the neighbouring Kings and their Clans being pre≈øent when the Goods were brought out, the parties chiefly concerned con≈øulted, what and to whom they ≈øhould give them; to every King then, by the hands of a per≈øon
for that work appointed, is a portion ≈øent, ≈øo ≈øorted and folded, and with that gravity, that it is admirable; then that King ≈øubdivideth it in like manner among the dependants, they hardly leaving them≈øelves an equal ≈øhare with one of their Subjects: and be it on ≈øuch occa≈øions as Fe≈øtivals, or at their common Meals, the Kings di≈øtribute, and to them≈øelves la≈øt; they care for little, and the rea≈øon is, a little contents them: In this they are ≈øufficiently revenged on us; if they are ignorant of our plea≈øures, they are al≈øo free from our pains. They are not di≈øquieted with Bills of Lading and Exchange, nor perplexed with Chancery-Suits and Exchequer-Reckonings; we ≈øweat and toil to live, their plea≈øure feeds them, I mean their Hunting, Fi≈øhing and Fowling, and this Table is ≈øpread every where; they eat twice a day, Morning and Evening; their Seats and Tables are the Ground. Since the Europeans came into tho≈øe parts, they are grown great lovers of ≈øtrong Liquors, Rum e≈øpecially; and for it they exchange the riche≈øt of their Skins and Furs: If they are healed with Liquors, they are re≈øtle≈øs till they have enough to ≈øleep; and this is their cry, Some more, and I will go to ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ep; but, when drunk, one of the mo≈øt wretched'≈øt ≈øpectacles in the world. In ≈øickne≈øs, impatient to be cured; for it, give any thing, e≈øpecially for their Children, to whom they are extreamly natural; they drink at tho≈øe times a Teran or Deco≈øtion of ≈øome Roots, in Spring-water; and if they eat any fle≈øh, it mu≈øt be of the Female of any Creature: if they die, they bury them with their Apparel, be they Men or Women, and the neare≈øt of Kin ≈ølings in ≈øomething precious with them, as a token of their love: their mourning is blacking of their faces, which they continue
for a Year: they are choice of the Graves of their dead; for, le≈øt they ≈øhould be lo≈øt by time, and fall to common u≈øe, they pick off the Gra≈øs that grows upon them, and heap up the fallen Earth with great care and exactne≈øs.

The≈øe poor people are under a dark Night in things relating to Religion,Their Religion. to be ≈øure the Tradition of it; yet they believe a God and Immortality without the helps of Metaphy≈øicks; for they ≈øay there is a great King that made them, who dwells in a glorious Country to the Southward of them, and that the Souls of the good ≈øhall go thither, where they ≈øhall live again. Their Wor≈øhip con≈øi≈øts of two parts, Sacrifice and Cantico: Their Sacrifice is their fir≈øt Fruits, the fir≈øt and fatte≈øt Buck they kill, goes to the Fire, where he is all burnt with a mournful Ditty of him that performs the Ceremony, but with ≈øuch marvellous fervency and labour of Body, that he will even ≈øweat to a Foam; the other part of their Cantico, is performed by round Dances, ≈øometimes Words, ≈øometimes Songs, then Shouts; two being in the middle that begin, and by ≈øinging and drumming on a Board, direct the Chorus; their Po≈øtures in the Dance are very antick and differing, but all keep mea≈øure. This is done with equal earne≈øtne≈øs and labour, but great appearance of Joy. In the Fall, when the Corn comes in, they begin to fea≈øt one another; there have been two great Fe≈øtivals already, to which all come that will: I was at one my ≈øelf; their entertainment was a great Seat by a Spring, under ≈øome ≈øhady Trees, and twenty Bucks, with hot Cakes of new Corn, both Wheat and Beans, which they make up in a ≈øquare form, in the Leaves of the Stem, and bake them
in the A≈øhes; and after that, they fell to dance; but they that go, mu≈øt carry a ≈ømall Pre≈øent of their Money, it may be ≈øix pence, which is made in the Bone of a Fi≈øh; the black is with them as Gold, the white Silver; they call it all Wampum.

Their GovernmentGovernment. is by Kings which they call Sachema, and tho≈øe by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, but always of the Mothers-≈øide; for in≈øtance, the Children of him that is now King, will not ≈øucceed, but his Brother by the Mother, or the Children of his Si≈øter, who≈øe Sons (and after them the Children of her Daughters) will reign; for no Woman inherits: the Rea≈øon they render for this way of De≈øcent, is, that their I≈ø≈øue may not be ≈øpurious. Every King hath his Council, and that con≈øi≈øts of all the old and wi≈øe men of his Nation, which perhaps is two hundred People: Nothing of moment is undertaken, be it War, Peace, ≈øelling of Land, Traffick, without advi≈øing with them; and which is more, with the young men too. 'Tis admirable to con≈øider how powerful the Kings are, and how they move by the Breath of the People. I have had occa≈øion to be in Council with them upon Treaties of Land, and to adju≈øt the Terms of Trade: Their Order is thus; The King ≈øits in the middle of a half-Moon, and hath his Council, the old and wi≈øe on each hand; behind them, or at a little di≈øtance, ≈øit the younger Fry in the ≈øame Figure; having con≈øulted and re≈øolved their Bu≈øi≈øine≈øs, the King ordered one of them to ≈øpeak to me, and he in the Name of his King ≈øaluted me; then took me by the hand, and told me, That he was ordered by his King to ≈øpeak to me; and that now it was not he, but the King that ≈øpoke; becau≈øe
what he ≈øhould ≈øay, was the King's Mind. He fir≈øt prayed me to excu≈øe them that they had not complied with me the la≈øt time, he feared there might be ≈øome fault in the Interpreter, being neither Indian nor Engli≈øh; be≈øides it was the Indian cu≈øtom to deliberate, and take up much time in Council before they re≈øolve; and that if the young People and Owners of the Land had been as ready as he, I had not met with ≈øo much delay. Having thus introduced this Matter, he fell to the Bounds of the Land they had agreed to di≈øpo≈øe of, and the Price (which now is little and dear, that which would have bought twenty Miles, not buying now two.) During the time that this Per≈øon ≈øpoke, not a man of them was ob≈øerved to whi≈øper or ≈ømile; the Old grave, the Young reverent in their deportment: They do ≈øpeak little, but fervently and with elegancy; I have never ≈øeen more natural ≈øagacity, con≈øidering them without the help of Tradition; and he will de≈øerve the Name of wi≈øe, that out-wits them in any Treaty about a thing they under≈øtand.

When the Purcha≈øe was agreed, great Promi≈øes pa≈ø≈øed between us of Kindne≈øs and good Neighbourhood, and that the Indians and Engli≈øh mu≈øt live in Love as long as the Sun gave Light; which done, another made a Speech to the Indians, in the Name of all the Sachamakers or Kings, fir≈øt to tell them what was done; next, to charge and command them to love Chri≈øtians; and particularly to live in peace with me, and the People under my Government: That many Governors had been in the River, but that no Governor had come him≈øelf to live and ≈øtay here before; and having now ≈øuch a one that had treated them well, they ≈øhould never do him or his any wrong. At every Sentence
of which, they ≈øhouted, and ≈øaid, Amen, in their way.

The Ju≈øticeTheir Ju≈øtice. they have is pecuniniary; in ca≈øe of any wrong or evil fact, be it Murder it≈øelf, they atone by Fea≈øts and Pre≈øents of their Wampum, which is proportioned to the quality of the Offence, or Per≈øon injur'd, of the Sex they are of: For in ca≈øe they kill a Woman, they pay double; and the rea≈øon they render, is, That ≈øhe breedeth Children, which men cannot do. 'Tis rare that they fall out, if ≈øober; and if drunk, they forgive it; ≈øaying, it was the Drink, and not the Man, that abu≈øed them. We have agreed, that in all differences between us, ≈øix of each ≈øide ≈øhall end the Matter. Don't abu≈øe them, but let them have Ju≈øtice, and you win them: The wor≈øt is, they are the wor≈øe for the Chri≈øtians, who have propagated their Vices, and yielded them Tradition for ill, and not for good things.
