But as low an Ebb as they are at, and in as glorious as their condition looks, the Chri≈øtians have not out-liv'd their ≈øight with all their Preten≈øions to an higher manife≈øtation. What Good then might not a good People graft, where there is ≈øo di≈øtinct a Knowledge left between good and evil? I be≈øeech God to encline the hearts of all that come into the≈øe parts, to out-live the Knowledge of the Natives, by a fixt obedience to their greater Knowledge of the Will of God; for it were mi≈øerable indeed for us to fall under the ju≈øt cen≈øure of the poor Indian Con≈øcience, while we make profe≈ø≈øion of things ≈øo far tran≈øcending.

For their Original,Their Original. I am ready to believe them of the Jewi≈øh Race; I mean of the ≈øtock of the
Ten Tribes; and that for the following Rea≈øons: Fir≈øt, They were to go to a Land not planted or known; which to be ≈øure A≈øia and Africa were, if not Europe; and he that intended that extraordinary Judgment upon them, might make the Pa≈ø≈øage not unea≈øie to them, as it is not unpo≈ø≈øible in it≈øelf, from the Ea≈øtermo≈øt; parts of A≈øia, to the We≈øtermo≈øt parts of America. In the next place, I find them of like countenance, and their Children of ≈øo lively re≈øemblance, that a man would think him≈øelf in Dukes-Place or Berry-Street in London, when he ≈øeeth them. But this is not all; they agree in Rites, they reckon by Moons, they offer their fir≈øt Fruits, they have a kind of Fea≈øt of Tabernacles, they are ≈øaid to lay their Altar upon twelve Stones, their mourning a year, Cu≈øtoms of Women, with many things that do not now occur.

So much for the Natives; next, the old Planters The old Planters. will be con≈øider'd in their Relation, before I come to our Colony, and the Concerns of it. The fir≈øt Planters in the≈øe parts, were the Dutch, and ≈øoon after them the Swedes and Finns. The Dutch applied them≈øelves to Traffick, the Swedes and Finns to Husbandry. There were ≈øome Deputies between them ≈øome years, The Dutch looked upon them as intruders upon their Purcha≈øe and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; which was finally ended in the ≈øurrender made by John Rizeing, the Swedes Governor, to Peter Styre≈øant, Governor for the States of Holland, Anno 1655. The Dutch inhabit mo≈øtly tho≈øe parts of the Province that lye upon or near the Bay, and the Swedes the Fre≈øhes of the River Delaware. There is no need of giving any de≈øcription of them, who are better known there than here,
but they are a plain, ≈øtrong, indu≈øtrious People, yet have made no great progre≈øs in Culture, or propagation of Fruit-trees; as if they de≈øired rather to have enough, than Plenty or Traffick. But I pre≈øume the Indians made them more carele≈øs, by furni≈øhing them with the means of Profit, to wit, Skins and Furs for Rum, and ≈øuch ≈øtrong Liquors. They kindly received me as well as the Engli≈øh, who were few, before the People concerned with me, came among them. I mu≈øt needs commend their re≈øpect to Authority, and kind behaviour to the Engli≈øh; they do not degenerate from the old Friend≈øhip between both Kingdoms. As they are People proper and ≈øtrong of Body, ≈øo they have fine Children, and almo≈øt every hou≈øe full; rare to find one of them without three of four Boys, and as many Girls; ≈øome ≈øix, ≈øeven and eight Sons: And I mu≈øt do them that right, I ≈øee few young men more ≈øober and laborious. The Dutch have a Meeting-place for Religious Wor≈øhip, at Newca≈øtle; and the Swedes three, one at Chri≈øtina, one at Tenecum, and one at Wicoco, within half a Mile of this Town.

There re≈øts, that I ≈øpeak of the Condition we are in, and what ≈øettlement we have made; in which I will be as ≈øhort as I can; for I fear, and not without rea≈øon, that I have tired your Patience with this long Story. The Countrey lieth bounded on the Ea≈øt,Its Scituation. by the River and Bay of Delaware and Ea≈øtern Sea; it hath the advantage of many Creeks, or RiversIts Rivers. rather, that run into the main River or Bay; ≈øome navigable for great Ships, ≈øome for ≈ømall Craft: Tho≈øe of mo≈øt eminency, are, Chri≈øtina, Brandy-wine, Shilpot and
Skulkil; any one of which have room to lay up the Royal Navy of England, there being from four to eight fathom water; the le≈ø≈øer Creeks or Rivers, yet convenient for Sloops and Ketches of good Burden, are, Lewis, Me≈øpilon, Ceda, Dover, Cranbrook, Fever≈øham, and Georges below, and Chiche≈øter, Che≈øter, Toacawry, Pemmapecka, Fortque≈ø≈øin, Ne≈øhimene, and Pennberry in the Fre≈øhes, many le≈ø≈øer, that admit Boats and Shallops. Our People are mo≈øtly ≈øetled upon the upper Rivers, which are plea≈øant and ≈øweet, and generally bounded with good Land.

The planted part of the Province and Territories, is ca≈øt into ≈øix Counties,Their Counties. Philadelphia, Buckingham, Che≈øter, Newca≈øtle, Kent and Su≈ø≈øex, containing about four thou≈øand Souls. Two General A≈ø≈øemblies have been held, and with ≈øuch Concord and Di≈øpatch, that they ≈øate but three weeks, and at lea≈øt ≈øeventy Laws were pa≈øt without one Di≈ø≈øent in any material thing. But of this more hereafter, being yet raw and new in our Geer: However, I cannot forget their ≈øingular re≈øpect to me in this Infancy of things; who, by their own private expences ≈øo early con≈øidered mine for the certain Goods imported and exported: which, after my acknowledgement of their Affection, I did as freely remit to the Province and the Traders to it.

And for the well-government of the ≈øaid Counties, Courts of Ju≈øtice Courts of Ju≈øtice erected. are e≈øtabli≈øh'd in every County, with proper Officers, as, Ju≈øtices, Sheriffs, Clerks, Con≈øtables, &c. Which Courts are held every two Months. But to prevent Law-≈øuits,
there are three Peace-makers cho≈øen by each County-Court, in the nature of common Arbitrators, to hear and end Differences between man and man; and Spring and Fall there is an Orphans-Court in each County, to in≈øpect and regulate the Affairs of Orphans and Widows.

Philadelphia, Philadelphia. the Expectation of tho≈øe that are concerned in this Province, is at la≈øt laid out to the great content of tho≈øe here that are any ways intere≈ø≈øed therein: The Situation is a Neck of Land, and lieth between two navigable Rivers, Delaware and Skulkil, whereby it hath two Fronts upon the Water, each a Mile, and two from River to River. Delaware is a glorious River, but the Skulkil being an hundred Miles Boatable above the Falls, and its Cour≈øe North-Ea≈øt towards the Fountain of Su≈øqitahannah (that tends to the heart of the Province, and both ≈øides our own) it is like to be a great part of the Settlement of this Age, in which tho≈øe that are Purcha≈øers of me, will find their Names and Intere≈øt. But this I will ≈øay for the good Providence of God, That of all the many Places I have ≈øeen in the world, I remember not one better ≈øeated; ≈øo that it ≈øeems to me, to have been apointned for a Town, whether we regard the Rivers, or the conveniency of the Coves, Docks, Springs, the loftine≈øs and ≈øoundne≈øs of the Land and the Ayr, held by the People of tho≈øe Parts, to be very good. It is advanced within le≈øs than a Year to about four≈øcore Hou≈øes and Cottages, ≈øuch as they are; where Merchants and Handicraft≈ømen are following their Vocations as fa≈øt as they can, while the Countrey-men are clo≈øe in their Farms: Some of them got a little Winter-Corn in the Ground la≈øt Sea≈øon, and the generality have had
a hand≈øom Summer-Crop, and are preparing for their Winter-Corn. They reaped their Barley this Year in the Month called May, the Wheat in the Month following; ≈øo that there is time in the≈øe parts for another Crop of divers things before the Winter-Sea≈øon. We are dayly in hopes of Shipping to add to our Number; for ble≈ø≈øed be God there is both room and accommodation for them; the Stories of our Nece≈ø≈øity being either the Fear of our Friends, or the Scare-crows of our Enemies; for the greate≈øt hard≈øhip we have ≈øuffered hath been Salt-Meat, which by Fowl in Winter, and Fi≈øh in Summer, together with ≈øome Poultry, Lamb, Mutton, Veal, and plenty of Veni≈øon the be≈øt part of the Year, hath been very pa≈ø≈øable I ble≈øs God, I am fully ≈øatisfied with the Country and Entertainment I can get in it; for I find that particular content which hath always attended me, where God by his Providence hath made it my Place and Service to re≈øide. You cannot imagine, my Station can be at pre≈øent free of more than ordinary an ordinary Bu≈øine≈øs; and as ≈øuch, I may ≈øay it is a trouble≈øom Work; but the Method things are putting in, will facilitate the Charge, and give an ea≈øier motion to the Admini≈øtration of Affairs. However, as it is ≈øome mens Duty to plow, ≈øome to ≈øow, ≈øome to water, and ≈øome to reap, ≈øo it is the Wi≈ødonm, as well as Duty of a man, to yield to the Mind of Providence, and chearfully, as well as carefully, embrace and follow the Guidance of it.

The City of Philadelphia, The Extent of Philadelphia. as now laid out, extends in length, from River to River, two Miles, and in breadth near a Mile; and the Governour, as a further manife≈øtation of his kindne≈øs
to the Purcha≈øers, hath freely given them their re≈øpective Lots in the City, without defalcation of any of their Qualities of Purcha≈øed Lands; and as it is now placed and modelled between two Navigable Rivers upon a neck of Land, and that Ships may ride in good Anchorage, in ≈øix or eight fathom Water in both Rivers, clo≈øe to the City, and the Land of the City level, dry and whol≈øom; ≈øuch a ≈øituation is ≈øcarce to be parallell'd. The City is ≈øo ordered now, by the Governour's Care and Prudence, that it hath a Front to each River, one half at Delaware, the other at Skulkil; and though all this cannot make way for ≈ømall Purcha≈øers to be in the Fronts, Yet they are placed in the next Streets, contiguous to each Front; viz. all Purcha≈øers of one thou≈øand Acres and upwards, have the Fronts, (and the High-Street) and to every five thou≈øand Acres purcha≈øe in the Front, about an Acre, and the ≈ømaller Purcha≈øers about half an Acre in the backward Street; by which means the lea≈øt hath room enough for a Hou≈øe, Garden, and a ≈ømall Orchard, to the great content and ≈øatisfaction of all here concerned.

The City con≈øi≈øts of a large Front-Street to each River, and a High-Street, (near the middle) front (or River) to front, of one hundred foot broad, and a broad Street in the middle of the City, from ≈øide to ≈øide, ≈øquare of ten Acres; at each Angle are to be Hou≈øes for Publick Affairs, as a Meeting-Hou≈øe A≈ø≈øembly or State-Hou≈øe, Market-Hou≈øe, School-Hou≈øe, and ≈øeveral other Buildings for other concerns. There are al≈øo in each Quarter of the City, a Square of eight Acres to be for the like u≈øes, as the Moor-fields in London, and eight Streets (be≈øide the High-Street) that run from Front to Front, and twenty Streets (be≈øides
the broad Street) that run cro≈øs the City, from ≈øide to ≈øide, all the≈øe Streets are of fifty foot breadth.

After he had continued there above a Year, from the time or giving this Relation, he came for England, upon the account of ≈øome Qarrels that aro≈øe between him and the Lord Baltamore, who claimed the Lands of Delaware; but after ≈øeveral Hearings before the Lords of the Committee, the Matter was decided, after which he publi≈øhed a further Account of the Progre≈øs they made in that Plantation, which is as followeth:

1. We have had about Ninety Sail of Ships, with Pa≈ø≈øengers,Its Pa≈ø≈øengers. ≈øince the beginning of the Year 1682, and not one Ve≈ø≈øel, de≈øigned to this Province, through God's mercy, hitherto mi≈øcarried.

The E≈øtimate of the People may be thus made; Eighty to each Ship; which comes to Seven thou≈øand two hundred Per≈øons: at lea≈øt a Thou≈øand there before, with ≈øuch as from other places in our neighbourhood are ≈øince come to re≈øide among us: and, I pre≈øume, the Births at lea≈øt equal to the Burials; for having made our fir≈øt Settlement high in the Fre≈øhes of the River, we do not find our ≈øelves ≈øubject to tho≈øe ≈øea≈øonings that affect ≈øome other Countries upon the ≈øame Coa≈øt.

The People are a Collection of divers Nations in Europe: Its Inhabitants. As French, Dutch, Germans, Swedes, Danes, Finns, Scotch, Iri≈øh, and Engl≈øh; and of the la≈øt, equal to all the re≈øt, and which is admirable, not a reflection upon that account: But as they are of one kind, and in one place, and under one Allegiance, ≈øo they live like People of one Country: which civil union has had a con≈øiderable
Influence towards the pro≈øperity of that place.

2. Philadelphia,
Philadelphia farther de≈øcrib'd. and our intended Metropolis, as I formerly writ, is two Miles long, and a Mile broad, and at each end it lies that Mile, upon a Navigable River; the Situation high and dry, yet repleni≈øhed with running ≈øtreams; be≈øides, the High-Street, that runs in the middle, from River to River, and is an hundred foot broad, it has eight Streets more, that run the ≈øame cour≈øe, the lea≈øt of which is fifty foot in breadth; and, be≈øides Broad-≈øtreet, which cro≈ø≈øeth the Town in the middle, and is al≈øo an hundred Foot wide, there are twenty Streets more, that run the ≈øame cour≈øe, and are al≈øo fifty foot broad. The Names of tho≈øe Streets are mo≈øtly taken from the things that ≈øpontaneou≈øly grow in the Countrey; As Vine-≈øtreet, Mulberry-≈øreet, Che≈ønut-≈øtreet, Walnut-≈øtreet, Strawberry-≈øtreet, Cranberry-≈øtreet, Plum-≈øtreet, Hickery-≈øtreet, Pine-≈øtreet, Oak-≈øtreet, Beach-≈øtreet, A≈øh-≈øtreet, Popler-≈øtreet, Sa≈ø≈øafras-≈øtreet, and the like.

3. I mentioned in my la≈øt Account,Increa≈øe of Building. that from my arrival in 1682, to the date hereof, being ten Months, we had got up four≈øcore Hou≈øes at our Town, and that ≈øome Villages were ≈øettled about it; from that time, to my coming away, which was a Year, within a few weeks, the Town advanced to 357 Hou≈øes, divers of them large, well built, with good Cellars, three Stories, and ≈øome Balconies.

4. There is a fair Key,A fair Key. of about 300 foot ≈øquare, built by Samuel Carpenter, to which a Ship
of 500 Tuns may lay her broad-≈øide: and others intend to follow his example. We have al≈øo a Rope-walk, made by B. Wilcox, and Cordage for Ships already ≈øpun at it.

5. There inhabits mo≈øt ≈øorts of u≈øeful Trade≈ømen; As Carpenters, Their Trades. Joyners, Bricklayers, Ma≈øons, Plai≈øterers, Plummers, Smiths, Gla≈øiers, Taylors, Shoe-maker, Butchers, Bakers, Brewers, Glovers, Tanners, Felmongers, Wheel-rights, Mill-rights, Ship-rights Boat-rights, Rope-makers, Sail-makers, Block-makers, Turners, &c.
6. There are two Markets every Week,Their Markets and Fairs. and two Fairs every Year. In other places Markets al≈øo, as at Che≈øter, and New-ca≈øtle.
7. Seven OrdinariesTheir Ordinaries. for the entertainment of Strangers, and Workmen, that are not Hou≈øe-keepers, and a good Meal to be had for Six-pence, Sterling.
8. The Hours for Work,Hours for Work. and Meals to Labourers are fixt, and known by ring of Bell.
9. After Nine at Night, the Officers go the Rounds, and no per≈øon, without very good cau≈øe, ≈øuffered to be at any Publick-hou≈øe, that is not a Lodger.Hours for Lodgers.

10. Though this Town ≈øeemed at fir≈øt contrived for the Purcha≈øers of the fir≈øt hundred ≈øhares,An Addition for Improvement. each ≈øhare con≈øi≈øting of 5000 Acres, yet few going, and that their ab≈øence might not check the Improvement of the Place, and Strangers, that flockt to us, be thereby excluded,
I added that half of the Town, that lies on the Skulkil, that we might have room for pre≈øent and after-comers, that were not of that number, and it hath already had great ≈øucce≈øs to the Improvement of the place.
11. Some Ve≈ø≈øelsVe≈ø≈øels built. have been here built, and many Boats, and by that means, a ready conveniency for pa≈ø≈øage for People and Goods.
12. Divers BrickeriesDivers Brickeries. going on, many Cellars already ≈øtoned, or bricked, and ≈øome Brick-Hou≈øes going up.

13. The Town is well furni≈øhed what with convenient Mills;Convenient Mills. and what with their Garden-Plots, (the lea≈øt half an Acre) the Fi≈øh of the River and their Labour, to the Country-man, who begins to pay with the Provi≈øions of his own growth, they live comfortably.

14. The ImprovementIts Improvement. of the place is be≈øt mea≈øured by the advance of value upon every man's Lot, I will venture to ≈øay, that the wor≈øt Lot in the Town, without any improvement upon it, is worth four times more than it was when it was laid out, and the be≈øt forty; and though it ≈øeems unequal, that the ab≈øent ≈øhould be thus benefited by the improvement, of tho≈øe upon the place, e≈øpecially when they have ≈øerved no Office, run no Hazard, nor as yet defrayed any Publick Charge, yet this Advantage doth certainly redound to them, and whoever theyare they are great Debtors to the Country; of which I ≈øhall now ≈øpeak more at large.

div.head: Of Country-Settlement.
div.p: 1. We do ≈øettle in the way of Town≈øhips or Villages,Their Settlements. each of which contains 5000 Acres in ≈øquare, and at lea≈øt ten Famlies, the regulation of the Country, being a Family to each 500 Acres; ≈øome Town≈øhips have more, where the intere≈øt of the People is le≈øs than that quantity, which often falls out.

2. Many that had right to more Land, were at fir≈øt covetous to have their whole quantity, without regard to this way of ≈øettlement, though by ≈øuch Wilderne≈øs-Vacancies they had ruined the Country, and their own Intere≈øt, of cour≈øe. I had in my View, Society, A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, ea≈øie Commerce, In≈øtruction of Youth, Government of Peoples Manners, Conveniency of Religious a≈ø≈øembling, Encouragement of Mechanicks, di≈øtinct and beaten Roads, and it was an≈øwered in all the≈øe re≈øpects, I think, to an univer≈øal content.

3. Our Town≈øhips lie ≈øquare, generally the Village in the centre; The Hou≈øes either oppo≈øite, or el≈øe oppo≈øite to the middle, betwixt two Hou≈øes over the way, for nearer neighbourhood. We have another method, that through the Village be in the centre, yet after a different manner: five hundred Acres are alotted for the Village, which, among ten Families, comes to fifty Acres each: this lies ≈øquare, and on the out≈øide of the Square ≈øtands the Hou≈øes, and their fifty Acres running back, who≈øe ends meeting, make the centre of the 500 Acres as they are to the whole. Before the Doors of whole Hou≈øes, lies the Highway, and cro≈øs it every man's 450 Acres of Land, that
makes up his Complement of 500; ≈øo that the conveniency of Neighbourhood is made agreeable with that of the Land.
4. I ≈øaid nothing in my la≈øt, of any number of Town≈øhips, but there were at lea≈øt Fifty ≈øettled, before my leaving tho≈øe Parts, which was in the Month called August 1684.

5. I vi≈øited many of them, and found them much advanced in their Improvements; Hou≈øes over their heads, and Garden-plots, Coverts for their Cattle, an encrea≈øe of Stock, and ≈øeveral Enclo≈øures in Corn e≈øpecially, the fir≈øt Commerce: And I may ≈øay of ≈øome poor men, even to the beginnings of an E≈øtate, the difference of labouring for them≈øelves and for others; of an Inheritance, and a Rack-Lea≈øe being never better under≈øtood.

div.head: The Product of the Earth.
div.p: 1. The Earth, by Gods Ble≈ø≈øing, has more than an≈øwered our expectation;The Earths Product. the poore≈øt places in our Judgement, producing large Crops of Garden ≈øtuff, and Grain; and though our Ground has not generally the Symptoms of the fat Necks that lie upon Salt Waters in Provinces Southern of us, our Grain is thought to excel, and our Crops to be as large. We have had the mark of the good Ground among≈øt us, from thirty to ≈øixty-fold of Engli≈øh Corn.
2. The Land requires le≈øs Seed; three Pecks of Wheat ≈øows an Acre; a Bu≈øhel at mo≈øt, and ≈øome have had the encrea≈øe I have mentioned.

3. Upon Trial, we find that the Corn and Roots that grow in England, thrive very well there; as, Wheat, Barley, Rye, Oats, Buck-Wheat, Pea≈øe,
Beans, Cabbages, Turneps, Carrots, Par≈øneps, Colliflowers, A≈øparagus, Onions, Charlots, Garlick, and Iri≈øh Potatoes; we have al≈øo the Spani≈øh, and very good Rice, which do not grow here.
4. Our Low-Lands are excellent for Rape, and Hemp and Flax. A Trial hath been made, and of the two la≈øt there is a con≈øiderable quantity dre≈ø≈øed yearly.

5. The Weeds of our Woods feed our Cattel, to the Market as well as Dairy: I have ≈øeen fat Bullocks brought thence to Market before Mid≈øummer. Our Swamps or Maar≈øhes yield us cour≈øe Hay for the Winter.

6. Engli≈øh Gra≈øs-Seed takes well; which will give us fatting Hay in time. Of this I made an Experiment in my own Court-Yard, upon Sand that was digg'd out of my Cellar, with Seed that had lain in a Cask, open to the Weather two Winters and a Summer; I caus'd it to be ≈øown in the beginning of the Month called April, and a fortnight before Mid≈øummer it was fit to mow; it grew very thick; but I ordered it to be fed, being in the nature of a Gra≈øs-Plot, on purpo≈øe to ≈øee if the Roots lay firm; and though it had been meer Sand ca≈øt out of the Cellar, but a year before, the Seed took ≈øuch Root, and held the Earth ≈øo fa≈øt, and fa≈øtened it ≈øelf ≈øo well in the Earth, that it held and fed like old Engli≈øh Ground. I mention this, to confute the Objections that lie again≈øt tho≈øe Parts; as if that, Fir≈øt, Engli≈øh Gra≈øs would not grow; next, not enough to mow; and la≈øtly, not firm enough to feed, from the levity of the Mould.

7. All ≈øorts of Engli≈øh Fruits that have been tried, take mighty well for the time; the Peach excellent; on Standers; and in great quantities:
They Sun-dry them, and lay them up in Lofts, as we do Roots here, and ≈øtew them with Meat in Winter-time. Musk-Melons and Water-Melons are rai≈øed here, with as little care as Pumpkins in England; the Vine e≈øpecially prevails, which grows every where; and upon Experience of ≈øome French People from Rochel, and the I≈øle of Rhee.

Good Wine Wine may be made there, e≈øpecially, when the Earth and Stem are fined and civilized by Culture. We hope that good skill in our mo≈øt Southern parts will yield us ≈øeveral of the Streights-Commodities, e≈øpecially, Oyl, Dates, Figs, Almonds, Rai≈øins and Currans.

div.head: Of the Product of our Waters.
div.p: 1. Mighty Whales rowl upon the Coa≈øt,The Waters near the Mouth of the Bay of Delaware; eleven caught and work'd into Oyl in one Sea≈øon. We ju≈øtly hope a con≈øiderable Profit by a Whalery, they being ≈øo numerous, and the Shore ≈øo ≈øutable.

2. Sturgeons play continually in our Rivers in Summer; and though the way of curing them, be not generally known, yet by a Receipt I had of one Collins, that related to the Company of the Royal Fi≈øhery, I did ≈øo well pre≈øerve ≈øome, that I had of them good there three Months of the Summer, and brought ≈øome of the ≈øame ≈øo for England.

3. Alloes, as they call them, the Jews, Alice, and our Igrorants, Shades, are excellent Fi≈øh, and of the bigne≈øs of our large≈øt Carp; they are ≈øo plentiful, that Captain Smith's Over≈øeer, at the Skulkil, drew ≈øix hundred and odd at one Draught; three hundred is no wonder, one hundred familiarly: They are excellent pickled or ≈ømoked, as
well as boyled fre≈øh; they are caught by Nets only.

4. Rocks are ≈øomewhat rounder and larger, al≈øo a whiter Fi≈øh, little inferior in reli≈øh to our Mallet; we have them almo≈øt in the like plenty. The≈øe are often Barrell'd like Cod, and not much inferior for their ≈øpending. Of both the≈øe, the Inhabitants increa≈øe their Winter-Store: The≈øe are caught by Nets, Hooks and Spears.

5. The Sheepshead, ≈øo called, from the re≈øemblance of its Mouth and No≈øe to a Sheep, is a Fi≈øh much preferred by ≈øome; but they keep in Salt Water; they are like a Roch in fa≈øhion, but as thick as a Salmon, not ≈øo long. We have al≈øo the Drum, a large and noble Fi≈øh, commended equal to the Sheeps-head, not unlike to a New-found-land Cod, but larger of the two. 'Tis ≈øo called from a noi≈øe it makes in its Belly when it is taken, re≈øembling a Drum. There are three ≈øorts of them, the Black, Red, and Gold-colour; the Black is fat in the Spring, the Red in the Fall, and the Gold-colour, believed to be the Black grown old, becau≈øe it is ob≈øerved that young ones of that colour have not been taken. They generally take them by Hook and line, as they do Cod, and they ≈øave like it, where People are skilful. There are abundance of le≈ø≈øer Fi≈øh to be caught at plea≈øure, but they quit not co≈øt, as tho≈øe I have mentioned, neither in magnitude nor number, except the Herring, which ≈øwarms in ≈øuch ≈øhoals, that it is hardly credible; in little Creeks, they almo≈øt ≈øhovel them up in Tubs. There is the Cat-fi≈øh, or Flat-head, Lamprey, Eel, Trout, Perch, black and white Smelt, Sun-fi≈øh, &c. Al≈øo Oy≈øters, Cockles, Conks, Crabs, Mu≈øcles, Manano≈øes.

div.head: Of Provi≈øion in general.
div.p: 1. It has been often ≈øaid, we are ≈øtarved for want of Food;Provi≈øion. ≈øome were apt to ≈øuge≈øt their Fears, others to in≈øinuate their Prejudice, and when this was contracted, and they a≈ø≈øured we had plenty, both of Bread, Fi≈øh and Fle≈øh, then 'twas objected, we were forced to fetch it from other places at great Charges: But neither is all this true, though all the World will, think we mu≈øt either bring Provi≈øion with us, or get it of the Neighbourhood till we had gotten hou≈øes over our heads, and a little Land in tillage. We fetched none, nor were we wholly kept by Neighbours; the old Inhabitants ≈øupplied us with mo≈øt of the Corn we wanted, and a good ≈øhare of Pork and Beef: 'Tis true, New-York, New-England, and Road-I≈øland, did with their Provi≈øions fetch our Goods and Money, but at ≈øuch Rates, that ≈øome ≈øold for almo≈øt what they gave, and others carried their Provi≈øions back, expecting a better Market nearer; which ≈øhewed no ≈øcarcity, and that we were not totally de≈øtitute in our own River. But if my Advice be of any value, I would have them buy ≈øtill, and not weaken their Herds, by killing up their young Stock too ≈øoon.

But the right mea≈øure of Information mu≈øt be the proportion of value of Provi≈øion there, to what they are in more planted and mature Colonies. Beef is commonly ≈øold at the rate of two pence per pound; and Pork for two pence halfpeny, Veal and Mutton at three pence, or three pence halfpeny of that Countrey Money; an Engli≈øh Shilling goes for Sixteen pence. Grain ≈øells by the Bu≈øhel; Wheat at four ≈øhillings, Rye, and excellent
good, at three ≈øhillings; Barley, two ≈øhillings ≈øix pence, Indian Corn two ≈øhillings ≈øix pence, Oats, two ≈øhillings, in that Money ≈øtill, which in a new Countrey, where Grain is ≈øo much wanted for Seed, as well as Food, cannot be called dear; and e≈øpecially if we con≈øider the con≈øumption of the many new Comers.
3. There is ≈øo great an encrea≈øe of Grain, by the diligent application of People to Husbandry, that within three years, ≈øome Plantations have got twenty Acres in Corn, ≈øome forty.

4. They are very careful to increa≈øe their Stock, and get into Dairies as fa≈øt as they can. They already make good Butter and Chee≈øe. A good Cow and a Calf by her ≈øide, may be worth three pounds Sterling, in Goods at fir≈øt co≈øt. A pair of working Oxen eight pound, a pair of fat ones little more, and a plain breeding Mare about five pounds ≈øterling.
5. For Fi≈øh, it is brought to the door, both fre≈øh and ≈øalt, ≈øix Alloes or Rocks for twelve pence, and ≈øalt-fi≈øh at three farthings per pound, Oy≈øters at two ≈øhillings per Bu≈øhel.

6. Our Drink has been Beer and Punch, made of Rum and Water; Our Beer was mo≈øtly made of Molo≈ø≈øes, which well boyled with Sa≈ø≈øafras or Pine, infu≈øed into it, makes very tolerable Drink; but now they make Malt, and Malt-Drink begins to be common, e≈øpecially at Ordinaries, and the hou≈øes of the more ≈øub≈øtantial people. In our great Town there is an able man that has ≈øet up a Brew-hou≈øe in order to furni≈øh the people with good Drink, both there and up and down the River.

Having ≈øaid this of the Country, for the time I was there, I ≈øhall add one of many Letters that have come to my hand, becau≈øe brief and full,
and that he is known to be a Per≈øon of an extraordinary Caution as well as Truth, in what he is wont to write or ≈øpeak.

body.head: Philadelphia, the Third of the Sixth Month, (Augu≈øt) 1685.
body.p:
HAving an opportunity by a Ship from this River (out of which ≈øeveral have gone this year) I thought fit to give a ≈øhort account of Proceedings, as to Settlement here, and the Improvement both in Town and Countrey: As to the Countrey, the Improvements are large, and Settlements very much thronged, by way of Town≈øhip and Villages, great inclination to planting Orchards, which are ea≈øily rai≈øed, and ≈øome brought to perfection, much Hay-≈øeed ≈øown, and much planting of Corn this year, and great product ≈øaid to be, both of Wheat, Rye and Rice; Barly and Oats prove very well; be≈øides Indian Corn and Pea≈øe of ≈øeveral ≈øorts; al≈øo Kidney-Beans, and Engli≈øh Pea≈øe of ≈øeveral kinds, I have had in my own Ground, with Engli≈øh Roots, Turnips, Par≈ønips, Carrots, Onions, Leeks, Radi≈øhes and Cabbages, with abundance of Herbs and Flowers: I know but of few Seeds that have mi≈øs'd, except Ro≈øemary Seed, which being Engli≈øh, might be old. Al≈øo I have ≈øuch plenty of Pumkins, Musk-Melons, Water Melons, Squa≈øhes, Co≈øhaws, Bucks-hens, Cucumbers and Simnels of divers ≈øorts, admired at by new comers, that the Earth ≈øhould ≈øo plentifully ca≈øt forth, e≈øpecially the fir≈øt years breaking up, and
on that which is counted the wor≈øt ≈øort of Sandy Land. I am ≈øatisfied, and many more, that the Earth is very fertil, and the Lord hath done his part, if man u≈øe but a moderate diligence: Grapes, Mulberries, and many wild Fruits, and natural Plums in abundance this year have I ≈øeen and eat of. A brave Orchard and Nur≈øery have I planted, and they thrive mightily, and bear Fruit the fir≈øt year; I endeavour to get choice of Fruits and Seeds from many parts; al≈øo Hay-Seed, and have ≈øowed a Field this Spring for Trial. Fir≈øt, I burned the Leaves, then had it grubb'd, not the Fields, but the ≈ømall Roots up, then ≈øow'd great and ≈ømall Clovers, with a little old Gra≈øs-Seed, and had it only raked over, not plowed nor harrowed, and it grows exceedingly: Al≈øo, for Experience, I ≈øowed ≈øome Patches of the ≈øame ≈øort in my Garden, and dunged ≈øome, and that grows wor≈øt; I have planted the Iri≈øh Potatoes, and hope to have a brave encrea≈øe to tran≈øplant next year. Captain Rapel (the Frenchman) ≈øaith, he made good Wine of the Grapes of the Country la≈øt year, and tran≈øplanted ≈øome, but intends to make more this year; al≈øo a Frenchman in this Town intends the ≈øame; for Grapes are very plentiful.

Now as to the Town of Philadelphia, it goes on in Planting and Building to admiration, both in the Front and backward, and there are about 600 Hou≈øes in three years time; and ≈øince I built my Brick-Hou≈øe, the Foundation of which was laid at my going, which I de≈øign after a good manner, to encourage others, and that from building with Wood; it being the fir≈øt, many take example; and ≈øome that built wooden Hou≈øes, are ≈øorry for it; Brick Building is ≈øaid to be as cheap: Bricks
are exceeding good, and better than when I built, more makers fallen in, and Bricks cheaper; they were before at 16 s. Engli≈øh, per Thou≈øand, and now many brave Brick hou≈øes are going up with good Cellars. Arthur Cook is building him a brave Brick Hou≈øe near William Frampton's, on the Front; for William Frampton hath ≈øince built a good Brick Hou≈øe, by his Brew-hou≈øe and Bake-hou≈øe, and lett the other for an Ordinary. John Wheeler from New-England, is building a good Brick Hou≈øe by the Blew Anchor, and the two Brick-makers a double Brick Hou≈øe and Cellars; be≈øides ≈øeveral other going on. Samuel Carpenter has built another Hou≈øe by his. I am building another Brick Hou≈øe by mine, which is three large Stories high, be≈øides a good large Brick Cellar under it of two Bricks and a half thickne≈øs in the Wall, and the next Story half under ground; the Cellar has an arched Door for a Vault to go (under the Street) to the River, and ≈øo to bring in Goods, or deliver out. Humphrey Murry, from New-York, has built a large Timber-Hou≈øe with Brick Chimneys. John Test has almo≈øt fini≈øhed a good Brick Hou≈øe, and a Bake-hou≈øe of Timber; and N. Allen a good Hou≈øe next to Thomas Wynn's Front-Lot. John Day a good Hou≈øe after the London fa≈øhion, mo≈øt Brick with a large Frame of Wood in the Front, for Shop-windows; all the≈øe have Balconies. Thomas Smith and Daniel P ‚Ä¢ ge are Partners, and ≈øet to making of Brick this year, and they are very good: Al≈øo Pa≈øtours, the German Friend; Agent for the Company at Frankford, with his Dutch People, are preparing to make Bricks next year. Samuel Carpenter is our Lime-burner on his Wharf. Brave Lime ≈øtone is found here, as the Workmen ≈øay, being proved. We build mo≈øt Hou≈øes with Balconies.
Lots are much de≈øired in the Town; great buying one of anothe. We are now laying the Foundation of a large plain Brick Hou≈øe for a Meeting-Hou≈øe, in the Center (≈øixty foot long, and about forty foot broad) and hope to have it ≈øoon up, there being many hearts and hands at work that will do it: A large Meeting-hou≈øe, fifty foot long, and thirty eight broad al≈øo going on the front of the River, for an Evening-Meeting, the Work going on apace; many Towns-people ≈øetling their Liberty-Lands. I hope the Society will rub off the Reproaches ≈øome have ca≈øt upon them. We now begin to gather in ≈øomething of our many great Debts.

I do under≈øtand three Companies for Whale-catching, are de≈øigned to fi≈øh in the Rivers-mouth this Sea≈øon, and find through the great plenty of Fi≈øh, they may begin early. A Fi≈øherman this year found a way to catch Whitings in this River; and it is expected, many ≈øorts of Fi≈øh more than has been yet caught, may be taken by the skilful. Fi≈øh are in ≈øuch plenty, that many ≈øorts on Tryal, have been taken with Nets in the Winter-time. The Swedes laughing at the Engli≈øh for going to try, have ≈øince tried them≈øelves. The River is ≈øo big, and full of ≈øeveral ≈øorts of brave Fi≈øh, that its believed, except frozen over, we may catch any time in the Winter. It is great pity, but two or three experienced Fi≈øhermen were here to ply this River, to ≈øalt, and ≈øerve, fre≈øh Fi≈øh to the Town. A good way to pickle Sturgeon is wanting; ≈øuch abundance being in the River, even before the Town: many are catcht, boyled, and eaten. La≈øt Winter great plenty of Deer were brought in by the Indiands and Engli≈øh from the Country. We are generally very well and healthy here, but abundance dead in Maryland this Summer.

The Manufacture of Linnen by the Germans goes on finely, and they make fine Linnen. Samuel Carpenter having been lately there, declares, They had gathered one Crop of Flax, and had ≈øown the ≈øecond, and ≈øaw it come up well, and, they ≈øay, might have had forwarder and better, had they had old Seed, and not ≈øtayed ≈øo long for the growth of the new Seed to ≈øow again. I may believe it, for large has my experience been this year, though in a ≈ømall piece of ground, to the admiration of many.

I thought fit to ≈øignifie thus much, knowing thou would≈øt be glad to hear of the People and Provinces welfare: The Lord pre≈øerve us all, and make way for thy return, which is much de≈øired, not only by our friends, but all ≈øorts, I am, &c. thy truly Loving Friend,

div.head: Of further Improvements for Trade and Commerce.
div.p: The≈øe things that we have in Pro≈øpect for Staples of Trade,Trade and Commerce. are Wine, Linnen, Hemp, Pot-a≈øhes and Whale-oyl; to ≈øay nothing of our Provi≈øions for the I≈ølands, our Saw-Mills, Sturgeon, ≈øome Tobacco, and our Furrs and Skins, which of them≈øelves are not contemptible: I might add Iron (perhaps Copper too) for there is much Mines, and it will be granted us, that we want no Wood, though I mu≈øt confe≈øs, I cannot know how to help preferring a Dome≈øtick or Self-≈øub≈øi≈øtence to a life of much profit, by the extream toyl of Foreign Traffick.

div.head: Advice to Adventurers how to imploy their E≈øtates with fair profit.
div.p: It is ≈øit now that I give ≈øome Adverti≈øement to Adventurers,Advice to Adventurers. which way they may lay out their money to be≈øt advantage, ≈øo as it may yield them fair returns, and with content to all concerned, which is the la≈øt part of my pre≈øent task; and I mu≈øt needs ≈øay ≈øo much wanting, that it has perhaps given ≈øome occa≈øion to ignorance and prejudice to run without mercy, mea≈øure or di≈øtinction, again≈øt America, of which, Pen≈øylvania to be ≈øure has had its ≈øhare.

1. It is agreed on all hands, that the poor are the hands and feet of the rich. It is their labour that improves Countries, and to encourage them, is to promote the real benefit of the Publick. Now as there are abundance of the≈øe People in many parts of Europe, extreamly de≈øirous of going to America, ≈øo the way of helping them thither, or when there, and the return thereof to the Disbur≈øers, will prove what I ≈øay to be true.

2. There are two ≈øorts, ≈øuch as are able to tran≈øport them≈øelves and Families, but have nothing to begin with there, and tho≈øe that want ≈øo much as to tran≈øport them≈øelves and Families thither.

3. The fir≈øt of the≈øe may be entertained in this manner. Say I have five thou≈øand Acres, I will ≈øettle ten Families upon them in way of Village, and build each an Hou≈øe, an out-Hou≈øe for Cattel, furni≈øh every Family with ≈øtock; as four Cows, two Sows, a couple of Mares, and a yoke of Oxen, with a Town-hor≈øe, Bull and Boar. I find them with Tools, and give each their fir≈øt Ground-≈øeed;
they ≈øhall continue ≈øeven years, or more, at half increa≈øe, being bound to leave the Hou≈øes in repair, and a Garden and Orchard, I paying for the Trees, and at lea≈øt twenty Acres of Land within Fence, and improved to Corn and Gra≈øs. The charge will come to about ≈øixty pounds Engli≈øh each Family; at the ≈øeven years end, the improvement will be worth, as things go now, one hundred and twenty pounds, be≈øides the value of the encrea≈øe of the Stock, which may be near as much more, allowing for ca≈øualties, e≈øpecially if the People are hone≈øt and careful, or a man be upon the Spot him≈øelf, or have an Over≈øeer ≈øometimes to in≈øpect them. The charge in the whole is eight hundred thirty and two Pounds. I think I have been mode≈øt in my Computation. The≈øe Farms afterwards are ≈øit for Lea≈øes at full Rent, or how el≈øe the owner ≈øhall plea≈øe to di≈øpo≈øe of them; al≈øo the People will by this time be skilled in the Country, and well provided to ≈øettle them≈øelves with Stock upon their own Land.

4. The other ≈øort of poor People may be very beneficially tran≈øported upon the≈øe terms. Say I have five thou≈øand Acres, I ≈øhould ≈øettle as before, I will give to each Family one hundred Acres, which in the whole makes one thou≈øand, and to each Family thirty Pounds Engli≈øh, half in hand and half there, which in the whole comes to three hundred Pounds, after four days are expired, in which time they may be ea≈øie, and in a good condition; they ≈øhall each of them pay 5 l. and ≈øo yearly for ever, as a Fee-farm-rent, which in the whole comes to fifty Pounds a year. Thus a Man that buys five thou≈øand Acres may ≈øecure and ≈øettle his four thou≈øand by the gift of one, and in a way that hazard and intere≈øt allowed for, amounts to at lea≈øt ten
per Cent. upon Land ≈øecurity, be≈øides the value it puts upon the re≈øt of the five thou≈øand Acres. I propo≈øe that there be at the lea≈øt two working hands be≈øides the Wife, whether Son or Servant, and that they oblige what they carry; and for further ≈øecurity, bind them≈øelves as Servants for ≈øome time, that they will ≈øettle the ≈øaid Land accordingly: And when they are once ≈øeated their improvements are ≈øecurity enough for the Rent.

5. There is yet another expedient, and that is, to give ten Families one thou≈øand Acres for ever, at a ≈ømall acknowledgment, and ≈øettle them in way of Village, as afore; by their ≈øeating thus, the Land taken up is ≈øecured from others, becau≈øe the method of the Country is an≈øwered, and the value ≈øuch a ≈øettlement gives to the re≈øt re≈øerved, is not incon≈øiderable, I mean the four thou≈øand Acres, e≈øpecially that which is contiguous, for their Children when grown up, and Handicrafts, will ≈øoon covet to fix next them, and ≈øuch and ≈øuch after ≈øettlements to begin at an improved rent in Fee, or for long Lea≈øes, or ≈ømall acknowledgments, and good improvements mu≈øt advance the whole con≈øiderably. I conceive any of the≈øe methods to i≈ø≈øue in a ≈øufficient advantage to Adventurers, and they all give good encouragement to feeble and poor Families.

6. That which is mo≈øt advi≈øable for People intended thither, to carry with them, is, in ≈øhort, all things relating to Apparel, Building, Hou≈øhold-≈øtuff, Husbandry, Fowling and Fi≈øhing, ≈øome Spice, Spirits, and double Beer, at fir≈øt, were not ami≈øs. But I advi≈øe all to proportion their E≈øtates thus, one third in Money, and two thirds in Goods. Upon Pieces of Eight there will be almo≈øt a third gotten, for they go at ≈øix ≈øhillings; and by Goods
well bought, at lea≈øt fifty Pounds Sterling for every hundred Pounds, ≈øo that a Man worth four hundred Pounds here, is worth ≈øix hundred Pounds there, without ≈øweating.

div.head: Of the Natives.
div.p: 1. Becau≈øe many ≈øtories have been Prejudicially progagated, as if we were upon ill terms with the Natives,The Natives. and ≈øometimes, like Job's Kindred, all cut off but the Me≈ø≈øenger that brought Tidings; I think it requi≈øite to ≈øay thus much, that as there never was any ≈øuch Me≈ø≈øenger, ≈øo the dead People were alive at our la≈øt advices, ≈øo far are we from ill Terms with the Natives, that we have lived in great friend≈øhip. I have made ≈øeveral Purcha≈øes, and in Pay and Pre≈øents they have received at lea≈øt twelve hundred Pounds of me. Our humanity has obliged them ≈øo far, that they generally leave their Guns at home, when they come to our Settlements; they offer us no affront, not ≈øo much as to one of our Dogs; and if any of them break our Laws, they ≈øubmit to be puni≈øhed by them: And to this they have tyed them≈øelves by an Obligation under their Hands. We leave not the lea≈øt indignity to them unrebuked, nor wrong un≈øatisfied; Ju≈øtice gains and awes them. They have ≈øome great Men among≈øt then, I mean, for Wi≈ødom, Truth and Ju≈øtice. I refer to my former Account about their Laws, Manners and Religious Rites.

div.head: Of the Government.
div.p: The GovernmentTheir Government. is, according to the words of the Grant, as near to the Engli≈øh as conveniently may be; in the whole we aim at Duty to the King, the pre≈øervation of Right to all, the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of Vice, and encouragement of Vertue and Arts; with liberty to all People to Wor≈øhip Almighty God, according to their Faith and Per≈øwa≈øion.

div.head: Of the ≈øea≈øons of Going, and u≈øual time of Pa≈ø≈øage.
div.p: 1. Though Ships go hence all times of the Year,The ≈øea≈øons of the Ships Pa≈ø≈øage. it mu≈øt be acknowledged, that to go ≈øo as to arrive at Spring or Fall, is be≈øt: For the Summer may be of the hotte≈øt for fre≈øh Comers; and in the Winter the Wind that prevails, is the North-We≈øt, and that blows off the Coa≈øt; ≈øo that ≈øometimes it difficult to enter the Capes.

2. I purpo≈øe therefore, that Ships go hence about the middle of the Months call'd February and Augu≈øt, which (allowing two Months for Pa≈ø≈øage) reaches time enough to plant in the Spring ≈øuch things as are carried hence to plant; and in the Fall, to get a ≈ømall Cottage, and clear ≈øome Land again≈øt the next Spring. I have made a di≈øcovery of about a hundred Miles We≈øt, and find tho≈øe back-Lands richer in Soil, Woods and Fountains, than that by Delaware, e≈øpecially upon the Sa≈øquehanah River.

3. I mu≈øt confe≈øs, I prefer the Fall to come thither, as believing it mo≈øt healthy to be followed with Winter than Summer; though (through the great goodne≈øs and mercy of God) we have had an extraordinary portion of Health for ≈øo new and numerous a Colony, notwith≈øtanding we have not been ≈øo regular in time.

4. The Pa≈ø≈øage is not to be ≈øet by any Man, for Ships will be quicker and ≈ølower; ≈øome having been four Months, and ≈øome but one: and as often generally between ≈øix and nine Weeks: One Year, or four and twenty Sail, I think, there was not three above nine, and there was one or two under ≈øix Weeks in Pa≈ø≈øage.

5. To render it more healthy; it is good to keep as much upon Deck as may be, for the Air helps again≈øt the offen≈øive ≈ømells of a crowd, and a clo≈øe place. Al≈øo to ≈øcrape often the Cabbins, under the Beds; and either carry ≈øtore of Rue and Wormwood, and ≈øome Ro≈øemary, or often ≈øprinkle Vinegar about the Cabbin. Pitch burnt is not ami≈øs ≈øometimes, again≈øt faintne≈øs and infectious Scents. I ≈øpeak my experience, for their benefit and direction that may need it.

And becau≈øe ≈øome has urged my coming back, as an argument again≈øt the place, and the probability of its improvement; adding, that I would for that rea≈øon never return: I think fit to ≈øay, That next Summer (God willing) I intend to go back, and carry my Family and the be≈øt part of my per≈øonal E≈øtate with me. And this I do not not only of Duty, but Inclination and Choice. God will ble≈øs and pro≈øper poor America.

I ≈øhall conclude with this further notice, That to the end ≈øuch as are willing to embrace any of the foregoing Propo≈øitions, for the improvement
of Adventurers E≈øtates, may not be di≈øcouraged from an inability to find ≈øuch Landlords, Tenants, Ma≈øters and Servants, if they intimate that de≈øire to my Friend Philip Ford, living in Bow-lane in London, they may in all probability be well accommodated; few of any quality or capacity, de≈øigned to the Province, that do not inform him of their inclination and condition.

Now for you that think of going, thither, I have this to ≈øay, by way of Caution. If an hair of our heads fall not to the ground, without the Providence of God, remember your removal is of greater moment. Wherefore have a due reverence and regard to his good Providence, as becomes a People that profe≈øs a Belief in Providence. Go clear in your≈øelves, and of all others. Be moderate in Expectation, count on Labour before a Crop, and Co≈øt before Gain; for ≈øuch Per≈øons will be≈øt endure difficulties, if they come and bear the ≈øucce≈øs, as well as find the comfort that u≈øually follows ≈øuch con≈øiderate undertakings.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION OF THE I≈øland of MONTSERRAT.
div.p: MOnt≈øerrat is a I≈øland of a ≈ømall extent,Its Extent. being not above Ten Miles long, and Nine broad. It was ≈øo called by the Spaniards, at their di≈øcovery of it, from a Mountain therein, which re≈øembles that of Mont≈øerrat, near Barcelona, in Spain. It is Situated in the Latitude of ≈øeventeen degrees on this ≈øide the Line.Its Situation. 'Tis very much inclined to Mountains, which for the mo≈øt part are very well cloathed with Cedar and other u≈øeful Trees; the Valleys and Plains being likewi≈øe very plea≈øant and fruitful. 'Tis chiefly Inhabited by Iri≈øh, Inhabitants. intermixed with ≈øome Engli≈øh, making together about ≈øeven Hundred Per≈øons. There is in it a very fair Church, of a delightful Structure, built by the liberal contributions of the Governour and Inhabitants; the Pulpit, Seats, and all the re≈øt of the Carpenters and Joyners Work, being framed of the mo≈øt precious ≈øweet-≈øented Wood of its own Product.

There is ≈øometimes taken upon the Coa≈øt of this I≈øland, a ≈øtrange kind of Mon≈øter,A ≈øtrange Mon≈øter. about four Foot long, and proportionable in bulk, having on its Head a great bunch like an Hedghog; his Skin hard and rough, like that of a Sea-Dog; of a black colour,; his Head is flat, having on the upper part of it many little ri≈øings, and among them two very ≈ømall black Eyes; his Mouth is very wide, his Teeth ≈øharp, and two of them crooked like a Boars; he has two Finns, and a broad forked Tail; all which renders him of ≈øo terrible a look, that they call him the Sea-Devil; which Name was given it chiefly upon his having two liltle black Horns, growing above the Eyes, turning towards his Back like a Rams; his Fle≈øh is ≈øoft, full of ≈øtrings, and of a poy≈øonous quality, cau≈øing ≈øtrange Vomitings and Swoonings, which prove mortal, if not timely prevented by a ≈øpecifick Antidote.

Another, called the Sea-∆≤nicorn, Sea-∆≤nicorn. is no le≈øs wonderful; ≈øome of them being eighteen Foot long, of a curious Vermilion colour; the Body covered with blew Scales, (intermix'd in ≈øome places with white) about the bigne≈øs of a Crown piece; it hath ≈øix large Finns, like the end of Galley Oars; a Head like a Hor≈øe, and a fair ≈øtreight Horn, about nine Foot long, i≈ø≈øuing out of the fore-part of it, waxing ≈ømaller and ≈ømaller to the very point; which is ≈øo exceeding hard and ≈øharp, that it will pierce through the harde≈øt Bodies; its Fe≈øh is delicate Meat, and its Body ≈øo large, that three Hundred Per≈øons are reported to have fed upon one taken in tho≈øe Parts.

But none of tho≈øe Sea Mon≈øters, that are eatable, are ≈øo much in e≈øteem as a certain Fi≈øh, called by the French, Lamantine, or Manaty; ≈øome whereof are eighteen Foot long, having a Head like a Cow, and is therefore called the Sea-Cow; it hath a thick dark coloured Skin, ≈øomewhat hairy, which when dried, ≈øerves for a defence again≈øt the Arrows of the Indians; in≈øtead of Finns they have two ≈øhort Feet, which ≈øeem much too weak for the ≈øupporting ≈øo heavy a Body; he lives upon what grows on the Rocks, and in ≈øhallow places. where there is not much Water.

Upon this Coa≈øt likewi≈øe are often ≈øeen great numbers of Fi≈øhes which Fly fifteen or twenty Foot above Water,Flying Fi≈øh. and near one Hundred Paces in length, but no more, in regard their Wings are dried by the Sun; they are ≈øomewhat like Herrings, but of a rounder Head and broader Back; their Wings like a Bats; in their flight they often ≈øtrike again≈øt the Sails of Ships, and fall, even in the day time, upon the Decks, and ≈øome report them to be very good Meat; the occa≈øion of their flying, is, to avoid danger from greater Fi≈øhes; but they meet with Enemies in the Air, as well as Water, having open ho≈øtility with certain Sea-Fowl, which living only upon prey, ≈øeize them as they fly.

The Sword-Fi≈øh The Sword-Fi≈øh. is worth ob≈øerving, as well as the Flying-Fi≈øh; it hath at the end of the upper Jaw a defen≈øive weapon, about the breadth of a great broad Sword, which hath ≈øharp hard Teeth on both ≈øides; ≈øeveral of the≈øe Swords are five Foot long, and about ≈øix Inches broad towards the lower end; with ≈øeven and twenty white ≈øolid Teeth in each rank, and the bulk of their Bodies
an≈øwering thereto; the Head of this Mon≈øter is flat, and hideous to behold, being in form of a Heart, having near their Eyes two vents, at which they ca≈øt out the Water they have ≈øwallowed; they have no Scales, but a grayi≈øh Skin on the Back, and white under the Belly, which is rough like a File; they have ≈øeven Finns, two on each Side, two on the back, and one which ≈øerves them for a Tail: Some call them Saw-Fi≈øhes, and others Emperours; becau≈øe there is always open War between them and the Whale, which is very often wounded to death by their terrible weapon.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION OF THE I≈øland of ANG∆≤ILLA.
div.p: THhis I≈øle of Anguilla, ≈øometimes called Snake-I≈øland, from its ≈øhape, ≈øeated in the Latitude of 18 deg. and 21 min. on this ≈øide the Equinoctial,Situation. is a long Tract of Land, and extendeth it≈øelf length about ten Leagues, and in breadth about three. The InhabitantsInhabitants. are Engli≈øh, which are computed to amount unto two or three Hundred; which Plant Tobacco, which is highly e≈øteemed by tho≈øe who are good Judges in that Commadity.

Before the di≈øcovery of America, there were not found in the≈øe Parts any Hor≈øes, Kine, Oxen, Sheep, Goats, Swine, or Dogs; but for the better conveniency of their Navigations, and ≈øupply of their Ships, in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity, they left ≈øome of the≈øe Creatures in ≈øeveral Parts of this New-found World; where they have ≈øince multiplied and become ≈øo numerous, that they are more common than in any Part of Europe.

But be≈øides the≈øe Forreign kind of Cattel, there were before in the≈øe I≈ølands certain ≈øorts of ≈øtrange four footed Beats;Their Bea≈øts and Cattel. as, the Opa≈ø≈øum, about the bigne≈øs of a Cat, with a ≈øharp Snout, the neither Jaw being ≈øhorter than the upper, like a Pigs; it hath very ≈øharp Claws, and climbs Trees ea≈øily, feeding upon Birds, and (in want thereof) upon Fruit; it is remarkable for a pur≈øe or bag of its own Skin, folded together under its Belly, wherein it carries its Young, which he lays upon the ground at plea≈øure, by opening that natural pur≈øe; and when he would depart, he opens it again, and the Young ones get in, and he carries them with him where-ever he goes; the Female ≈øuckles them without ≈øetting them on the ground, for her Teates lie within that pur≈øe; they commonly bring ≈øix Young ones; but the Male, who hath ≈øuch another natural pur≈øe under his Belly, takes his turn to carry them, to ea≈øe the Female.

There is al≈øo in ≈øome of the≈øe I≈ølands a kind of wild Swine, with ≈øhort Ears, almo≈øt no Tail, and their Navels on their Backs; ≈øome of them are all black, others have certain white ≈øpots; their ≈øtrange grunting is more hideous than that of Swine; they are called Javaris; the fle≈øh is of ta≈øte
good enough, but very hardly taken, in regard the Boar is in a manner unwearied, by rea≈øon of a vent or hole he hath on his Back, by which his Lungs are mightily refre≈øhed; and if he be forced (when he is pur≈øued by Dogs) to ≈øtop, he is armed with ≈øuch ≈øharp and cutting Tu≈øhes, that he tearts to pieces all that ≈øet upon him.

The Tatous is another ≈øtrange Creature, armed with a hard ≈øcaly coat, wherewith they cover and ≈øecure them≈øelves, as with armour; having a Head and Snout like a Pig, wherewith they turn up the ground; they have al≈øo in each Paw five very ≈øharp Claws, which help them to thru≈øt out the Earth with the more ea≈øe, and pull up the Roots whereupon they feed in the night time; they have in their Tail a ≈ømall bone, which is reported to help deafne≈øs, and noi≈øe, and pains in the Ears; they are about the bigne≈øs of a Fox, and their fle≈øh is accounted delicate Meat; when they are pur≈øued or ≈øleep, which is u≈øually in the day time, they clo≈øe them≈øelves clo≈øe up together like a Bowl, and get in their Feet, Head and Ears with ≈øo much dexterity under their hard Scales, that their whole Body is by that natural armour ≈øecured again≈øt all the attempts of Hunt≈ømen and Dogs; and when at any time they come near any precipiece, or ≈øteep hill, they roul down without getting any harm.

There is likewi≈øe the Agouty, another Creature of a dark colour, with a little Tail, without Hair, having two Teeth only in each Jaw; it holds its meat in the two fore-Claws like a Squirrel, and its u≈øual cry is, as if it di≈øtinctly pronounced the word Covey; when it is hunted, it gets into hollow Trees, out of which it is not to be forced but by ≈ømoak, making a hideous cry before they will
leave the holes in which they are gotten; if taken while young, they are ea≈øily tamed; but if old, with exceeding difficulty; when they are angry, they ≈øtrike the ground with their hind-feet like a Rabbet, being about the ≈øame bigne≈øs and ≈øhape, only their Ears are ≈øhort and round; 'tis a fierce Creature, and its hair (when angry) ≈øtands perfectly upright.

There is likewi≈øe Musk-Rats, which live in holes and boroughs like Rabbets; there comes from them a ≈øcent like Musk, which cau≈øes melancholly, and ≈øo ≈øtrongly perfumes their boroughs, that it is ea≈øie to find them out.

But of all the Creatures which this I≈øland produces, the Alegator is the mo≈øt remarkable; it keeps near the Sea, and in Rivers, and I≈ølands un-inhabited, and ≈øometimes likewi≈øe on ≈øhore, among the Reeds; it is a Creature very fearful to behold, and grows to the very la≈øt day of its life; ≈øo that many of them are eighteen Foot long, and as big about as a Hog≈øhead; their lower Jaws are immoveable, but their Mouth is ≈øo wide, and their Teeth ≈øo exceeding ≈øharp, that they can with ea≈øe bite a Man in two: Tho≈øe that are bred in fre≈øh Water ≈ømell of Musk, and that ≈øo ≈øtrongly, that they perfume the very Air an hundred Paces round about them, and ≈øcent the very Water in which they live; tho≈øe of them that live in the Sea have not ≈øo ≈øtrong a ≈øcent, however both kinds are exceeding dangerous to ≈øuch as ≈øwim in tho≈øe Parts; they are always very ≈øly, and make u≈øe of a cunning ≈ølight for the ≈øeizing Hor≈øes and Cows, it being their cu≈øtom to lye lurking at the places where u≈øually they come to drink, watching his advantage; and having half ≈øhut his eyes, ≈øloats upon the top of the Water like a piece of rotten
Wood, by which means he gets by ≈ømall degrees ≈øtill nearer to the poor Bea≈øt, and while he is drinking, without the lea≈øt dread of ≈øuch an Enemy, ≈øuddenly ≈øeizes him by the lips, dragging him under Water until he is drown'd, after which he eats him.

He likewi≈øe ≈øometimes ≈øurprizes Men by the ≈øame ≈ølight; for one who was a Servant to the Con≈øul of Alexandria, going to take up one of them, thinking it had been a piece of Wood, was ≈øuddenly ≈øeized on, and drawn by it to the bottom of the River, and never ≈øeen more.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION Of the ISLAND of BARBADA, or BARB∆≤DA.
div.p:
BArbada is ≈øituated in 17 degrees and a half of Northern Latitude;Situation. of no great extent, not exceeding fifteen Miles in length, and of no great account to the Engli≈øh, who are the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors of it; yet it is found to be of a fertile Soyl, well ≈øtored with Cattel and Sheep, and might produce ≈øeveral good Commodities were it well manag'd, to the advantage of the Inhabitants. But it is ≈øubject to one great inconveniency, as well as ≈øome others of tho≈øe I≈ølands, viz. the Caribeans of Dominica, and other places,
make frequent Incur≈øions, and commit great Spoils in it; the enmity and aver≈øion which tho≈øe Canibals have received again≈øt the Engli≈øh Nation in general, be ≈øo great & irreconcilable, that there ≈øeldom pa≈ø≈øeth a Year wherein they do not make an Eruption into ≈øome one or other of the≈øe I≈ølands; and if not pre≈øently di≈øcovered, and vigorou≈øly oppo≈øed at their fir≈øt Landing, do much mi≈øchief, de≈øtroying all before them with Fire and Sword, except the Women and Children, which, together with the Spoil and Plunder, they carry off to their own Territories.

The Caribeans, who Inhabit divers of tho≈øe I≈ølands, are generally thought to have been formerly driven by their Enemies from the Continent of America, and forced to take ≈øhelter here, having among≈øt them≈øelves various and very different Opinions, Cu≈øtoms and Ceremonies; ≈øuch as live near, and conver≈øe with the Chri≈øtians, have relinqui≈øh'd many of their ancient barbarous U≈øages, and have very much civiliz'd their Conver≈øations; which gave occa≈øion to two ancient Caribeans to entertain ≈øome of the European Chri≈øtians with this or the like Di≈øcour≈øe. Our People are now quite degenerated from what they formerly were, and in a manner become ju≈øt like yours; and ≈øo different are we now grown from what we were before, that we find it a matter of ≈øome difficulty, for us to know our≈øelves. To which degeneracy of ours, attribute tho≈øe furious Hurricanes which happen now more frequently, than they were wont to do in the Days of Old.

The Inhabitants are hand≈øom, well-proportioned, of a ≈ømiling Countenance, their Eyes and Hair are black, their Foreheads and No≈øes flat, being cru≈øhed down by their Mothers, at the
time of their Birth, and all the time of their Sucking, becau≈øe they imagine that flatne≈øs to be a kind of beauty and perfection: Their Feet are large and thick, and ≈øo exceeding hard, that although they go bare-foot, neither ≈øhall you ≈øee any of them blind, lame, crook-back'd, bald, or having any other natural infirmity. Such Scars and Deformities as they get in the Wars, they glory in, as evident demon≈øtrations of their Valour. Their Hair is ≈øtrait and long, the Women attributing the highe≈øt excellency to that which exceeds in blackne≈øs; both Men and Women tye up their Hair behind, which they bind ≈øo hard, that it ≈øtands up upon their Heads like a horn, but hangs loo≈øe upon the top; it falls down again on each ≈øide of their Heads. The Men, ≈øo ≈øoon as their Beards begin to grow, pluck them up by the roots, accounting it a great deformity to the Europeans to wear any: both Men and Women go naked, and if any ≈øhould ≈øo much as endeavour to touch their Privy-Parts, all the re≈øt will deride them: and tho≈øe who conver≈øe among≈øt the Chri≈øtians, though they are much civilized, and have for≈øaken many of their odd and barbarous Cu≈øtoms, yet no per≈øwa≈øion can prevail with them to relinqui≈øh this.

They generally ≈øay, they came naked into the World, and it will be a madne≈øs for them to hide the bodies nature has be≈øtowed upon them; notwith≈øtanding which they change the natural colours of their skins, by dying them with a red Compo≈øition, which they make for that purpo≈øe, and wherewith they always anoint them≈øelves after wa≈øhing; and many times, to make them≈øelves appear the more gallant, as they imagine, they draw black Circles about their Eyes with the Juyce of Juniper-Apples;
and when they would appear more gallant than ordinary, put on a Crown of Feathers of different colours, and hang Fi≈øh-bones, or Buck, made of Gold, Siver, or Tin, in their Ears, and ≈øome of them make holes through their Lips, or in the ≈øpace between their No≈øtrils, wherein they hang Rings, Fi≈øh-bones, or ≈øome ≈øuch Toys, to increa≈øe their gallantry; and ≈øome of the better ≈øort wear Necklaces of Amber, Coral, Cri≈øtal, or ≈øome ≈øuch kind of glittering ≈øtuff.

There are not many venomous CreaturesVenomous Creatures. to be found in this I≈øland, nor in any of the Caribbees, but yet there are many Snakes and Serpents of many colours and forms, ≈øome whereof are nine or ten foot long, and near as big as a Man's thigh; one whereof being killed, a whole Hen, feathers and all, were found in her belly, be≈øides a dozen Eggs, upon which the Hen was ≈øitting when the Serpent ≈øeized her, which ≈øhews them to be very large; notwith≈øtanding they are not poy≈øonous, but plea≈øure the inhabitants by freeing their Hou≈øes from Rats and other ≈øuch like Vermine, which they kill and devour. There is another ≈øort of Serpent, above an Ell long, and not above an Inch about, which feed upon Frogs and Birds, and are in colour of ≈øo lovely green, that they are very delightful to the eye. But there are two ≈øorts of Snakes that are very hurtful and dangerous; the fir≈øt is gray on the back, and feels ≈øoft like Velvet; the other is either yellow or red, very dreadful to look on, their heads being flat and broad, and their jaws exceeding wide, and armed with eight or ten teeth as ≈øharp as Needles, from whence they produce their poy≈øon, which lies in little pur≈øes near the roots of their teeth; they do not chew their Food, (but ≈øwallow it down whole) for if they ≈øhould, the inhabitants ≈øay, they would poy≈øon them≈øelves: they are ≈øo exceeding venomous,
that if a man chance to be hurt by them, if help be not immediately had, the wound in two hours proves incurable: nor have they any other vertue, that de≈øerves commendation, but this, they never hurt any man, which doth not fir≈øt mole≈øt them.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION OF THE I≈ølands of BERM∆≤DAS, OR THE SUMMER-ISLANDS.
div.p: EA≈øt of Virginia and Carolina, which is a part of Florida, lies the I≈øles of Bermudas, ≈øo called from John Bermudas, by whom they were fir≈øt di≈øcovered, or the Summer-I≈ølands, as they are likewi≈øe ≈øometimes called, from the Shipwreck which Sir George Summers, an Engli≈øh-man, ≈øuffered upon that Coa≈øt; they are a great multitude of I≈øles, being no le≈øs than 400 in number, as ≈øome affirm, that lie di≈øtant 1600 Leagues from England, from Madera 1000, from Hi≈øpaniola 400, and from Carolina, which is the neare≈øt part of land, about 300 Leagues.

figure.head: AESTIVARUM INSULAE ‚Ä¢ BARMUDAS
Lat. 32D 25m 3300 miles from London 500 from Roanoke in Virginia
figure.p: Circa≈øoltitium ae≈øtirum Anno 16 ‚Ä¢ 6 ≈øolvere ex his In≈øulis quinque viri in Schapha ≈øuperne aperta trium doliorum majorum capacitatis, et po≈øt ≈øeptem hebdomadarum navigationuÃÑ omnes incolumes in Hiberniam appulerunt, quale ab hominum memoria vix accidi≈øs creditur.

div.p: The bigge≈øt of the≈øe I≈øles is called St. Georges, St. Georges. and is about five or ≈øix Leagues long, and in the broade≈øt place not a League broad, all the re≈øt being much le≈øs. The whole clu≈øter do together form a body much like a Cre≈øcent, and inclo≈øe ≈øeveral very good Ports, the chief whereof are tho≈øe of the Great Sound, Harrington's Inlet, Southhampton, and Pagets, which, with their Forts of Dover and Warwick, take their names from the ≈øeveral Noblemen that have been concerned as Adventurers.
The Earth in tho≈øe I≈øles is exceeding fertile, yielding two Crops every Year,Fertility. which they generally gather in about the Months July and December.

They have ≈øeveral ≈øorts of excellent Fruits,Fruits. as Oranges, Dates, Mulberries both white and red, (in the Trees whereof breed abundance of Silk-worms, which produce great plenty of that Commodity) and Tobacco: there has been found ≈øome Pearl and Amber-grea≈øe. They have likewi≈øe there plenty of Tortoi≈øe, their fle≈øh being counted there very delicious: they have good ≈øtore of Hogs, and great variety of Fowls and Birds, among≈øt which are Cranes, and a ≈øort of Sea-Fowl, which breeds in holes, like our Rabits; and ≈øuch is the fruitfulne≈øs and the delightful verdure wherein the≈øe I≈øles always appear, that Summers ≈øeemed to take plea≈øure in his Shipwreck, and, neglecting his return for England, endeavoured, with the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Sir Thomas Gates, to ≈øettle a Plantation there. At their fir≈øt coming a≈øhore they found them≈øelves ≈øupplied by a va≈øt variety of Fowl, which were taken without difficulty, no le≈øs than one thou≈øand of
one kind, ≈øomewhat bigger than a Pigeon, being caught by them in two or three hours ≈øpace: this ≈øort of Fowl lay ≈øpeckled Eggs, as large as Hens, on the Sand, and this they do every day, without being frighted, though Men ≈øit down by them. The greate≈øt inconveniency that attends the place, is their want of fre≈øh Water; there is none for their occa≈øions, but what is to be found in Wells Pits, there being neither Fountain nor Stream in all the≈øe I≈øles.

The Sky is almo≈øt continually ≈øerene and clear, and the AirAir. ≈øo exceeding temperate and healthy, that it is rare to hear of a Man's dying of any other di≈øtemper than that of Old Age, which has occa≈øioned many to remove from England thither, barely for the enjoyment of a long and healthful Life, and when they have continued there for any con≈øiderable time, they are exceeding fearful of removing out of ≈øo good an Air, le≈øt it ≈øhould ha≈øten their removal to the grave: However, when the Sky is at any time darkened with Clouds, it Thunders and Lighten, and the Weather proves exceeding ≈øtormy and tempe≈øtuous, the Wind ≈øometimes rather thundering than blowing from every quarter, for forty eight hours together. The North and North-We≈øt Winds cau≈øe Winter in December, January, and February, which is however ≈øo very moderate, that young Birds and Fruits, and other Concomitants of the Spring are ≈øeen there in tho≈øe Months. The I≈øle of St. Georges, which is the bigge≈øt and of more fame than all the re≈øt, and to which the name of Bermudas is more generally given, is ≈øituated in thirty two Degrees and thirty Minutes of North-Latitude.

No venomous Bea≈øtsBea≈øts. are to be found in this I≈øland, neither will they live, if brought thither; their Spiders are no way poy≈øonous, but are of ≈øundry and various colours, and in hot weather make their Webs ≈øo exceeding ≈øtrong that the ≈ømall Birds are ≈øometimes entangled and caught therein.
There grows in this I≈øland a ≈øort of Ceder-trees, Trees. which differ from all other in the World, in ≈øeveral re≈øpects, the Wood whereof is very ≈øweet and well ≈øented.

The Engli≈øh, who ≈øettled them≈øelves upon this I≈øle in the Year 1612, are the only ProprietorsProprietors. thereof, having now e≈øtabli≈øhed a powerful Colony there, wherein are about five thou≈øand Inhabitants. The I≈øland is exceeding ≈øtrong, and defended as it were with a kind of natural Fortification, being ≈øo fenced about with Rocks, that without knowledge of the Pa≈ø≈øages, a Boat of ten Tun cannot be brought into the Haven, although, by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of a skilful Pilot, there is entrance for Ships of the greate≈øt burden. And, be≈øides the natural ≈øtrength of tho≈øe I≈ølands, the Engli≈øh have, ≈øince their ≈øettling there, added ≈øuch artificial helps, and ≈øo ≈øtrongly fortified the approaches, by Blockhou≈øes and Forts, as renders it impregnable.

In the Year 1616, which is four Years after the fir≈øt ≈øettling there, Captain Tucker is ≈øent over with a new Supply, whereupon they applied them≈øelves the more earne≈øtly to the planting of Corn, Tobacco, and other Commodities, ≈øo that, in about three Years, tho≈øe I≈øles began to gain ≈øo much repute in England, that the improving them became a publick bu≈øine≈øs, many great Lords and Per≈øons of Quality intere≈øting them≈øelves therein, as Adventurers,
whereupon Captain Buttler, was di≈øpatched thither with a new Supply of 500 Men, about which time the I≈øle was divided into Tribes or Counties, and the whole reduced to a ≈øettled Government, both in Church and State; after which, things ≈øucceeded ≈øo well, that it has been ever ≈øince growing to greater perfection.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION OF CAROLINA.
div.p: CAROLINA, ≈øo called from his late Maje≈øty King Charles the Second, of eternal Memory, is a new Colony not long ≈øince ≈øettled by the Engli≈øh in that part of Florida adjoyning to Virginia, which makes its Northern bounds in the Latitude of thirty ≈øix Degrees,Situation. and extends its ≈øelf to the Latitude of 29 Degrees, which terminates its extream Southern bounds; It is on the Ea≈øt wa≈øhed with the Atlantick Ocean, and is bounced on the We≈øt by Mare Pacificum of the South-Sea.

This Province of Carolina (≈øaith he) was in the Year 1663. granted by Letters Patents from his late Maje≈øty, in propriety to Edward, Earl of Clarendon; George, Duke of Albemarl; William, Earl of Craven; John, Lord Berkley; Anthony, Lord A≈øhly, ≈øince Earl of Shaftsbury; Sir George Carteret, and Sir John Coleton, Knights and Baronets; and Sir William Berkley, Knight: By which Letters Patents the Laws of England are always to be in force in Carolina, only the Lords Proprietors have power, with the con≈øent of the Inhabitants, to make ≈øuch By-laws as may be thought nece≈ø≈øary for the better government of the Province. So that no Money can be rai≈øed, or Law made, without the con≈øent of the Inhabitants or their Repre≈øentatives. They are likewi≈øe thereby indued with a right to appoint and impower Governours and other Magi≈øtrates, to grant Liberty of Con≈øcience, make Con≈øtitutions, with many other great Priviledges, &c. as will ≈øufficiently appear by the Letters Patents. And the ≈øaid Lords Proprietors have there ≈øettled a Con≈øtitution of Government, whereby is granted Liberty of Con≈øcience, and wherein all po≈ø≈øible care is taken for the equal admini≈øtration of Ju≈øtice, and for the la≈øting ≈øecurity of the Inhabitants both in their Bodies and E≈øtates. And by their Care and Endeavours, and at their very great charge, two Colonies are likewi≈øe ≈øettled in that Province, one at Albemarl, in the mo≈øt Notherly part, and the other at A≈øhly-River, which is in the Latitude of thirty two Degrees and ≈øome odd Minutes.

Albemarl, Albemarl. which borders upon Virginia, only exceeds it in Health, Fertility, and Mildne≈øs of Winter, being in the Growths, Productions, and other things much of the ≈øame nature with it, and therefore I ≈øhall not trouble my ≈øelf nor the Reader with a particular De≈øcription of that part, but apply my ≈øelf principally to di≈øcour≈øe of the Colony ≈øettled at A≈øhly-River.

This Colony was fir≈øt ≈øettled in the Month of April, 1670. by the Lords Proprietors, who did, at their ≈øole charge, furni≈øh out three Ships with a con≈øiderable number of able Men, and eighteen Months Provi≈øion, together with Cloth, Tools, Ammunition, and what≈øoever el≈øe was thought nece≈ø≈øary for this new Settlement; and continued for ≈øeveral years after to ≈øupply the place with all things nece≈ø≈øary, until the Inhabitants were, by their own indu≈øtry, able to live of them≈øelves; in which condition they have now been for divers years pa≈øt, and are arrived to a very great degree of plenty, ≈øo that mo≈øt ≈øorts of Provi≈øions are cheaper there than in any other of the Engli≈øh Colonies.

A≈øhly-River, A≈øhly-River. about ≈øeven Miles from the Sea, divides it≈øelf into two branches, the Southermo≈øt ≈øtill retains the name of A≈øhly, but the North branch is called Cooper-River. Upon the Point of Land, which divides tho≈øe two Rivers, the Proprietors, in the Year 1680. ordered the Port-Town, that ≈øhould ≈øerve for them both, to be built, calling it Charles-Town, which is ≈øince con≈øiderably advanced, to the number of near two hundred Hou≈øes, more being daily rai≈øing by per≈øons of all ≈øorts, that repair thither from the more Northern Engli≈øh
Colonies in the Sugar-I≈ølands, be≈øides tho≈øe that go from England and Ireland; many per≈øons who likewi≈øe went thither Servants, having, ≈øince their times were out, gotten good ≈øtocks of Cattel and Servants of their own, built them≈øelves Hou≈øes, and exerci≈øe their Trades. Many that went thither in that condition, being now worth ≈øeveral hundred Pounds, living in a very plentiful condition, and continually adding to, and increa≈øing their E≈øtates; ≈øo that Land is already become of that value, near the Town, that it is ≈øold for twenty Shillings per Acre, though pillaged of all its valuable Timber, and not cleared of the re≈øt. And the Land that is cleared and fitted for planting, and fenced, is let for ten Shillings per Annum, the Acre, though twenty Miles di≈øtance from the Town; and ≈øix Men will, in ≈øix Weeks time, fell, clear, fence in, and fit it for planting. At this Town, as ≈øoon as its Foundations were well laid, there Rode, at one time, ≈øixteen Sail of Ships, (≈øome whereof carried above two hundred Tun) that came from divers Parts of the King's Dominions, to traffick there, which great concour≈øe of Shipping will undoubtedly make it a con≈øiderable Town of Trade.

It's a Country ble≈ø≈øed with a temperate and whol≈øom Air,Temperature. neither the heat in Summer, nor the cold in Winter, being the lea≈øt trouble≈øom or offen≈øive, the latter being ≈øo exceeding moderate, that it doth not ≈øo much as check the growth and flouri≈øhing of the Trees and Plants; which is occa≈øioned either by rea≈øon of its having the great Body of the Continent to the We≈øtward of it, and by con≈øequence the North-We≈øt Wind, which always blows contrary to the Sun, and is the freezing
Wind, as the North-Ea≈øt is with us in Europe, or el≈øe from the frozen Lakes which lie beyond Canada, or from the uncultivated Earth, which being for the mo≈øt part covered with large, ≈øhading Trees, or from all tho≈øe rea≈øons together; but certain it is, much more moderate both in heat and cold than any other place that lies in the ≈øame Latitude; December and January, which are the colde≈øt Months, are much of the ≈øame temperature as the latter end of March or beginning of April in England, which ≈ømall Winter cau≈øes a Fall of the Leaf, and doth as it were adopt the Country-Production of all the Grains and Fruit that grow with us in England, as well as tho≈øe that require a greater degree of heat, ≈øo that the Apple, the Pear, the Plum, the Quince, the Apricock, the Peach, the Walnut, the Mulberry, and the Che≈ønut, thrive very well in the ≈øame Garden, with the Orange, the Limon, the Pomgranate, the Figg, and the Almond. Nor is the Winter ≈øubject to Clouds and Fogs, but the Rain, though it fall often in the Winter Months, u≈øually comes in quick Showers, and are no ≈øooner pa≈øt, but the Sun pre≈øently ≈øhines out again.

The Summer is not ≈øo hot as in Virginia, Climate. which is chiefly occa≈øioned, as I ≈øaid before, from tho≈øe Briezes which con≈øtantly ri≈øe about Eight of the Clock in the Morning, and blow from the Ea≈øt, till about Four in the Afternoon, about which time it cea≈øeth, and a North-wind ri≈øeth, which blowing all Night, keeps it exceeding fre≈øh and cold.

Such as are ≈øeated near Mar≈øhy places, are ≈øomewhat inclined to Agues, but in other places 'tis ≈øo exceeding healthy, that in the fir≈øt nine years there died but one of tho≈øe Ma≈øters of Families
that went over, and he was ≈øeventy five years of Age before he came their; in≈øomuch that divers from the Bermudas removed thither, though they could never be prevailed upon to for≈øake that for any other Countrey than Carolina; where there is a fairer Pro≈øpect both of Health, Plea≈øure and Profit than in any other place in all the We≈øt-Indies; ≈øeveral per≈øons who went out of England ≈øickly and con≈øumptive, having pre≈øently upon their Arrival there, recovered their health.

The Soyl is generally very fruitful,Its Fertility. and be≈øides what is proper to the Climate, produces good Wheat, Rye, Barley, Oats and Pea≈øe, Turnips, Carrots, Par≈ønips and Potatoes, and near twenty ≈øorts of Pul≈øe which we have not in England, ≈øo that our Garden-Bean is not regarded there.

Near the Sea, the TreesThe Trees. are not very large, but further up they are bigger, and grow further a≈øunder, and ≈øo free from Under-wood, than you may ≈øee near half a Mile between the Bodies of tho≈øe Trees, who≈øe tops meeting, make a plea≈øing ≈øhade without hindering the Gra≈øs, Mirtle, and other ≈øweet-≈øented Shrubs from growing under them. There grow be≈øides the Cedar, Cypre≈øs and the like, the Oak, A≈øh, Elm, Poplar, Beech, and all other u≈øeful Timber.

Their Woods likewi≈øe abound with Hares, Squirrels, Racoons, Bea≈øts and Cattel Conies and Deer, which la≈øt are ≈øo plentiful, that an Indian Hunter killed nine fat ones in a day, and the con≈øiderable Planters have one of tho≈øe Indian Hunters for le≈øs than twenty ≈øhillings a year, who will find the Family, con≈øi≈øting of thirty People, with as much Veni≈øon
and Fowl as they can well eat; their Woods and Fields being likewi≈øe ≈øtored with great plenty of wild Turkeys, Partridges, Doves, Paraquetes, Pigeons, Cranes, and divers other Birds who≈øe fle≈øh is delicate Meat. They have likewi≈øe plenty of Sheep and Hogs, both which increa≈øe wonderfully there.
