Carolina doth ≈øo well abound with Rivers,Its Rivers. that within fifty miles of the Sea, you can ≈øcarcely place your ≈øelf ≈øeven miles from one that is navigable; and ≈øome of them are navigable for big Ve≈øels above three hundred miles up into the Countrey. Their Rivers and Brooks abound with great variety of excellent Fi≈øh, and near the Sea with good Oy≈øters, in ≈øome whereof Pearls are often found.

The Engli≈øh have a perfect Friend≈øhip with the Natives, and the Proprietors have taken care that no inju≈øtice ≈øhall be done them; a particular Court of Judicature compos'd of the ≈øobere≈øt and di≈øintere≈øted Per≈øons being e≈øtabli≈øhed by their order, to determine all differences that ≈øhall happen between the Engli≈øh and them. They are a People of a ready wit, and though illiterate, are generally found to be of a good under≈øtanding. For their keeping an account of Time, they make u≈øe of Hieroglyphicks, and in≈øtruct their Children in ≈øuch matters as relate to their Family and Countrey, which is ≈øo pre≈øerved from one generation to another. Where a Battel hath been fought, or a Colony ≈øetled, they rai≈øe a ≈ømall Pyramid of Stones, con≈øi≈øting of the number of the ≈ølain, or tho≈øe ≈øetled at the Colony; and for Religious Rites, as Sacrifices, Burials, and the like, they make round Circles with Straws or Reeds, by the differing placing whereof, it is known for
what it is made; and to meddle with any of tho≈øe Circles, is accounted by them no better than Sacrilege.

They are generally well proportioned, and ≈øo well affected to the Engli≈øh, that they are ready upon all occa≈øions to contribute their A≈ø≈øi≈øtance to them; they are generally of a good and hone≈øt meaning, being no ways addicted to Vice or any Extravagancies, and always content them≈øelves with a mean Diet and Apparel for their pre≈øent ≈øub≈øi≈øtance, without taking much care for the time to come. They are much addicted to Mirth and Dancing, and to Acts of Courage and Valour, which they prefer above all other Virtues, and are therefore almo≈øt continually engaged in War, one Town or Village again≈øt another; their Governments generally being of no greater extent; and that ≈øide which Fortune crowns with Victory, rejoyce with triumphant Jollities: By which means ≈øeveral Nations have been in a manner quite de≈øtroyed ≈øince our fir≈øt Settlement at A≈øhley River; which keeps them ≈øo thin of People, and ≈øo divided among them≈øelves, that were they le≈øs affected to the Engli≈øh, yet they would have no rea≈øon to entertain the lea≈øt apprehen≈øions of Danger from them, being already too ≈øtrong for all the Indians that inhabit within five hundred miles of them, if they were perfectly united; which the Indians know ≈øo well, that they will never adventure to fall out with them, nor offer the lea≈øt injury to any of thy Engli≈øh Nation.

They wor≈øhipTheir Wor≈øhip. one God, as the creator of all things, whom they call Okee, and to whom their High Prie≈øt offers Sacrifice, but believes he hath ≈øomething el≈øe to do than to mind humane affairs;
which they fancy he commits to the Government of le≈øs Deities, that is, to good and evil Spirits, to whom their inferior Prie≈øts make their Devotion and Sacrifices. They believe the tran≈ømigration of Souls; and when any of them die, their Friends inter with their Corps Provi≈øions and Hou≈øhold-≈øtuff for their Elizium Shades, which they imagine to be beyond the Mountains from the Indian Ocean. They are very ≈øuperititious in their Marriages, and from a ≈øtrange kind of Belief which is entertained among≈øt them, that from four Women only all Mankind ≈øprang: They divide them≈øelves into the like number of Tribes, and have four Burying-places; believing it to be a wicked and ominous thing to mingle their Bodies even when dead.

The Lords Proprietors do immediately grant to all per≈øons that come thither to inhabit, the following terms; for each Ma≈øter or Mi≈øtre≈øs of a Family, fifty Acres of Land, and for every able Son or Man-≈øervant that they carry, or cau≈øe to be carried thither, fifty Acres more, and the like for each Daughter and Woman-Servant that is marriageable, and for every Child or Man or Woman-Servant under the Age of Sixteen, forty Acres, and fifty to each Servant ≈øo ≈øoon as their Time with their Ma≈øter is expired; which Land is to be enjoyed by them and their heirs for ever, upon paying only one penny an Acre as a Quit-Rent to the Lords Proprietors, which is not to commence neither till two years after their fir≈øt taking up their Land.

And in regard ≈øome who have already ≈øetled them≈øelves at Carolina, and others that intend to go thither, are de≈øirous to ≈øecure to them≈øelves large convenient Tracts of Land, without being compelled
to carry over a great number of Servants at one time, or being cumbred with the payment of a yearly Rent, the Lords Proprietors have been prevailed upon to enter into an agreement to ≈øell Land outright to ≈øuch who have a mind to buy it at the rate of fifty pounds for a thou≈øand Acres, re≈øerving to them≈øelves only a Pepper-corn, when demanded.

The way of a man's taking up Land there,Their way of taking up Land. due to him either by carrying him≈øelf or Servants into the Countrey, or by Purcha≈øe from the Lords Proprietors, is after this manner; Having found a place to his Liking, which is not already po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by another, he applies him≈øelf to the Governor, and the Proprietors Deputies, to ≈øhew what Right he hath to it by Purcha≈øe or otherwi≈øe; who thereupon immediately i≈ø≈øue out their Warrant to the General Surveyor to mea≈øure them out a Plantation containing ≈øuch a number of Acres, as he hath proved to be his Right; which being pre≈øently done, the Surveyor makes a Certificate that he hath mea≈øured out the Land, and determined the Bounds of it: Whereupon, a Deed is prepared, and ≈øigned by the Governour and the Deputies; which being ≈øealed with the Proprietor's Seal, and regi≈øtred, is there accounted a good Conveyance in Law, the E≈øtate being thereby a≈ø≈øured and confirmed to him and his Heirs for ever: For the improving whereof, he ought to carry with him from England as many Axes, Bills, broad Hoes, and grubbing-Hoes as he de≈øigns to have men in his Plantation, together with a Saw or two, a Set of Wedges, Frames and Beetle-rings, ≈øome reaping-hooks, Scythes, Hooks, Hinges, Bolts, Locks, and Nails of all ≈øorts;
and if his Stock will reach it, ≈øuch Commodities as are the be≈øt Merchandize, and will yield him ready Money there; which are, Linnen and Woollen Cloth, and all other Stuffs to make Cloaths with; together with Thred, Silk, Buttons, Ribonds, Hats, Stockings, Shoes, and the like; which go off there at very good rates, and for which a man may purcha≈øe what≈øoever Provi≈øion he hath need of. Ships are generally going thither at all times of the Year, and the Pa≈ø≈øage of a Man or Woman is generally five pounds.

The CommoditiesCommodities. which this Countrey produceth, for the Profit as well as the ≈øub≈øi≈øtence of the Inhabitants, are ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Wines; five ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Grapes growing naturally there; and there is care taken to plant the Rheni≈øh, Canary, Claret, Mu≈øcat, Madera and Spani≈øh Grapes; of all which are already Vineyards compleated, and Wine made, which proves very good both in colour and ta≈øte, the Countrey having gentle ri≈øing Hills, of a fertil ≈øandy Earth, proper for the production of Vines; and further from the Sea ≈øeveral Gravel-Rocks, whereon they naturally grow, being indifferent large, and lu≈øcious in ta≈øte; ≈øo that ≈øeveral French Prote≈øtants, that inhabit there, doubt not but in a little time to produce great quantities of good Wine. Oyl Olive, which being carried thither from Portugal and Bermudas, flouri≈øh and increa≈øe exceedingly, and will in all probability produce as large quantities of Oyl, that it will very much conduce to the enriching of the Inhabitants; Cotton, Indigo, Silk, Ginger, Tobacco, Flax, Hemp, Pitch, Tar, Jallop, Sa≈ø≈øaparilla, Turmerick, Sa≈ø≈øafras, Snake-root, and the like.

There are in this Countrey ≈øeveral ≈øorts of ≈øtrange and mon≈øtrous Creatures;Creatures. for an Engli≈øh Gentleman travelling with ≈øome Indians, they met with a Rattle-Snake two yards and a half long, and as big as a mans Arm, which by the greatne≈øs of its Belly, they imagined to be big with young; but having killed and opened her, they found there only a ≈ømall Squirrel, which ≈øhe had ≈øwallowed whole; the Indians affirming, that tho≈øe Serpents u≈øe to lie under Trees upon which they ≈øee any Squirrels, and fixing their Eyes ≈øtedfa≈øtly upon them, the little Creature is ≈øo frighted thereby, that he falls down,, and tumbles into the Jaws of his Enemy. Travelling through a Wood, a Deer ≈øeized by a wild Cat, cro≈ø≈øed their way, almo≈øt ≈øpent with the Burden and Cruelty of his Rider, who having fa≈øtned upon his Shoulder, continued ≈øucking his Blood till the poor Bea≈øt fell down under her; which one of the Indians perceiving, ≈øhot an Arrow at the wild Cat, which wounding her under the Belly, made her leave her Prey, which was already ≈ølain, and run towards them with a fierce and dreadful Look; but her wound being mortal, her ≈øtrength and ≈øpirits failed before ≈øhe reached them; whereby they e≈øcaped her revenge, which peradventure otherwi≈øe ≈øome of them might have felt. This Creature is ≈øomewhat larger than a Fox, of a kind of a reddi≈øh gray Colour, and in figure every way like an ordinary Cat, but exceeding fierce, ravenous, and ≈øo cunning, that knowing the Deer, upon which they chiefly prey, to be two ≈øwift for them, they lurk upon Branches of Trees, and as the Deer walk and feed under them, ≈øuddenly jump down upon their backs. Their Fur is greatly
e≈øteemed, and their Fle≈øh, though as rank as that of a Dog, is eaten by the Indians.

They ≈øaw daily great Herds of Red and Fallow Deer, Bears, Leopards and Wolves, but no Lions. The Wolves were to exceeding ravenons, that they were in great fear le≈øt their Hor≈øes ≈øhould have been devoured; for in the night-time they got together in clu≈øters, and howled ≈øo near them, that it was impo≈ø≈øible to have ≈øaved them, had not the Fires which they kept continually burning in the night-time, terrified them, and frighted them away: The Woods were likewi≈øe full of Bears, Otters and gray Foxes: And arriving at length to the Appalatean Mountains, which were ≈øo high and ≈øteep, that they were a whole day before they could gain the Top; from whence the next Morning they had a beautiful pro≈øpect of the Atlantick Ocean, which wa≈øhes the Virginian Shores; but to the North and We≈øt other Mountains prevented their ≈øight, and the exceeding Coldne≈øs prevented further Di≈øcovery, and compelled them to a ≈øpeedy return.

The ≈øame Gentleman, at another time, when he went to make what Di≈øcovery he could of the Countrey, met with another ≈øort of Indians, who were Enemies to the Chri≈øtians; yet venturing among≈øt them, and pre≈øenting them with ≈øome ≈ømall Trifles of Gla≈øs and Metals, found them very kind to him, and would fain have obliged him to have ≈øetled among≈øt them, by propo≈øing a Match between him and their King's or ≈øome other Great Man's Daughter, whom he ≈øhould be≈øt fancy; nor could he wave their Courte≈øie, nor obtain leave to depart, without a Promi≈øe of returning again within ≈øix Months. And South-we≈øt from them, he found a Nation differing in Government from
all the other Indians that inhabit tho≈øe Parts, being rather Slaves than Subjects to their King, who was a very grave Man, and courteous to Strangers, yet horrid barbarous in his Super≈øtition; that whil≈øt this Gentleman was there, he ≈øent three Youths to kill as many young Women of their Enemies as they could meet withal, to ≈øerve his Son (who was then newly dead) in the other World. They were not long before they returned with Skins torn off the Head and Faces of ≈øeveral young Girls, which they laid at the Feet of their King, who received them as the mo≈øt acceptable Pre≈øents.

opener.signed: CHARLES the Second, by the Grace of God, King of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, &c.

body.p:
Whereas by Our Letters Patents, bearing date the Twenty Fourth Day of March, in the Five and Twentieth Year of Our Reign, We were graciou≈øly plea≈øed to give unto our right Tru≈øty and right Well-beloved Couzen and Coun≈øellor, Edward, Earl of Clarendon, Our High Chancellour of England; Our right Tru≈øty & right entirely Beloved Couzen & Coun≈øellour,. George, Duke of Albemarl, Ma≈øter of Our Hor≈øe; Our right Tru≈øty and Well-beloved William, now Earl of Craven; Our right Tru≈øty and Well-beloved Councellour, Anthony, Lord Chancellour of our Exchequer; Our right Tru≈øty and Well-beloved Coun≈øellour, Sir George Carteret, Knight and Baronet, Vice-Chamberlain of Our Hou≈øhold; Our right Tru≈øty and Well-beloved, Sir John Colleton, Knight and Barronet;
and Sir William Berkley, Knight, all that Territory Province, or Tract of Ground, called Carolina, ≈øituate, lying and being within our Dominions of America; extending from the North end of that I≈øland called Luke-I≈øland, which lyeth in the Southern Virginia Seas, within ≈øix and thirty deg. of Northern Latitude; and to the We≈øt, as far as the River of St. Matthias, which Bordereth upon the Coa≈øt of Florida, and within one and thirty deg. of Southern Latitude; and ≈øo We≈øt, in a direct Line, as far as the South Seas afore≈øaid. Now know ye, that We, at the humble Reque≈øt of the ≈øaid Grantees in the afore≈øaid Letters Patents named, and as a farther mark of Our particular Favour towards them, We are graciou≈øly plea≈øed to enlarge Our ≈øaid Grant unto them, according to the Bounds and Limits hereafter ≈øpecified; and in Favour to the Pious and Noble purpo≈øe of the ≈øaid Edward, Earl of Clarendon, &c. of Our e≈øpecial Grace, certain Knowledge, and meer Motion, have Given, Granted, and Confirmed; and by this Our pre≈øent Charter, for Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, do Give, Grant, and Confirm unto the ≈øaid Edward, Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, at that Province, Territories, or Tract of Land, ≈øituate, lying and being within Our Dominions of America afore≈øaid; extending North and Ea≈øtward as far as the North end of Carah-Tuck River or Inlett, upon a ≈øtraight We≈øterly Line, to Wianoacke Creek, which lyeth within or about thirty ≈øix deg. thirty min. of Northern Latitude; and ≈øo We≈øt, in a direct Line, as far as the South-Seas; and South and We≈øtward, as far as thirty nine deg. inclu≈øive Northern Latitude, and ≈øo We≈øt in a direct Line
as far as the South Seas; together with all and ≈øingular Ports, Harbours, Bays, Rivers and I≈ølets, belonging unto the Province and Territory afore≈øaid; and al≈øo all the Soil, Lands, Fields, Woods, Mountains, Fenns, Lakes, Rivers, Bays, I≈ølets, ≈øituated or being within the Bounds or Limits la≈øt before mentioned; with the Fi≈øhing of all ≈øorts of Fi≈øh, Whales, Sturgeons, and all the Royal Fi≈øhes in the Seas, Bays, I≈ølets and Rivers, within the Premi≈øes; and the Fi≈øh therein taken, together the Royalty of the Sea upon the Coa≈øt, within the Limits afore≈øaid. And moreover, all Veins, Mines and Quarries, as well di≈øcovered as not di≈øcovered, of Gold, Silver, Gems, and Precious Stones, and all other what≈øoever, be it of Stones, Marble, or any other thing what≈øoever, found or to be found within the Province, Territory, I≈øles and Limits afore≈øaid. And furthermore, the Patronage and Advow≈øons of all the Churches and Chappels, which (as Chri≈øtian Religion ≈øhall encrea≈øe within the Province, Territory, I≈øles, I≈ølets and Limits afore≈øaid) ≈øhall happen hereaf-to be Erected; together with Licence and Power to Build and Found Churches, and Chappels, and Oratories, in convenient and fit places within the ≈øaid Bounds and Limits, and to cau≈øe them to be dedicated and con≈øecrated according to the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Laws of our Kingdom of England; together with all and ≈øingular the like, and as ample right, Juri≈ødictions, Priviledges, Prerogatives, Royalties, Liberties, Immunities and Franchi≈øes, of what kind ≈øoever, within the Territories, I≈øles, I≈ølets, and Limits afore≈øaid, to have U≈øe, Exerci≈øe, and enjoy the ≈øame as amply and fully, and in as ample manner as any
Bi≈øhop of Durham, in our Kingdom of England, ever heretofore had, held, u≈øed or enjoyed, or of right, ought or could have, u≈øe or enjoy; and them, the ≈øaid Edward, Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, we do by the≈øe Pre≈øents, for Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, make, create and con≈øtitute the true and ab≈øolute Lords and Proprietors of the ≈øaid Province or Territory, and of all other the Premi≈ø≈øes, ≈øaving always the Faith, Allegiance, and Sovereign Dominions, due to Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, for the ≈øame, to have, hold, po≈ø≈øe≈øs and enjoy the ≈øaid Province, Territories, I≈øles, I≈ølets, and all and ≈øingular of them the Premi≈ø≈øes, unto them the ≈øaid Edward, Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, for ever, to be holden of Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, as of our Manor of Ea≈øtgreen, within Our County of Kent, in free and common Soccage, and not in Capite, nor by by Knight-Service, yielding and paying a parly to Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors for the ≈øame, a fourth part of all Gold and Silver O ‚Ä¢ r, which (within the Limits hereby granted) ≈øhall from time to time happen to be found over and be≈øide the yearly Rent of twenty Marks, and the fourth part of the Gold and Silver Oar in and by the ≈øaid recited Letter Patents re≈øerved and payable. And that the Province or Territory hereby granted and de≈øcribed, may be dignified with as large Titles and Priviledges, as any other Part of our Dominions and Territories in that Region, Know ye, that We of our further Grace, certain Knowledge, and meer Motion, have thought fit to annex the ≈øame Tract, Ground and Territory unto the ≈øaid Province of Carolina, and out of the fulne≈øs of our Royal
Power and Prerogative, ≈øo do for Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, annex and unite the ≈øame to the ≈øaid Province of Carolina. And for as much as we have made and ordained the afore≈øaid Edward, Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, the ame Lords Proprietors of all the Province or Territory afore≈øaid, Know ye therefore moreover, that We repo≈øing e≈øpecial Tru≈øt and Confidence in their Fidelity, Wi≈ødom, Ju≈øtice, Prudence and Circum≈øpection, for Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, Do Grant full and ab≈øolute Power, by virtue of the≈øe Pre≈øents, to them the ≈øaid Edward, Earl of Clarendon, and their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, for the good and happy Government of the ≈øaid whole Province or Territory, full Power and Authority to Erect and make ≈øeveral Counties, Baronies and Colonies of and within the ≈øaid Province, Territories, Lands and Hereditaments, in and by the ≈øaid Rented Letters Patents, and the≈øe Pre≈øents Granted or mentioned to be Granted as afore≈øaid, with ≈øeveral and di≈øtinct Juri≈ødictions, Powers, Liberties and Priviledges; and al≈øo to make, ordain and enact, and under their Seals to publi≈øh any Laws and Con≈øtitutions what≈øoever, either appertaining to the Publick State of the ≈øaid whole Province or Territory, or of any di≈øtinct or particular County, Barony or Colony of or within the ≈øame, or to the private Utility of particular Per≈øons, according to their be≈øt direction, by and with the Advice, A≈ø≈øent and Approbation of the Free-men of the ≈øaid Province or Territory, or of the Free-men of the County, Barony or Colony for which ≈øuch Laws or Con≈øtitutions ≈øhall be made; or of the greater part of them, or of their Diligates or
Deputies, whom for enacting of the ≈øaid Laws, when and as often as need ≈øhall require, We will that the ≈øaid Edward, Earl of Clarendon, &c. and their Heirs or A≈ø≈øigns ≈øhall from time to time A≈ø≈øemble in ≈øuch manner and form as to them ≈øhall ≈øeem be≈øt; and the ≈øame Laws duly to execute upon all Per≈øons within the ≈øaid Province, Territory, County, Barony or Colony, or the Limits thereof, for the time being, or which ≈øhall be con≈øtituted under the Power and Government of them, or any of them, either ≈øayling towards the ≈øaid Province or Territory of Carolina, or returning from thence towards England, or any other of our Foreign Dominions, by Impo≈øition of Penalty, Impri≈øonment, or any other Puni≈øhment; yet if it ≈øhall be needful, and the quality of the offence require it, by taking away Member and Life, either by them the ≈øaid Edward, Earl of Clarendon, &c. and theirs, by them or their Deputies, Lieutenants, Judges, Ju≈øtices, Magi≈øtrates, Officers and Mini≈øters, to be ordained and appointed according to the Tenor and true Intention of them Pre≈øents; and likewi≈øe to Erect or make any Court or Courts what≈øoever of Judicature, or otherwi≈øe, as ≈øhall be requi≈øite; and to appoint or e≈øtabli≈øh any Judges, Ju≈øtices, Magi≈øtrates or Officers what≈øoever, as well within the ≈øaid Province as at Sea, in ≈øuch manner and form as unto the ≈øaid Edward, Earl of Clarendom, &c. or their Heirs, ≈øhall ≈øeem mo≈øt convenient; al≈øo to remit, relea≈øe, pardon and aboli≈øh (whether before Judgement and after) all crimes and offences what≈øoever again≈øt the ≈øaid Laws; and to do all and every other thing & things, which unto the compleat e≈øtabli≈øment of Ju≈øtice unto Courts,
Se≈ø≈øions and forms of Judication, and manner of proceedings therein do belong, although in the≈øe Pre≈øents expre≈øs mention is not made thereof, and by Judges, by him or them deligated, to award, pre≈øs, hold, plea≈øe and determine in all the ≈øaid Courts, Places of Judicature, all Actions, Suits and Cau≈øes what≈øoever, as well Criminal as Civil, Real, Mixt, Per≈øonal, or any other kind or nature what≈øoever, which Laws ≈øo as afore≈øaid to be publi≈øhed, Our Plea≈øure is, and we do enjoyn, require and Command, ≈øhall be ab≈øolute, firm and available in Law; and that all the liege People of Us, Our Heirs or Succe≈ø≈øors, within the ≈øaid Province or Territory, do ob≈øerve and keep the ≈øame inviolably in tho≈øe Parts, ≈øo far as they concern them, under the Patents or Penalties therein expre≈ø≈øed, or to be expre≈ø≈øed, provided neverthele≈øs that the ≈øaid Laws be con≈øonant to Rea≈øon, and as near as may be conveniently agreeable to the Laws and Cu≈øtoms of this our Kingdom of England; and becau≈øe ≈øuch A≈ø≈øemblies of Freeholders cannot be ≈øo ≈øuddenly called, as there may be occa≈øion to require the ≈øame, We do therefore by the≈øe Pre≈øents, Give and Grant unto the ≈øaid Edward, Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns by them≈øelves and their Magi≈øtrates in that behalf, lawfully authorized, full power and authority from time to time, to make and ordain fit and whol≈øom Orders and Ordinances within the Province or Territory afore≈øaid, or any County, Barony or Province of or within the ≈øame, to be kept and ob≈øerved, as well for the keeping of the Peace, as for the better Government of the People there abiding, and to publi≈øh the ≈øame to all whom it may concern;
which Ordinances we do by the≈øe Pre≈øents ≈øtreightly Charge and Command to be inviolably ob≈øerved within the ≈øame Province, Territory, Counties, Baronies and Provinces, under the Penalty therein expre≈ø≈øed, ≈øo as ≈øuch Ordinances rea≈øonable, and not repugnant and contrary, but as near as may be agreeable to the Laws and Statutes of this our Kingdom of England, and ≈øo as the ≈øame Ordinances do not extend to the bringing, charging, or the taking away of the Right of any Per≈øon or Per≈øons in their Free-hold, Goods or Chattels what≈øoever; and to the end the ≈øaid Provinces or Territories may be the more happily encrea≈øed by the multude of People re≈øorting thither, and likewi≈øe be the more ≈øtrongly defended from the Incur≈øion of Savages and other Enemies, Pirates and Robbers, therefore We, for Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, do Give and Grant by the≈øe Pre≈øents, Power, Licence and Liberty to all the Leige People, for Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, in Our Kingdom of England, or el≈øewhere, within any other Our Dominions, I≈ølands, Colonies or Plantations, excepting tho≈øe who ≈øhall be expre≈øly forbidden to Tran≈øport them≈øelves and Families into the ≈øaid Province or Territory with convenient Shipping, and fitting Provi≈øion, and there to ≈øettle them≈øelves to dwell and inhabit, any Law, Act, Statute, Ordinance, or any thing to the contrary in any wi≈øe notwith≈øtanding. And We do al≈øo of Our more ≈øpecial Grace, for Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, ≈øtreightly Enjoyn, Ordain, Con≈øtitute and Command, that the ≈øaid Province or Territory ≈øhall be of our Allegiance; and that all and ≈øingular the Subjects and Liege People
of Us, Our Heirs or Succe≈ø≈øors, Tran≈øported or to be Tran≈øportcd into the ≈øaid Province, and the Children of them, or ≈øuch as ≈øhall de≈øcend from them, there born, or hereafter to be born, be and ≈øhall be Denizens and Lieges of Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors of this Our Kingdom of England, and be in all things held, treated and imputed as the Liege faithful People of Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, born within this Our Kingdom, or any other of Our Dominions; and may inhabit, or otherwi≈øe purcha≈øe and receive, take, have, hold, buy and po≈ø≈øe≈øs any Lands, Tenements or Hereditaments within the ≈øaid places, and then may Occupy and Enjoy, Give, Sell, Alien and Bequeath; as likewi≈øe Liberties, Franchi≈øes, Priviledges of this Our Kingdom of England, and of other Our Dominions afore≈øaid, may freely and quietly Have, Po≈ø≈øe≈øs and Enjoy, as our Liege People born within the ≈øame, without the lea≈øt mole≈øtation, vexation, trouble or grievance of Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, any Statute, Act, Ordinance or Provi≈øion to the contrary notwith≈øtanding. And farthermore, That Our Subjects of this Our Kingdom of England, and other Our Dominions, may be rather encoured to undertake this Expedition with ready and chearful minds, Know ye, that We of Our e≈øpecial Grace, certain Knowledge and meer Motion, do Give and Grant by vertue of the≈øe Pre≈øents, as well to the ≈øaid Edward Earl of Clarendon, &c. and their Heirs, as unto all others as ≈øhall from time to time repair unto the ≈øaid Province or Territory, with a purpo≈øe to Inhabit there, and to Trade with the Natives thereof, full Liberty and Licence, to Lade and Freight in any Ports what≈øoever of Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors and
into the ≈øaid Province of Carolina, by them, their Servants and A≈ø≈øigns, to Tran≈øport all and ≈øingular their Goods, Wares and Merchandizes; as likewi≈øe all ≈øorts of Grain what≈øoever, and any other things what≈øoever, nece≈ø≈øary for their Food and Cloathing, not Prohibited by the Laws and Statutes of Our Kingdoms and Dominions, to be carried out of the ≈øame without any Lett or Mole≈øtation of Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, or of any other Our Officers and Mini≈øters what≈øoever: Saving al≈øo to Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, the Cu≈øtoms, and other Duties and Payments due for the ≈øaid Wares and Merchandizes, according to the ≈øeveral Rates of the Places from whence the ≈øame ≈øhall be Tran≈øported. We will also, and by the≈øe Presents for Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, do Give and Grant, Licence by this Our Charter, unto the ≈øaid Edward Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, and to all the Inhabitants or Dwellers in the Province or Territory afore≈øaid, both pre≈øent and to come, full Power and ab≈øolute Authority to Import or Unlade, by them≈øelves or their Servants, Factors or A≈ø≈øigns, all Merchandize and Goods what≈øoever, that ≈øhall ari≈øe of the Fruits and Commodities of the ≈øaid Province or Territory, either by Land or by Sea, into any the Ports of Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, in the Kingdoms of England, Scotland and Ireland; or otherwi≈øe to di≈øpo≈øe of the ≈øaid Goods in the ≈øaid Ports: And if need be, within one year after the Unlading, to Lade the ≈øame Merchandize or Goods again into the ≈øame or other Ships, and to Export the ≈øame into any other Countries, either of Our Dominions or Foreign, being in Amity with Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, ≈øo as they pay ≈øuch Cu≈øtoms, Sub≈øidies
and other Duties, for the ≈øame, to Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, as the re≈øt of Our Subjects of this Our Kingdom, for the time being, ≈øhall be bound to pay; beyond which, We will not that the Inhabitants of the ≈øaid Province or Territory ≈øhall be any way charged, provided neverthele≈øs. And Our Will and Plea≈øure is, and We have farther, for the Con≈øiderations afore≈øaid, of Our ≈øpecial Grace, certain Knowledg, meer Motion, Given and Granted, and by the≈øe Pre≈øents for Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, do Give and Grant unto the ≈øaid Edward Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, full and free Licence and Liberty, and Power and Authority, at any time or times, from and after the Fea≈øt of St. Michael the Arch-Angel, which ≈øhall be in the Year of our Lord Chri≈øt, 1667. as well to Import and bring into any of Our Dominions, from the ≈øaid Province of Carolina, or any parts thereof, of the ≈øeveral Goods and Commodities herein after mentioned; that is to ≈øay, Silks, Currans, Rai≈øons, Capers, Wax, Almonds, Oyl and Olives, without paying or an≈øwering to Us, Our Heirs or Succe≈ø≈øors, any Cu≈øtoms, Impo≈øts, or other Duty, for on in re≈øpect thereof, for or during the term or ≈øpace of ≈øeven years to come, and be accounted or from and after the fir≈øt Importation of four Tuns of any the ≈øaid Goods, in any one Bottom, Ship or Ve≈ø≈øel, from the ≈øaid Province or Territory, unto any of Our Dominions: As al≈øo, to Export and carry out of any of Our Dominions, into the ≈øaid Province or Territory, Cu≈øtom-free, all ≈øorts of Tools which ≈øhall be u≈øeful and nece≈ø≈øary for the Planters there, in the accommodation and improvement of the Premi≈øes, any thing before in the≈øe Pre≈øents contained,
or any Law, Act, Statute, Prohibition, or other matter or thing heretofore Had, Made, Enacted or Provided, or hereafter to be Had, Made, Enacted or Provided to the contrary in any wi≈øe notwith≈øtanding. And furthermore, of our more ample and e≈øpecial Grace, certain Knowledge and meer Motion, We do for Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, Grant unto the ≈øaid Edward Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, full and ab≈øolute Power and Authority to Make, Erect and Con≈øtitute, within the ≈øaid Province or Territory, and I≈ølet or I≈ølets afore≈øaid, ≈øuch and ≈øo many Sea-Ports, Harbours, Creeks, and other places for Di≈øcharge and Unlading of Goods and Merchandizes out of Ships, Boats and other Ve≈ø≈øels, and for Lading of them in ≈øuch and ≈øo many places, as with ≈øuch Juri≈ødictions, Priviledges and Franchi≈øes, unto the ≈øaid Ports belonging, as to them ≈øhall ≈øeem mo≈øt expedient; and that all and ≈øingular the Ships, Boats, and other Ve≈ø≈øels which ≈øhall come for Merchardize, and Trade into the ≈øame Province or Territory, or ≈øhall depart out of the ≈øame ≈øhall be laden and unladen at ≈øuch Ports, only as ≈øhall be erected and Con≈øtituted by the ≈øaid Edward Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, and not el≈øewhere any Use, Cu≈øtom or any thing to the contrary in any wi≈øe notwith≈øtanding. And We do furthermore Will, Appoint and Ordain, and by the≈øe Pre≈øents, for Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, do Grant unto the ≈øaid Edward Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, that they the ≈øaid Edward Earl of Clarendon, &c. and their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, may from time to time for ever, have and enjoy the Cu≈øtoms and Sub≈øidies in the Ports, Harbours,
Creeks, and other places within the Province afore≈øaid, payable for Goods, Merchandizes and Wares, there Laden or Unladen, the ≈øaid Cu≈øtoms to be reasonably A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed upon any occa≈øion by them≈øelves, and by and with the con≈øent of the free People there, or the greater part of them as afore≈øaid, to whom we give Power by the≈øe Presents, for Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, for ju≈øt Cau≈øe, and in due Proportion, to A≈ø≈øe≈øs and Impo≈øe the ≈øame.

And furthermore, of Our e≈øpecial Grace, certain Knowledge and meer Motion, We have Given, Granted and Confirmed, and by the≈øe Pre≈øents, for Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, do Grant and Confirm unto the ≈øaid Edward Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, full and ab≈øolute Licence, Power and Authority, that they the ≈øaid Edward Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, from time to time hereafter, for ever, at his and their Will and Plea≈øure, may Alien, Grant, Demi≈øe or Enfeoff the Premi≈øes, or any part or parcel thereof, to him or them that ≈øhall be willing to Purcha≈øe the ≈øame, and to ≈øuch Per≈øon or Per≈øons as they ≈øhall think fit, To have and to hold to them the ≈øaid Per≈øon or Per≈øons, their Heirs of A≈ø≈øigns, in the Fee-≈øimple or Fee-tail, or for term of Life, or Lives, or Years, to be held of them the ≈øaid Edward Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, and not immediately of Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors. And to the ≈øame Per≈øon or Per≈øons, and to all and every of them, We do Give and Grant by the≈øe Pre≈øents, for Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, Licence and Authority and Power, that ≈øuch Per≈øon or Per≈øons, may have and take the Premi≈øes, or any parcel thereof, of the ≈øaid Earl
of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, and the ≈øame to hold to them≈øelves, their Heirs or A≈ø≈øigns, in what e≈øtate of Inheritance ≈øoever, in Fee-≈øimple or in Fee-tail, or otherwi≈øe, as to them and the ≈øaid Earl of Clarendon, their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, ≈øhall ≈øeem expedient. The Statute of the Parliament of Edward, Son of King Henry, heretofore King of England, Our Predece≈ø≈øor, commonly called the Statute of Quia Emptores Terrarum, or any other Statutes, Act, Ordinance, U≈øe, Law, Cu≈øtoms, or any other Matter, Cau≈øe or Thing, heretofore Publi≈øhed or Provided to the contrary, in any wi≈øe notwith≈øtanding; and becau≈øe many Per≈øons born or Inhabiting in the ≈øaid Province, for their De≈øerts and Services, may expect to be capable of marks of Honour and Favour, which in re≈øpect of the great di≈øtance cannot be conferred by Us; Our Will and Plea≈øure therefore is, and We do by the≈øe Pre≈øents, Give and Grant unto the ≈øaid Edward Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, full Power and Authority, to give and confer unto, and upon ≈øuch of the Inhabitants of the ≈øaid Province or Territory, as they ≈øhall think do or ≈øhall merit the ≈øame, ≈øuch Marks of Favour and Titles of Honour as they ≈øhall think fit, ≈øo as tho≈øe Titles of Honour be not the ≈øame as are enjoyed by and conferred upon any of the Subjects of this Our Kingdom of England. And further al≈øo, We do by the≈øe Pre≈øents, for Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, Give and Grant by the≈øe, to them the ≈øaid Edward Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, full Power, Liberty and Licence, to Erect, Rai≈øe and Build, within the ≈øaid Province and Places afore≈øaid, or any other part or parts thereof, ≈øuch and ≈øo many Forts, Fortre≈ø≈øes,
Ca≈øtles, Cities, Boroughs, Towns, Villages and other Fortifications what≈øoever, and the ≈øame or any of them, to fortifie and furni≈øh with Ordnance, Powder, Shot and Arms, and all other Weapons, Ammunition, and Habiliments of War, offen≈øive and defen≈øive, as ≈øhall be thought fit and convenient for the welfare and ≈øafety of the ≈øaid Province or places of any parts thereof, and the ≈øame, or any of them, from time to time, as occa≈øion ≈øhall require, di≈ømantle, disfurni≈øh, demoli≈øh, and put down, and al≈øo to place, con≈øtitute and appoint in, or over all, or any of the ≈øaid Ca≈øtles, Forts, Fortifications, Cities, Towns, or Places afore≈øaid, Governours, Deputy-Governours, Magi≈øtrates, Sheriffs, and other Officers, Civil and Military, as to them ≈øhall ≈øeem meet, and to the ≈øaid Cities, Towns, Boroughs, Villages, or any other place or places within the ≈øaid Province or Territory, to grant Letters or Charters of Incorporation, with all Liberties, Franchi≈øes and Priviledges, requi≈øite and u≈øual, or to be within any Corporation within this Our King of England, granted or belonging: And in the ≈øame Cities, Boroughs, Towns, and other places, to con≈øtitute, erect, and appoint, ≈øuch and ≈øo many Markets, Marts, and Fairs, as ≈øhall in that behalf be thought fit and nece≈ø≈øary. And further al≈øo, to make and erect, in the Province or Territory afore≈øaid, or any parts thereof, ≈øo many Mannors, with ≈øuch Seignories as to them ≈øhall ≈øeem meet and convenient, and every of the ≈øaid Mannors to hold and to have a Court-Baron, with all things what≈øoever which to a Court-Baron doth belong, and to have and to hold Views of Frank-pledge and Courts-Leet, for the con≈øervation of the peace and better
government of tho≈øe Parts, with ≈øuch Limits, Juri≈ødictions, Precincts, as by the ≈øaid Edward, Earl of Clarendon, &c, or their Heirs ≈øhall be appointed for that purpo≈øe, with all things what≈øoever, which to a Court-Leet or a View of Frank-pledge belong, the ≈øame Courts to be holden by Stewards to be deputed and authorized by the ≈øaid Edward, Earl of Clarendon, &c. or their Heirs, or by the Lords, other Mannors and Leets for the time being, when the ≈øame ≈øhall be erected, and becau≈øe that in ≈øo remote a Country, and ≈øituate among ≈øo many Barbarous Nations, the Inva≈øion as well of Savages as other Enemies, Pirates and Robbers may probably be ≈øeared, Therefore we have, as for Us, our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øours, given power by the≈øe pre≈øents unto the ≈øaid Edward, Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, by them≈øelves or their Captains or other Officers, to Levy, Mu≈øter and Train all ≈øorts of Men of what condition ≈øoever, born whether in the ≈øaid Province or el≈øewhere, for the time being, and to make War, and to pur≈øue the Enemies afore≈øaid, as well by Sea as by Land, yea even without the Limits of the ≈øaid Province, and, by God's a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, to vanqui≈øh and take them, and, being taken, to put them to death, by the Laws of War, and to ≈øave them at their plea≈øure, and to do all and every thing which to the Charge and Office of a Captain-General of any Army belongs, or hath accu≈øtomed to belong, as fully and freely as any Captain-General of an Army hath ever had the ≈øame. Al≈øo Our Will and Plea≈øure is, and by this Our Charter We do give unto the ≈øaid Edward, Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, full Power and Authority, in cau≈øe of Rebellion,
Tumults, or Sedition, if any ≈øhould happen, (which God forbid) either upon the Land, within in the Province afore≈øaid, or upon the main Sea, in making a Voyage thither, or returning from thence, by him and them≈øelves, their Captains, Deputies, or Officers, to be authorized under his or their Seals for that purpo≈øe, to whom al≈øo for Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øours, We do give and grant by the≈øe pre≈øents, full power and authority to exerci≈øe Martial Laws again≈øt mutinous and ≈øeditious per≈øons of the≈øe parts, ≈øuch as ≈øhall refu≈øe to ≈øubmit them≈øelves to their Government, or ≈øhall refu≈øe to ≈øerve in the Wars, or ≈øhall flie to the Enemy, or ≈øhall for≈øake their Colours or En≈øigns, to be loyterers or ≈øtraglers otherwi≈øe how≈øoever offending again≈øt Law, Cu≈øtom, or Di≈øcipline Military, as freely and in as ample manner and form as any Captain-General of an Army, by vertue of his Office might or hath accu≈øtomed to u≈øe the ≈øame. And Our further plea≈øure is, and by the≈øe pre≈øents, for Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øours, We do grant unto the ≈øaid Edward, Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, and to the Tenents and Inhabitants of the ≈øaid Province or Territory, both pre≈øent and to come, and to every of them the ≈øaid Province or Territory, and the Tenents and Inhabitants thereof ≈øhall not from henceforth be held or reputed any member or part of any Colony what≈øoever in America, or el≈øewhere now tran≈øported or made, or hereafter to be tran≈øported or made, nor ≈øhall be depending on or ≈øubject to their Government, but be ab≈øolutely divided and ≈øeparated from the ≈øame. And Our Plea≈øure is, that they be ≈øeparated, and that they be ≈øubject immediately to our Crown of
England, as depending thereof, for ever, and that the Inhabitants of the ≈øaid Province or Territory, nor any of them, ≈øhall hereafter be compelled or compellable, or be any ways ≈øubject or liable to appear or an≈øwer to any Matter, Suit, Cau≈øes or Plaints what≈øoever, out of the Province or Territory afore≈øaid, in any other of our I≈ølands, Colonies or Dominions in America, or el≈øewhere, other than in Our Realm of England or Dominion of Wales, and becau≈øe it may happen, that ≈øome of the People and Inhabitants of the ≈øaid Province cannot in their Private Opinions conform to the Publick Exerci≈øe of Religion, according to the Liturgy, Forms and Ceremonies of the Church of England, or take or ≈øub≈øcribe the Oaths and Articles made and e≈øtabli≈øhed in that behalf. And, that the ≈øame, by rea≈øon of the remote di≈øtance of tho≈øe places, will (as we hope) be no breach of the Unity and Uniformity e≈øtabli≈øhed in this Nation, Our Will and Plea≈øure therefore is, and We do by the≈øe pre≈øents, for Us, Our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øours, give and grant unto the ≈øaid Edward, Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, full and free Licen≈øe, Liberty and Authority, by ≈øuch ways and means as they ≈øhall think fit to give and grant to ≈øuch per≈øon or per≈øons inhabiting and being within the ≈øaid Province and Territory hereby, or by the ≈øaid recited Letters Patents mentioned to be granted, as afore≈øaid, or any part thereof, ≈øuch Indulgences and Di≈øpen≈øations, in the behalf for and during ≈øuch time and times, and with ≈øuch limitations and re≈øtrictions as the ≈øaid Edward, Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs or A≈ø≈øigns, ≈øhall in their direction think fit and rea≈øonable. And that no
per≈øon or per≈øons, unto whom ≈øuch liberty ≈øhall be given, ≈øhall be any way mole≈øted, puni≈øhed, di≈øquieted, or called in que≈øtion, for any difference in Opinion, or practi≈øes in Matters of Religious Concernment, who do not actually di≈øturb the Civil Peace of the Province, County or Colony, that he or they ≈øhall make their abode in, but all and every ≈øuch per≈øon and per≈øons may from time to time and at all times freely and quietly have and enjoy their Judgment and Con≈øciences in Matters of Religion throughout the whole Province or Colony, they behaving them≈øelves peaceably, and not u≈øing this Liberty to Licentiou≈øne≈øs, nor to the Civil Injury or outward di≈øturbance of others, any Laws, Statutes or Clau≈øe contained or to be contained, U≈øage or Cu≈øtom of Our Realm of England, to the contrary hereof in any wi≈øe notwith≈øtanding. And in ca≈øe it ≈øhall happen, that any Doubts or Que≈øtions ≈øhould ari≈øe concerning the true ≈øence and under≈øtanding of any Word, Clau≈øe or Sentence contained in this Our pre≈øent Charter, We Will, Ordain and Command, that at all times and in all things, ≈øuch Interpretations be made thereof, and allowed in all and every of Our Courts what≈øoever, as lawfully maybe adjudged as mo≈øt advantagious and favourable to the ≈øaid Edward, Earl of Clarendon, &c. their Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, although expre≈øs mention of the true yearly value or certainty of the Premi≈øes, or of any of them, or of any other Gifts or Grants by Us, or by any of Our Progenitors or Predecece≈ø≈øors heretofore made to the ≈øaid Edward, Earl of Clarendon, &c. in the≈øe pre≈øents is not made, or any Statute, Act, Ordinance, Provi≈øion, Proclamation or Re≈øtriction heretofore had,
made, enacted, ordnined or provided, or any other Matter, Cau≈øe or Thing what≈øoever to the contrary hereof in any wi≈øe notwith≈øtanding. In witne≈øs whereof We have cau≈øed the≈øe Our Letters to be made Patents.

closer.dateline: Witne≈øs Our≈øelf at We≈øtmin≈øter, the Thirtieth Day of June, in the Seventeenth Year of Our Reign.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION OF VIRGINIA.
div.p: THis Country of Virginia, now ≈øo called, hath for its Southern limits, Carolina; for its Ea≈øtern, the Atlantick Ocean; for its Northern,Its Situation. Mariland; and for its We≈øtern, that va≈øt; Tract of Land which runneth into the South-≈øea.

figure.figDesc: map of Virginia, Maryland, Pennsylvania, New Jersey
figure.head: A New Map of VIRGINIA. MARYLAND. PENSILVANIA. NEW YARSEY.

div.p: This Country was fir≈øt di≈øcovered in the Year 1497.Its Di≈øcovery. by Seba≈øtian Cabot, a Portugue≈øe, but his Mariners were all Engli≈øh, and therefore may ju≈øtly be claimed by us. But it was more fully di≈øcovered, together with all that Tract of Sea-Coa≈øt, by Sir Francis Drake, and was called Virginia by Sir Walter Rawleigh, who vi≈øited it ≈øoon after in honour of his Virgin Mi≈øtris, Queen Elizabeth. In the Year 1603. divers per≈øons, who obtained the Propriety of it from Sir Walter, made a Voyage thither, who di≈øcovered Whit≈øon-Bay in forty one Degrees. The People u≈øed Snake-skins of ≈øix Foot long for Girdles, and were exceedingly ravi≈øhed with the Mu≈øick of a Gittern, a Boy dancing in a Ring about him; they were more afraid of two Engli≈øh Ma≈øtives than of twenty Men.

There being much time ≈øpent in the di≈øcovery of this Country, and not without vale Expences, in the ≈øetting forth of Ships, and that not without the lo≈øs of ≈øeveral Mens lives before it could be brought to perfection, but at length, in the Year 1607. Sir John Popham, and others, ≈øettled a Plantation at the Mouth of the River Saghadoc, but Captain James Davis having cho≈øen a ≈ømall place, almo≈øt an I≈øland, to ≈øet down in, where, having heard a Sermon, read their Patent and Laws, and, after he had built a Fort, ≈øailed further up the River and Country, where, finding an I≈øland that had a great fall of Water, and having haled their Boat over with a Rope, they came to another fall, which, by rea≈øon of its being very ≈øhallow and ≈øwift, proved unpa≈ø≈øable; the Head of the River lying in about forty five Degrees: They ‚Ä¢ all their Fort, St. George, Captain George Popham being Pre≈øident; and the People ≈øeemed much affected
with our mens devotion, and would ≈øay, King James is a good King, and his God a good God, but our God Tanto a naughty God, which is the Name of the evil Spirit that haunts them every new Moon, and makes them wor≈øhip him for fear; he commanded the Indians not to conver≈øe, nor come near the Engli≈øh, threatning to kill ≈øome of them, if they did, and inflict ≈øickne≈øs upon others, if they di≈øobey'd him, beginning with two of their Sagamores or King's Children, affirming he had power to do the like again≈øt the Engli≈øh, and would the next new Moon execute it on them. In January, in the ≈øpace of ≈øeven hours, they had Thunder, Lightning, Rain, Frost and Snow, all in very great abundance: There is likewi≈øe found a Bath ≈øo hot for two Miles about, they cannot drink of it. One of the Indians, for a Straw-hat and Knife, ≈øtript him≈øelf of his cloathing, which was Beaverskins, worth in England 50 s. or 3 l. to pre≈øent them to the Pre≈øident, only leaving him≈øelf a piece to cover his Nudities.

About this time, by the indu≈øtry of Capt. Go≈ønold and Capt. Smith, James-Town was built,James-Town built. the Indians ≈øupplying their Nece≈ø≈øities, which were ≈øometimes very extream; the Winter approaching, the Rivers afforded them very great plenty of Cranes, Swans, Gee≈øe, Ducks, wherewith they had Pea≈øe and wild Bea≈øts, &c. But in the di≈øcovery of Chickahamine-River, George Ca≈ø≈øon was ≈øurpri≈øed, and Smith, with two others, be≈øet with two hundred Savages, his Men ≈ølain, and him≈øelf taken Pri≈øoner; but in about a Months time he procured not only his liberty, but was in great favour among them, being extraordinary well plea≈øed with his Di≈øcour≈øes of God, Nature and Art, ≈øo
that he had a mo≈øt noble Entertainment from Powhatan, one of their Emperours, who ≈øate in ≈øtate upon his Bed of Mats, Pillow of Leather, imbroidered with Parl and white Beads, attired with Robes of Skins, as large as an Iri≈øh-Mantle; at his Head ≈øate a hand≈øom young Woman, and another at his Feet, and on each ≈øide the Room twenty others, their Heads and Shoulders painted red, with a great Chain of white Beads about their Necks, and a Robe of Skins, large like an Iri≈øh-Mantle; before the≈øe ≈øate his chiefe≈øt Men, in their orders: In his Palace or Arbour, one Newport, who accompanied Captain Smith, gave the Emperour a Boy, in requital whereof Powhatan be≈øtowed upon him Namontack his Servant, who was afterwards brought into England; yet after this Powhatan treacherou≈øly contrived the Murder of ≈øixteen of of our Men, which was happily prevented by Captain Smith, who ≈øeized another of their Kings, and thereby obtained Peace with them upon his own Terms.

This Emperour had about thirty Kings under him, his chief Trea≈øure con≈øi≈øting of Skins, Copper, Pearls, Beads, and the like, all which were kept in ≈øtore again≈øt his Burial, being re≈øerved on purpo≈øe again≈øt that time; his Hou≈øe being fifty or ≈øixty Yards long, frequented only by Prie≈øts; at the four Corners ≈øtood four Images, as Centinels, one of a Bear, another a Dragon, the third a Leopard, and the fourth a Giant: He hath as many Women as he plea≈øes, whom, after he is grown weary of, he be≈øtows upon his Favorites. His Will, with the Cu≈øtom of the Country, are his Laws, puni≈øhing his Malefactors by broiling to death, inclo≈øed about with fire, with ≈øeveral other Tortures. About ten Miles from James-Town one
of their Kings made a Fea≈øt in the Woods, the people being mo≈øt mon≈øtroully painted, ≈øome like black Devils, with Horns, and their Hair loo≈øe, of variety of colours; they continued two days dancing in a Circle of a quarter of a Mile about, four in a rank, in two companies, exerci≈øing ≈øeveral Antick Tricks, the King leading the Dance; all in the mid≈øt had black Horns on their Heads, and green Boughs in their Hands; next whom were four or five principal Men, differently painted, who with Clubs beat tho≈øe forward that tired in the Dance, which held ≈øo long, that they were ≈øcarce able either to go or ≈øtand; they made a helli≈øh noi≈øe, and throwing away their Boughs, ran clapping their Hands up into a Tree, and tearing down a Branch, fell into their order again. After this, fifteen of their proper Boys, between ten and fiften years old, painted white, were brought forth to the people, who ≈øpent the Forenoon in ≈øporting and dancing about them with Rattles; then, the Children being fetched away, the Women wept, and pa≈ø≈øionately cried out, providing Mo≈øs, Skins, Mats and dry Wood, making Wreaths for their Heads, and decking their Hair with Leaves; after which, they were all ca≈øt on a heap in a Valley as dead, where a great Fea≈øt was made for all the company for two hours; they then fell again into a Circle, and danced about the Youths, cau≈øing a Fire to be made on an Altar, which our Men thought was de≈øigned to ≈øacrifice them to the Devil, but it was a mi≈øtake, and the Indians deluded our Men by fal≈øe ≈øtories, one denying, and another affirming the ≈øame thing, being either ignorant or unwilling to di≈øcover the devili≈øh My≈øteries of their Religion; but a King being demanded the meaning of this Sacrifice, an≈øwered, That the Children
were not all dead, but the Okee, or the Devil, did ≈øuck the Blood from their left Breast, till ≈øome of them died, but the rest were kept in the Wilderne≈øs, till nine Moons were expired, during which they must not conver≈øe with any; of the≈øe were made Prie≈øts and Conjurers.

They think the≈øe Sacrifices ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary, that if omitted, they believe their Okee or Devil, & their other Gods would hinder them from having any Deer, Turkies, Corn or Fi≈øh, and would likewi≈øe make a great Slaughter among them. They imagine their Prie≈øts after Death, go beyond the Mountains toward the Sun-Setting, and remain there continually in the ≈øhape of their Okee, having their Heads painted with Oyl, and finely trimmed with Feathers, and being furni≈øed with Beads, Hatchets, Copper and Tobacco, never cea≈øe to dance and ≈øing with their Predece≈ø≈øors; yet they ≈øuppo≈øe the common People ≈øhall die like Bea≈øts, and never live after Death: Some of their Prie≈øts were ≈øo far convinced, that they declared our God exceeded theirs, as much as our Guns did their Bows and Arrows, and ≈øent many Pre≈øents to the Pre≈øident, intreating him to pray to his God for Rain, for their God would not ≈øend them any. By Break of Day, before they eat or drink, the Men, Women and Children above ten years old, run into the Water, and there wa≈øh a good ≈øpace, till the Sun ari≈øe; then they offer Sacrifice to it, ≈øtrewing Tobacco on the Land and Water, repeating the ≈øame Ceremony at Sun-Set. George Ca≈ø≈øon aforementioned, was ≈øacrificed, as they thought, to the Devil, being ≈øtript naked, and bound to two ≈øtakes, with his Back again≈øt a great Fire; after which they ript up his Belly, and burnt his Bowels, drying his Fle≈øh to the Bones, which
they kept above ground in a Room; many other Engli≈øhmen were cruelly and treacherou≈øly executed by them, though perhaps not ≈øacrificed, and none had e≈øcaped if their Ambu≈øh had ≈øucceeded. Powhatan invited one Captain Ratcliff and thirty others to trade for Corn, and having brought them within his Ambu≈øh, murdered them all.

Virginia, after its di≈øcovery, co≈øt no ≈ømall pains before it was brought to perfection, with the lo≈øs of many Engli≈øhmens Lives. In the Reign of King James the Fir≈øt, a Patent was granted to ≈øeveral Per≈øons as a Corporation, and called the Company of Adventurers of Virginia. But upon ≈øeveral Mi≈ødemeanors and Mi≈øcarriages in 1623. the Patent was made null; ≈øince which, it hath been free for all his Maje≈øties Subjects to Trade into the≈øe Parts.

This Countrey is ble≈øt with a ≈øweet and whol≈øom Ayr,Temperature. and the Climate ≈øo agreeable to the Engli≈øh, ≈øince the clearing it from Woods, that few die of the Countrey-Di≈øea≈øe, called Sea≈øoning.

It is every where interlaced with delectable Hills and rich Vallies,Its Fertility. and of a Soil ≈øo fertile, that an Acre of Ground commonly yieldeth 200 Bu≈øhels of Corn, and produceth readily the Grain, Fruits, Plants, Seeds and Roots which are brought from England, be≈øides tho≈øe that are natural to this Countrey and the re≈øt of America.

Here are excellent Fruits in great abundance,Its Fruits. which may be compared to tho≈øe of Italy or Spain; as, Apricocks, Peaches, Melons, Apples, Pears, Plums, Cherries, Grapes, Figs, Quinces, Marrocks, Punchamins, Che≈ønuts, Walnuts, Olives, Strawberries, Rasberries,
Goo≈øeberries, and Mulberries in great abundance. Of their Apples they make Sider, of their Pears Perry, and of their Grapes Wine.

They have ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Roots, as, Potatoes, Carrots, Turnips, Their Roots. Artichokes, Onions, Cabbages, Colliflowers, A≈øparagus, &c. with mo≈øt ≈øorts of Garden-Herbs known to us, in great plenty.

They have great plenty of Fowl; as, wild Turkeys, Their Fowl. which u≈øually weigh ≈øix Stone, or forty eight pound; Partridges, Swans, Gee≈øe, Ducks, Teal, Wigeons, Dotterels, Heath-cocks, Oxe-eyes, Brants, Pigeons, Cranes, Herons, Eagles, and ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Hawks, and for ≈ømall Birds, innumerable quantities of ≈øundry ≈øorts; as, Black-birds, Thru≈øhes, Red-birds, and above all, the Mock-bird, which counterfeits the Noi≈øe of all Birds.

They have great ≈øtore of wild Bea≈øts; as, Lions, Bears, Leopards, Wild Bea≈øts. Tygers, Wolves, and Dogs like Wolves, but bark not; Buffeloes, Elks, who≈øe Fle≈øh is as good as Beef, Ro≈øconnes, ∆≤tchunquois, Deer, Hares, Bevers, Otters, Foxes, Martins, Polcats, We≈øels, Musk-Rats, Flying Squirrels, &c. And for tame Cattel, Cows, Sheep, Goats, Hogs, and Hor≈øes in great plenty.

There is great plenty of excellent Fi≈øh, as well in the Sea,Their Fi≈øh. and Bay of Che≈øopeack, as in the Rivers; viz. Cods, Thornback, Sturgeon, Crampu≈ø≈øes, Porpu≈ø≈øes, Drums, Cat-Fi≈øh, Ba≈ø≈øes, Sheeps-heads (which makes Broth like that of Mutton) Coney-fi≈øh, Rock-fi≈øh, Cray-fi≈øh, White Salmons, Soals, Plaice, Mullets, Makarel, Trouts, Perches, Conger-Eels, Herrings, Oy≈øters, Shrimps, Cockles, Mu≈øcles, &c.

The CommoditiesCommodities. which the Countrey doth or may produce, are, Hemp, Flax, Hops, Rape-≈øeed, Anni≈øe-≈øeed, Woad, Madder, Pot-A≈øhes, Honey, Wax, Silk, if they would make it, ≈øince Mulberry-leaves grow in ≈øo great plenty, ≈øeveral ≈øweet Gums and excellent Bal≈øoms of ≈øovereign Vertues; ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Plants and Woods u≈øed by Dyers; Here are Veins of Allum, Iron and Copper, together with ≈øundry ≈øorts of rich Furs, Elk-Skins (which maketh excellent Buff) and other Hides; Pitch, Tar, Rozen, Turpentine, Butter, Chee≈øe, ≈øalted Fi≈øh and Fle≈øh, which find vent at Barbados and other Charibby-I≈ølands; but above all, Tobacco, which is their principal Commodity, and the Standard whereby all the re≈øt are prized.
There grows a kind of Flax, called Silk-gra≈øs, of which the Indians make Thred and Strings, and is good to make Linnen Cloth and Shifts, and and would make excellent ≈øtrong Cables.

Here all Trade≈ømen, e≈øpecially Handicrafts find good encouragement; and for tho≈øe Commodities afore≈øaid, the Engli≈øh (who have the ≈øole Trade) bring them all ≈øorts of Apparel, all manner of Uten≈øils belonging to Hou≈øhold-≈øtuff, or nece≈ø≈øary for their Plantations, or otherwi≈øe; al≈øo Wine, Brandy, and other ≈øtrong Drinks; likewi≈øe all Silks, Stuff, and Cloth, both Linnen and Woollen, which they convert to ≈øeveral U≈øes according to their ≈ølancies, being now ≈øupplied with Taylors.

Here groweth likewi≈øe ≈øundry ≈øorts of Trees;Their Trees. as, the red and white Oak, black Walnut, Cedar, Pine, Cypre≈øs, Che≈ønut, Poplar, A≈øh, Elm, &c. many of which are very good for the building of Ships, and other U≈øes.

This Countrey is well watered with ≈øeveral great and ≈øwift Rivers,Their Rivers. which lo≈øe them≈øelves in the Gulph or Bay Che≈øopeak, which gives entrance for Shipping into this Countrey, and al≈øo to Maryland, next adjoyning, which ≈øaid Bay is very large, capacious, and commodious for Shipping, being ≈øaid to run up into the Countrey Northwards 75 Leagues; in breadth in many places being 5, 6, or 7 Leagues, and ≈øometimes more, and 6 or 7 fathom deep; and its opening to the South, between Cape Henry, which beginneth Virginia, and Cape Charles on the other ≈øide oppo≈øite, being about 10 or 12 Leagues wide.

The principal of the≈øe Rivers beginning at Cape Henry, are Pawhonan, now called James's River, being found navigable about 50 Leagues. Pamaunke, now York-River, al≈øo large and navigable about 20 Leagues. Rapahanock, or Topahanock, likewi≈øe a good River, and navigable about 40 Leagues, which is the la≈øt River of Virginia northwardly, that falls into the Bay of Che≈øopeak.

Upon, or near the≈øe Rivers, for the conveniency of Shipping, the Engli≈øh are ≈øeated, which at pre≈øent do amount unto the number of about thirty or forty thou≈øand, and have ≈øome Towns; the chief among≈øt which is James-Town, or rather James-City, commodiou≈øly ≈øeated on James-River; the Town is beautified with many fair and well-built Brick Hou≈øes; and as it is the chief Town of the Countrey, here are kept the Courts of Judicatory, and Offices of publick Concern.
Next to James-Town, may be reckoned that of Elizabeth, ≈øeated at the bottom of the ≈øaid River, a well built Town. Al≈øo Dales-Gift, Wicocomeco, Bermuda, and others.

The Governour is ≈øent over by His Maje≈øty; who at pre≈øent is the Right Honourable the Lord Howard of Effingham, and the Countrey is governed by Laws agreeable with tho≈øe of England, for the deci≈øion of all Cau≈øes both Civil and Criminal; which ≈øaid Laws are made by the Governour, with the con≈øent of the General A≈ø≈øembly, which doth con≈øi≈øt of his Council, and the Burge≈ø≈øes cho≈øen by the Freeholders. And for the better Government, the Countrey po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Engli≈øh, is divided into ≈øeveral Counties, in each of which are Sheriffs, Ju≈øtices of the Peace, and other Officers, which are from time to time appointed by the Governor.

The Names of the Counties, are tho≈øe of Carotuck, Their Counties. Charles, Gloce≈øter, Hartford, Henrico, James, New-Kent, Lanca≈øter, Middle≈øex, Nan≈øemund, Lower-Norfolk, Northampton, Northumberland, Rappahanock, Surrey, Warwick, We≈øtmorland, I≈øle of Wight, and York, and in each of the≈øe Counties are held petty Courts every Month; from which there may be Appeals to the Quarter-Court held at James-Town.

The Virginians are not born ≈øo ≈øwarthy as they appear;Their Complexion. their hair is generally black and flaggy, which they wear long; few men have Beards, becau≈øe they pluck out the Hairs that would grow; their oyntments and ≈ømoaky hou≈øes do in a great mea≈øure cau≈øe their Blackne≈øs, whereby they look like Bacon; they are of a ready wit, very ≈øubtle and treacherous, not much addicted to Labour, being too great lovers of their ea≈øe, and much given to hunting. They have one Wife, many Concubines, and are likewi≈øe Sodomites; the
ancient Women are u≈øed for Cooks, Barbers, and other Services, the younger for Dalliance; they are mode≈øt in their Carriage, and ≈øeldom quarrel, in entertaining a Stranger, they ≈øpread a Mat for him to ≈øit down, and then dance before him; they wear their Nails long to flea their Deer, and put Bows and Arrows into the hands of their Children before they are ≈øix years old. In each Ear they have generally three great holes, wherein they commonly hang Chains, Bracelets, or Copper; ≈øome wear a Snake therein, coloured green and yellow, near half a yard long, which crawls about their necks, and offers to ki≈øs their Lips; others have a dead Rat tied by the Tail. The women raze their Bodies, Legs and Thighs with an Iron incurious knots and ≈øhapes of Fowls, Fi≈øhes, and Bea≈øts, and rub a painting therein which will never come out. The Queen of Apometica was attired with a Cornet be≈øet with many white bones, with Copper in her Ears, and a Chain of the ≈øame, ≈øix times encompa≈ø≈øing her Neck. The Sa≈øquchanocks are a Giant-like People, very mon≈øtrous in proportion, behaviour and attire; their Voice ≈øounds as out of a Cave, their Garments are Bear-skins, hanged with Bears Paws, a Wolfes Head, and ≈øuch odd Jewels, their Tobacco-pipes three quarters of a yard long, with the Head of ≈øome Bea≈øt at the end, ≈øo weighty, as to beat out the Brains of a Hor≈øe. The Calf of one of their Legs was mea≈øured three quarters of a yard about, their other Limbs being proportionable. They have ≈øeveral ridiculous Conceits concerning their Original; as that a Hare came into their Countrey, and made the fir≈øt men, and after pre≈øerved them from a great Serpent; and two other Hares came thither, the fir≈øt killed a Deer for their entertainment,
which was then the only Deer in the world, and ≈øtrewing the hairs of that Deer, every hair became a Deer.

In the Reign of King James the Fir≈øt, one Tomacona, an Indian, and Councellor to one of their Kings, came into England; who landing in the We≈øt, was much ≈øurprized at our plenty of Corn and Trees, imagining we ventured into their Countrey to ≈øupply tho≈øe defects; he began then to number the Men he met with, but his Arithmetick ≈øoon failed him. He related that Okee their God, did often appear to him in his Temple; to which purpo≈øe four of their Prie≈øts go into the Hou≈øe, and u≈øing certain ≈øtrange words and ge≈øtures, eight more are called in, to whom he di≈øcovers what his Will is; upon him they depend in all their Proceedings; as in taking Journeys, or the like: ≈øometimes when they re≈øolve to go a hunting, he by ≈øome known token will direct where they ≈øhall find Game; which they with great chearfulne≈øs acknowledging, follow his Directions, and many times ≈øucceed therein; he appears like an hand≈øom Indian, with long black Locks of Hair; after he has ≈øtaid with his twelve Confederates for ≈øome time, he a≈øcendeth into the Ayr from whence he came. The Natives think it a di≈øgrace to fear Death, and therefore when they mu≈øt die, they do it re≈øolutely; as it happened to one that robbed an Engli≈øhman, and was by Pawhatan (upon complaint made again≈øt him) fetched ≈øixty miles from the place where he lay concealed, and by this Tomocomo executed in the pre≈øence of the Engli≈øh, his Brains being knockt out, without the lea≈øt ≈øhew of fear or terror.

Their Apparel Their Apparel. is but mean, only contenting them≈øelves with ≈øomething to cover their nakedne≈øs; and for the better defending them≈øelves from the Weather, they anoint their bodies with certain Oyles mixt with Bears-Grea≈øe.
Their Hou≈øes Their Hou≈øes. are no better than our Engli≈øh Hog≈øties, being made of Boughs, and covered with Barks of Trees, and in the mid≈øt thereof is placed their Chimney, or Fire-place.
Their DietTheir Diet. in meanne≈øs, is an≈øwerable to their Hou≈øes not endeavouring to plea≈øe their Palats, with curious Sauces, or pampering their Bodies with provocative Meats.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION OF MARY-LAND.
div.p:
THE Province of Mary-Land is ≈øituated between the degrees of 37 and 50 min. or thereabouts,Situation. and 40 deg. of Northern Latit. It is bounded on the North with Penn≈øylvania, New-England, and New-York, formerly part of New-England; on the Ea≈øt, the Atlantick Ocean, and Delaware Bay; on the South,
by Virginia; from whence it is parted by the River Patowmeck, who≈øe Southern Banks divide the Province from Virginia.

The Bay of Che≈øopeack, giving entrance to Ships, both into this Countrey and Virginia, pa≈ø≈øing through the heart of this Province, being found near 200 miles in the Land, into which falls ≈øeveral con≈øiderable River;Its Rivers as, Patowmeck, Patuxent, Ann-Arundel, (alias Severn) and Sa≈øque≈øahanough, lying on the We≈øt-≈øide of the Bay; and to the Ea≈øt of the ≈øaid Bay, tho≈øe of the Choptanke, Nantecoke, Pocomocke, and ≈øeveral other Rivers and Rivulets, to the great improvement of the Soyl, and Beauty of the Province.

The ClimateThe Climate. of late is very agreeable to the Engli≈øh Con≈øtitution, e≈øpecially ≈øince the felling of the Woods, and the People accu≈øtoming them≈øelves to Engli≈øh Diet, is very healthful and agreeable to the con≈øtitution of the Engli≈øh, few now dying at their fir≈øt coming, of the Country Di≈øea≈øe or ≈øea≈øoning; neither is the Heat extream in Summer, being much qualified by the cool and gentle Briezes of winds from the Sea, and refre≈øhing Showers of Rain, and the Cold in Winter, being of ≈øo little durance, that the Inhabitants cannot be ≈øaid to ≈øuffer by either.
The Countrey is generally plain and even, yet ri≈øing in ≈øome places into ≈ømall and plea≈øant Hills, which heighten the Beauty of the adjacent Vallies.

The Soyl is rich and fertil, naturally producing all ≈øuch Commodities as are particularly ≈øet down to its neighbouring Colony, Virginia; as, all ≈øorts of Beasts and Fowl, both tame and wild;
Fi≈øh, Fruits, Plants, Roots, Herbs, Gums, Trees, Bal≈øoms, &c. as likewi≈øe all Commodities produced by Indu≈øtry, are here found in as great plenty and perfection. But the chief Trade of Mary-Land depends upon Tobacco, which is e≈øteemed better for a foreign Market than that of Virginia, finds greater vent abroad; which Trade is not incon≈øiderable, ≈øince a hundred Sail of Ships have in one year traded thither from England, and the neighbouring Engli≈øh Plantations. There is a competent ≈øtock of ready Money in this Province, both of Engli≈øh and Foreign, and his Lord≈øhips own Coin; yet their chief way of Commerce is by way of Barter or Exchange of Commodities.

The Natives, The Natives. as to their Complexion, Stature, Cu≈øtoms, Di≈øpo≈øitions, Laws, Religion, Apparel, Diet, Hou≈øes, &c. are much the ≈øame with tho≈øe of Virginia, already treated of, being likewi≈øe many different Tribes or ≈øorts of People, and each governed by their particular King.

They believe, that after this Life, the Soul ≈øhall be di≈øpo≈øed of according to its Works here, either to the habitation of the Gods, to enjoy perpetual happine≈øs, or to a great Pit or Hole in the furthe≈øt part of their Countrey toward Sun≈øet (which they count the furthermo≈øt part of the World) there to burn continually; which place they call Popogu≈ø≈øo; and relate, that one that was buried, was the next day ≈øeen to move upon his Grave; whereupon his Body was taken up again, who, when he was revived, declared, that his Soul was near entring into Popogu≈ø≈øo, had not one of the Gods ≈øaved him, and ≈øuffered him to return, and warn his Friends to avoid that terrible place: another being taken up, related, that his Soul was alive while his Body was in the Grave, and had been travelling in a long broad way, on both ≈øides whereof, grew delicate Trees, bearing excellent Fruits, and at length arrived at mo≈øt curious hou≈øes, where he met his Father, that was dead before. who charged him to go back, and ≈øhew his Friends what good they were to do to enjoy the plea≈øures of this Place, and then to return to him again: Whatever Tricks or Subtilty the Prie≈øts u≈øe, the Vulgar are hereby very re≈øpectful to their Governors, and careful of their actions, though in criminal Cau≈øes they inflict puni≈øhments according to the quality of the Offence; they are great Negromancers, and account our Fire-works, Guns and Writing to be the works of God rather than Men. When one of their Kings was ≈øick, he ≈øent to the
Engli≈øh to pray for him: Some of them imagine that we are not mortal men, nor born of Women, but ≈øay we are an old Generation revived, and believe that there are more of us yet to come to kill their Nation, and take their places, who are at pre≈øent invi≈øible in the Air without Bodies, and that at their interce≈ø≈øion they cau≈øe tho≈øe of their Nation to die who wrong the Engli≈øh.

Their Idol they place in the innermo≈øt Room of the Hou≈øe, of whom they relate incredible Stories, they carry it with them to the Wars, and ask coun≈øel thereof, as the Romans did of their Oracles; they ≈øing Songs as they march towards Battel, in≈øtead of Drums and Trumpets; their Wars are exceeding bloody, and have wa≈øted the people very much. Once a year they hold a great Fe≈øtival, meeting together out of ≈øeveral Villages, each having a certain Mark or Character on his Back, whereby it may be di≈øcerned who≈øe Subject he is; the place where they meet is ≈øpacious, and round about are Po≈øts carved on the top like a Nuns Head; in the mid≈øt are three of the faire≈øt Virgins lovingly embracing and cla≈øping each other; about this living Image and artificial Circle they dance in their ≈øavage manner. Their chief Idol, called Kiwa≈øa, in made of wood four foot high, the Face re≈øembling the Inhabitants of Florida, painted with fle≈øh-colour, the Brea≈øt white, the other parts black, the Legs only ≈øported with white, with Chains and Strings of Beads about his neck. This Idol is the Keeper of the dead Bodies of their Kings, which are advanced on Scaffolds nine or ten foot high, this Kiwa≈øa or Guardian being placed near them, and underneath liveth a Prie≈øt, who there mumbles his Devotions night and day.

This Province of Mary-Land, His Maje≈øty King Charles the Fir≈øt, in Anno 1632. granted by a Patent to the Right Honourable Caecilius Calvert, Lord Baltemore, and to his Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, and by that Patent created him and them the true and ab≈øolute Lords and Proprietors of the ≈øame (≈øaving the Allegiance and Sovereign Dominion due to His Maje≈øty, his Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors;) thereby likewi≈øe granting to them all Royal Juri≈ødictions both military and Civil; as, Power of enacting Laws, martial Laws, making of Warand Peace, Pardoning Offences, conferring of Honours, coyning of Money, &c. and in acknowledgment thereof, yielding and paying yearly to his Maje≈øty, his Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, two Indi ‚Ä¢ n Arrows at Wind≈øor-Ca≈øtle in the County of Berks, on Ea≈øter-Tue≈øday, together with the fifth part of all the Gold and Silver-Oar that ≈øhall be found there.

The Lord Baltemore hath his Re≈øidence at Mattapany, about eight miles di≈øtance from St. Maries, where he hath a plea≈øant Seat, though the general A≈ø≈øemblies and Provincial Courts are kept at St. Maries; and for the better inviting of People to ≈øettle here, his Lord≈øhip by the Advice of the General A≈ø≈øembly of that Province, hath long ≈øince e≈øtabli≈øhed a Model of good and whol≈øom Laws, for the ea≈øe and benefit of the Inhabitants, with toleration of Religion to all ≈øorts that profe≈øs the Faith of Chri≈øt, which hath been a principal motive to many to ≈øettle under that Government, rather than in another, where Liberty of Con≈øcience was denied them.

figure.figDesc: map of New England, New York
figure.head: NEW ENGLAND And NEW YORK

div.p: The Inhabitants (being in number about 16000) have begun the building of ≈øeveral Towns, which in few years 'tis hoped may come to ≈øome perfection; as, Calverton, Herrington, and Harvey-Town, all commodiou≈øly ≈øeated for the benefit of Trade, and conveniency of Shipping; but the principal Town is St. Maries, ≈øeated on St. Georges River, being beautified with divers well-built Hou≈øes, and is the chief Place, or Scale of Trade for the Province.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION Of NEW-YORK.
div.p:
ADjoyning to Mary-Land Northwards, is a Colony called New-York, from our pre≈øent Gracious Sovereign, when Duke of York, the Proprietor thereof by Grant from His Maje≈øty, and is that part of New-England which the Dutch once po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed; it was fir≈øt di≈øcovered by Mr. Hud≈øon, Its Di≈øcovery. and ≈øold pre≈øently by him to the Dutch without
Authority from his Sovereign the King of England, in 1608. The Hollanders in 1614. began to plant there, and called it New-Netherland; but Sir Samuel Argal, Governour of Virginia, routed them; after which, they got leave of King James to put in there for Fre≈øh-Water in their Pa≈ø≈øage to Brazile, and did not offer to plant till a good while after the Engli≈øh were ≈øetled in the Countrey. In 1664. His late Maje≈øty King Charles the Second ≈øent over four Commi≈ø≈øioners to reduce the Colony into bounds, that had been encroached upon by each other; who marched with three hundred Red-Coats to Manhadees, and took from the Dutch the chief Town, then called New-Am≈øterdam, now New-York; and Aug. 29. turned out their Governour with a Silver Leg, and all the re≈øt but tho≈øe who acknowledged Subjection to the King of England; ≈øuffering them to enjoy their Hou≈øes and E≈øtates as before. Thirteen days after, Sir Robert Car took the Fort and Town of Aurania, now called Albany, and twelve days after that, the Fort and Town of Ara≈øapha, then Delaware-Ca≈øtle, manned with Dutch and Swedes; ≈øo that now the Engli≈øh are Ma≈øters of three hand≈øom Towns, three ≈øtrong Forts and a Ca≈øtle, without the lo≈øs of one man. The fir≈øt Governour of the≈øe Parts for the King of England was Colonel Nicols, one of the Commi≈ø≈øioners.

It is a Countrey of a rich and fertil Soyl,Its Fertility. well watered with Rivers, as in Mary-Land, already ≈øpoken of; and is found to produce the ≈øame Bea≈øts, Birds, Fi≈øh, Fruits, Commodities, Trees, &c. and in as great plenty; and it is reported that one Bu≈øhel of European Wheat has yielded an hundred in one year.

The mo≈øt con≈øiderable Town is that of New-York; Its Situation. being well ≈øeated both for Trade, Security, and Plea≈øure, in a ≈ømall I≈øle called Manahatan, regarding the Sea, made ≈øo by Hud≈øon's River, which ≈øevereth it from Long-I≈øland, which ≈øaid River is very commodious for Shipping, being about two Leagues broad. The Town is large, containing about five hundred well-built Hou≈øes, built with Dutch-Brick, and the meane≈øt not valued under one hundred Pounds; to the landward it is encompa≈ø≈øed with a Wall of good thickne≈øs, and fortified at the entrance of the River, ≈øo as to command any Ship which pa≈ø≈øeth that way, by a Fort, called James-Fort: and for Civil Government, it hath a Mayor, Alderman, Sheriff, and Ju≈øtices of the Peace for their Magi≈øtrates. The Inhabitants are mo≈øt Engli≈øh and Dutch, who have a very con≈øiderable Trade with the Indians, for the Skins of Elks, Deer, Bears, &c. al≈øo for tho≈øe of Beaver, Otter, Racoon-skins, with other rich Furs, and are ≈øupplied with Veni≈øon and Fowl in the Winter, and Fi≈øh in the Summer, by the Indians, at an ea≈øie price.

This Province formerly contained all that Land which is ≈øeated in the North part of America, betwixt England and Mary-Land, the length toward the North being not fully known; the breadth is about 200 Miles: The chief Rivers are Hud≈øon-River, Raritan River, and Delaware-Bay; and the principal I≈ølands are the Manahatan-I≈øland, Long-I≈øland, and Stater-I≈øland. Manahatan-I≈øland, ≈øo called by the Indians, lieth within land, betwixt forty one and forty two Degrees of North Latitude, and is in length about fourteen Miles, and two broad. New-York is ≈øeated on the We≈øt-end of
this I≈øland, having a ≈ømall Arm of the Sea, which divides it from Long-I≈øland on the South. Long-I≈øland runs Ea≈øtward above a hundred Miles, and in ≈øome places eight, twelve and fourteen Miles broad, inhabited from one end to the other, having a rich Soil for all Engli≈øh-Grain; the Fruits, Trees and Herbs very good; in May you may ≈øee the Woods and Fields ≈øo richly bedecked with Ro≈øes, and variety of other delightful Flowers, as equal, if not excel, many Gardens in England.

This Country is al≈øo po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with ≈øundry ≈øorts of People,Its Inhabitants. not much unlike the Indians of Virginia, being well-proportioned, ≈øwarthy, blackhaired, very expert in their Bow and Arrows, which are their chief Weapons of War; they are very ≈øerviceable and courteous to the Engli≈øh, being of a ready Wit and very apt to recieve In≈øtruction from them; but there are now but few Indians upon the I≈øland, being ≈øtrangely decrea≈øed ≈øince the Engli≈øh fir≈øt ≈øettled there, for not long ago there were ≈øix Towns full of them, which are now reduced to two Villages, the re≈øt being cut off by Wars among them≈øelves, or ≈øome raging, mortal Di≈øea≈øes. They live principally by Hunting Fowling and Fi≈øhing, their Wives tilling the Land and planting the Corn; they feed on Fi≈øh, Fowl and Veni≈øon, likewi≈øe Pol-cats, Turtles, Racoon and the like: they build ≈ømall moveable Tents, which they remove three times a year, chiefly quartering where they plant their Corn, be≈øides their Hunting and Fi≈øhing-Quarters. Their principal Recreation are Foot-ball and Cards, at which they will play away all they have, except a Flap to cover their nakedne≈øs: they are very great lovers of
Strong-drink, ≈øo that without they have enough to be drunk, they care not to drink at all; if their company be ≈øo great, that they have not enough to make them all drunk, they u≈øually chu≈øe ≈øo many as are proportionable to that quantity, and the re≈øt mu≈øt be ≈øpectators; if any happen to be drunk, before he has taken his ≈øhare, which is ordinarily a quart of Brandy, Rum or Strong-waters; to ≈øhew their Ju≈øtice, they will pour the re≈øt down his Throat: in which debauches they often kill one another, which the Friends of the dead revenge upon the Murtherer, unle≈øs he purcha≈øe his Life with Money, which is made of Periwinkle-≈øhell, both black and white, ≈øtrung like Beads.
