They ob≈øerve ≈øeveral Ceremonies in their Reigious Rites,Their Religion. and are ≈øaid to Wor≈øhip the Devil, which u≈øually they perform once or twice a Year, unle≈øs upon ≈øome extraordinary occa≈øion, as the making of War, or the like, when their Corn is ripe, which is u≈øually about Michaelmas; The day being appointed by their Chief Prie≈øt, or Pawaw, mo≈øt of them go a Hunting for Veni≈øon; when they are all a≈ø≈øembled, if the Prie≈øt wants Money, he then tells them, their God will accept no Offering, but Money; which the People believing, every one gives according to his ability: the Prie≈øt takes the Money, and putting it into ≈øome Di≈øhes, ≈øets them upon the top of their low, flat-roofed Hou≈øes, and ≈øo falls a calling upon their God, to come and receive it, which, with many loud hollows and out-crys, ≈øtriking the ground with ≈øticks, and beating them≈øelves, is performed by the Prie≈øt, and ≈øeconded by the People. After, being thus wearied, a Devil, by his conjuration, appears among≈øt them, ≈øometimes in the ≈øhape of a Fowl,
a Beast, or a Man, which ≈øo amazeth the people, that they dare not ≈øtir; the Prie≈øt improves the opportunity, and ≈øtepping out, makes ≈øure of the Money, and then returns to lay the Spirit, who is often gone before he comes back, having taken ≈øome of the company along with him; but if at ≈øuch times any Engli≈øh come among them, it puts a period to their proceedings, and they will de≈øire his ab≈øence, ≈øaying, Their God will not come, till they are departed. They are much addicted to go to War again≈øt one another, but they ≈øight no pitch'd Battel, but upon their Enemies approach, (having fir≈øt ≈øecured their Wives and Children in ≈øome I≈øland, or thick Swamp) armed with Guns and Hatchets, they way-lay their Enemy, and it's counted a great Fight when ≈øeven or eight are ≈ølain; they ≈øeldom give quarter to any, but the Women and Children, whom they re≈øerve and make u≈øe of for the increa≈øing their ≈øtrength.

When an Indian dies, they bury him upright,Their way of Burial. ≈øitting upon a Seat, with his Gun, Money, and Goods, to furni≈øh him in the other World, which they believe to be We≈øtward, where they ≈øhall have great ≈øtore of Game for Hunting, and live at ea≈øe; at his Funeral, his Relations paint their Faces black, making, at his Grave, once or twice every day, ≈øad Lamentations; thus continuing till the blackne≈øs is wore off their Faces; and after that, once a Year they mourn afre≈øh for him, vi≈øiting and trimming up the Grave, not ≈øuffering any Gra≈øs to grow near it, fencing it with a Hedge, and covering it with Mats for a ≈øhelter from the Rain. Notwith≈øtanding all this bu≈øtle, when an Indian is dead his Name dies with him, none daring ever after to mention his Name, it being not
only a breach of their Law, but an affront to his Friends and Relations, as if done on purpo≈øe to renew their grief. And every per≈øon, bearing the ≈øame Name, in≈øtantly changes it for another, which every one invents for him≈øelf; ≈øome call them≈øelves Rattle≈ønakes, others Buckshorn, or the like; yea, if a per≈øon die, who≈øe Name is ≈øome Word u≈øed in common Speech, they change that Word, and invent a new one, which makes their Language very trouble≈øom. When any one is ≈øick, after his Friends have u≈øed all po≈ø≈øible means, every one pretending skill in Phy≈øick, but all proving ineffectual, they ≈øend for a Pawaw, or Prie≈øt, who, ≈øitting down by the ≈øick per≈øon, without the lea≈øt inquiring after the Di≈øtemper, expects a Fee or Gift, according to which he proportions his work, beginning with a low voice to call ≈øometimes upon one God, and then on another, ≈øtill rai≈øing his vice, beating his naked brea≈øts and ≈øides till the ≈øweat runs down, and his breath is almo≈øt gone, and what remains, he breaths upon the face of the ≈øick per≈øon three or four times together, ≈øo takes his leave.

Their Weddings are performed without any Ceremony,Their Marriages. the Match being fir≈øt made by Money, which being agreed on, and given to the Woman, makes a Con≈øummation of the Marriage, if we may ≈øo call it; after which, he keeps her during plea≈øure, and, upon the lea≈øt di≈ølike, turns her away and takes another. It is no offence for their married Women to lie with another Man, provided ≈øhe acquaint her Husband, or ≈øome of her neare≈øt Relations therewith; but if not, they account it ≈øuch a fault as is ≈øometimes puni≈øhable by death. When any Woman finds her≈øelf quick with
Child, ≈øhe keeps her≈øelf cha≈øte, or untouched by Man, until her delivery, the like ≈øhe ob≈øerveth in her giving ≈øuch, a ≈øtrange Cu≈øtom which our European Ladies would not well reli≈øh. An Indian may have two or three or more Wives if he plea≈øe; but it is not now ≈øo much u≈øed, as before the Engli≈øh came, they being inclined to imitate them in things both good and bad. Any Maid, before ≈øhe is married, lies with whom ≈øhe plea≈øes for Money, without the lea≈øt ≈øcandal or a≈øper≈øion, it being not only cu≈øtomary, but lawful. They are extream charitable to one another, for if any one has to ≈øpare, he freely imparts to his friends, and whatever they get by Gaming, or otherwi≈øe, they ≈øhare one with another, leaving commonly the lea≈øt part to them≈øelves.

When their King or Sachen ≈øits in Council, he hath a company of armed Men to guard his per≈øon, great re≈øpect being ≈øhewed him by the people, which chiefly appears by their ≈øilence; after he has declared the cau≈øe of their convention, he demands their Opinions, ordering who ≈øhall fir≈øt begin, who, having delivered his mind, tells them, he hath done, for no man interrupts him, though he makes never ≈øo many long ≈øtops and halts, till he ≈øays, he hath no more to ≈øay; the Council having all delivered their Opinions, the King, after ≈øome pau≈øe, gives the definitive Sentence, which is commonly ≈øeconded by a ≈øhout from the people, thereby ≈øignifying their a≈ø≈øent or applau≈øe. If any per≈øon be condemned to die, which is ≈øeldom, but for Murder, or Ince≈øt, the King him≈øelf goes out in per≈øon, (for they have no Pri≈øons, and the guilty per≈øon flies into the Woods) to ≈øeek him out, and having found him, the King ≈øhoots fir≈øt, though at never ≈øuch a di≈øtance, and then happy is the
man that can ≈øhoot him down, who, for his pains, is made ≈øome Captain or Military Officer.

Their ClothingTheir Clothing. is a yard and a half of broad Cloth, which they hang on their Shoulders, and half a yard of the ≈øame, being put between their Legs, is tied up before and behind, and fa≈øtened with a Girdle about their middle, and hangs with a ≈ølap on each ≈øide; they wear no Hats, but commonly tye either a Snakes-skin about their ‚Ä¢ eads, a Belt of their Money, or a kind of Ruff, made with Deers-hair, and dyed of a Scarlet-colour, which they e≈øteem very rich, they grea≈øe their Bodies and Hair very often, and paint their Faces with divers Colours, as Black, White, Red, Yellow, Blew, which they take great pride in, every one being painted in a ≈øeveral manner. Thus much for the Cu≈øtoms of the Indians, and the Colony of New-York.

Hud≈øon's River runs by New-York Northward into the Country, towards the head of which is ≈øeated New-Albany, a place of a very con≈øiderable Trade with the Natives, betwixt which and New-York, being above an hundred Miles di≈øtance, is as good Corn-land as the World affords; it was reduced to his Maje≈øties obedience by Col. Nicholas, and a League of Friend≈øhip concluded between the Inhabitants and the Indians, by whom they have never been ≈øince di≈øturbed, but every man hath ≈øate under his own Vine, and hath peaceably reaped and enjoyed the Fruits of his own Labour, which God continue.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION OF NEW ENGLAND.
div.p:
Its Di≈øcovery. NEw-England was fir≈øt di≈øcovered, as well as the other Northern-Coa≈øts of America, by Seba≈øtian Cabot, in the Year 1497. and in 1584. Mr. Philip Amadas, and Mr. Arthur Barlow, were the fir≈øt Chri≈øtians that took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof for Queen Elizabeth. The Year following Sir Richard Greenvile conveyed an Engli≈øh Colony thither, under the government of Mr. Ralph Lane, who continued there till the next Year, but, upon ≈øome extraordinary occa≈øion, returned with Sir Francis Drake into England, being accounted by ≈øome the fir≈øt di≈øcoverer thereof. It is ≈øeated on the North of Mary-Land, Its Situation. and on the South Virginia, lying about 40 and 41 Degrees of North-Latitude, and it is reported to have 70 Miles of Sea-Co≈øt, where are found divers good Havens, ≈øeveral of which being capable to harbour five hundred Sail of Ships from the rage of the Sea and Winds, by rea≈øon of the interpo≈øition of ≈øeveral I≈øles (to the number of about 200) which lie about this Coa≈øt. The Account of the Wor≈øhip and Ceremonies of the Indians hath been
much perfected by the Indu≈øtry and Voyages of Capt. Go≈ønold, Capt. Hud≈øon, Capt. Smith, and others, the la≈øt of which gives a very large Account, this Captain being taken Pri≈øoner by the Natives, and while he ≈øtayed among them ob≈øerved their Magical Rites, three or four days after his being ≈øeized, ≈øeven of their Prie≈øts, in the Hou≈øe, where he lay, each with a Rattle, (making him ≈øit down by them) began about Ten in the Morning to ≈øing about a fire, which they encompa≈ø≈øed with a Circle of Meal, at the end of every Song (which the Chief Prie≈øt begun, the re≈øt followed in order) they laid down two or three Grains of Wheat, then the Prie≈øt di≈øgui≈øed with a great Skin, his Head hung round with little Skins of Wea≈øles, and other Vermine, and a Cornet of Feathers, painted as ugly as the Devil, at the end of every Song he u≈øed ≈øtrange and vehement Ge≈øtures, throwing great Cakes of Deer-Suet and Tobacco into the fire, thus the≈øe howling Devotions continued till Six a Clock at Night, and held ≈øo three days. This they pretended was to know of their God, whether any more Engli≈øh ≈øhould arrive, and what they intended to do in that Country. They ≈øed Capt. Smith ≈øo high, that he much doubted they would have ≈øacrificed him to their Chief Deity, the Image of whom is ≈øo deformed, that nothing can be more mon≈øtrous, the Women likewi≈øe, after he was freed and Pre≈øident of the Company made him a very odd Entertainment, thirty of them came out of the Woods, only covered before and behind with a few green Leaves, their Bodies painted of different colours the Commander of the≈øe Nymphs had on her Head a large pair of Stag's Horns, and a Quiver of Arrows at her Back, with Bow and
Arrows in her hand; the re≈øt followed with Horns and Weapons all alike; they ru≈øhed through the Streets with helli≈øh ≈øhouts and crys, dancing about a fire, which was there made for that purpo≈øe, for an hour together; then they ≈øolemnly invited him to their Lodging, where he was no ≈øooner come, but they all ≈øurrounded him, and crying, Love you not me? after which they fea≈øted him with great variety, cook'd after their mad fa≈øhion, ≈øome ≈øinging and dancing all the while, and at la≈øt lighted him home with a Firebrand, in≈øtead of a Torch, to his Lodgings.

And although this Country is ≈øeated in the mid≈øt of the Temperate Zone, yet is the Clime more uncertain,Temperature. as to the heat and cold, than tho≈øe European Kingdoms, which lie Parallel with it; and, as to Virginia, this may be compared as Scotland is to England.
The AirThe Air. is found very healthful, and agreeable to the Engli≈øh, which makes them po≈ø≈øe≈øs many Potent Colonies, being very numerous and powerful.

When they de≈øign to make War, they fir≈øt con≈øult with their Prie≈øts and Conjurers, no People being ≈øo Barbarous almo≈øt, but they have their Gods,Their Religion. Prie≈øts, and Religion; they adore as it were all things that they think may unavoidably hurt them, as Fire, Water, Lightning, Thunder, our Great Guns, Muskets and Hor≈øes; yea, ≈øome of them once ≈øeeing an Engli≈øh Boar, were ≈øtruck with ≈øome terror, becau≈øe he bri≈øtled up his Hairs and gna≈øhed his Teeth, believing him to be the God of the Swine, who was offended with them. The chief God they
Wor≈øhip is the Devil, which they call Okee; they have conference with him, and fa≈øhion them≈øelves into his ≈øhape: In their Temple they have his Image ill-favouredly Carved, Painted and Adorned with Chains, Copper and Beads, and covered with a Skin. The Sepulchre of their Kings is commonly near them, who≈øe Bodies are fir≈øt Imbowelled, dried on a Hurdle, adorned with Chains and Beads, and then wrapped in white Skins, over which are Matts; they are afterwards Intombed orderly in Arches made of Matts, their Wealth being placed at their feet: But for their common Burials, they dig a hole in the Earth with ≈øharp Stakes, and the Corps being wrapped in Skins and Matts, they lay them in the Ground, placing them upon ≈øticks, and then cover them with Earth; the Burial ended, the Women having their Faces painted black with Cole and Oyl, ≈øit Mourning in the Hou≈øe twenty four hours together, howling and yelling by turns.

The Natives are cloathed with loo≈øe Mantles made of Deers Skins, and Aprons of the ≈øame round their Middle,Their Cloathing. all el≈øe being naked; of Stature like to us in England: They Paint them≈øelves and their Children, and he is mo≈øt Gallant who is mo≈øt deformed. The Women Imbroider their Legs, Hands, and other Parts, with ≈øeveral Works, as of Serpents, and the like, making black ≈øpots in their Fle≈øh. Their Hou≈øes are made of ≈ømall Poles, round, and fa≈øtened at the top in a circle like our Arbours, covered with Matts twice as long as broad; they are exact Archers, and with their Arrows will kill Birds flying, or Bea≈øts running full ≈øpeed: One of our Men was with an Arrow ≈øhot through the Body and both the Arms at once. Another Indian ≈øhot an Arrow of an Ell long through a Target,
that a Pi≈øtol Ballet could not pierce; their Bows are of tough Hazle, and their Strings of Leather; their Arrows of Cane or Hazle, headed with Stones or Horn, and Feathered Artificially: They ≈øoon grow heartle≈øs, if they find their Arrows do no execution. They ≈øay there is Men among them of above two hundred years of Age.

Though the Planting of this Country was de≈øigned by ≈øeveral of the Engli≈øh, yet it lay much neglected, 'till a ≈ømall company of Planters, under the Command of Captain George Popham, and Captain Gilbert, was ≈øent over at the charge of Sir John Popham, in 1606. to begin a Colony upon a Tract of Land about Saga de hoch, the mo≈øt Northernly part of New-England, but that de≈øign within two years expired with its Founder. Soon after, ≈øome Honourable Per≈øons of the We≈øt of England, commonly called the Council of Plymouth, being more certainly informed of ≈øeveral Navigable Rivers, and Commodious Havens, with other places ≈øit either for Planting or Traffick, newly di≈øcovered by many skilful Navigators, obtained of King James the Fir≈øt, a Patent under the Great Seal, of all that part of North America, called New-England, from forty to forty eight Degrees of North Latitude. This va≈øt Tract of Land, was in 1612. Cantoned, and divided by Grant into many le≈ø≈øer Parcels, according as Adventurers pre≈øented; which Grants being founded upon uncertain and fal≈øe De≈øcriptions, and reports of ≈øome that Travelled thither, did much interfere one with another, to the great di≈øturbance of the fir≈øt Planters, ≈øo that little profit was reaped from thence: Nor was any greater Improvement made of tho≈øe Grand Portions of Land, ≈øaving the erecting ≈øome few Cottages for Fi≈øhermen, and a few incon≈øiderable Buildings for
the Planters; yea, for want of good Conduct, they were by degrees in a manner quite de≈øtitute of Laws and Government, and left to ≈øhift for them≈øelves

This was the beginning of New-England, when, in the Year 1610. one Mr. Robin≈øon a Presbyterian, or rather Independent Preacher, and ≈øeveral other Engli≈øh, then at Leyden in Holland, though they had been courteou≈øly entertained by the Dutch as Strangers; yet fore≈øeeing divers inconveniences might follow, and that they could not ≈øo well provide for the good of their Po≈øterity under the Government of a Foreign Nation, they re≈øolve to intreat ≈øo much Favour of their Sovereign Prince, King James, as to grant them Liberty, under the Protection of his Royal Authority, to place them≈øelves in ≈øome place of New-England. Having therefore obtained a Patent or Grant for ≈øome place about Hud≈øons River, they ≈øet Sail from Plymouth, in September, for the Southern Parts of New-England; but as they intended their Cour≈øe thither-ward, they were through many dangers, at la≈øt, about November the eleventh, ca≈øt upon a bo≈øom of the South Cape of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets Bay, called Cape Cod. When, Winter approached ≈øo fa≈øt, that they had no opportunity to remove, and finding ≈øome encouragement from the hopefulne≈øs of the Soyl, and courte≈øie of the Heathen, they re≈øolved there to make their aboad, laying the Foundation of a new Colony, which from the la≈øt Town they Sailed from in England, they called New-Plymouth, containing no con≈øiderable Tract of Land, ≈øcarce extending one hundred Mile in length through the whole Cape, and not half ≈øo much in breadth, where broade≈øt.

From this time, to the Year 1636. things were very pro≈øperou≈øly and ≈øucce≈øsfully carried on in New-England, which was much increa≈øed in Buildings and Inhabitants; at which time, the Naragan≈øet Indians, who are the mo≈øt Warlike and Fierce, and much dreaded by all the re≈øt, committed divers outrages upon ≈øeveral of them, and likewi≈øe upon the Engli≈øh and Dutch, as they came occa≈øionally to Trade with them, barbarou≈øly murthering Capt. Stone, Capt. Oldham, with ≈øeveral others: Whereupon the Inhabitants of all the Colonies unanimou≈øly falling upon them, in 1637. they were ea≈øily ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, about ≈øeven hundred of them being de≈øtroyed, and the re≈øt cut off by their neighbour Indians. Upon which, Miantonimoh, the chief of the Magchins, expecting to be ≈øole Lord and Ruler over all the Indians, committed many In≈øolencies upon ≈øome others, who were in Confederacy with the Engli≈øh as well as him≈øelf; and he being ≈øent for to the Ma≈ø≈øacu≈øets Court, at Bo≈øton, endeavoured to clear him≈øelf, but was clearly convicted by one of his fellows, named ∆≤ncas: In revenge of which, after his return home, he made War upon Vncas, by whom being taken Pri≈øoner, by the Advice and Coun≈øel of the Engli≈øh, he cut off his Head, it being ju≈øtly feared no firm Peace could be concluded while he was alive. This happened in 1643. from whence, to 1675. there was always an appearance of Amity and good Corre≈øpondence on all ≈øides, only in 1671. one Matoonas, being vexed that an intended De≈øign again≈øt the Engli≈øh did not take effect, out of meer malice again≈øt them, ≈ølew an Engli≈øhman on the Road; the Murtherer was a Nipnet Indian, and under the Command of the Sachem of Mount-Hope, the Author of all the mi≈øchief again≈øt the Engli≈øh in 1675.

Upon a due inquiry therefore of all the Tran≈øactions between the Indians and Engli≈øh, from their fir≈øt ≈øetling on the≈øe Coa≈øts, there will appear no ground of quarrel or provocation given by the Engli≈øh. For when Plymouth Colony was fir≈øt Planted in 1620. within three months after, Ma≈ø≈øa≈øoit, the chief Sachem or Commander of all that ≈øide of the Country, repairs thither to the Engli≈øh, and entred ≈øolemnly into a League upon the following Articles. 1. That neither he nor any of his ≈øhould injure or do any hurt to any of their People. 2. If any of his hurt the Engli≈øh, he ≈øhould ≈øend them the offender to puni≈øh. 3. If any thing ≈øhould be taken away by his, he ≈øhould ≈øee it re≈øtored, and the Engli≈øh to do the like to them. 4. If any made War unju≈øtly again≈øt him, they were to aid him, and he likewi≈øe them. 5. That he ≈øhould certifie his neighbour Confederates hereof, that they might be likewi≈øe compri≈øed in the Peace. 6. That when his men ≈øhould come to the Engli≈øh they ≈øhould leave their Arms behind; which were then Bows and Arrows, and were then their only Weapons, though now they have learn- the u≈øe of Guns and Swords as well as the Chri≈øtians. This League the ≈øame Sachem confirmed a little before his death, in 1630. coming with his two Sons, Alexander and Philip, to Plymouth, and renewing the ≈øame for Him≈øelf, his Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors; yet it is apparent this Ma≈ø≈øa≈øoit never loved the Engli≈øh, and would have ingaged them never to have attempted to draw away any of his People from their old Pagan Super≈øtition and Devili≈øh Idolatry, to the Chri≈øtian Religion: But finding they would make no Treaty with him upon ≈øuch Conditions, he urged it no further. But this was a bad Omen, that whatever kindne≈øs he pretended to the Englijh, yet he hated them for being
Chri≈øtians; which ≈øtrain was more apparent in his Son that ≈øucceeded him, and all the People: In≈øomuch, that ≈øome di≈øcerning Per≈øons of that Juri≈ødiction, were afraid that that part of the Indians would be all rooted out, as it is ≈øince come to pa≈øs.

Neither was Pa≈ø≈øaconaway, the great Sagamore or Sachim of Merimack River, in≈øen≈øible of the fatal con≈øequence of oppo≈øing the Engli≈øh; for a Per≈øon of Quality relates, that being invited by ≈øome Sachims to a great Dance, in 1660. Pa≈ø≈øaconaway intending at that time to make his la≈øt and farewel Speech to his Children and People, that were then all gathered together: He addre≈ø≈øing him≈øelf to them in this manner. I am now going the way of all fle≈øh, or ready to die, and not like to ≈øee you meet together any more; I will now leave this word of Coun≈øel with you, that you take heed how you quarrel with the Engli≈øh, for though you may do them much mi≈øchief, yet a≈ø≈øuredly you will all be de≈øtroyed and rooted off the Earth if you do: For I was as much an Enemy to them, at their fir≈øt coming into the≈øe Parts, as any one what≈øoever, and tryed all ways and means po≈ø≈øible to have de≈øtroyed them, at lea≈øt to have prevented them ≈øitting down here, but could no way effect it, therefore I advi≈øe you never to contend with the Engli≈øh, nor make War with them. And accordingly, his elde≈øt Son, a≈ø≈øoon as he perceived the Indians were up in Arms, withdrew him≈øelf into ≈øome remote place, that he might not be hurt either by the Engli≈øh or Indians.

But to proceed, after this digre≈ø≈øion; After the death of Ma≈ø≈øa≈øoit, his elde≈øt Son Alexander ≈øucceeded, about twenty years ≈øince, who, notwith≈øtanding the League he had entred into with the Engli≈øh with his Father, in 1639. had no affection
to them nor their Religion, but was Plotting to Ri≈øe again≈øt them; whereupon a ≈øtout Gentleman was ≈øent to bring him before the Council of Plymonth, who found him and eight more in a Hunting-Hou≈øe, where they were ju≈øt come in from Hunting. leaving all their Guns without doors, which being ≈øeized by the Engli≈øh, they then entred the Wigwam, and demanded Alexander to go along with them before the Governor. At which Me≈ø≈øage he was much appalled, but being told that if he ≈øtirred or refu≈øed to go, he was a dead man, he was per≈øuaded by one of the chief Confidents to go; but ≈øuch was the Pride of his Spirit, that his very Indignation for this ≈øurprizal, ca≈øt him into a Feaver, whereof he ≈øoon after died. After his death, Philip his Brother, nick-named King Philip, for his haughty Spirit, came in his own Per≈øon, in 166. with Sau≈øaman his chief Secretary and Coun≈øellor, to renew the former League that had been made with his Predece≈ø≈øors; and there was as much corre≈øpondence betwixt them, for the next ≈øeven years, as had ever been in former times; and yet without any kind of provocation, this treacherous Man, in 1676. harboured mi≈øchievous thoughts again≈øt them, Plotting a general In≈øurrection in all the Engli≈øh Colonies, all the Indians being to ri≈øe as one man again≈øt the Plantations which were next them. Which being di≈øcovered by John Sau≈øaman, Philip thereupon cau≈øed him to be murthered; the Murtherers being apprehended, were Executed, and Philip fearing his own Head, got openly into Arms, killing, burning and de≈øtroying the Engli≈øh, and their Habitations, with all manner of Barbarity and Cruelty. Which Troubles continued almo≈øt two years, 'till at length, after ≈øeveral Defeats given to Philips and his Forces, the lo≈øs of his
Friends, bereavement of his dear Wife and beloved Son, whom in his ha≈øte he was forced to leave Pri≈øoners to ≈øave his own life, his Trea≈øurers taken, and his own Followers Plotting again≈øt his life, Divine Vengeance overtook him for cau≈øele≈øly breaking his League. For having been Hunting like a Savage Bea≈øt through the Woods, about a hundred Miles backwards and forwards, at la≈øt he was driven to his own Den upon Mount Hope, retiring him≈øelf, with a few of his be≈øt Friends, in a Swamp, which proved now a Pri≈øon to ≈øecure him 'till the Me≈ø≈øenger of death came.

For ≈øuch was his hatred again≈øt the Engli≈øh, that he could not hear any thing ≈øhould be ≈øugge≈øted to him about Peace, in≈øomuch that he cau≈øed one of his Confederates to be kill'd for propounding it; which ≈øo provoked ≈øome of his Company, not altogether ≈øo de≈øperate as him≈øelf, that one of them (that was near Kin to him that was killed) fled to Road-I≈øland, and informed Captain Church where Philip was, offering to lead him thither: Upon this welcome news, a ≈ømall Party of Engli≈øh and Indians came very early in the Morning and ≈øurrounded his Swamp, from whence (as he was endeavouring to make his e≈øcape) he was ≈øhot through the Heart by an Indian of his own Nation; for Capt. Church having appointed an Engli≈øhman and an Indian to ≈øtand at ≈øuch a place of the Swamp, where it happen'd that Philip was breaking through; the Morning being very wet and rainy, the Engli≈øhman's Gun would not fire; the Indian having an old Musket, with a large Touch-hole, it took fire the more readily; which when Philip was di≈øpatch'd, the Bullet pa≈ø≈øing directly through his heart, ≈øoon after ≈øeveral of his Confederates and Coun≈øellors were taken, and ≈øuffered de≈øerved
puni≈øhment, and in a ≈øhort time mo≈øt of the Murtherers received their condign rewards. It cannot be altogether impertinent, but may di≈øcover much of the temper and management of the Indians in this War, to in≈øert an account of one Stockwell, of Deerfield, concerning his Captivity and Redemption, with other notable occurrences during his continuance among them, written with his own Hand, and are as follow in his own Words, viz.

September 19. 1677. About Sun-≈øet, I and another Man being together, the Indians with great ≈øhouting and ≈øhooting came upon us, and ≈øome other of the Engli≈øh hard by, at which we ran to a Swamp for refuge; which they perceiving, made after us, and ≈øhot at us, three Guns being di≈øcharged upon me; the Swamp being mine, I ≈ølipt in, and fell down; whereupon an Indian ≈øtept to me, with his Hatchet lifted up to knock me on the head, ≈øuppo≈øing I was wounded, and unfit for Travel: It happened I had a Pi≈øtol in my Pocket, which (though uncharged) I pre≈øented to him, who pre≈øently ≈øtept back, and told me, if I would yield I ≈øhould have no hurt, boa≈øting fal≈øely, that they had de≈øtroyed all Hatfield, and that the Woods were full of Indians; whereupon I yielded my≈øelf, and fell into the Enemies Hands, and by three of them was led away to the place whence I fir≈øt fled; where two other Indians came running to us, and one lifting up the But-end of his Gun to knock me on the head, the other with his hand put by the blow, and ≈øaid I was his Friend. I was now near my own Hou≈øe, which the Indians burnt la≈øt year, and I was about to build up again, and there I had ≈øome hopes to e≈øcape from them; there was a Hor≈øe ju≈øt by, which they bid me take, I did ≈øo, but attempted no e≈øcape, becau≈øe the Bea≈øt was
dull and ≈ølow, and I thought they would ≈øend me to take my own Hor≈øes; which they did, but they were ≈øo frighted, that I could not come near them, and ≈øo fell again into the Enemies Hands, who now took me, bound me, and led me away. Soon after, I was brought to other Captives, who were that day taken at Hatfield, which moved two contrary Pa≈ø≈øions, Joy, to have Company; and Sorrow, that we were in that mi≈øerable Condition: We were all pinion'd and led away in the Night over the Mountains, in dark and hideous ways, about four Miles further, before we took up our place of re≈øt, which was a di≈ømal place of a Wood on the Ea≈øt-≈øide of that Mountain; we were kept bound all that night, the Indians watching us, who, as they Travell'd, made ≈øtrange noi≈øes, as of Wolves, Owls, and other Birds and Bea≈øts, that they might not lo≈øe one another; and if followed, might not be di≈øcover'd by the Engli≈øh.

About break of day we marched again, and got over the great River Pecompt uck; there the Indians marched out upon Trays, the number of their Captives and Slain, as there manner is: Here I was again in great dange0r, a quarrel ari≈øing who≈øe Captive I was, and I was afraid I mu≈øt be killed to end the controver≈øie; they then asked me who≈øe I was, I ≈øaid three Indians took me; ≈øo they agreed to have all a ≈øhare in me: I had now three Ma≈øters, but the Chief was he that fir≈øt laid hands on me, which happened to be the wor≈øt of the company, as A≈øhpelon the Indian Captain told me, who was always very kind to me, and a great comfort to the Engli≈øh, In this place they gave us Victuals which they had brought away from the Engli≈øh, and ten Men were again ≈øent out for more
Plunder, ≈øome of whom brought Provi≈øion, others Corn out of the Meadows, upon Hor≈øes; from hence we went up above the Falls, where we cro≈øt that River again, when I fell down-right Lame of my old Wounds received in the War; but the apprehen≈øion of being killed by the Indians, and what cruel death they would put me to, ≈øoon frighted away my pain, and I was very brisk again. We had eleven Hor≈øes in that company? which carried Burthens and the Women; we travell'd up the River till night, and then took up our Lodgings in a di≈ømal place, being laid on our Backs and ≈øtaked down, in which po≈øture we lay many nights together; the manner was, our arms and legs being ≈øtretched out, were ≈øtaked fa≈øt down, and a Cord put about our necks, ≈øo that we could not po≈ø≈øibly ≈øtir; the fir≈øt night (being much tired) I ≈ølept as comfortably as ever; the next we lay in the Saquahog-Meadows; our Provi≈øion was ≈øoon ≈øpent, and whil≈øt we were there, the Indians went a Hunting, and the Engli≈øh Army came out after us. Then the Indians moved again, dividing them≈øelves and the Captives into many companies, that the Engli≈øh might not follow their Track; at night, having cro≈ø≈øed the River, we met again at the place appointed; the next day were pa≈ø≈øed it, where we continued a long time, which being about thirty Miles above Squag, the Indians were quite out of fear of the Engli≈øh, but much afraid of the Mo-hawks, another ≈øort of Indians, Enemies to them.

In this place they built a ≈øtrong Wigwam, and had a great Daunce, as they call'd it, where it was concluded to burn three of us; having provided Bark for that purpo≈øe, of whom (as I heard afterwards) I was to be one, Serjeant Plumpton
another, and the Wife of Benjamin Wait the third; I knew not then who they were, yet I under≈øtood ≈øo much of their Language, that I perceived ≈øome were de≈øigned thereto; that night I could not ≈øleep for fear of the next day's work, the Indians (weary with dancing) lay down and ≈øtept ≈øoundly. The Engli≈øh were all loo≈øe, whereupon I went out for Wood, and mended the fire, making a noi≈øe on purpo≈øe, but none awaked; I thought if any of the Engli≈øh ≈øhould wake, we might kill them all ≈øleeping; to which end I removed out of the way all the Guns and Hatchets, but my heart failing, I put all things where they were again. The next day (when they intended to burn us) our Ma≈øter and ≈øome others ≈øpoke for us, and the evil was prevented at this time: We lay here about three Weeks, where I had a Shirt brought me to make; one Indian ≈øaid it ≈øhould be made this way, another a different way, and a third this way, whereupon I told them I would make it according to my chief Ma≈øter's order; upon this an Indian ≈øtruck me on the face with his fi≈øt, I ≈øuddenly ro≈øe in anger to return it again, which rai≈øed a great Hubbub; the Indians and Engli≈øh coming about me, I was fain to humble my ≈øelf to my Ma≈øter, which ended the matter. Before I came to this place, my three Ma≈øters were gone a Hunting, and I was left with only one Indian (all the company being upon a march) who fell ≈øick, ≈øo that I was fain to carry his Gun and Hatchet, whereby I had opportunity to have di≈øpatched him, but did not, becau≈øe the Engli≈øh Captives had engag'd the contrary to each other, ≈øince if one ≈øhould run away, it would much endanger the remainder: Whil≈øt we were here, Benjamin Stebbins, going with ≈øome Indians to Wachu≈øet Hills, made his e≈øcape, the tydings whereof
cau≈øed us all to be called in and bound. One of the Indians Captains, and always our great Friend, met me coming in, and told me Stebbins was run away, and the Indians ≈øpoke of burning us; ≈øome were only for burning our fingers, and then biting them off; he ≈øaid there would be a Court, and all would ≈øpeak their minds, but he would ≈øpeak la≈øt, and declare, That the Indian, who ≈øuffered Stebbins to make his e≈øcape, was only in fault; and bid us not fear any hurt ≈øhould happen to us, and ≈øo it prov'd accordingly.

Whil≈øt we lingered here-about, Provi≈øion grew ≈øcarce, one Bear's Foot mu≈øt ≈øerve five of us a whole day; we began to eat Hor≈øe-fle≈øh, and devoured ≈øeveral Hor≈øes, three only being left alive. At this time the Indians had fallen upon Hadley, where ≈øome of them being taken, were relea≈øed, upon promi≈øe of meeting the Engli≈øh on ≈øuch a Plain, to make further Terms: Captain A≈øhpalon was much for it, but the Sachins of Wachu≈øet, when they came, were again≈øt it; yet were willing to meet the Engli≈øh, only to fall upon and de≈øtroy them. A≈øhpalon charged us Engli≈øh not to ≈øpeak a word of this, ≈øince mi≈øchief would come of it. With the≈øe Indians from Wachu≈øet, there came above four≈øcore Squaws, or Women and Children, who reported the Engli≈øh had taken ∆≤ncas and all his Men, and ≈øent them beyond the Seas; whereat they were much enraged, asking us if it were true; we deny'd it, which made A≈øhpalon angry, ≈øaying he would no more believe Engli≈øhmen. They then examin'd every one apart, and dealt wor≈øe with us for a time, than before; ≈øtill Provi≈øion was ≈øcarce; at length we came to a place called Squaro-Maug-River, where we hoped to find Salmon, but came too late; this
place I reckon two hundred Miles above Deer-field, then we parted into two companies, ≈øome went one way, and ≈øome another; we pa≈ø≈øed over a mighty Mountain, being eight days in travelling of it, though we marched very hard, and had every day either Snow or Rain; we ob≈øerved that on this Mountain all the Water ran Northward. Here we likewi≈øe wanted Provi≈øion, at length we got over and came near a Lake, where we ≈øtaid a great while to make Canoes, wherein to pa≈øs over. Here I was frozen, and here again we were like to ≈øtarve; all the Indians went a Hunting, but could get nothing ≈øeveral days; they Pawawed, or Conjured, but to no purpo≈øe; then they de≈øired the Engli≈øh to pray, confe≈ø≈øing they could do nothing, and would have us try what the Engli≈øhmans God could do: I prayed, ≈øo did Serjeant Plumpton in another place, the Indians reverently attending Morning and Night; next day they killed ≈øome Bears, then they would needs make us de≈øire a Ble≈ø≈øing, and return Thanks at Meals; but after a while they grew weary of it, and the Sachim forbid us; when I was frozen, they were very cruel to me, becau≈øe I could not do as at other times.

When we came to the Lake, we were again ≈øadly ≈øtreightned for Provi≈øion, and forced to eat Touch-wood fried in Bear's Grea≈øe; at la≈øt we found a company of Racoons, and then we made a Fea≈øt, the Cu≈øtom being that we mu≈øt eat all; I perceived I had too much for one time, which an Indian that ≈øate by ob≈øerving, bid me to ≈ølip away ≈øome to him under his Coat, and he would hide it for me till another time; this Indian, as ≈øoon as he had got my meat, ≈øtood up and made a Speech to the re≈øt, di≈øcovering what I had done, whereat
they were very angry, and cut me another piece, forcing me to drink Racoons Grea≈øe, which made me ≈øick and vomit; I told them I had enough, after which they would give me no more, but ≈øtill told me I had Racoon enough, whereby I ≈øuffered much, and (being frozen) was in great pain, ≈øleeping but little, and yet mu≈øt do my task that was ≈øet me; as they came to the Lake, they killed a great Moo≈øe, ≈øtaying there till it was all eaten, and then entered upon the Lake; a Storm aro≈øe, which endangered us all, but at la≈øt we got to an I≈øland, and there the Indians went to Pawawing, or Conjuring; the Pawaw declared, that Bejamin Wait and another were coming, and that Storm was rai≈øed to ca≈øt them away: This afterwards appeared to be true, though then I believed it not; upon this I≈øland we lay ≈øtill ≈øeveral days, and then ≈øet out again, but a Storm took us, ≈øo that we continued to and fro upon certain I≈ølands about three weeks; we had no Provi≈øions but Racoons, that the Indians them≈øelves were afraid of being ≈øtarved; they would give me nothing, whereby I was ≈øeveral days without any Victuals: At length we went upon the Lake on the Ice, having a little Slead, upon which we drew our Loads; before Noon I tired, and ju≈øt then the Indians met with ≈øome Frenchmen: One of the Indians, who took me, came and called me all manner of ill Names, throwing me on my back; I told him I could do no more, then he ≈øaid he mu≈øt kill me, which I thought he was about to do, for pulling out his knife, he cut off my Pockets and wrapt them about my Face, and then he helped me up, and took my ‚Ä¢ lead and went away, giving me a bit of Bisket like a Walnut, which he had of the Frenchman, and told me he would give me a Pipe of Tobacco; when my
Slead was gone, I ran after him, (but being tired) ≈øoon fell to a foot-pace, whereby the Indians were out of ≈øight; I followed as well as I could, having many falls upon the Ice; at length I was ≈øo ≈øpent, I had not ≈øtrength enough to ri≈øe again, but crept to a Tree that lay along, upon which I continued all the cold night, it being very ≈øharp weather.

I now counted no other but I mu≈øt here die, which whil≈øt I was ruminating of, an Indian hollowed, and I an≈øwered; he came to me and called me bad Names, telling me if I would not go, he mu≈øt knock me on the head; I told him he mu≈øt then do ≈øo, he ≈øaw how I had wallowed in the Snow, but could not ri≈øe, hereupon he wrapt me in his Coat, and going back, ≈øent two Indians with a Slead; one ≈øaid he mu≈øt knock me on the head, the other ≈øaid no, they would carry me away and burn me; then they bid me ≈øtir my In≈øtep, to ≈øee if that were frozen, I did ≈øo; when they ≈øaw that, they ≈øaid there was a Chirurgeon with the French that could cure me; then they took me upon a Slead and carried me to the fire, making much of me, pulling of my wet, and wrapping me in dry Cloaths, laying me on a good Bed, they had killed an Otter, and gave me ≈øome of the Broth, and a bit of the Fle≈øh; here I ≈ølept till towards day, and was then able to get up and put on my Cloaths; one of the Indians awaked, and ≈øeeing me go, ≈øhouted, as rejoycing at it. A≈ø≈øoon as it was light, I and Samuel Ru≈ø≈øel went afore on the Ice upon a River, they ≈øaid I mu≈øt go on foot as much as I could for fear of freezing; Ru≈ø≈øul ≈ølipt into the River with one foot, the Indians called him back and dried his Stockins, and ≈øent us away with an Indian Guide; we went four or five Miles before the re≈øt of the Indians overtook us; I was pretty
well ≈øpent, Ru≈ø≈øel ≈øaid he was faint, and wondred how I could live, for he ≈øaid he had had ten Meals to my one; I was then laid on the Slead, and they ran away with me on the Ice; the re≈øt and Ru≈ø≈øel came ≈øoftly after, who≈øe face I never after ≈øaw more, nor knew what become of him. About midnight we got near Shamblee, a French Town, where the River was open; when I came to travel, I was not able, whereupon an Indian who ≈øtaid with me would carry me a few Rods, and then I would go as many, telling me I would die if he did not carry me, and I mu≈øt tell the Engli≈øh how kind he was.

When vve came to the fir≈øt hou≈øe, there vvas no Inhabitants; the Indian and I were both ≈øpent and di≈øcouraged, he ≈øaid vve mu≈øt novv both die; at la≈øt he left me alone, and got to another hou≈øe, from vvhence came iom≈ø French and Indians, vvho brought me in; the French vvere very kind, putting my hands and feet in cold Water, and gave me a dram of Brandy, and a little Ha≈øty-Pudding and Milk; vvhen I ta≈øted Victuals, I vvas very hungry, but they vvould not ≈øuffer me to eat too much; I lay by the ≈øire vvith the Indians that night, yet could not ≈øleep for pain; next morning the Indians and French fell out about me, the Indians ≈øaying, that the French loved the Engli≈øh better than the Indians: The French pre≈øently turned the Indians out of doors, being very careful of me, and all the Men in the Tovvn came to ≈øee me: Here I continued three or four days, and vvas invited f ‚Ä¢ om one hou≈øe to another, receiving much civility from a young Man, vvho let me lie in his Bed, and vvould have bought me, but the Indians demanded a hundred Pounds; vve travell'd to a place called S ‚Ä¢ rril, vvhither this young Man accompanied me to prevent my being abu≈øed by the Indians; he carried
me on the Ice one day's Journey, for novv I could not go at all; vvhen vve came to the place, the People vvere kind.

Next day, being in much pain, I asked the Indians to carry me to the Chirurgeon, as they had promi≈øed; vvhereat they vvere angry, one taking up his Gun to knock me dovvn, but the French vvould not ≈øuffer it, falling upon them and kicking them out of doors; vve vvent avvay from thence to a place tvvo or three Miles of, vvhere the Indians had Wigwams; ≈øome of them knevv me, and ≈øeemed to pity me: While I vvas here, vvhich vvas three or four days; the French came to ≈øee me, and (it being Chri≈øtmas time) they brought me Cakes and other Provi≈øion, the Indians tried to cure me, but could not; then I asked for the Chirurgeon, at vvhich one of them in anger ≈øtruck me on the face vvith his ≈øi≈øt; a Frenchman being by, vvho ≈øpoke to him ≈øome vvords, and vvent his vvays; ≈øoon after came the Captain of the place to the Wigwam, vvith about tvvelve armed Men, and asked vvhere the Indian vvas that ≈øtruck the Engli≈øhman, and ≈øeizing him, told him, he ≈øhould go to the Bribocs, and then be hanged: The Indians vvere much terrified at this, as appeared by their countenance and trembling; I vvould have gone avvay too, but the Frenchman bid me not fear, the Indians dur≈øt not hurt me.

When that Indian vvas gone, I had tvvo Ma≈øters ≈øtill, I asked them to carry me to that Captain, that I might ≈øpeak in behalf of the Indian; they an≈øvvered, I vvas a Fool, did I think the Frenchmen vvere like the Engli≈øh, to ≈øay one thing and do another? they vvere Men of their Words; but at length I prevailed vvith them to help me thither,
and ≈øpeaking to the Captain by an Interpreter, told him, I de≈øired him to ≈øet the Indian free, declaring hovv kind he had been to me; he replied, he vvas a Rouge, and ≈øhould be hanged; then I privately alledged, that if he vvere hanged, it might fare the vvor≈øe vvith the Engli≈øh Captives; the Captain ≈øaid, that ought to be con≈øider'd, vvhereupon he ≈øet him at liberty, upon condition he ≈øhould never ≈øtrike me more, and bring me every day to his hou≈øe to eat Victuals; I perceived the common People did not approve of vvhat the Indians acted again≈øt the Engli≈øh: When he vvas free, he came and took me about the middle, ≈øaying, I vvas his Brother, I had ≈øaved his life once, and he had ≈øaved mine (he ≈øaid) thrice; he then called for Brandy, and made me drink, and had me avvay to the Wigwam again; vvhen I came there, the Indians one after another ≈øhook hands vvith me, and vvere very kind, thinking no other but I had ≈øaved the Indian's life.

Next day he carried me to the Captain's hou≈øe, and ≈øet me dovvn; they gave me my Victuals and Wine, and being left there avvhile by the Indians, I ≈øhevved the Captain and his Wife my Fingers, vvho vvere a≈ø≈ørighted thereat, and bid me lap it up again, and ≈øent for the Chirurgeon, vvho vvhen he came, ≈øaid, he vvould cure me, and dre≈ø≈øed it: That night I vvas full of pain, the French vvere afraid I vvould die, five Men did vvatch me, and ≈øtrove to keep me chearful, for I vvas ≈øometimes ready to faint; oft-times they gave me a little Brandy.

The next day the Chirurgeon came again and dre≈ø≈øed me, and ≈øo he did all the while I was among the French, wich was from Chri≈øtmas till May. I continued in this Captain's Hou≈øe till Benjamin Wait
came, and my Indian Ma≈øter (being in want of Money) pawned me to the Captain for fourteen Beavers, or the worth of them, by ≈øuch a day; which if he did not pay, he mu≈øt lo≈øe his Pawn, or el≈øe ≈øell me for one and twenty Beavers; but he could get no Beaver, ≈øo I was ≈øold, and (in Gods good time,) ≈øet at liberty, and returned to my Friends in New-England again.

This Country is po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by divers ≈øorts of People, who are judged to be of the Tartars, called Samoids, bordering upon Mu≈øcovia, being divided into Tribes; tho≈øe to the Ea≈øt and North-Ea≈øt are called Churchers, Tarentines, and Monhegans: To the South are the Pequets and Naragan≈øets: We≈øtwards, Connecticuts and Mow-hacks: To the North, Aberginians, which con≈øi≈øt of Mattachu≈øets, Wippanaps and Tarentines: The Pocanets live to the We≈øtward of Plymouth. Not long before the Engli≈øh came into the Country, happened a great Mortality among them, e≈øpecially when the Engli≈øh afterwards planted. The Ea≈øt and Northern Parts were ≈øore ≈ømitten, fir≈øt by the Plague, after, when the Engli≈øh came, by the Small-Pox; the three Kingdoms, or Sagamor≈øhips of the Mattachu≈øets, being before very populous, having under them ≈øeven Dukedoms or petty Sagamor≈øhips, but were now by the Plague reduced from 30000 to 300. There are now many to the Ea≈øtward, the Pequods were de≈øtroyed by the Engli≈øh, the Mow-hacks are about five Hundred, their Speech is a Dialect of the Tartars, they are of Per≈øon tall, and well Limbed, of a pale and lean Vi≈øage, black Ey'd, which is counted ≈øtronge≈øt for ≈øight; and black Hair'd, both ≈ømooth and curled, generally wearing it long; they have ≈øeldom any Beards, their Teeth very white, ≈øhort and even, which they account
the mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary and be≈øt part of Man; and as the Au≈øtrians are known by their great Lips, the Bavarians by their Pokes under their Chins, the Jews by their goggle Eyes, ≈øo the Indians are remarkable for their flat No≈øes. The Inde≈ø≈øes, or young Women, are ≈øome very comely, with round plump Faces, and generally plump of their Bodies (as well as the Men,) ≈øoft and ≈ømooth like a Mole-skin, of a rea≈øonable good Complexion, but that they dye them≈øelve≈ø Tawny; yet many pretty Brownetto's and ≈ømall finger'd La≈ø≈øes are found among≈øt; them; the Vetuala's, or old Women, are lean and ugly, yet all of a mode≈øt demeanour, con≈øidering their ≈øavage breeding; and indeed they ≈øhame our Engli≈øh Ru≈øticks, who≈øe rudene≈øs in many things exceeds theirs.

The Natives are of a very incon≈øtant, crafty and timorous di≈øpo≈øition, but are very ingenious and quick of apprehen≈øion, ≈øoon angry, and ≈øo malicious, that they ≈øeldom forget injury; and barbarou≈øly cruel, witne≈øs their direful revenge upon each other; prone to injurious violence and ≈ølaughter, both Men and Women being very theevi≈øh, and great haters of Strangers; all of them Canibals, or Eaters of humane Fle≈øh ; and ≈øo were formerly the Heathen Iri≈øh, who us'd to feed upon the Buttocks of Boys, and the Paps of Women. The Spani≈øh Relation gives an account, that the Natives would not eat a Spaniard, till they had kept him two or three days dead, to grow tender, becau≈øe their fle≈øh was hard. At Martins Vineyard, an I≈øland that lies South of Plymouth, in the way to Virginia, certain Indians ≈øeized upon a Boat that put into a by Cove, killed the Men, and in a ≈øhort time eat them up before they were di≈øcovered.

Wives they have two or three, according to their ability and ≈øtrength of body; the Women have the ea≈øie≈øt labour of any in the World, for when their time is come, they go out alone, carrying a Board with them two Foot long, and a Foot and an half broad, bored full of holes on each ≈øide, having a foot beneath, and on the top abroad ≈øtrap of Leather, which they put over their Forehead, the Board hanging at their Back; when they come to a convenient Bu≈øh or Tree, they lay them down, and are delivered in an in≈øtant, without ≈øo much as one groan; they wrap the Child up in young Beaver Skin, with his Heels clo≈øe to his Buttocks, and laced down to the Board upon his Back, his Knees re≈øting upon the foot beneath; then put the ≈øtrap of Leather upon their Forehead, with the Infant hanging at their Back, home they trudg, and dye the Child with a liquor of boil'd Hemlock-Bark, and then throw him into the Water, if they ≈øu≈øpect it gotten by any other Nation; if it will ≈øwim, they acknowledg it for their own; they give them Names when they are Men grown, and love the Engli≈øh, as Robbin, Harry, Philip, and the like; they are very indulgent to their Children, as well as Parents; but if they live ≈øo long as to be burthen≈øom, they either ≈øtarve or bury them alive, as it was ≈øuppo≈øed an Indian did by his Mother at Ca≈øco, in 1669.

Their Apparel,Their Apparel before the Engli≈øh came among them, was the Skin of wild Bea≈øts, with the hair on; Buskins of Deer Skins, or Moo≈øe, dre≈øt, and drawn with lines into ≈øeveral works, the lines being coloured with yellow, blew or red; Pumps too they have, made of tough Skins, without ≈øoles. In the Winter, when Snow will bear them, they
fa≈øten to their Feet Snow-Shoes, made like a large Racket for Tennis Play, laced on before, and behind they wear a ≈øquare piece of Leather, tied about their Middle with a ≈øtring, to hide their Secrets. But ≈øince they have had to do with the Engli≈øh, they buy of them a Cloth called Trading-Cloth, of which they make Mantles, Coats with ≈øhort Sleeves, and Caps for their Heads, but the Men keep their old Fa≈øhion. They are very proud, as appears by decking them≈øelves with white and blew Beads of their making, and painting their Faces with variety of Colours, and ≈øometimes weave curious Coats with Turkey Feathers for their Children, &c.

This Countrey is well watered with Rivers, the chief among which, are Agamentico, Conecticut, Kinebequy, Merrimick, Mi≈øhum, Mi≈øtick, Neragan≈øat, Pa≈øcataway, Pemnaquid, Tachobacco, &c. And in the≈øe Rivers, together with the Sea, are taken excellent Fi≈øh, as Cod, Thorn-back, Sturgeon, Porpu≈ø≈øes, Haddock, Salmons, Herrings, Mackarel, Oy≈øters, Crab-fi≈øh, Tortoi≈øe, Cockles, Mu≈øcles, Clams, Smelts, Eels, Lamprons, Alewives, Ba≈ø≈øes, Hallibuts, Shacks, Scales, Grampus and Whales.

Here are great variety of Fowls, as Phea≈øants, Patridges, Heath-Cocks, Turkeys, Gee≈øe, Ducks, Herons, Cranes, Cormorants, Swans, Widgeons, Sheldrakes, Snipes, Doppers, Black-birds, the Humbird, Loor, &c.
The wild Bea≈øts of chief note, are Lions, Bears, Foxes, Rackoons, Moo≈øes, Mu≈øqua≈øhs, Otters, Beavers, Deer, Hares, Coneys, &c. and for tame Bea≈øts, Cows, Sheep, Goats, Swine and Hor≈øes.
Among≈øt the hurtful things in this Countrey, the Rattle-Snake is mo≈øt dangerous. Here is al≈øo ≈øeveral ≈øorts of ≈øtinging Flies, which are found very trouble≈øom to the Inhabitants.

Here are ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Trees, as the Oak, Cyprus, Pine, Che≈ønut, Cedar Walnut, Firr, A≈øh, A≈øp, Elm, Alder, Maple, Birch, Sa≈ø≈øaphras, Sumach; ≈øeveral Fruit-Trees, as Apples, Pears, Plums, with ≈øeveral others that are growing in Virginia and Mary-Land, which hath already been taken notice of.

This Countrey affordeth ≈øeveral ≈øorts of rich Furrs, Flax Linnen, Amber, Iron, Pitch, Tarr, Cables, Ma≈øts, and Timber to build Ships; al≈øo ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Grain, wherewith they drive a con≈øiderable Trade to Barbadoes, and other Engli≈øh Plantations in America, ≈øupplying them with Flower, Bisket, Salt, Fle≈øh and Fi≈øh, &c. and in return, bring Sugars, and other Commodities. They al≈øo drive a con≈øiderable Trade with England for wearing Apparel, Stuffs, Cloth, Iron, Bra≈øs, and other Uten≈øils for their Hou≈øes, and ≈øuch like things that are u≈øeful to Man, and not found among≈øt them.

As to the Coins, Weights and Mea≈øures of New-England, and the re≈øt of the American Plantations belonging to his Maje≈øty, are the ≈øame with tho≈øe of England; but as to Coins, they are not much made u≈øe of in Trade, their way being Bartering of one Commodity for another, &c.

The Engli≈øh, now Inhabiting in New-England, are very numerous and powerful, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing many Potent Colonies, and are governed by Laws of their own making, having having ≈øeveral Courts of Judicature, where they a≈ø≈øemble together once a Month, as well for the making of new Laws, aboli≈øhing
of old, hearing and determining of Cau≈øes: As for the Electing of a Governor, Deputy-Governor, A≈ø≈øi≈øtants, Burge≈ø≈øes, and other Magi≈øtrates, (every Town having two Burge≈ø≈øes) each County annually Electing ≈øuch like Officers. The Government, both Civil and Eccle≈øia≈øtical, is in the hands of Independents or Presbyterians. The Military part of their Government, is by one Major-General and three Serjeant-Majors, to whom belong the four Counties of Suffolk, Middle≈øex, E≈ø≈øex and Norfolk.

Here are ≈øeveral fine Towns, as Bo≈øton, the Metropolis of New-England, commodiou≈øly ≈øeated for Traffick on the Sea-≈øhore; it is at pre≈øent a very large and ≈øpacious Town, or rather City, compo≈øed of ≈øeveral well-ordered Streets, and graced with ≈øeveral fair and beautiful Hou≈øes, which are well Inhabited by Merchants and Trade≈ømen, who drive a con≈øiderable Trade for ≈øuch Commodities as the Country affordeth, to Barbadoes and other Caribbee I≈øles; as al≈øo to England and Ireland, taking in exchange ≈øuch Commodities as each place affordeth, or are found u≈øeful to them. It is a place of good ≈øtrength, having two or three Hills adjoyning, on which are rai≈øed Fortifications, with great Pieces mounted thereon, which are well guarded.

Charles-Town, ≈øeated on and between the Rivers Charles and Mi≈øtick; it is beautified with a large and well-built Church, and near the River-≈øide is the Market-place, from which runneth two Streets, in which are ≈øeveral good Hou≈øes.
Dorche≈øter, ≈øituated near the Sea, where there falls two Rivulets; an indifferent Town.

Cambridge, formerly New-Town, ≈øeated on the River Merrimick: This Town con≈øi≈øts of ≈øeveral
Streets, and is beautified with two Colledges, and divers fair and well-built Hou≈øes.
St. Georges Fort, ≈øeated on the mouth of the River Sagadebock.
New-Plymouth, ≈øeated on that large Bay of Patuxed.
Reading, commodiou≈øly ≈øeated above a great Pond, and well Watered and Inhabited. In this Town are two Mills, one for Corn, and the other for Timber.
Salem, plea≈øantly ≈øeated between two Rivers.
Other Towns placed Alphabetically.

Berwick, Braintree, Bri≈øtol, Concord, Dartmouth, Dedham, Dover, Exeter, Falmouth, Gloce≈øter, Greens-Harbour, Hampton, Hartford, Haverhil, Hingham, Hull, Ip≈øwich, Lin, Mulden, New-bury, New-Haven, Northam, Norwich, Oxford, Rowley, Roxbury, Salisbury, Sandwich, Southampton, Springfield, Sudbury, Wenham, Weymouth, Woburne and Tarmouth.

Mo≈øt of the≈øe having their Names from ≈øome Towns in England, many of them being of good account, and commodiou≈øly ≈øeated, either on the Sea Shore, or on Navigable Rivers, and are well Inhabited. And mo≈øt of the≈øe Towns are known to the Indians by other Names. The pre≈øent Governour for his Maje≈øty, is Henry Cranfield, E≈øq

div.head: A DESCRIPTION OF NEW-FO∆≤ND-LAND.
div.p: NEw-found-land is an I≈øland, in ExtentIts Extent. equal to England, from whence it is di≈øtant little above ≈øix hundred Leagues, lying near half way between Ireland and Virginia.

It is ≈øituated between 46 and 53 Degrees North Latitude;Its Situation. the North part being better Inhabited than the South, though fitter for Habitation; and it is only ≈øevered from the Continent of America, by an Arm of the Sea, like that which ≈øeparates England from France.
Its Bays, Rivers, Fi≈øh, Fowls, Bea≈øts, &c.
It is famous for many ≈øpacious and excellent Bays and Harbours; and within the Land, for the variety of fre≈øh Springs, who≈øe Waters are excellent delicious.

It is enriched by Nature with plenty of Fi≈øh, Land and Water Fowl, and ≈øufficiently ≈øtocked with Deer, Hares, Otters, Foxes, Squirrels, and other Bea≈øts, which yield good Furrs; Cod-Fi≈øh,
Herrings, Salmons, Thorn-back, Oy≈øters, Mu≈øcles, &c. And though not over-run generally with Woods, it doth afford (be≈øides ≈øtore of Fewel) abundance of ≈øtately Trees fit for Timber, Ma≈øts, Planks, and ≈øundry other u≈øes.

The Soyl in mo≈øt places is reputed fertile,Its Fertility. the Climate whol≈øom, though the rigour of the Winter ≈øea≈øon, and the excels of Heats in Summer, doth detract ≈øomething from it due prai≈øe.

The I≈øland of New-found-land was fir≈øt di≈øcovered by Seba≈øtian Cabot; The fir≈øt Di≈øcoverer. likewi≈øe Fabian gives an account, that in the time of Henry the Seventh, three men being taken in New-found-land were brought to the King: And Robert Thorn writes, that his Father, and one Mr. Eliot, were the Di≈øcoverers of the New-found-land, in 1530. Mr. Hore ≈øets out for a further Di≈øcovery, but was brought to ≈øuch extremity by Famine, that many of his Company were killed and eaten by their fellows; and tho≈øe which returned, were ≈øo altered, that Sir William Butts, a Norfolk Knight, could not know his Son Thomas, who was one of this ≈øtarved number, but only by a Wart that grew upon one of his knees.

After the fir≈øt Di≈øcovery, the bu≈øine≈øs of Trading thither was laid a≈øide for many years. In the mean time, the Normans, Portugals, and Brittains of France, re≈øorted to it, and changed the Names which had been given by the Engli≈øh to the Bays and Promontories; but the Engli≈øh would not ≈øo ≈øoon relinqui≈øh their Preten≈øions: And therefore, in 1583. Sir Humphrey Gilbert took Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof, in the Name, and by the Commi≈ø≈øion, of Queen Elizabeth, forbidding all other Nations to
u≈øe Fi≈øhing, and intending to have ≈øetled an Engli≈øh Colony there, but being wrack'd in his return, the ≈øetling of the Colony was di≈øcontinued till 1608. and then undertook by John Guy, a Merchant of Bri≈øtol, who in twenty three days failed from thence to Conception Bay in New-found-land. In 1611. they had ≈øcarce ≈øix days of Fro≈øt in October and November, which pre≈øently thawed, the re≈øt of the Months being warmer and dryer than in England, neither were the Brooks frozen up three nights together with Ice able to bear a Dog: They had Filberds, Fi≈øh, Mackerel and Foxes in the Winter, White Patridges in the Summer, larger than ours, who are much afraid of Ravens. They kill a Wolf with a Ma≈øtiff and a Greyhound.

In 1612. they found ≈øome Hou≈øes of the Natives, which were nothing but Poles ≈øet round, and meeting on the top, ten foot broad, the fire in mid≈øt, covered with Deer-skins. The People are of a rea≈øonable Stature, Beardle≈øs, Broad-faced, their faces covered with Oker: Some of them went naked, only their Privities covered with a Skin. They believe in one God, who Created all things, but have many whim≈øical Notions, and ridiculous Opinions; for they ≈øay, That after God had made all things, he took a number of Arrows, and ≈øtruck them in the Ground, from whence Men and Women fir≈øt ≈øprung up, and have multiplied ever ≈øince. A Sagamore or Governour being asked concerning the Trinity, an≈øwered, There was only one God, one Son, one Mother, and the Sun, which were four, yet God was above all. Being que≈øtioned if they or their Ance≈øtors had heard that God was come into the World, he ≈øaid, That he had not ≈øeen him. Some among them ≈øpeak vi≈øibly to the Devil, and he tells them what they mu≈øt do, as well in War as other matters.

One Samuel Chaplain, in 1603. gives an acconnt of a Fea≈øt made by one of their Great Lords in his Cabbin; eight or ten Kettles of Meat were ≈øet on ≈øeveral Fires, ≈øome yards a≈øunder: The men ≈øate on both ≈øides the Room, each of them having a Di≈øh of the Bark of a Tree, one of which was appointed to give every man his Portion. Before the Meat was boyled, one took his Dog and Danced about the Kettles, and when he came before the Sagamore, threw the Dog down, and then another ≈øucceeded in the like Exerci≈øe: After the Fea≈øt, they Danced with the Heads of their Enemies in their hands, ≈øinging all the while. Their Canoes are of the Bark of Birch, ≈øtrengthned with little Wooden Hoops, they have many Fires in their Cabbins, ten Hou≈øholds ≈øometimes live together, lying upon Skins one by another, and their Dogs with them, which are like Foxes. At another Fea≈øt, the Men cau≈øe all the Women and Maids to ≈øit in Ranks, them≈øelves ≈øtanding behind Singing; ≈øuddenly all the Women threw off all their Mantles of Skins, and ≈øtrip them≈øelves ≈øtark naked, being not at all a≈øhamed; their Songs ended, they cryed with one Voice, Ho, Ho, Ho, and then covered them≈øelves with their Mantles, and after a while renewed their former Songs? and Nakedne≈øs. When a Maid is fourteen or fifteen years of Age, ≈øhe hath many Lovers, and u≈øes her Plea≈øure with as many of them as ≈øhe plea≈øes, for five or ≈øix years, and then takes whom ≈øhe likes for a Husband, providing he be a good Hunter, living Cha≈øtly with him all her life after, except for Barrenne≈øs he for≈øakes her.

When any dies, they make a Pit, and therein put all his Goods with the Corps, covering it over with Earth,Their Iurials. and ≈øetting many pieces of Wood over
it, and a ≈øtake Painted red. They believe the immortality of the Soul, and that the Dead go into a far Country, to make merry with their Friends. If any fall ≈øick, they ≈øend to one Sagamon Memberton, a great Conjurer, who made Prayers to the Devil, and blowed upon the Party, and cutting him, ≈øucks the Blood; if it be a Wound, he heals it after the ≈øame manner, applying a round ≈ølice of Beaver Stones, for which they make him a Pre≈øent of Veni≈øon or Skins. If they de≈øire News of things ab≈øent, the Spirit an≈øwers doubtfully, and ≈øometimes fal≈øe. When the Savages are hungry, they con≈øult with this Oracle, and he tells them the place where they ≈øhall go; if they find no Game, the excu≈øe is, the Bea≈øt hath wandered and changed his place, but mo≈øt times they ≈øpeed, which makes them to believe the Devil to be God, though they do not Wor≈øhip him. When the≈øe Conjurers con≈øult with the Devil, they fix a ≈øtaff in a Pit, to which they tie a Cord, and putting their Head into the Pit, make Invocation in an unknown Language, with ≈øo much ≈øtirring and pains, that they ≈øweat again; when the Devil is come, the Wizard per≈øuades them he holds him fa≈øt with his Cord, forcing him to an≈øwer before he lets him go: Then he begins to ≈øing ≈øomething in prai≈øe of the Spirit, who hath di≈øcovered where there are ≈øome Deer, and the other Savages an≈øwer in the ≈øame Tune; they then Dance and Sing in a ≈øtrange Tongue: After which they make a Fire, and leap over it, putting an half Pole-out of the top of the Cabbin, wherein they are, with ≈øomething tied thereto, which the Devil carrieth away. Memberton wore about his neck the mark of his Profe≈ø≈øion, which was a Triangle Pur≈øe, with ≈øomething within it like a Nut, which he ≈øaid was his Spirit. This Office
is Hereditary, they teaching this My≈øtery of Iniquity to their Sons by Tradition.

In 1613. fifty four Engli≈øh-men, ≈øix Women, and two Children, Wintered there; they killed Bears, Otters and Sables, ≈øowed Wheat, Rye, Turnips and Coleworts. Their Winter was dry and clear, with ≈øome Fro≈øt and Snow: Several had the Scurvey, again≈øt which, their Turnips proved a ≈øovereign Remedy. There are Musk-Cats and Musk-Rats, and near the Coa≈øts, is great killing of Mar≈øes, or Sea-Oxen; a ≈ømall Ship, in a ≈ømall time, ≈ølew fifteen hundred of them: They are bigger than an Ox, the Hide dre≈ø≈øed, is as thick again as a Bull's; they have Teeth like Elephants, about a foot longer, growing downwards out of the upper Jaw, and therefore le≈øs dangerous: It is ≈øold dearer than Ivory, and by ≈øome thought ns great an Antidote as the ∆≤nicorn's Horn. The young ones eat like Veal, which the old will defend to the utmo≈øt, holding them in their Arms or Fore-feet; out of the Bellies of five of the≈øe Fi≈øhes (which live both on the Land and Water) they make an Hog≈øhead of Train-Oyl: They ≈øleep in great Companies, and have one Centinel, or Watchman, to wake the re≈øt upon occa≈øion. Their S ‚Ä¢ ins are ≈øhort-haired like Seals, theirfaces re≈øembles a Lion's, and may therefore more ju≈øtly be called Sea-Lyons than Sea-Oxen or Hor≈øes.

Ea≈øt of New-found-land, over again≈øt Cape-Ray, at the di≈øtance of about 70 Miles from that Shore, lies a Bank or Ridge of Ground, extending about 300 Miles in length, and not above 75 in breadth, where broade≈øt. This great Bank is covered with Water when the Sea is high, and uncovered and dry on the Ebb, on all ≈øides whereof the Sea is 200 fathom deep, ≈øo that ≈øhips of a con≈øiderable Burthen
may ride over it. And about this Bank lies di≈øper≈øed ≈øeveral ≈ømall I≈øles, called by St. Seba≈øtian Cabot (the fir≈øt Di≈øcoverer) Los Boocaloos, or the I≈øles of Cod-Fi≈øh, from that Prodigious quantities of Cod-fi≈øh there found, which were ≈øaid to ob≈øtruct the pa≈ø≈øage of his Ve≈ø≈øels.

It is almo≈øt incredible how many Nations yearly Trade thither,Their Trade. amounting to between three or four hundred Sayl of Ships, that are a≈ø≈øured to find ≈øufficient Freight of Cod and Poor John, one man catching an hundred in an hour; they Fi≈øh with Hooks, which are no ≈øooner thrown into the Sea, but the greedy Fi≈øh ≈ønapping the Bait, is taken, and drawn on Ship-board, where they lay him on a Plank, one cutting off his Head, another guts and takes out its bigge≈øt Bones, another ≈øalts and barrels it; which being thus ordered, is hence tran≈øported by the European Nations to all parts of Chri≈øtendom, and through mo≈øt other parts of the World: They fi≈øh only in the Day, the Cod not biting in the Night; nor doth the Fi≈øh la≈øt all Sea≈øons, but begins towards Spring, and ends in September; for in Winter they retire to the bottom of the Sea, where Storms and Tempe≈øts have no power.

Near the≈øe Coa≈øts is another kind of Fi≈øhing for Cod, which the call Dried, as the other Green-Fi≈øh. The Fi≈øhermen retire into ≈øome Harbour, and every Morning ≈øend out their Shallops two or three Leagues into the Sea, who fail not of their Load by Noon or ≈øoon after, which they bring to Land, and order as the other: After this Fi≈øh has lain ≈øome days in Salt, they take it out, and dry it in the Wind, laying it again in heaps, and expo≈øing it daily to the open Ayr till it be dry, which ought
to be good and temperate, to make the Fi≈øh ≈øaleable; for Mi≈øts moi≈øten it and make it rot, and the Sun cau≈øes yellowne≈øs.

At this their Fi≈øhing, the Mariners have likewi≈øe the plea≈øure of taking Fowl without going out of their Ve≈ø≈øels; for baiting their Hook, with the Cod's Livers, the≈øe Fowls are ≈øo greedy that they come by Flocks, and fight who ≈øhall get the Bait fir≈øt, which ≈øoon proves its Death; and one being taken, the Hook is no ≈øooner thrown out, but another is in≈øtantly catcht.

And were the Engli≈øh diligent to in≈øpect the advantage that might accrue to this Nation by ≈øetling Plantations on the I≈øland, and rai≈øe Fortifications for the ≈øecurity of the Place, we might give Laws to all Foreigners that come to Fi≈øh there, and in few years engro≈øs the whole Fi≈øhery to our ≈øelves; the greate≈øt Ballance perchance of Foreign Trade.

In the Year 1623. Sir George Calvert Knight, and Principal Secretary of State, and afterwards Lord Baltemore, obtained a Patent of part of New-found-Land, which was erected into a Province, and called Avalon; where he cau≈øed a Plantation to be ≈øetled, and a ≈øtately Hou≈øe and Fort to be built at Ferryland, and afterwards tran≈øported him≈øelf and Family thither, and continued the Plantation by his Deputy, till by De≈øcent (after his Lord≈øhips Decea≈øe) it came to his Son and Heir, the right Honourable Caecilius, now Lord Baltemore, who by Deputies from time to time was no le≈øs careful to pre≈øerve his intere≈øt there; which tho' during the la≈øt Troubles in England, was by Sir David Kirk's means, for ≈øome years di≈øcontinued; he was ≈øoon re-inve≈øted in the ≈øame by His Maje≈øties mo≈øt happy Re≈øtauration.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION OF THE I≈øland of TOBAGO.
div.p: THis I≈øland of Tobago is ≈øituaated in 11 degrees,Iss Situation. 30 minutes North Latitude, and in 53 degrees 6 minutes Longitude, We≈øt from the Lizard, and about 40 League di≈øtance from Barbados, its extent not exceeding 32 Miles in Length, and about 11 in Breadth.

It is a Countrey ble≈øt with a temperate and whole≈øom Air,Its Temperature. by rea≈øon of a warm and temperate heat; being moderated by a continual Brieze of Wind; ≈øo that here is no Summer ≈øpent on purpo≈øe for Winter-provi≈øions, becau≈øe all the year long both Herbage and Fruit bud up by a perpetual Spring. And the I≈øland is ≈øo well ≈øtored with Materials for Building, that provided you bring dextrous Hands, and good Artificers, you may in a ≈øhort time with little Charge, build both Hou≈øes, Towns, and Fortifications.

The Soyl doth naturally produce Indian-Corn, Corn & Grain. ≈øuch as grows at Virginia, New-York, Carolina, &c. But no Engli≈øh Grain grows here: however
there are Engli≈øh Pea≈øe of divers ≈øorts, and Beans and Pul≈øe enough; likewi≈øe there is Guinea-Corn, Bonevis, the French-Pea, the Kidney-Pea, the Pigeon-Pea, the French-Bean, &c.

Here are excellent Fruits in great abundance;Its Fruits. as, the Cu≈øhen-Apple, which are both Meat and Drink, only made di≈øtingui≈øhable by the Art of Boyling; who≈øe Nut if pre≈øerved, you may eat, and of the Rinds while green, make an excellent Lamp-Oyl, which by ≈ømall Labour is ea≈øily obtained.
Here is a Fruit called a Bonano, which may be eaten raw, or bettered by an ea≈øie decoction of Fire.
Here is al≈øo the Fig-tree, ≈øuch as is that in Spain and Portugal and ≈øeveral parts in America.

Then there is the Prickle-Apple, the Pomegranate, the Pine-Apple, Pome Citrons, Oranges of three ≈øorts; the ≈øower for Sawce, and the Flowers for E≈ø≈øences, the ≈øweet ones are eaten for Recreation. But the China-Orange, that grows here in America, ≈øuper-excels tho≈øe in Europe beyond expre≈ø≈øion.

Of Limons here are two ≈øorts; the ≈øower one for Limonadoes; and the ≈øweet one for Delectation. So of Limes al≈øo, here are ≈øweet and ≈øower; with the la≈øt of which, they make Limeads and Punch. Guavers is a Fruit that is exceeding ≈øtony; there is the White and the Red; but they differ in virtue; and if baked or boyled green, if you pick out the ≈øtones, you have then a Ba≈øis for Marmalade to equalize Quinces. Tamarinds grow here naturally; but the Plantin, of all Fruit the Negroes love be≈øt, which is a nouri≈øhing, ≈øovereign, whol≈øom Food.

Here are Grapes great ≈øtore, but are eaten off the Clu≈øter; for the Planter has another Pro≈øpect
more profitable than Wine. Then there's the Cu≈øtard-Apple, the Sowr-Soap, the Papaw-Apple, the Mamme-Apple, the Yellow-Plum. There are Cherries al≈øo (which bear the year about) who≈øe Fruit is ≈øomewhat of a ≈øharpi≈øh ta≈øte; but the Coco-Nut-Tree, and the Fruit that hangs upon it, the Indians idolize, and call it Gods-Tree, becau≈øe it produces both Meat, Drink and Cloaths; it is true beyond di≈øpute, that the Nut of it ≈øelf is a Sweet beyond the ≈øweete≈øt Almond; the Shell ≈øerves for Cups, Spoons and Di≈øhes, &c. Of the Maccaw-Nut ≈øhell the Indians make the Bowls of their Tobacco-Pipes; the Kernel is eatable, the Nut makes an excellent Lamp-Oyl. Then there is the Phy≈øick-Nut; al≈øo two ≈øorts of Melons, the one is called Musk, the other Water-Melon. Al≈øo there are Penguins, Cucumbers, Pumpkins. Then there's two ≈øorts of Gourds, the ≈øweet are tho≈øe which the Planter boyls to make Broth Medicinal; and the Wild Gourd, for In≈øtruments, and Ve≈ø≈øels to contain Liquors.

They have ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Roots; as, Potatoes, Eddies, Yanis: Their Roots. The≈øe and Potatoes are their natural Bread, if not improper to call it ≈øo; however it is Food, if not Bread of another fa≈øhion: Then there are Carrots, Turnips, Par≈ønips, Onions, Ca≈ø≈øado-Root: Likewi≈øe Tea grows naturally, Tobago-Cinamon, Long-Pepper, Cod-Pepper, Bell-Pepper, and Round Pepper, ≈øome red, and ≈øome green, that grows naturally without Cultivation; al≈øo Jamaica-Pepper, with great plenty of other Fruits and Roots.

They have great ≈øtore of Wild Bea≈øts; as, the Wild-Hog, Wild Bea≈øts. of which ≈øort of Cattel their Numbers are
innumerable, when yearly the People cut off at lea≈øt twenty Thou≈øand, and yet they increa≈øe at ≈øuch a prodigious rate, that neither Gun, nor any other Artifice can be found to de≈øtroy them.
The Pickery is a Bea≈øt much re≈øembling a Hog, ≈øave only he draws his Breath at his Ventricle; which for the mo≈øt part concentrates on the middle of his Back.
Then here is great quantities of the Armadillaes, which the Hollanders call Tattoos.

Likewi≈øe here is two ≈øorts of Guanoes, the one of a green, but the other of a grey colour, which is ≈øhaped like a Lizard, ≈øomewhat re≈øembling the Allegator; ≈øome of them being four or five foot in length; they live upon Herbs, In≈øects and Fruits, and burrough like a Coney in the hollow Pits in Sand. The Indian Coney is much taller and larger than ours, and their Skins ≈ømell of Musk.

Then there is the Apo≈øtum, much like our Engli≈øh Badger (but his Legs are equal) and mo≈øt of all a≈ø≈øimilates the Racoon, and naturally, becau≈øe ≈øo affected with Mankind in general, that he follows him, comes to him, and delights to gaze on him.
Then there are Hor≈øes, Cows, A≈øs-Negroes, Sheep, Deer, Hogs, Goats, Rabbets, &c.

Likewi≈øe there is the Land-Tortoi≈øe, al≈øo Land-Crabs (viz.) the red, the black and white Crab; and there is the Land-Shell-Souldier, who≈øe Claws re≈øemble the Claws of a Crab, but is of him≈øelf a very little Creature; ≈øome ≈øay they are eatable; their Fat is a ≈øovereign Oyl, and of that ≈øingular virtue and excellency, as to blunt the venom of a poy≈øoned Dart.

Here is great plenty of excellent Fi≈øh; as, the Groper, the grey Porgo, the red Porgo, the Cavallus, the green and the grey; the la≈øt we call Hor≈øe-Eye,
of the ≈øize of a Salmon, and ≈øcaled much alike; of the Mullet here are plenty, from the ≈øize of a Makarel, to the extent of a Pickerel.

The Manatee, or Sea-Cow, is of an amphibious nature, it eats Gra≈øs like an Oxe, and ≈øwims like an Otter, that ≈øwims ≈øometimes under water, and grows to a prodigious greatne≈øs; for ≈øome of them have weighed ten and twelve hundred pound weight; they are ≈øtruck with harping-Irons, or other Engines, and ≈øo taken; who≈øe Fle≈øh of Fi≈øh nece≈ø≈øity only extols it. There are various ≈øorts of Turtles; the Hawks-Bill, the Vandorus, the Loggerhead, and the green Turtle; which la≈øt the Natives think ≈øacred; for they call its Gods-fi≈øh, by rea≈øon of that extraordinary virtue that is found therein, it being found a very great Antidote again≈øt Poy≈øon, and for the Gonorhaea, the Yaws, and the French Pox, there is not in nature a Food more effectual; ≈øhe lives in the Water, and without it, it ≈øwims like a Fi≈øh, and yet in the Sand lays Eggs like a Fowl; who≈øe Fi≈øh is Fle≈øh, and admits of various ta≈øtes, as, of Veal, of Beef, but the Fat is green, and eats like Marrow, and their Eggs undi≈øtingui≈øhable from tho≈øe of a Hen, &c. And al≈øo there is Barracooto, and they are of two ≈øorts, and ≈øome about two foot in length, they have a long Beak or Snout filled full of Teeth. The white-mouth'd Barracooto is the whol≈øome≈øt Fi≈øh, but the black-mouth'd Fi≈øh his Teeth are venomous. Likewi≈øe there is the Great Garr, which the Spaniards call Needle-fi≈øh, the Pilchard, the Anchovy, much ≈ømaller than a Pilchard, the Hedg-hog-fi≈øh, the Coney-fi≈øh, the Dolphin, the Indian Sturgeon, the Flying-fi≈øh, the Parrot-fi≈øh, the Amber-fi≈øh, the Albacore, the Boneto, the Lob≈øter or Craw-fi≈øh, the Sea-Souldier, the Crunk, the Horn-fi≈øh, the Orney,
the Shallop-fi≈øh, Cockles, the Sea-Snail, the Rock-Oy≈øter, the Mangrove-Oy≈øter; the Sea-Egg is of two ≈øorts, ≈øome black, and ≈øome grey; but the grey Eggs are the Oy≈øters, becau≈øe re≈øembling them in ta≈øte, and are eaten raw, with Vinegar and Pepper, but better ≈øtewed with Wine and Shellots, &c.

Here is great plenty of Fowl;Their Fowl. as, the Bill-bird, who≈øe Bill or Beak ≈øhews as big as his Body; the Black-bird, about the bigne≈øs of a Crow, who≈øe fle≈øh is nothing inferior to a Pigeon; but the ≈ømaller Black-bird re≈øembles ours in England, ≈øave only it hath a longer Bill. Then there is the Booby-bird, the blew-headed Parrot, the Macaw, the Flamingo, Ducks, the Sea-gull, the Sea-mew, the Plover, the Turtle-Dove, the Man of War-bird, the Bird of Paradi≈øe, or the King-fi≈øher, the Pelican, the Cockerrico, the Indians Name for the Tobago-Plea≈øants; the Carlew, the Wood-Pigeon, &c.

Here are ≈øundry ≈øorts of Trees,Their Trees. as, the Cedar, Green-Hart, Locust, of two ≈øeveral ≈øorts, the one white, and the other red, Ma≈øtick, Mohogony, Man-grove, White-wood, yellow Sanders, Bay, Box, Brazil, Bully, Crocus, Ca≈ø≈øia, Callabo≈øh, Lignum vitae, Ebony, with ≈øeveral others.

CommoditiesCommodities. which the Country doth or may produce, are, Cacao-Nut, Sugar, Tobacco, Indico, Ginger, Sar≈øaparilia, Semper-vivum, Bees-Was, Vinillioes, Natural Bal≈øam, Balm, Silk-Gra≈øs, Green Tar, Soap-Earth, &c. with many curious Shells, Stones, Marka≈øites and Minerals found up and down the I≈øland of Tobago, who≈øe Virtue and Worth is yet unknown.

div.head: DIRECTIONS For Improvement of the I≈øland of TOBAGO.
div.p: SUppo≈øe a man that has an Hundred Pound Sterling, is minded to tran≈øport him≈øelf and Family, con≈øi≈øting of Eleven in number, to this I≈øland of Tobago and ≈øuppo≈øe their Pa≈ø≈øage co≈øt him fifty pound, and Manuals, with other things requi≈øite and nece≈ø≈øary for Planting, as al≈øo Provi≈øion for the fir≈øt Twelve Months, together with the Charge of Hou≈øhold-≈øtuffs, and all other Nece≈ø≈øaries, may ≈øtand him in forty ≈øeven pound ten ≈øhillings more; ≈øuppo≈øe al≈øo this man takes a Lea≈øe of fifty Acres of Land for a Thou≈øand Years at the rate of Twelve pence an Acre annually, it amounts but to Two pound Ten ≈øhillings a Year (except otherwi≈øe he purcha≈øe the Fee ≈øimple of the Proprietors) which compleats the Hundred pound.
