This is the fir≈øt Money laid out, nor need he be at any more Charge for in twelve Months time, he will have Ground-provi≈øion enough, and in all probability two Crops of Tobacco.

The next thing to con≈øider of, is the ImprovementIts Improvement. of the ≈øaid Land, which is as followeth: After your arrival in the I≈øland of Tobago, the fir≈øt ≈øix Months may be ≈øpent to clear fifteen Acres of Land, and to put Provi≈øns into the Ground; to build Conveniencies to accommodate your ≈øelf and Family; to adapt and fit Ground for planting a Nur≈øery of Cacao-Nuts; as al≈øo a Bed ≈øowed with Tobacco-≈øeeds, and be ≈øure to keep your Nur≈øery clear from Weeds: then, about a Months time after, you have ≈øown your Tobacco-≈øeed, (provided the Sea≈øon be good) you may then draw your Tobacco-Plants, and plant them about ≈øome four foot di≈øtance one from another, regularly and in rows, which ≈øaid Tobacco, Tobago produces, is nothing inferiour to Spani≈øh Trinidado, that lies about ≈øeven Leagues di≈øtance from the ≈øaid I≈øland of Tobago, who ≈øell their Trinidado-Tobacco at the rate of Two Shillings a Pound, which ≈øaid Tobacco the Spaniards tran≈øport from thence to Old Spain, and ≈øell it there for con≈øiderable advantage. Now among your Tobacco-Plants, you may plant your Cacao, and tran≈øplant them, when about ≈øix Months old, into new Ground, at ten or twelve foot di≈øtance, and be ≈øure to keep them clear from Weeds, in which latter ≈øix Months time, you may have on your cleared Ground two Crops of Tobacco. Now admitting you make but Eight thou≈øand Weight of Neat Tobacco on the ≈øaid Ground, yet in all probability (provided your People be healthy) it may double the number to Sixteen thou≈øand. But if it do not, and put the ca≈øe your Tobacco ≈øell but for an eighth part of what the Spaniards ≈øell for in Trinidado, (which is but three Pence per Pound, ≈øold here in our I≈øland) yet will
this Crop yield you One hundred Pound ≈øterling, which is your Money gained the very fir≈øt Year, and in ≈øix Months time all Charges being born.

Now ≈øuppo≈øe at the beginning of the ≈øecond Year, the ≈øaid ≈øixteen Acres be all cleared, and Provi≈øion enough put into the Ground, ≈øufficient for double your number of hands, you may rationally then expect four Crops in twelve Months time, when as formerly you made two Crops in the la≈øt ≈øix Months; ≈øo that with the Hundred Pounds you gained la≈øt Year, you may now purcha≈øe ≈øeven or eight Slaves, or Servants, which may in all probability treble the fir≈øt Year. But put the ca≈øe, it but only double, yet at the wor≈øt, it may yield you (and all Charges born) Two hundred Pounds ≈øterling.

Now we cannot otherwi≈øe conclude, (if things ≈øucceed well) but the third Year will double the ≈øecond by improvement, as is above expre≈ø≈øed; and if ≈øo, your Crop will amount to Four hundred Pounds ≈øterling, and the fourth Year double the third, by rea≈øon of the Cacao that was planted the fir≈øt Year on the fifteen Acres of Land, may produce to the value of Thirty Pounds ≈øterling an Acre, be≈øides the encrea≈øe of Tobacco, and clearing of more ground, together with your encrea≈øe of Servants ana Slaves, and planting of more Cacao-Trees, which at lea≈øt will ari≈øe to Eight hundred Pounds ≈øterling the fourth Year; the fifth Year, in all probability, doubles the fourth Year; the ≈øixth Year you may very well clear Six thou≈øand Pounds ≈øterling, and all Charges born, by rea≈øon the Cacao, planted the fir≈øt Year, is now come to perfection, and at its full height of bearing; which in this Latitude may yield One hundred Pounds ≈øterling an Acre, viz. the fir≈øt fifteen Acres which were planted
the fir≈øt Year; and the ≈øecond years Plants, planted the ≈øecond Year, will yield you Sixty Pounds ≈øterling; and the third years Plants, as by the ≈øame Calculation, may yield you Thirty Pounds ≈øterling an Acre: So that by purcha≈øing the more Servants and Slaves, you may, if you plea≈øe, decline ≈øo much planting of Tobacco, as formerly you did.

The ≈øeventh Year you will have all your Land planted with Cacao, and that increa≈øing, you need not plant above ten or fiften Acres of Tobacco this Year among≈øt your Cacao; but you may plant Provi≈øions among≈øt them, for ≈øupport and maintenance of your ≈øelf and Family. So that from that Increa≈øe of your ≈øeventh Year's Crop, you may hope and expect, by a mode≈øt computation, to clear from the ≈øaid fifty Acres of Land, at lea≈øt Five thou≈øand Pounds ≈øterling a Year.

And now we come to the Rea≈øons for this great Improvement;The Rea≈øons for Improvement. You mu≈øt con≈øider, that the Spaniards in Trinidado, &c. give among them≈øelves One hundred Pounds ≈øterling, for a Negro-Slave, and yet the ≈øaid Slave will not ≈øtand his Ma≈øter in one ≈øingle Penny at the Year's end for his purcha≈øe; and all the labour and ≈øervice the Spaniard imploys him in the Year about, is only in Cacao and Spani≈øh-Tobacco, in this our Latitude.

Now pray con≈øider, that we can have Negro-≈ølaves brought and delivered to us at Fifteen Pounds ≈øterling a head, by rea≈øon we have an open Trade, and the Spaniards allows not of a free Trade. Where note, the Spaniard pays Six-pence or more for every thing he wants, when we have the ≈øame for a ≈øingle Penny. That's one Rea≈øon.

The ≈øecond Rea≈øon is, The Spaniard cannot have any Tunnage for Goods from Old Spain to the West-Indies, and home again, for le≈øs than Forty or Fifty Pounds ≈øterling per Tun; be≈øides, the Duties run very high: And we can have, Freight for Five or Six Pounds per Tun, and no Duties from us to a tree Port. When therefore, to con≈øider and compute the Charge on either ≈øide, we profit by what we tran≈øport ≈øix to one; which makes the Spaniard generally ≈øo poor in the Indies, and we generally to flouri≈øh ≈øo much the more.

The third Rea≈øon is, That in a Ship of Three hundred Tun, the Spaniards have ≈øeldom le≈øs than two hundred Men belonging to her, and the Wages each Man comes to at lea≈øt Fifty Shilling ≈øterling per Month, which, in the whole, amounts to Five hundred Pounds a Month, barely for Wages; then you are to con≈øider the Monthly Provi≈øions, to accommodate the≈øe Men, cannot come to le≈øs than One hundred and fifty Pounds ≈øterling; and Ten Months, at Six hundred and fifty Pounds per Month, amounts to Six thou≈øand and five hundred Pounds ≈øterling for Ten Months. Moreover, this Ship of Three hundred Tun, ≈øeldom carries le≈øs than Forty Pieces of Ordnance, which with their Provi≈øions, &c. by mode≈øt computation, takes up no le≈øs room than One hundred and fifty Tun; ≈øo that the Ship, in all probability, cannot bring home more than One hundred and fifty Tun of Merchants Goods, and the Freight of the≈øe Goods comes to Forty Pounds ≈øterling a Tun, to pay Ware and Tare of the Ship and Mens Wages; ≈øo that for the Ship's Ware and Tare, it comes barely but to One hundred and fifty Pounds ≈øterling clear.

Now admit an Engli≈øh Ship of Three hundred Tun, be bound for Jamaica, and ≈øuppo≈øe the
Freight of this Ship be at Six Pounds ≈øterling per Tun, this Ship ≈øhall make her Voyage better in Eight Months time than the Spaniard ≈øhall in Ten Months; now the Freight of the Engli≈øh Ship comes to One thou≈øand eight hundred Pounds ≈øterling, and the Wages and Victuals of the ≈øaid Ship, at Sixty Pounds per Month, comes to Four hundred and eighty Pounds ≈øterling; ≈øo that you ≈øee the Ship clears, for her Ware and Tare, the ≈øum of One thou≈øand three hundred and twenty Pounds ≈øterling. See here therefore the great difference.

The fourth and la≈øt rea≈øon is this; The King of Spain contracts with a body of Merchants, to furni≈øh the We≈øt-Indies with Four thou≈øand Negroes every Year, and the Nigrilloes, or Merchants, there engage to pay the King one hundred Pieces of Eight Cu≈øtom for each Negro-≈ølave brought unto them; which comes to Four hundred thou≈øand Pieces of Eight by the Year, which is paid to the ≈øaid King; the King therefore prohibits all Merchants and others, for bringing Negroes to the We≈øt-Indies; and each Piece of Eight is valued at Five Shillings ≈øterling in Barbadoes, but in the Leeward I≈ølands it goes for ≈øix.

div.head: The Propo≈øals lately made by Captain John Poyntz, for Him≈øelf and Company, to all ≈øuch People as are minded to Tran≈øport or Concern them≈øelves in the I≈øland of Tobago.
div.p: WHereas his late Maje≈øty, Charles the Second, King of Great Britain, hath given and granted unto James, Duke of Courland, his Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øours, the ≈øaid I≈øland of Tobago, on condition that none ≈øhall inhabit the ≈øaid I≈øland, ≈øave only the Subject of the King of England, and the Duke of Courland, their Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øours, on the ≈øaid condition, I have contracted with the ≈øaid Duke, that my ≈øelf and Company ≈øettle One hundred and twenty thou≈øand Acres of Land in the ≈øaid I≈øland, and to have ≈øeveral great and large Priviledges, ≈øome of which are here in≈øerted, viz.

Imprimis, That one hundred and twenty thou≈øand Acres of Land, in the ≈øaid I≈øland of Tobago, is given and granted to my ≈øelf and Company, and our Heirs for ever, and ≈øeven Years to be free from the payment of any Rent, and after the expiration of ≈øeven Years, each for him≈øelf is to pay Two-pence per Acre every Year, to the Duke, his lawful Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øours.
Secondly, That my ≈øelf and Company, and all the Inhabitant ‚Ä¢ , ≈øhall enjoy Liberty of Con≈øcience, without interruption, Roman-Catholicks only excepted.

Thirdly, That my ≈øelf and Company, &c. are to be governed by a Governour, Deputy-Governour, and A≈ø≈øembly, to be yearly cho≈øen by the majority of Freeholders Votes, of the People in the I≈øland, to make good and whol≈øom Laws for the good Government and Defence of the ≈øaid I≈øland; and all Controver≈øies in the Promi≈øes to be decided by the majority of Voices.

Note, The≈øe are but Breviates and part of the Heads of the Grant from the Duke of Courland, and ratified to my ≈øelf and Company, whereby we hold and enjoy our Land; for that end I do refer all People to the Grant, as more at large, as al≈øo them that have been on the skirt or body of the ≈øaid I≈øland, to confirm the truth of what is before ≈øpoken of the Products of the ≈øaid I≈øland.

div.head: Propo≈øals for further Encouragement.
div.p: First, THo≈øe that are de≈øirous to concern them≈øelves in the ≈øaid I≈øland, ≈øhall and may have as much Land as they them≈øelves plea≈øe, either by Lea≈øe or Purcha≈øe, only they are to put upon every Fifteen Acres of Land, one White Man, and ≈øo in proportion to the re≈øt; and this to be done in three Years time.

Secondly, All Per≈øons that are de≈øirous to tran≈øport them≈øelves to the ≈øaid I≈øland, in the quality of Servants, ≈øhall have better Encouragement from my ≈øelf and Company than has been yet propounded by any of his Maje≈øties Subjects in any Settlement in the American Plantations.

Thirdly, And, for a further encouragement, all tho≈øe Per≈øons and Planters that are any way concerned in the Premi≈øes, ≈øhall have Credit given unto them from Crop to Crop, as the Factory is ≈øtored, for what they ≈øhll ≈øtand in need of; for which the ≈øaid Company will erect a Bank or Factory of Credit in the ≈øaid I≈øland, the Debtor allowing only two and a half per Cent.

Fourthly, All Merchants and others, that ≈øhall import any Negroes, or other Merchandize, into the ≈øaid I≈øland, ≈øhall have their Goods and Debts in≈øured, and di≈øpo≈øed of for two and a half per Cent. with Facto ‚Ä¢ age Storage, Wharfage, &c. and exported again for two and a half per Cent. more.
And all Trade≈ømen and others, that contract any Debts again≈øt them≈øelves, ≈øhall have Credit given them out of the Bank or Factory, from Crop to Crop, for two and a half per Cent. And the Proprietors to engage their whole Intere≈øt for the true performance of the fore≈øaid Premi≈øes.

Fifthly, All Merchants and others, that have Goods fit to accommodate the ≈øaid I≈øland, and have not ready Money to purcha≈øe Land, nor to pay for their own or ≈øervants Pa≈ø≈øage, ≈øuch may Barter with Goods in lieu of Money: Always this implies only ≈øuch Per≈øons as Contract with the Proprietors, or ≈øome of them, before the fir≈øt Shipping departs out of the River of Thames, to Ship off, as above, their proportion of Goods or People, as is already ≈øufficiently above expre≈ø≈øed.

div.head: ASTRONOMICAL TABLES,
SHEWING The Ri≈øing and Setting of the Sun; with the Length of the Days and Nights in all the Principal Engli≈øh Plantations in the We≈øt-Indies.
div.p: ALSO, Tables of the New and Full Moons in every Month, from the Year 1686, to 1700, in the Meridian of London, and from thence referred to the Meridians of the Principal Plantations above≈øaid.
The which Tables will ≈øerve as a con≈øtant Diary or Calendar, for the U≈øe of the Engli≈øh Inhabitants in tho≈øe Ilands.
ALSO, A Table by which, at any Time of the Day or Night here in England, you may know what Hoar it is in any of tho≈øe I≈ølands.
AND How to make Sun-Dials fitting for all tho≈øe Remote Parts.

div.head: A Table ≈øhewing the Prime or Golden Number, the Dominical (or Sunday Letter,) and the Moveable Fea≈øts from the Year 1686, to the Year 1700.
The V≈øe of this Table.
div.p: TO find the Moveable Fea≈øts for any Year, ≈øeek the Year in the fir≈øt Row (or Column) of the Table, and in the ≈øame Line you ≈øhall have your de≈øire. ‚Äî Example; In the Year 1686, find 1686 in the fir≈øt Column, and again≈øt it in the ≈øame Line you have 15 for the Epact. C for the Dominical (or Sunday Letter.) February 14 for Shrove Sunday. April 4 for Ea≈øter-day. May 13 for A≈øcer≈øion-day. May 23 for Whit-Sunday. November 28 for Advent-Sunday. And ≈øo for any other Year, till 1700.

div.head: A De≈øcription of the following Tables.
div.p: 1. IN the fir≈øt Column of each Table towards the Left Hand, you have the Day of the Month.

2. In the ≈øecond, you have the Day of the Week noted with A, B, C, D, E, F G, for the ≈øeven Days of the Week; and the≈øe Letters continue in this order, from the Fir≈øt of
‚Ä¢ anuary, beginning with A, to the Thirty Fir≈øt of December, ending with A al≈øo ‚Äî And here it is to be noted, that which ≈øoever of the≈øe Letters is Domical (or Sunday Letter) for any Year, all tho≈øe Days in the Calendar, which have that Letter ≈øtanding again≈øt them, are Sundays for that Year. As for Example: In the Year 1686 you found (by the former Table) that C was Dominical (or Sunday Letter,) wherefore all the Days that have C ≈øtanding again≈øt them, were Sundays that Year; as in the Month of January, C ≈øtands again≈øt the 3, the 10, the 17, the 24, and the 31 Days, all which Days were Sundays ‚Äî Again, by the former Table, you may find in the Year 1690, the Dominical Letter will be E; wherefore, that Year, all the Days that have E ≈øtanding again≈øt them, in any Month, are Sundays; as in the Month of March, E ≈øtands again≈øt the 2, the 9, the 16, the ‚Ä¢ 3, and the 30, all which D ‚Ä¢ ys will be Sundays in the Year 1690. But if there be two Dominic ‚Ä¢ l Letters in one Year, (as in the Year 1688, 1692, &c.) then the fir≈øt of tho≈øe two Lerters is Sunday Letter till the 25 of February, and the other of them to the end of the Year.
3. The Third Colum contains the Fixed Fea≈øts, with the Suns Ri≈øing and Setting at London, &c.
4. The other part of each Page, is divided into five parts or ≈øpaces;

The 1 2 3 4 5 Shews the Ri≈øing and Setting- of the Sun, with the Length x The Vof the Da vs and Nights for) every fi≈øth Day, accordi ngs 5 to the Titles, at
New-England.
Virginia.
Carolina & Bermudas.
Barbadoes.
Jamaica.

5. On the other Page are Tables, ≈øhewing the time of the New and Full Moon in every Month of the Year, from 1686, to 1700, in the Meridian at London (in Old-England.) By help whereof, and the little Table following, the time of the New or Full Moon, in any of the Places mentioned in this Book, may be ea≈øily attained.

div.p: Example. In the Month of January, 1687, I find that it is New Moon upon the 3d. Day, 56 m. after 7 at Night. Now to know what time it will be New Moon at Virginia upon that Day, look in this Table, and again≈øt Virginia you will find 4 h. 40 m. which added to 7 h. 56 m. the Sum will be 12 h. 36 m. at which time it will be New Moon at Virginia upon the 3d. of January, 1687.

div.head: How the≈øe I≈ølands and Plantations are ≈øeated upon the Globe of the Earth; and of other things relating thereunto: And,
I. Of Virginia, at James Town.
div.p: IT is ≈øituate in 37 deg. 15 min. of North Latitude. The Sun ri≈øes there upon their longe≈øt Day at 45 min. after 4 in the Morning; and ≈øets 15 min. after 7 at Night.
Their longe≈øt Day is 14hou. 30 min.
Their ≈øhorte≈øt Day is 9 hou. 30 min.
The Sun ri≈øes upon their longe≈øt Day 30 deg. 4 min. di≈øtant from the Ea≈øt towards the North, and ≈øets as many deg. from the We≈øt Northwards.
The greate≈øt Altitude that the Sun hath at Noon, is 76 deg. 15 min; and the lealt Altitude at Noon, 29 deg. 15 min.
It bears from London N. N. W.
It is di≈øtant from thence 3420 miles.
Its length from N. to S. is 116 miles; and its breadth from E. to W. 80.
It differeth in Longitude from London We≈øtward 75 deg. 40 min. or (in Time) 5 hou. 12 min.

div.head: II. Of Bo≈øton, in New-England.
div.p: It lieth in 42 deg. 32 min. of North Latitude.
It differs in Longitude We≈øt ward 68 deg. 30 min. or (in Time 4 hou. 40 min.
The Sun ri≈øeth there, upon their longe≈øt day, at 28 min. after 4 inthe morning; and ≈øets 32 min. after 7 at Night.
The length of their longe≈øt Day, is 15 hou. 4 min.
The length of their ≈øhorte≈øt Day 8 hou. 56 min.
The Sun ri≈øes upon their longe≈øt day 32 deg. 45 min. di≈øtant from the Ea≈øt Northward; and ≈øets as many deg. from the We≈øt towards the North.
The greate≈øt Altitude that the Sun hath at Noon on their longe≈øt day, is 71 deg. and the lea≈øt Meridian Altitude that they have, is 24 deg.
It bears from London N. W. by W.
It is di≈øtant from London 47 deg. or 2820 miles.
The length of New-England from N. to S. is unknown; and its breadth E. and W. from Ma≈øchu≈ø≈øets Bay, to Hud≈øons River, is 158 miles.

div.head: III. Of Port-Royal, in Jamaica.
div.p: It is ≈øituate in 18 deg. 51 min. of Northern Latitude.
It differs in Longitude from London We≈øtward 75 deg. 30 min. or (in Time) 5 hou. 4 min.
The Sun ri≈øeth there upon the longe≈øt day (viz. June 11) at 26 min. ufter 5 in the Morning; and ≈øets 34 min. after 6 at Night.
The length of their longe≈øt day is 13 hou. 8 min.
The length of their ≈øhorte≈øt day is 10 hou. 52 min.
The Suns Amplitude or place of Ri≈øing upon the longe≈øt day, is 24 deg. 53 min. from the Ea≈øt Northward, and his ≈øetting as many deg. from the We≈øt Northward.
Their Meridian Altitude upon their longe≈øt day, is 85 deg 21 min. from the North part of the Horizon; and 94 deg. 39 min. from the South part thereof.
The Sun is in their Zenith, that is, it pa≈ø≈øeth ju≈øt over their heads, upon the Fifth of May, and the Fifteenth of July.
It bears from London W. by N.
It is di≈øtant from London 70 deg. or 4200 miles.
Its length is 150 miles, and breadth above 60.

div.head: IV. Of Barbadoes.
div.p: It is ≈øituate in 13 deg. 10 min. of North Latitude.
It differs in Longitude from Lond ‚Ä¢ n We≈øt ward 58 deg. 25 min. or (in Time) 3 hou. 53 min.
The sun ri≈øes upon their longe≈øt day at 37 min. after 5 in the morning; and ≈øets 23 min. after 6 at night.
The length of their longe≈øt day is 12 hou. 46 min.
The length of their ≈øhorte≈øt day is 11 hou. 14 min.
The Sun ri≈øes 24 deg. from the Ea≈øt Northwards, and ≈øets as many from the We≈øt; towards the North.
The Meridian upon their longe≈øt day, is 100 deg. 20 min. from the South part of the Horizon; and 79 deg. 56 min. from the North part thereof.
The Sun is in their Zenith, or pa≈ø≈øeth ju≈øt over their heads, upon the Fourth of May, and the Eighteenth of July.
It beats from London W. by S.
It is di≈øtant from London 61 deg. or 3660 miles.
Its length from N. to S. is 24 miles.
Its breadth from E. to W. is 5 Leagues, or 15 Miles.

div.head: V. Of Charles Town, in Carolina.
div.p: It is ≈øituate in 33 deg. 10 min. of North Latitude.
It differs in Longitude from London We≈øtward 78 deg. 30 min. or (in Time) 5 hou. and 3 quarters.
The Sun ri≈øeth, upon their longe≈øt day, 50 min. after 4 in the morning; and ≈øets 10 min. after 7 at night.
The length of their longe≈øt day is 14 hou. 20 min.
The length of their ≈øhorte≈øt day is 9 hou. 40 min.
The Sun ri≈øes upon their longe≈øt: day 28 deg. 27 min. from the Ea≈øt Northward; and ≈øets as many from the We≈øt towards t he North al≈øo.

The Meridian Altitude, upon the longe≈øt day, is 80
deg. 20 min. and upon the ≈øhorte≈øt day 33 deg. 20 min.
It bears from London W. N. W.
It is di≈øtant from London 60 deg. or 3600 miles.
Its length is from N. to S. 540 miles, and its breadth from E. to W. 230 miles.

div.head: VI. Of Bermudas.
div.p: It is ≈øituate in 32 deg 25 min. of North Latitude.
It differs in Longitude from London 63 deg. 30 min. or (in Time) 4 hou. 14 min.
Upon the longe≈øt day there, the Sun ri≈øes 4 min. before 5 in the morning; and ≈øets 4 min after 7 at. night.
The length of their longe≈øt day, is 14 hou. 8 min.
The length of their ≈øhorte≈øt day, is 9 hou. 52 min.

The Amplitude of the Suns ri≈øing, upon their longe≈øt day, is 28 deg. 11 min. from the Ea≈øt towards the North; and his ≈øetting, as many from the We≈øt Northwards; And, on the ≈øhorte≈øt day, it ri≈øes and ≈øets as much from the Ea≈øt and We≈øt Southwards, as, on the longe≈øt day, it doth Northward.
It bears from London W. by. N.
It is di≈øtant from London 49 deg. or 2940 miles.
Its length is 17 miles.
Its breadth not above 3 miles in the breade≈øt place.

div.head: The ∆≤≈øe of this Table.
div.p: IF at Eight of the Clock in the Morning at London, you would know what it were a Clock in all the above-named Places, you ≈øhall find it then to be at Virginia 2 hou. 48 min. Morning. At New-England 3 hou. 20 min. Morn. At Jamaica 2 hou. 56 min. Morn. At Barbadoes 4 hou. 7 min. Morn. At Carolina hou. 16 min. Morn. And at Bermudas 3 hou. 46 min. Morn.

table.head: A Table of the true Hour-di≈øtances, for Horizontal Dials, for all the≈øe Plantations following; with their Halves and Quarters, ready Calculated.

div.head: How to Set any of the≈øe Dials, or any other, truly upon a Po≈øt in a Garden, or el≈øewhere.
div.p: LET the Square in the Figure at the end of this Book, noted with A B C D, be the top of a Po≈øt (or other level Plain or Window) upon which you would ≈øix your Dial.

About the middle thereof, as at O, de≈øcribe a Circle, as E G F, and upon O (the Centre) erect a ≈ømall Pyn or Wire, as O S, exactly perpendicular, and in the Forenoon ob≈øerve when the point of the ≈øhadow of the top of the Pyn or Wire touches the Circle, which ≈øuppo≈øe to be at the point E, (which point mark.) Then again (in the Afternoon of the ≈øame day) ob≈øerve when the ≈øhadow touches the ≈øame Circle, (which (in the Afternoon) let be at the point F.

The≈øe two Ob≈øervations being made, divide the Circle between E and F, into two equal parts, which will be at G; ≈øo a line drawn from G through O (as the line G O H) ≈øhall be a true Meridian line; upon which the Hour line of XII of your Dial mu≈øt be placed, and the Dial ≈øo fixed, (truly Horizontal) ≈øhall con≈øtantly give you the true Hour.
You may make more Circles than one upon the Plain, le≈øt the Sun upon the ≈øame day ≈øhould not be ≈øeen exactly at the ≈øame time of both parts of the day, as the Figure plainly ≈øhews.
